Justification: Most of these data come from the 'Freedom House' reports, particularly the archived reports from the late 1990s. After a highly contended election in 1997, in which the most of the media had been forced to support the incumbent President Daniel arap Moi, and in which voter registration was so badly mismanaged that entire regions of the country were declared invalid, judicial reforms were announced to make the country operate more democratically. However, according to the 1999 Freedom House report, Moi repeatedly changed his position on accepting these reforms. Various reports by United States thinktank the Cato Institute discuss ethnic differences as a major cause of electoral inequality, which has contributed to the demands for reform in recent decades.

Justification: Eritrea 2010. In 2010 Eritrea faced international condemnation for its poor treatment of human rights and accused of destabilizing the stability and security of the region. In 2009, Human Right Watch accused the PFDJ led government for turning the nation into 'giant prison 'and similarly in 2010 Amnesty International reported there were unlawful killings by security forces and also abuses, tortures were common practices for those military service deserters . And in 2010 Universal Periodic Review (UPR ) of human rights accused Eritrea of violating the convention of human rights against torture. At the end of 2010 though the situation in Eritrea on the basis of humanitarian situation was the same but Eritrea has got considerable amount of foreign aid and China was one of those countries which donated the most ( Human right 2010 ) . In 2010, according to US State Department office the rights of workers were not respected the government introduced forced labour and even under age children were forced to join the forced labour carried out in the name of National service In 1998, both Ethiopia and Eritrea entered in the bloody border war and as a result thousands of lives and millions estimated properties had been lost. Therefore, in August 2009, International Tribunal based on Hague ordered both countries would pay compensations for the damages caused in 1998-2000 and the sanction that imposed in2009 again tightened in 2010 as the regime kept continuing supporting the Somalia based Islamic terrorist group. A year before namely in August 2009, international tribunal in Hague ordered both Eritrea and Ethiopia would pay compensations for the damages for 1998- 2000 war. Political freedom. According to U.S Department of State ( 2010 ) the Eritrean government refrained 'freedom of speech, press, assembly, association and religion' . Citizens have refrained from freedom of movement and also foreign national, According FIDH 2010 ( a world movement for Human Rights) International humanitarian (NGO) staff members faced arbitrary arrests, denied services ( from getting fuels ) and the rejection of entry visa . And the report added that the there was no freedom of movement its staff were not allowed to travel without approval of the especially traveling outside Asmara (capital city ) . To cite one example, Internationa l Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) was one of those agencies which faced severe restriction from carrying out its activities because since 2009 ICRC was trying to visit the areas where Ethiopian origin citizens and also prisoners of war imprisoned repeatedly asked the government to get access on october 2010 Freedom of movement, according to the UN special Rapporteur keettharuth ( 2014 ) the movement of citizens even those who are in national service have no chance of freely moving through the country because identification paper was required to pass every check points There was no freedom speak and journalists faced imprisonment. In 2010, according to Reporters without Borders (RSF), about twenty nine journalists who worked on the state owned media, were detained without any trail and their whereabouts were also unknown. Freedom of association has been violated since 1990s especially there is freedom of religion. No one is allowed to practice his/her religion while he or she services military services because practicing religion during national service is prohibited According to human rights watch ( 2010 ) religious minority, not members of the four registered religious organizations ( Orthodox, Catholic, Islam and Protestant ) faced abuses, tortures and arrests because the government does not acknowledge to freely exercise their faith. For example in 2008 and 2009 about twenty five Jehovah witness members have been arrested. Similarly, in December, 2008 members of the orthodox church arrested by the security forces and the patriarch of the orthodox church got arrested ( 2006 ) War with Djibouti In 2010, UN and African Union requested the Eritrean government to investigate cause of the conflict between Eritrea and Djibouti, however, the Eritrean government refused to cooperate. In the same year the Qatari government brokered both Eritrea and Djibouti and Eritrea withdrew its troops. In 2008, Eritrea attacked Djibouti, after denying allegation of militantly attacking Djibouti, in June 2010, Eritrea pulled its troops Corruption According to World Bank 'public power is exercised for personal gain 'and there are petty and grand form of corruption 'in Eritrea. In control of corruption Eritrea ( 2010 ) percentile rank 39 and scores -0.455980033. Therefore there ttreamnent of human being when I was in prison ( makeshift ) was very poor even the food we had been given was not enought regardless its qaulity. Generally speaking not only based on findings but with the news I heard and read Eritrea is still under the leadership of military comanded by a single man. what happened in the 2010 namely Eritrea was acussed of violating human right and its defiance to withdraw troops from the Djibouti territory but later withdrew its troops from the disputed areas by the mediation Qatar reflect the true nature of the regime. Justification: The justification for question 4. Freedom House says on their website that: 'The government undertook a series of political reforms after 1998, including the introduction of an independent electoral commission, a single-ballot voting system, public campaign financing, and a third vice presidential position in the legislature for the opposition leader.' (Freedom House, 2008) Accessed: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2008/burkina-faso#.VVrnbdOqqko Dispite this Freedom House go on to state that: 'International monitors concluded that the 2005 presidential election was generally free, although not entirely fair, due to Compaore's [Burkino Faso's presedent] of privileged access to state resources and the media.' (Freedom House, 2008) Also in 2007, for example, only 57% of the population voted according to Freedom House, if elections were truly free and fair it would seem logical that more people than that would be voting (Freedom House, 2007) . Accessed: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2007/burkina-faso#.VVrnztOqqko The New Encyclopedia of Africa states that: 'In the presidential election of November 2005 Compaore easily won a third term over a badly frag- mented opposition, garnering 80 percent of the vote.' (Ritz-Mu  Ller. U, 2008) Reference: Burkina Faso. (2008) . In J. Middleton & J. C. Miller (Eds.), New Encyclopedia of Africa (2nd ed., Vol. 1, pp. 271-279) . Detroit: Charles Scribner's Sons. This suggests that one of the reasons why elections may not seem fair (one party gets the vast majority of the votes) is in fact because the opposition is extremely fractured and unable to coordinate together to pose a real threat to Compaore's government. Accordign to Freedom House in 2006 there were more than 100 opposition parties (Freedom House, 2006) . Retrieved from: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2006/burkina-faso#.VVr2-NOqqko The justification for question 5. Szajkowski (Ed.), Political Parties of the World (6th ed., pp. 95-97) . London: John Harper Publishing . According to the World Value's Survey, in the year 2007, 58.4% of participants in a survey said that they voted in recent parliament elections (World Values Survey, 2007) . This sugests that although there may technically be Universal suffrage, there are still barriers stopping people from voting. Retrieved from: http://www.worldvaluessurvey.org/WVSOnline.jsp The justification for question 6. According to The Economist Intelligence Unit (2007) 'Blaise Compaoré, who has already held power for nearly 20 years. This is not because the CDP and Mr Compaoré are universally popular: in fact, there is widespread public dissatisfaction with current economic and social conditions. However, as in many other African states, the opposition has failed to capitalise on such discontent.' ( The Economist Intelligence Unit, 2007) Reference: Burkina faso politics: Blaise's trail. (2007) . () . New York: The Economist Intelligence Unit N.A., Incorporated Also: 'Burkina Faso needed a 'profound reform of its political institutions' in order to deepen democracy and 'give equal chances to all political parties', a less than subtle critique of the CDP's overwhelming dominance of the presidency and parliament' . Also most other political parties were relatively small. Because of this and other reasons, according to The New Encyclopedia of Africa: 'In the presidential election of November 2005 Compaore easily won a third term over a badly frag- mented opposition, garnering 80 percent of the vote.' The justification for question 7. The Economist Intelligence Unit writes in 2008: 'The main challenge to the CDP's grip on power will come from the unions, which have threatened further strikes, and from disgruntled elements within the government. Whatever political realignments may result over the coming months, Mr Compaoré remains firmly in control and, despite the potential for further political and social unrest, the Economist Intelligence Unit expects the government to remain in power over 2008-09.' (The Economist Intelligence Unit, 2008) Reference: Burkina faso politics: Outlook - political and social discontent rises. (2008) . () . New York: The Economist Intelligence Unit N.A., Incorporated This suggests that organised political groups such as unions have the best chance of accessing political power. Although it would appear that ordinary citizens also have some access to political power in the following ways. According to a World Values Survey: 11.9% of people in Burkina Faso have signed a petition. 6.1% of people are an active member of a political party. 11.1% have joined a boycott. 18.1% have joined a peaceful demonstration. 21.8% have joined a peaceful and lawful demonstration. ( World Values Survey, 2007) Retrieved from: http://www.worldvaluessurvey.org/WVSOnline.jsp The justification for question 8. ( World Press Freedom Index, 2015) Retrieved From: https://index.rsf.org/#!/index-details/BFA According to World Press Freedom Index, no journalists have been killed in Burkina Faso since the 1990s. Retrieved from: http://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-barometer-journalists-killed.html?annee According to a World Values Survey: 31.6% of people have 'quite a lot' of confidence in the press and 28.2% have 'not very much' confidence in the press ( World Values Survey, 2007) . Overall this survey suggests that more people have some confidence in the press than do not. Also 60.6% of people said that they had listened to a news broadcasts on radio or TV in the past week. ( World Values Survey, 2007) Retrieved from: http://www.worldvaluessurvey.org/WVSOnline.jsp According to Freedom House, in 2013: 'there are over 50 private radio stations, three private television stations, and several independent newspapers. (Freedom House 2013) But: 'Although freedom of expression is constitutionally guaranteed and generally respected, many media outlets practice self-censorship. Journalists occasionally face criminal libel prosecutions, death threats, and other forms of harassment and intimidation.' (Freedom House 2013) Retrieved from: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2013/burkina-faso#.VVsFKdOqqko The justification for question 9. According to The Economist Intelligence Unit (2004) 'Mr Compaore's most implacable opponents-the 'Sankarist' parties, which draw their ideology from the revolutionary president, Thomas Sankara, who died in Mr Compaore's 1987 coup--used the anniversary [Blaise Compaore's 20 years in office ] of to highlight their anger at violations of human rights and rising corruption.' Justification: Although a small nation, with a population not exceeding 1.7 million, Guinea-Bissau has had a turbulent political history and is still one of Africa's most fragile nations. Not once since independence in 1974 has an elected President completed an entire 5 year term. [1] A cycle of political violence (characterised by frequent military interventions) and ineffective governance has left it one of the poorest nations in the world. [2] The country is also an international hub for the illicit drug trade, commonly used as a route for cocaine produced in South America to reach markets in Europe. [3] The classifications bellow relate to the period 2012-2015: a military coup took place in 2012 and civilian rule was restored in 2014. As far as political rights are concerned Guinea-Bissau performs somewhat strangely on our metric, with notable areas of strength which perhaps do not reflect the nation's reality. Elections are considered to be relatively free and fair and so it achieved a top score of three points. [4] It also allows universal suffrage to all those over 18 and voters'support often swings, so there is a high likelihood of the main opposition party gain power in an election. [5] Political power is achieved through political parties, but these are dominated by existing power groups, and the ability of ordinary citizens to access power is limited. The media is technically free, but journalists are discouraged (through poor pay, working conditions and harassment) from reporting on issues sensitive to the military regime. A strong performance in our first 3 criteria somewhat hides the reality of the situation however. In actual fact, power is strongly centralised in the role of the President and elected governments are often overthrown (although new elections are often called soon afterwards) . [6] Unfortunately, our metric does not provide any option to lower Guinea-Bissau's score as a result. The civil liberties section of our metric was more difficult to complete. In almost all criteria assessed Guinea-Bissau had at least some procedures or institutions in place to protect civil liberties, although none of these appeared to function well. [7] Most difficult to answer was question 13 regarding equal treatment: many strong protections for minority groups exist in law (such as the legal nature of same-sex relations) so a score of 2 was given, yet due to the inability of the judiciary to function (score of 0) these protections are unlikely to be upheld. It is clear that Guinea-Bissau is extremely corrupt, although following the wording of our definition is was difficult to classify it as such. In order to accurately gauge the reality of the situation in Guinea-Bissau, a score of C was awarded for corruption, although it could be scored higher on a technicality. Corruption in the country is not linked as much to the misuse of public resources as is it to the trafficking of drugs and other illicit activities. Justification: Having involved in the Burmese democracy movement for about ten years as one of student activists, I have first-hand experience and knowledge about my own country, Burma. However, to support my answers, I used a book called 'A History of Modern Burma' as the primary source, which was written by Michael W. Charney. A History of Modern Burma was first published by Cambridge University Press in 2009. The book covered almost everything about the Burmese military regime since it took power by a coup in 1962. As the so-called democratic transition was led by the Burmese military junta in 2010, the political situation in Burma has changed a little bit than before. Thus, I only researched the period from 1992 to 2009.

Justification: Question 4 - Free and fair elections: I answered, 'There are elections for the executive and the legislature but there is a very low likelihood of government change via elections'. There are almost 300 political parties in Cameroon, but it is essentially a one party state; most of these parties are too fragmented to provide any real contest. The SDF is the largest opposition party and in the 2011 elections president Biya still claimed 78% of the votes. Biya also determines Cameroon's electoral calendar. Sources for this information were Freedom-house and, in a minor capacity, Wikipedia. Question 5 - Universal suffrage: I answered, 'The majority of people in this country are able to vote. However, there are minor restrictions because of things such as age or incarceration, etc.' According to the CIA 'World Factbook' anyone over the age of 20 may vote in Cameroon. However, I was close to selecting 'there is partial suffrage, but there are widespread and blanket restrictions on groups of people voting for reasons such as ethnicity, gender, religion or age' as, according to Freedom House, while on paper everyone over the age of 20 has the right to vote, the Baka people face discrimination in Cameroon and are not represented in either house of parliament or in the top levels of government. So it appears that there may be some under the table racial discrimination on terms of suffrage. Question 6 - Opposition: I answered, 'There is an opposition, however the system is constructed so that there is little potential for it to gain power.' The SDF forms Cameroons primary opposition but has never received more than 22% of the vote due to President Biya's manipulation of the system. According to Freedom House 'State patronage and Biya's control of high-level appointments help his CPDM retain its hold on power, as does de facto state control over the timing of the release of mandated public funding for campaigning political parties and the government's payment of village chiefs'salaries; voting recommendations by village chiefs are often still followed absolutely.' Question 7 -Access to political power: I couldn't find any information relating specifically to this question; however, based on other information sourced from Freedom House, I answered 'Many people have access to political power, with some exceptions', as there are almost 300 political parties in Cameroon, indicating a reasonable access to political power, but some ethnic minorities, such as the Baka, have no political representation. Wealth may also influence the access to political power in Cameroon, as bribery is commonplace, but I did not think that this was the most pertinent factor. Transparency International also scores Cameroon poorly in terms of voice and accountability; the extent to which a countries citizens are able to participate in selecting their government, as well as freedom of expression, freedom of association, and a free media. Question 8 -Media: I answered that there is 'No state censorship, but a degree of self-censorship may exist, or there is substantial government influence on what is reported.' I based this on information found on Freedom House as, while Cameroon's constitution guarantees freedom of speech and stopped prepublication censorship, this freedom of expression is not entirely genuine; an article of the charter allows officials to ban newspapers etc. based on claimed 'threats to public order', with defamation remaining a criminal offense. Freedom house provides several examples of this article being potentially abused and misused. I thought that while there is no state censorship officially, the article in question might lead to a degree of self-censorship, as individuals/organisations do not wish to be penalised or imprisoned. As such there is still government influence on what is reported. Transparency International ranks Cameroon 97 th out of 179 countries on its Press Freedom Index. Question 9 -Rule of law: I answered, 'The leaders of the state are not subject to the rule of law.' According to information found on Freedom House and Transparency International, Cameroon's police force and government are highly corrupt, with bribe-taking common; it was ranked 84/91 in Transparency International's 2001 Corruption Perceptions Index and 144/177 in 2013. Critics have also accused President Biya of removing several political rivals. Question 10 -Human rights: I answered, 'Partial rights exist, but there is still heavy suppression and monitoring.' According to Freedom House Cameroon scores a 6 out of 7 on both its freedom rating and for civil liberties, 7 is the worst possible score. So while some rights exist in Cameroon many are supressed, especially for minority groups; those suspected of homosexual activity are targeted and persecuted, and while the constitution grants men and women equal rights, traditional legal values often take precedence. Travel is largely unrestricted. Question 11 -Judiciary: According to Freedom House the judiciary is subordinate to the Ministry of Justice and the courts are weakened by political influence and corruption. On a scale of 1 to 7, with 1 being heavily influenced and 7 being entirely free, Transparency International scores Cameroon a 2.7. As such, I answered, 'The judiciary sometimes operated independently, but it susceptible to undue influence and corruption.' Questions 12 -Measures for regime accountability: I answered, 'There are no checks and balances on power, or independent bodies established to investigate misuse of power.' While President Biya introduced an anti corruption campaign, operation sparrowhawk, in 2006, the organisation seems to exist largely on paper; and when it doesn't it is being used to convict Biya's opponents rather than place checks on his government. Cameroon's electoral commission, Elections Cameroon or ELECAM, was also formed in 2006 but remains dominated by appointees with close ties to the ruling party. Cameroon also scores poorly for accountability on Transparency International. Questions 13 -Minority Groups: I answered, 'There are no effective rights or measures to empower or protect minority ethnic or cultural groups' I couldn't find any specific information relating to this questions, but based on other factors, such as the lack of representation of the Baka people and the prosecution and targeting of homosexuals, I decided that it was unlikely that there were rights or measures to empower or protect minority ethnic or cultural groups. Question 14 -Confidence in answers: On the scale of 1-5 I chose a 4. I am quite confident in my answers and their justifications; however, there were a couple of cases where I was tossing up between two answers and had to make an educated guess due to the lack of explicit information. Question 15 -Corruption: I answered, 'Corruption is pervasive from the head of government to low-level government workers.' Cameroon ranks 136 th out of 175 countries on Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index, and scores 27 out of 100; where zero is the worst possible score. It also scores in the 17 th percentile for control of corruption, reflecting the lack of anti-corruption measures in place and the extent to which public power is exercised for private gain. Question 16 -Forms of corruption: I answered, 'Bribe-taking by public officials.' Freedom House cites bribery as commonplace and pervasive in all sectors in Cameroon; including anything from gaining school admissions to fixing traffic infractions. Cameroonians seeking to resettle abroad can allegedly base fraudulent asylum claims on purchased, and faked, police reports and medical records, and even on news articles alleging persecution that were written in exchange for bribes. According to Transparency Internationals Global Corruption Barometer for 2010/11, 54% of those surveyed in Cameroon reported having payed a bribe.

Justification: I chose to focus on the period between 1996 and 2001 (between two general elections), because this period included four governmental changes, and four different Prime Ministers (Prodi, D'Alema, Amato, and Berlusconi) . My justifications for each of the RCE's questions are as follows: Due to the fact that both elections held in 1996 and 2001 resulted in new governments formed by different parties, I can deduce that the Italian election system was free and fair during this period. They were both competitive and transparent. The CIA World Factbook sates that Italy has universal suffrage, 'except in senatorial elections, where the minimum age is 25.' https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2123.html . See Question 4 Justification. There is effective opposition, and they do have a chance to be elected to govern. I feel that all Italian adult citizens have fair access to political power. I consider the number of political parties on the 1996 and 2001 electoral list to be a sign of fair access in the Italian political system. The fact that leaders like Romano Prodi have come from middle-class families is also a positive sign of inclusion in the system. http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/299254.stm . Berlusconi's ownership of much of Italy's media industry means that he has an incredible influence over the direction and context used by Italia media outlets. While he was in power he was able to shut-down any story going through his companies. While his reign has Prime Minister was before and after this period, he was still an active member of Parliament between 1996 and 2001. http://www.academia.edu/7393447/Censorship_and_media_ownership_in_Italy_in_the_Era_of_Berlusconi . I could not find any cases of politicians and leaders being able to dodge the law. Silvio Berlusconi is currently held on charges abuse of office and has been convicted of fraud. All of which are dated outside of this period. http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/silvio-berlusconi/11455606/Silvio-Berlusconi-completes-community-service.html . Between 1998 and 2001, Freedom House ranks Italy favourably when it comes to civil liberties (2 out of 7) . Freedom to assemble and freedom of religion, among others are guaranteed by the constitution. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/1998/italy#.VV212vmqqko . In 2001, Freedom House called the Italian judiciary system, 'independent but notoriously slow and inefficient' . It also states that the post-Mussolini constitution sharply restricts the powers of the executive, in-favour of the legislative and judicial branches. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2001/italy#.VV23EPmqqkp . There are effective processes to hold the government accountable, and hold them liable for their actions. Romano Prodi was removed from power after a vote of no confidence by the parliament. As with Question Eleven, the Constitution gives the legislative the ability to question the executive. The independent court system has the power to prosecute leaders if the break the law. Difficult to answer. There are always cases of social discrimination. Northern League leader, Umberto Bossi, launched a xenophobic attack against gays, Muslims, and foreigners in 2000. This drew criticism from his political opponents and rights advocates, however did not lead to criminal charges. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2001/italy#.VV289_mqqko . Educated guess, no record of high level corruption in the studied period. However there were the Mani Pulite corruption scandals in the early 1990s, I am assuming that these could have possibly spilled over into this period. There were also accusations of corruption against Silvio Berlusconi during his governance both before and after this period. It would be hard to imagine that this did not continue through his time as a Minister of Parliament. http://italychronicles.com/italys-corruption-scandal-anniversary/ . Aside from the Mani Pulite scandal and accusations against Berlusconi, there were no significant cases of corruption that I could find. Because the charges for the scandal occurred before the period, I did not consider them for this question.

Justification: Brazil's government under Fernando Henrique Cardoso (FHC) between 1995 and 2003 was one that saw major changes to the country's economic, social, and political framework. This was a president who began the process of tackling corruption, poverty, and the massive wealth gap. The sources used for this exercise include Freedom House reports, Transparency International, Forbes, Time Magazine, and local news reports from the time. Elections in Brazil appear to have been free and fair, especially during the 1998 election where FHC secured the largest winning margin in Brazilian history. Freedom House reports that the elections were free and fair with opposition parties gaining seats and winning several gubernatorial districts. This is backed up by transparency international reports who claim that since 1988 there have been strong electoral regulations surrounding campaigning and funding to political parties (Transparency International, 2013) . Brazil has some of the strongest laws surrounding campaigning and the electoral process. This has allowed me to give it a high score in the free and fair elections framework. Universal Suffrage also exists, however some isolated communities often find it difficult to get to election booths due to the remoteness of much of the interior of Brazil. Access to political power is very restricted to those who have either pre-existing connections with powerful individuals or large amounts of money. Often Oligarchs and business magnates become governors or politicians to further their own interests. Access to political parties is free and association is a guaranteed right under Brazillian law, however this does not always translate into political power as only those with the aforementioned connections or wealth have the means to become leaders. This restricts access to the baubles of office but does allow for political activism through political parties (Mello, 2013) . Freedom of expression and the freedom of media are two important aspects of Brazil that, during the FHC years, were improved on through congressional order. Anti-corruption measures in the police meant that opponents of the government were more able to openly criticize public offices without fear of retribution from the police. The media is privately owned and acts as a major critic of the government. This was apparent during FHC's term as president as he privatized the state telecommunications company Telebras. This opened access to the network for private media outlets who had no government affiliations (Epstein, 1998) . During FHC's presidency he also sought to engage with civil society for consultation on many of his landmark policies this was an unprecedented move from his predecessors who sought to act unilaterally excluding minority and civil society groups. FHC used his expertise in sociology and academia to engage with interest groups and gain favour with a broad spectrum of Brazilian society. Between 1995 and 2003 huge leaps were conducted in terms of human rights for indigenous minorities in Brazil. Marginalized groups of the interior had been ignored for too long by central government and FHC sought to establish reservations for them to guarantee them land and fundamental human rights (Amnesty International, 2014) . However, there is an underlying issue with the Brazilian judiciary. It has long been underfunded and 'local justice'prevails in many states. Between 1995 and 2003 no major advances in the Brazilian judicial system took place, it remains underfunded and powerless to be an effective check on the power of the legislature and executive (Freedom House, 1998) . Corruption in the police force has also undermined many efforts to try to alleviate some of the issues in the judiciary as the legitimacy of police actions is questionable, especially in the favelas of the large cities. This is why Brazil ranks poorly in the judicial and accountability indexes. Corruption at all levels has proven to be a formidable issue for Brazil to overcome and FHC tried to mitigate this through transparent campaigning and a focus on building trust with civil society. Leading by example did not have the desired flow on effects through the rest of central and local government with corruption still rife at almost all levels of government. Taskforces have been established by numerous presidents since FHC but due to the weakness of the judiciary have been unable to tackle widespread corruption. A certain degree of corruption is culturally accepted in Brazil due to its longevity and how it has become ingrained in society. So, it is not necessarily something that troubles society there, it just undermines the legitimacy of government institutions. This is why the corruption index is remarkably low for Brazil. Corruption is present in most forms, but primarily in the form of political patronage, where well connected officials receive benefits or policy concessions. Illicit commercial activities also continue to fund many governors of the interior and, although the campaign process is heavily regulated, funds are only disclosed after elections are held and this disclosure usually leads to no further investigation. So, during the FHC years Brazil made moves to become a freer country, with a more legitimate government and where the central government engaged with civil society to build trust and guarantee freedoms. Despite these intentions corruption and a weak judiciary have constantly undermined congressional moves to address such issues (Antunes, 2013) . References Amnesty International. (2014) . Justification: After an independence in the 1960s, Algeria was ruled by President Houari Boumediene, who took over in a military coup in 1965. Boumediene ruled Algeria for the next decade, overseeing a massive programme of socialisation and industrialisation. His successor, Chadli Bendjedid, also introduced reforms. However, Algeria's economic dependency on oil revenue led to hardship when the price collapsed in the 1980s. Economic recessions, as well as widespread dissatisfaction with the regime caused widespread unrest that eventually saw Bendjedid introduce a multi-party system in Algeria (BBC, 2015) . This classification looks at Algeria from 1990, just after the new system was introduced, to 1998, after the election collapsed and Algeria spiralled into civil war. The first election in December 1991, according to a background paper by Cornell University, saw over 5,000 candidates compete for 231 seats in the country's parliament. The results of the first round saw the Islamic Salvation Front, which campaigned on a platform of Sharia law, win 188 seats -an outright majority. At a news conference soon after the election, Prime Minister Sid Ahmed Ghozali, said the first round had taken place 'generally in an atmosphere of calm and reassurance' and that independent sources had confirmed that elections were free and clean (Cornell, n.d.) . Suffrage was widespread, with Algeria a country generally regarded as reasonably liberal towards women, and unlike other countries in the region, equality wad enshrined in Algeria's laws and the constitution, which allowed them to vote and run for political positions. However, some societal norms restricted the freedom of women to vote, particularly in rural areas (Reuters, 2009 ) . After a promising election, things turned to custard for Algeria. In 1992, the Army cancelled the second round of the election because it feared an Islamic state. The military then took over and effectively instilled martial law in the country (Freedom House, 1998) . In 1993, Major General Lamine Zeroual was appointed President after Benjedid was forced from office. Algeria then descended into a bloody civil war between government forces and Islamist militant groups which, according to Freedom House, killed as many as 70,000 people. During the Civil War, strict laws were introduced to constrain public debate. Freedom of assembly was extremely limited except for those that supported the government, NGOs had to be licensed, and heavy-handed censorship was brought in to control the media. Journalists, particularly those who worked for state media became targets for Islamist militants, while State controls were also excessive -broadcast media and newspapers were threatened with closure, and editors and reporters were constantly arrested. All war reports had to be approved by government censors (Freedom House, 1998) . In 1997, the United Nations Human Rights Commission issued a report highly critical of the Algerian regime's human rights record. Human rights groups charged government forces with thousands of disappearances, torture, and other excesses against alleged militants and their suspected supporters (Freedom House, 1998) . After the 1991 election collapsed, democracy in Algeria was further eroded. In 1995, a presidential election drew a 75-percent turnout in a vote that was restricted to only regime-approved candidates that Freedom House said gave Zeroual limited legitimacy. A new constitution in 1996 banned Islamist parties and expanded presidential powers, which gave the regime the power to declare a State of Emergency and pass anti-terrorism laws which gave the regime almost unlimited power. In parliamentary elections in 1997, the regime, still heavily controlled by the military, swept back to parliament in a poll that Freedom House says heavily restricted freedom of expression and association and was condemned by international observers as flawed (Freedom House, 1998) . Regarding corruption, in his article 'Algeria: A Future Hijacked by Corruption', Djilali Hadjadj said that while Bendjedid's introduction of a multi-party system was partly in response to systemic corruption, corruption continued to flourish in all levels of government through the 1990s (Hadjadj 2007, p 264) . He said that already corrupt system was exacerbated in 1994 and 1995, when Algeria was forced to negotiate to reschedule its foreign debt with the International Monetary Fund. This resulted in a disastrous structural adjustment programme that had serious social and economic consequences, one of which was new infusions of money going into corrupt networks instead of being used to meet the country's needs (Hadjadj 2007, p 264) . Hadjadj also wrote that corruption was rampant in the judiciary, which was supposed to be independent under the constitution, but in reality was subject to the authority of the executive branch, and as such, many magistrates sought personal benefit in order to block investigations and other such matters for the regime. ====== Justifications: Q4: For this question, I went by the 1991 election, which was largely deemed free and fair. However, the barrier was that the opposition -- the Islamist group -- was barred by the military from becoming government, a rather serious barrier that this question didn't really allow for as Algeria descended into civil war and authoritarianism again as a result of this. Q5: Again, for the 1991 election there was widespread suffrage. But this was marked down because of some women being prevented from voting. Q6: Again, for the 1991 election. There was an effective, and popular, opposition -- it just wasn't allowed to govern. Q13: This one was difficult to answer because as far as I could tell, there wasn't really a situation of minorities as it was a case of government allies vs. government enemies. Justification: Political Rights: All the sources I found point to political rights in Equatorial Guinea between 1998 and 2013 being thorough supressed with tight control maintained by the Executive. This has allowed President Teodoro Obiang Nguema Mbasogo has maintained power since 1979 when he overthrew his uncle Francisco Macías Nguema in a coup d'etat ( http://web.archive.org/web/20080612161320/http://www.dangardner.ca/Featnov605.html ) . Although Equatorial Guinea has universal suffrage and a voting age of 18 these facts do not really count for much in securing meaningful political freedoms. To begin with I looked at websites of organizations such as Freedom House and Human Rights Watch to establish the level of political rights in the country. Freedom House has consistently ranked Equatorial Guinea as 'Not Free'between 1998 and 2013, scoring them a 7 most years (the lowest score) for political rights. For example, although elections do occur Freedom House noted in 2003 that 'Equatorial Guinea's citizens are unable to change their government through peaceful, democratic means' and that during the presidential elections in 2002 government officials 'were present at polling stations and were opening ballot envelopes after votes were cast' . Similarly they state that the presidential elections in 2009 along with parliamentary elections in 1999, 2004, 2008 and 2013 were not free and fair, each returning Obiang to power by huge margins or allowing his Democratic Party of Equatorial Guinea and their allies to maintain of the countries legislature ( https://freedomhouse.org/country/equatorial-guinea#.VV5Kqvmqqko ) . A referendum in 2011 giving the executive even greater powers also passed following intimidation and harassment of opposition ( http://www.egjustice.org/post/flawed-referendum ) . While there is an opposition, the Convergence for Social Democracy, they have virtually no chance at gaining political power (they won 1 seat out of 100 in the last parliamentary elections) and their activities are closely monitored although they are active and visible within. Hence I had to give Equatorial Guinea a score to 2 for question 6, which I thought was too high given the reality inside the nation but it was the only choice that really fitted. More information can be found here: http://africanelections.tripod.com/gq.html https://www.freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/WorstOfTheWorst2011.pdf http://www.hrw.org/news/2009/11/24/equatorial-guinea-human-rights-concerns-taint-election Accesses to political power is primarily given on to those from Obiang's own clan ( http://www.refworld.org/cgi-bin/texis/vtx/rwmain?page=country&category=&publisher=MRGI&type=&coi=GNQ&rid=&docid=4954ce2a2&skip=0 ) and in the period 2002 -2013 media independent media was heavy suppressed (Reporters Without Boarders features many articles such as this http://en.rsf.org/equatorial-guinea-police-seize-opposition-newspaper-14-06-2005,14075.html ) and Freedom House continually ranked the country 'Not Free'in terms of freedom of the press ( https://freedomhouse.org/country/equatorial-guinea#.VV5TGvmqqkp ) . Civil Liberties: As with political rights, Equatorial Guinea between 1998 and 2013 was a repressive and unequal society. I found the Ibrahim Index of African Governance (IIAG) to be a useful tool for assessing civil liberties, in addition to the likes of Freedom House and Human Rights Watch. On a scale of 1 to 100 the IIAG continually ranked Equatorial Guinea in the mid-twenties for rule of law between 2001 and 2011 ( http://www.moibrahimfoundation.org/interact/ ) . Looking forward to 2014 when Obiang's son and likely successor was forced to settle with the U.S. Department of Justice for money laundering ( http://www.cnbc.com/id/102077842 ) but has not faced any discipline in Equatorial Guinea, it seems reasonable to conclude that during the period 1998 to 2013 similar actions took place where the leaders of the state acted above the law but faced no penalties. I cannot find evidence that the rule of law is not upheld in criminal and civil matters involving 'everyday'citizens. Hence a score of 1 for question 9. Every year since 1998 Freedom House has reported something to the effect of: 'With partial exception for members of legalized political parties, freedom of association and assembly is restricted. Authorization must be obtained for any gathering of ten or more people for purposes the government deems political. Freedom of domestic and international travel is also restricted. ' Hence a score of 1 for question 10. Freedom House notes that Equatorial Guinea does not have an independent judiciary. Human rights watch adds that: ' Although the constitution nominally recognizes the principle of judicial independence, it designates the president as the 'chief magistrate' of the country and permits him to name Supreme Court justices and others without parliamentary approval. The International Bar Association, following a visit to Equatorial Guinea in 2003, concluded that, 'The courts are not independent and impartial,' citing in part 'direct intervention from the president in order to protect his personal interests' and expectations that judges demonstrate 'loyalty' to the government. Multiple sources indicate that the situation remains unchanged. Lawyers in Equatorial Guinea interviewed by EG Justice in 2011 said that judges assigned to sensitive cases concerning human rights or national security regularly tell the lawyers that the judges needed to consult with the office of the president regarding their decisions. ' ( http://www.hrw.org/news/2011/11/11/equatorial-guinea-move-consolidate-power ) For these reasons I scored the country 0 for question 11. The same report continues: The president exercises heavy influence over members of the legislature& undermining the potential& [for it] to act as a check on his power. The ruling party, and other parties aligned with it, control 99 of 100 seats in parliament. The legislature almost exclusively acts under the direction or at the request of the presidency and consistently rubber-stamps presidential initiatives. ' Therefor I again rated the country 0 for question 12. The Fang ethnic group (to which the president belongs) make up at least 80% of the population. The treatment of the Bubi ethnic group has been poor and they have very limited political representation ( http://www.refworld.org/cgi-bin/texis/vtx/rwmain?page=country&category=&publisher=MRGI&type=&coi=GNQ&rid=&docid=4954ce2a2&skip=0 ) . Hence a 0 for question 13. I am fairly confident in the answers I have given and feel I have researched thoroughly using credible sources. A few educated guesses have been made so I scored myself 4 for question 14 but over all I am confident my answers do a good job of assessing the situation inside Equatorial Guinea. Corruption: Corruption is extremely pervasive in Equatorial Guinea but concentrated at certain levels. The oil state, with high per capita GDP and rapid economic growth, has allocated very little to funds for public works, health care and education. A 2009 Human Rights Watch report stated that 'the broader population& enjoys little of the benefit and has not been lifted from poverty, while the elite directs the country's newfound wealth into its own pockets ' ( http://www.hrw.org/node/84252/section/1 ) . Corruption it seems is undertaken almost exclusively by political elites while the rest of the citizenry is left to scrape out a living in any way possible.

Justification: Political Rights to gauge the extent of political rights among citizens of this country I used a combination of Academic analysis, media outlets and NGO reports. These included 'Ethnic politics and public sector management in Trinidad and Guyana, by Deryck R. Brown. Stories from Kaieteur news, for example 'David A Granger Sworn in as Guyana's 8 th Executive President, and studies from the World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples NGO. After comparing the evidence from these sources I was able to paint an accurate picture of Guyana's political landscape. Although Guyana has in name free and fair elections, with no legislative discrimination as to who can run or form political parties, their system is far from ideal. For nearly three decades the same political party controlled the government (this is also in part due to the five year terms of office), a situation that has only recently ended with the swearing in of David Granger as the new Executive President. However even this most recent election has been marred by accusations of election fraud. Historically most of this fraud surrounded the counting of special votes cast by Guyana nationals living internationally. Accusations have been made that in some cases more special votes were cast than there were actual international citizens, with these extra votes favouring the incumbent. I scored most of the political rights questions around two points, as there are characteristics of a free political environment in Guyana but it is significantly hampered by fraud, corruption and the consolidation of power by one party. Civil Liberties In this section I used sources such as the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA), INews Guyana, and Country studies US, a website that contains the on-line versions of books published by the Federal Research Division of the Library of Congress . Through this analysis I answered the Civil Liberties questions with a mean of two. Guyana has many of the systems we associate with civil liberty; free media, an independent judiciary and groups charged with bettering Indigenous rights. However they suffer the same challenges as seen in the political rights section. In a recent attempt by the CIDA to assist with new media laws to encourage free and responsible media, the government withdrew its support of the initiative at the last minute, hampering its effectiveness significantly. Further to this leaders in the judiciary are appointed by the government, something that gives them all though not total control, significant influence. Lastly recent changes to the structure of Indigenous initiatives have come under criticism for centralizing power within government bodies at the expense of indigenous NGO groups and local organizations. Finally in Order to assess the corruption levels of Guyana I utilized a Transparency International report of the state of corruption in Guyana. Unfortunately this report came with the caveat that there is very little solid evidence around corruption in the country. For this reason their results were more forecasts and expected trends rather than actual data. However they were still confident in saying that there is wide spread corruption in both political and business spheres, details however were hard to attain.

Justification: Georgia is in a very interesting period of political change. The questions were, at times, very difficult to answer, as these changes are in constant flux. There are growing political efforts made to solve Georgia's historic corruption and human rights problems that occured within the last decade, e.g. new legislation passed to protect minority groups, and formal anti-corruption actions acted upon (e.g. recent dismissals of corrupt ministers by the prime minister) . Questions relating to their constitutional structure were difficult because it is very complex. Most notably, a system of checks and balances does exists to ecourage judical independance, however, it is still very vulnerable to the influence from the executive branch. The main point to reiterate is that there is a heavy focus on reform in Georgia, with slow but steady improvements being sought. While in the middle of this transition, Georgia as a country has made considerable progress since the presidential elections of 2012, where a new government has been making visable and ligitimate efforts to improve equality and human rights.

Justification: It was difficult to find sources and had to depend a lot on websites, so how correct my answers are, I am not sure. I chose the period 1992-2006 because this was how long the prime minister was in office for and he appeared to make conscious efforts to improve the economy and create transparency, and is known for that also... While elections are free and fair, there was also incredibly low voter turnout. In 1997, barely 30% voted and in 2002, just over 50% voted. Jamaica has a high murder rate and violence tends to skyrocket around election times, with party supporters target other party supporters. Media is private and free, but self-censor to avoid public backlash. The criminal system also fails to control masses and there is not a very strong judiciary. There are minority parties but competition is usually between only 2 parties and the chances of being elected are fairly equal, though the prime minister during 1992-2006 was elected three times before he retired, he was the first black man to be elected so perhaps gave him some staying power being able to relate to the majority of Jamaica. There are numerous amounts of human rights abuses, especially from police and mobs. The corruption boxes I ticked above a based on rumoured corruption (such as gang-party partnerships) which are strongly regarded to be true by much of the public. There are many attempts to avoid fraud during elections such as finger-printing and ID cards, but not all are collected and there is plenty of opportunity for fraud ('overvote') . Sources: Freedom house The Carter House: observing the 2002 Jamaica parliamentary elections

Justification: Corruption as merriam-webster states is definied as 'dishonest or illegal behavior especially by powerful people (such as government officials or police officers) '. In regard to the question above, i believe that the Slovak Republic over the time period of 1994 (one year after formation) to 1998 was a deeply corrupt state. My first example of the corruption is the son of the opposition party was kidnapped in 1994 and left beaten in Austia. Involvement by the government was heavily denied although the son stated that the opposition party was most definitely invovled, most specifically the SIS who report directly to the president. WHen questioned the SIS refused to allow their personel to be questioned over the case, and in turn a police chief resigned from the police force due to pressure while another officer was dropped from the case. In the same case, a journalist who was covering the case was subject to surveillance (misuse of public resources) and was beaten. Months after this occured a opposition politician was put under surveillance for two days and subsequently beaten. In each of these cases the government officials sought to discredit the victims case and downplay the alleged role of the government. In questioning the son who was kidnapped 'In September the President's son reported that police investigators, while questioning him in connection with his abduction, revealed knowledge of his private domestic conversations that could only have been obtained by electronic surveillance. There were no reports of mail tampering.' This is important as mail tampering as well as wire tapping has to go through a process that is given legitimacy by the judicial system. There was no report of the Son being under surveillance so this points to a misuse of surveillance tools as well as corruption in the sense of short-cutting processes which uphold the human rights of civilians. In regard to corruption I believe the Slovak media to be heavily corrupt. During the time period mentioned, the Slovak government pressed for private owned media, converting much of its government broadcasters into private entitites. While this does not fit under corruption it is important to note that ' Opposition views are given scant coverage in news programs. Slovak television also carries relatively little coverage of the activities of the President, who has been the target of repeated attacks by members of the governing coalition. In April it refused to broadcast a speech by the President, although it has carried others' This misuse of the Media i believe fits under the definition of corruption as the people in charge of the Media are blatantly manipulating the public through their personal agendas. In this case i believe the options above did not cover corruption in the way in which it was undertaken in the Slovak Republic.

Justification: My first country is Czech Republic, and the request is to study this country in the period of 2009. Czech Republic is a state that is landlocked in Central Europe. It is a pluralist multi-party parlimentary representative democracy, with the Prime Minister as the head of the government. The year of 2009 was politically disruptive in the Czech Republic since the government was collapsed in March of the same year, as the government has rejected and denied any plans for earlier election to be held. Since the government was unstable and a shaky ground the topple of Prime Minister Mirek Topolanek's cabinet was something expected, while the government was performing bad since the time that they step in power. Czech Republic enjoy free and fair elections for either state's executive and legislature. It is an electoral democracy state. The country allow universal suffrage. The state of Czech Republic as most of the European democratic states allow universal suffrage. in Czech Republic all people who who are over 18 have the right to vote and so the inability to vote is only posed in some restrictions, such for those who are well below the legal age for voting or other factors that prevent people to vote, for instance, legal barriers. Regarding Czech government and its opposition in the year of 2009, this year showed a that the state within that time were enjoying a good opposition party and corrupted regime. The collapse of the Czech Republic government on that time, showed the strength of the opposition party who owned ambitious to take over the government. However, the opposition has to achieve its goal and gain the power. After unsuccessful attempts the Czech Social Democratic Party opposition has fallen to bring the Cabinet down. The Topolanek's Civic Democratic Party and the opposition party of Czech Social Democratic Party have called for an election, the result that the election showed was in favor for the ODS with a big gab between the two parties results, by 31.5% for the ODS party and 22.4% for the CSSD opposition party. This proves that, there is opposition in the Czech Republic state however, this opposition is not strong enough to overthrow the government and take over its position even in weaknesses time of the ruling party and bad performance as happened in the Czech Republic case of study in the period of 2009, at the time of irrevocably weakness of the ruling party and its lack of ability to conduct the situation as required and dispite the imbalance the government suffering the the Czech Social Democratic Party failed to achieve its aspirations. Do people have access to political power? The lower rate in election turnout in the year of the study, 2009, puts before us the hypothesis of that the people of Czech Republic have limited access to political power. In the election that was carried out in 2009, of a number of registration people of 8,401,374 registered persons only 2,371,009 have voted making a percentage of 28% of the whole number of registration. This might be because of the limited access of political power. some might think this might be because of the fact that there was no compulsory voting but the previous elections has showed slight good result. Media act as a check and balance on power? The freedom of opinion and other's opinion, freedom of press is constitutionally guaranteed under the rights that any democratic state should provide for its different sectors. On the other hand, the government has restrictions over the media. these restrictions are appointed in speech that might infringe on national security, public health, individual rights, morality, that evoke hater on race, ethnicity. Censorship exist in some of the times. The broadcast media is always regulated by the Czech Radio and Television Broadcasting Council, while the Czech television is regulated and controlled by its own council. However, the Print media is more likely to be self-regulated. Therefore, Independent media exist in the Print ones which act as a real check and balance on power, while other media is regulated by councils that are authorized by the state. Does the regime uphold the rule of law? The Czech Republic government of 2009 has upheld the rule of law, exept some of the issues that the government has failed to address. This things form in the fact of how the government is treating minorties and how it is dealing with the elections matters. Therefore, in this case we mentioned the injustice which subjected on the Roma's minority and the low turnout in election. All people within the regime have exercised their general rights of, freedom of assembly and association, freedom of speech and expression. Free independent and fair judiciary? Czech Republic has free independent and fair judiciary, and its know and defined by the Constitution and based on that the court exercise their duties as being an independent authorities. The Czech Republic like many countries fell into the trap of inequality intentionally or by mistake. and here we can appoint to the Roma's minority who are being discriminated against in Czech Republic state. Romas have limited access to education and live in the country side. The issue of this minor group is old age problem that remain unfixed. the Czech is considered being moderate in the scale of corruption. In 2009 the country was ranked as the 52 in the world, with rate of 49% of not being corrupted. The corruption exists in many forms, for example the performance of the economy, political financial funding, the lack of fair and free election and inequality among the society. With regard to Czech Republic, corruption lies on the negligence of sensitive issues such as equality to minorities, upholding the rule of law in the requested way. some of the question above was really difficult to answer either because the suggested answers did not fit with the country or because of the lack of information that is published about the particular matter. Due to the difficulty of finding the exact information, some of my answers were guesses which is predicted from other events.

Justification: I chose the 2002-2010 period in which the state of Bahrain had already become a constitutional monarchy and before the 2011 uprisings because it represented the most stability of the regimes around my reference year of 2010. Elections in Bahrain are not free and fair, political parties are illegal, de facto political parties operate and are known as 'political societies' there is much influencing occurring by the state in favour of the state. There are no foreign monitors allowed to cover elections and the independent human rights society for Bahrain has previously been ousted from the polls, there is also very little chance of regime change. Voting rights are highly restricted only native Bahrainis over the age of 20 can vote, so 300,000 of a total 1 million. The head of state is the King and all power resides with him, he selects the high councils and judges and has the authority to overrule the lower house, therefore judiciary are not independent, with the courts often coming under pressure, and accountability of this regime is minimal. All senior positions within government are held by the Royal family. Media in Bahrain is often controlled by the state, opposition media is typically banned and whilst foreign reporters can cover the vote, they have been known to be banned and there are no foreign monitors. The constitution that entrenched this regime emphasises rights of freedom, freedom of speech, press, cultural protection but law restricts the flow of these rights, especially the right to assembly, public gatherings or demonstrations must be submitted to the Ministry of the Interior at least 72 hours in advance. Bahrain has some anti corruption laws, but enforcement is weak, and high-ranking officials suspected of corruption are rarely punished. Government officials have been recognised for taking resources from the public purse, damaging the economy and fueling popular grievances. Ethnic minorities do have some sort of freedoms but they are still restricted in their ability to run for office. Non-Muslim minorities are generally free to practice their faiths. All religious groups must obtain a permit from the Ministry of Justice and Islamic Affairs to operate legally. Foreign workers are also not protected by the labor law and lack the right to organize. The most difficult thing was to find substantial evidence of corruption rather than pieces alluding to corrupt practices.

Justification: The time period that has been chosen for the study of Rwanda political regime is the period from 2003 to 2014. The political regime of this period was non-democratic. Despite the regime's effort to adopt certain democratic practices, it has yet to transform into a democracy. Rwanda suffered from a devastating civil war in which genocide of the Tutsi ethnic group occurred in 1994. Since the end of the civil war, Rwanda struggled to establish a stable political system that could effectively manage the ethnic division. The politics of Rwanda under this political regime has been overshadowed by the issue of stability and ethnic division. The Constitution of 2003 has established the political foundation for present-day Rwanda. Rwanda has a presidential system in which the president is both the head of state and the head of government. During this period, there have been peaceful transitions of power however power remains concentrated and the electoral practices did not reflect democratic principles. There is a separation of power between three branches of the government, legislative, executive, and judiciary. The legislative branch has a bicameral parliament that is made up of the Chambers of Deputies and the Senate. The Chambers of Deputies consists of 53 elected members as well as 27 indirectly elected quota members from different groups of society (females, youth, and the disabled) . It appears the regime has attempted to adopt democratic ideals of representation through creating quotas for some groups of society. However, these chamber members are not directly elected and can be subjected to the influence of the government-of-the-day. The Senate is made up of members elected by provincial councils, appointees of the president and university staff. There are no direct elections for the senate. The executive branch composes of the president, prime minister, and ministers appointed by the president. Power is concentrated in the executive branch. Moreover, the president's terms last for seven years, which can lead to the consolidation of the president's powers. The judiciary branch consists of multiple levels of courts, the highest court being the Supreme Court. Since the civil war, the judiciary has been occupied with cases concerning the perpetrators of the genocide. However, the Rwandan judiciary is seen as being influenced by the executive. According to Human Rights Watch, there have been cases of detainment without charge, false charges of members of government, falsification of evidence, and interference by the executive in prosecution. Moreover, people who raise controversial issues or question the government was often charged with 'divisionism' or 'genocide ideology' . These charges reflect Rwanda's terrible past and make it difficult for others oppose it. The judiciary is often seen as an important part of the practice of the rule of law and monitoring the actions of the government, however in Rwanda, the judiciary is influenced by the executive which has resulted in multiple cases of injustice. Despite, Rwanda's attempt to democratize, the elections in Rwanda in this political regime remains largely undemocratic. Since 2003, elections are held for both the legislative and executive branch, however, elections are neither free nor fair. In 2003, Rwanda held its first presidential election since the Rwandan Civil War and genocide in 1994. The presidential election in 2003 brought Paul Kagame into power. During 2003-2014 period, legislative elections occurred in 2003, 2008, and 2013. And the most recent presidential election was in 2010, in which Kagame remains the president of Rwanda. In 2006, Rwanda was considered as not free with bad scores for political rights. The scores remained the same until 2014. European Union observers discovered that there were problems of fraud, intimidation, manipulation of lists, and ballot box stuffing, and lack of transparency in counting of the votes. More importantly, there was little secrecy in the voting process because voters had to print their fingers rather than marking pen or stamp, the votes were not anonymous as the fingerprints can be used to identify voters. Despite having elections, opposition parties were unable to gain any significant power. Throughout 2003-2014, the dominant party was the Rwanda Patriotic Front (RPF), the party that won the civil war and establishes the post-civil war government. The party belongs to the Tutsi ethnic group who were the target in the genocide. The established power of the RPF made it difficult for any significant contestation of power. The parties that competed in the elections were aligned with the president and RPF. In 2003 elections, the ban on political organizations was lifted, however, political parties that were seen as promoting ethnic divisions has been banned to prevent future ethnic conflicts. The Rwandan government has been in support of ethnic equality especially because the dominant party, the minority Tutsi is in power. However, Rwanda's ethnic division had led to the restriction of political freedoms and rights. There is no freedom of speech or assembly. The majority of the media is controlled by the government and the RPF. Although, changes have been made allowing for the liberalization of media, but the change was insignificant. Once again, the government's reasoning for the restriction of political rights is the issue of ethnic division and conflict. Rwanda also faces problems of corruption. Despite, the centralization of power of the government that can possibly lead to the abuse of power by those in power, the regime has put a lot of effort on reducing corruption. According to Transparency International Rwanda report, between 2005 and 2009, the perceived frequency of corruption occurs in business and privileges for friends and family of government officials. At the individual level, corruption happens in forms of giving money and at the institutional level there public institutions are more corrupt than private institutions. Moreover, the most corrupt institution is the National Police that often accept bribes. The main corruption issue that exists in the judiciary is bribes given to judges to reduce the penalty. Generally, corruption happens at lower and local level of government rather than among top officials. However, high-level corruption was not unheard of. In 2005, the minister of agriculture and ambassadors to France, Ethiopia, and African Union were removed from office because of corruption and embezzlement charges. President Kagame prioritized good governance and corruption reduction. Consequently, between 2008 and 2011 corruption cases processed by prosecutor increased from 75% to 80%. The government has been active in educating the people against corruption. Rwanda ratified the UN Convention Against Corruption and the African Union Convention on Prevention of Combating Corruption. More importantly, Rwanda CPI ranking improved from being no. 121 in 2006 to being no. 55 in 2014. Rwanda has made significant improvement in reducing corruption under the political regime.
