Justification: Mexico 1996 was a life changing year in Mexico. The Partido Revolucionario Institucional (PRI) began their fall from power in the Mexican government, where once they ruled absolutely. The PRI dominated Mexican politics from around the 1930s up until 1994, using many incentives to keep the party in government. It was in 1996 that the then president Ernesto Zedillo proposed electoral reform to eliminate political instability (Garrido de Sierra, 2012) . It was this reform which changed politics in Mexico as the reform allowed for a new government to start to move in. With this electoral reform, the economic collapse, opportunities in the international market and economic liberalisation all lead to the PRI eventually losing power (Garrido de Sierra, 2012) . I will be looking at the period of 1996- 2001 as this is where the change in government can be seen. In the 1997 elections no majority was found in the mid- term elections and the chamber of deputies was handed to Muñoz Ledo, one of the founders for the Party of the Democratic Revolution. While in 2000 the Mexican government changed hands for the first time since 1929. Under the National Action Party (PAN) Vicente Fox was president from 2000 winning with 43 percent of the vote (Shahani, 2012) . These years provide a look into Mexico moving away from government officials regularly bribing the public into what became a free and fair system. The reforms in 1996 allowed for opposition parties to be on a more level playing field with the PRI. The significant change was when the Federal Electoral Institute (IFE), a group which is completely separate from the governing bodies, began conducting the elections. This change allowed for the Mexican elections to be regarded as 'fraud- proof' (Peschard-Sverdrup, 1997) . The reforms the IFE put into place, including access to media, gave the opposition parties greater potential to govern and challenge the PRI (Peschard-Sverdrup, 1997) . While the 1996 election was won by the PRI, it is thought that there were competitive and transparent free and fair elections with a high chance of the governing arrangements changing as a result of them. The success of the IFE is obvious when looking at the 2000 election, where the National Action Party took over parliament. With these reforms it was clear that there were now competitive, transparent free and fair elections with a high chance of the governing arrangements changing as a result in Mexico. The country also has universal suffrage (Freedom house, 1999) . That is, it allows for all persons, over the age of 18 to vote. The introduction of the IFE also brought with it identification cards, which people used when they went to vote. The voting cards meant the possibility of electoral fraud was very small and facilitated the prospect of a fairer system in the state. It was also compulsory to vote in the state (Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance, n.d.) . Due to the IFE becoming an independent body, the electoral process was regarded as 'fraud-proof' and as Peschard-Sverdrup (1997) states the new reforms allowed for opposition parties to become likely candidates for election as was seen in 2000. Although the PRI still held majority of government in 1996 under Zedillo, the 1997 midterm elections showed their majority dwindling. It is for this reason that I would say Mexico developed a significant opposition with a likelihood of being able to gain power in an election. During the rule of the PRI in Mexico, I believe that it could be said that the majority of people did not have any access to political power; as power was concentrated within an elite few. However, I am focusing on the years 1997- 2001 where there was a change of government and the country was moving into democracy which leads me to conclude that many people have access to political power, with some exceptions . The exceptions are due to circumstances like the mid- term election in 1997 where Muñoz Ledo became president of the Chamber of Deputies. Due to the PRI's power over the state, this was prevented but eventually allowed (Acosta, 2008) . The election shows that while many have access to political power, the power can also be concentrated within the elites who don't wish for change. While the state held reforms to make the elections less biased towards one party, the media is still very biased. Joseph Chappell H. Lawson stated that as on 1997 the media was able to show propaganda of all three parties and not just present PRI propaganda (Chappell H. Lawson, 2002) . There were many deaths in Mexico involving journalists, at least seven journalists were killed in Mexico from 1996 to 2000 (Committee to Protect Journalists, n.d.) . This reflects why Reporters without Borders stated Mexico had 'noticeable problems' in terms of their free press (Kholsa, 2014) . For these reasons it is believed that though there is no state censorship, a degree of self-censorship may exist, or there is substantial government influence on what is reported . As the Economist (2014) points out it wasn't till 2000 that democracy started to seriously begin in Mexico, although rule of law was not implemented fully when democracy began. The PRI still ruled much of the state through organisations such as the police and enforced political control in the states. In another sense Mexico was ruled by organised crime, particularly that of drugs. Much of the drug flow into the United States flows from Mexico. The state also allows for corrupt individuals, particularly politicians, to be protected and not punished by the government (The Economist, 2014) . It is for these reasons that the leaders (or ex-leaders) of the state are not subject to the rule of law . America Quarterly (2012) points out that prior to 1994 general elections were largely a façade to show the power that the PRI held within the state. That is there was no independent body like Mexico has now, the IFE, which was able to regulate the elections and due to this official tallies almost always showed the PRI had an absolute majority win. It was found that the election results were manipulated to show these preferences. Though American Quarterly (2012) shows that after the IFE was put into place the judiciary began to act independently, there was still concerns of influence within the state (Shahani, 2012) . The judiciary is operated independently and transparently, but there are some concerns about political influence in Mexico. In 1999 the state according to Freedom House (1999) had a civil liberties rating of four out of seven, with one being best. The rating shows that Mexico has struggled with civil liberties over the years. While in Mexico there are human rights groups and pro-democracy forums, these groups have been subject to intimidation. Freedom House (1999) reports that while an official human rights commission was set up in the 1990s the commission was not allowed to enforce recommendations on political and labour violations. Also the government used forms of intimidation such as anonymous death threats to those who opposed the current government position (Freedom House, 1999) . Although, religious freedom was said to be constitutionally upheld and protected by the state. It is shown that there is there are legal and statutory rights, but there is active social and procedural discrimination and inequality towards groups or minorities. Also, fundamental human rights partially exist though there is heavy suppression of these, such as how the human rights commission was set up though they were unable to enforce recommendations. Mexico in 1997 had a lower congress held by a separate party. This allowed for unbiased opinions within the government. However, the lower congress was also undermined by bribery. Therefore, I believe that while the state did have active civil liberties to hold the regime accountable these were constantly undermined and thus ineffective i.e. somewhere in between (Chappell H. Lawson, 2002) . Transparency International (2015) rates the corruption in Mexico during 1999 3.4 out of ten and in 2000 3.3 with countries such as Denmark and New Zealand being the countries with the least corrupt and Nigeria being one of the most corrupt seen. This puts Mexico in the middle of these groups, though I would say, on the basis of the evidence above, it was more corrupt than what the number seems to imply. Over 85 percent of Mexico City believed that corruption is widespread with in the state said Stephen D. Morris (n.d.) . Around 60 percent of internal auditor's encountered corruption at some level whilst supervising and in Mexico City over 60 percent of those surveyed stated that it was sometimes necessary to bribe in order to resolve a conflict (Morris, n.d) . These statistics show that corruption was widespread throughout the state and did not just reside in the work of government officials, therefore it is necessary to state that corruption was pervasive from the head of government to low-level government workers during 1997- 2001. As noted above corruption was present in many places but particularly in bribe-taking by public officials, special privileges granted to politically-connected people, misuse of public resources by top officials and condoning of illegal business dealings. The above answers provide reasonable evidence for each of the questions on the Regime Classification exercise. Therefore I would rate my confidence in my answers at 5.4 as I thoroughly researched the Mexican state not just focusing on using one website and used this information to make a qualified assessment. Due to the years of the PRIs demise being heavily documented I did not find it very difficult to find research on 1996- 2001 and answer the questions during about those years. References Acosta, L. Justification: The political rights section of the questions were simple to answer as China between the period 1994-2002 were (and still is) on the extreme end of political freedom (i.e. no political freedom (Score: 0/15) . Using the resources found on the internet, especially 'freedom house' as the questions were mainly based off this site, I found that China political rights status being 'Worst of the Worst' (Freedom House) as the country scored a '7' out of 7 which is the worst score for political freedom. The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) elites have complete control over who becomes the leader (s) of the state as there are no elections held in the state to decide leadership roles. The public has no political say on who becomes part of the elite and the elite can remove any opposition they might face in their party (e.g. high ranking political military leaders) which relates to the corruption section. No voting means no universal suffrage. Ordinary people have no right to access political power unless they are permitted (must be heavily screened over years of service and dedication to the party) or considered eligible to join. Recruitment from youth is possible though. Slight exception to political dominance occurs in the 'Special Administration Regions'of China. Hong Kong and Macau are the only exceptions to absolute political freedom in China as these two regions use to be controlled by foreign powers Great Britain (Hong Kong) and Portugal (Macau) . After their return in 1997 (HK) and 1999 (Macau), they were allowed to use their own media, judicial and political systems to an extent as there still CCP monitor. Civil liberties of the state are almost just as bad in as their political freedom, hence the low civil liberties score (2/15) . Freedom House rated China's civil liberties a 6 out of 7 (7=worst) (an increase from 7/7) only due to changes to a decrease in 'state intrusion into personal lives of citizens.' The media is heavily censored and any media outlets are completely controlled by the government. No open criticism of CCP is permitted. The judicial system is controlled by the CCP. Judges are mainly loyalists to the CCP and high levels of corruption occur in all levels of government from bribes for favourable judicial outcomes and the use of torture and harassment is also present. Therefore judicial system is not free or fair. There is no balance of power of any form to hold the CCP accountable to any actions. The CCP heavily persecute minorities especially those in Xinjiang, Inner Mongolia and Tibet. Restricting the practices of their faith and limiting their freedoms such as public gatherings. Opportunities are different for those in urban and rural areas with better benefits to those in the cities. Restrictions to mobility (eg. Migration to urban areas) is also present. Corruption as explained above is very present in the country from all levels of government. From the taking of regional resources by officials (e.g. Xinjiang) to removal of political opponents by government elites and also the poor judicial system; China is definitely a state that is NOT FREE. Justification: Question Four: Haiti conducts elections for their government however, there are many issues that surround this. The elections are not entirely free or fair. There have been allegations for years that the electoral process is riddled with corruption. The public is free to vote for whomever they please; however, there are efforts by opposing parties to prevent this from happening. The Provisional Electoral Council (CEP) has been the object of boycott by several political parties. The public has been calling for boycott on elections because of lack of fairness and transparency. An article by the Institute of Justice and Democracy in Haiti, states that the CEP lacks authenticity in Haiti for reasons such as it being picked by President Preval, a previous CEP, with many of the same members, made an effort to exclude members of Haiti's largest political party (Famni Lavalas) from senatorial elections, and excluded a further 15 parties from the Parliamentary elections. Thus, elections are ambiguous when it comes to how 'free' or 'fair' they really are. http://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/72E4371CA4A52631852577E4007115E3-Full_Report.pdf Question Five: This country offers universal suffrage in the fact that all adults (over eighteen) are able to vote. Question Six: In Haiti, the ruling party, Lespwa has several opposing parties such as the Rally of Progressive National Democrats, Fanmi Lavalas and the Democratic Alliance Party. There is the opportunity for one of these parties to be elected to govern, however, as stated before, there are allegations and corruption within the Provisional Electoral Council stops particular parties from being allowed to participate, often without credible reason. In some cases, presidents have found a loophole that can prevent elections form being held at all, meaning the legislature could not mess with the executive's agenda. http://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/72E4371CA4A52631852577E4007115E3-Full_Report.pdf http://www.usnews.com/news/articles/2015/01/13/haitian-election-impasse-has-roots-in-dictatorships-past Question Seven: This question was difficult to find a definitive answer, however based from the information available, it was safest to conclude the only those with considerable wealth could access political power. Preval came to power through his association with President Jean-Bertrand Aristide. Haiti is very poor and impoverished, only those with significant wealth have the funds and time to do this. However, the public can access political power through ways of petition. Question Eight: The government does not censor media in Haiti. Constitutionally, journalists are allowed exercise their profession without censorship from the government. However, Freedom House explains that under the conditions of poverty, corruption of the judiciary and the tradition of partial media coverage, their jobs can be difficult. There are however, instances where journalists have been threatened or attacked. There have also been instances where the judiciary has failed to respond to journalist's murders in the past. Additionally, Transparency International have ranked Haiti 52/179 countries on their press freedom index. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2008/haiti#.VV6mHkJ0ba4 http://www.transparency.org/country#HTI Question Nine: Again, information is sparse, however it appears that many leaders are not subject to the rule of law. This answer fit best because often leaders, Preval for example, do things the law does not allow with zero consequences. For example holding elections when they are due, rather than undemocratically, continually pushing them back. Question Ten: All citizens have access to fundamental human rights such as freedom of speech. The Human Rights Commission's report states that Haiti has issues when it comes to inhumane conditions in prisons, weak government institutions, and no repercussions for human rights offences in the past. Question Eleven: This country does not have a free, independent judiciary. Transparency international have ranked Haiti 140/142 countries on judicial independence, making it one of the worst in the world. The law provides for an independent judiciary, however in reality the executive and legislative have significant influence over this branch. The judiciary still suffers structure issues from earlier dictatorship years. A major example of this is former president Jean-Claude Duvalier, who was responsible for many human rights crimes in the twentieth century, involving torturing and killing Haitians. The judiciary decided to pardon Duvalier, proving that the justice system is on the side of the rich and powerful elite. https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/01/31/haiti-duvalier-ruling-disappoints-justice Question Twelve: This regime does not have processes to keep the governing party accountable. Does investigate alleged breaches, for example the investigations electoral fraud in 2006. However, these investigations rarely make a lot of difference. There is a small budget for the Office of the Ombudsman and next to no information about the implementation of its recommendations. http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2033387,00.html

Justification: Investigating Afghanistan's government proved to be somewhat difficult, as I found a lot of information that was contradictory and biased to some extent. I believe this to be a result of the fact that the West has spent over a trillion dollars fighting the Taliban since 2001 and to this day there is not a lot to show for it. Traditional Western media seems to paint the conquest as successful but when I looked a little deeper the situation is better but still in no way at all satisfactory. Due to these factors I concluded the failures to institute a strong state and stabilize Afghan society is a source of embarrassment for many western powers that had promised so much more. Afghanistan is still thwart by the scourge of war, corruption and oppression although there is evidence that this is not an integral part of the regime, more so a result of decades of fighting. The Brutality of the Taliban regime that started in 1996 when they seized power in a coup has severely tainted the country and has left a fragmented society. Although removed from government in 2001 the absence of strong, corruption free state systems has meant that large parts of Afghan society has resorted to self-governance and tribal justice. We can see this in many notable cases of brutal mob justice occurring in which unspeakable acts of violence occur to which authorities turn a blind eye. Afghanistan has major problems at many levels of government and in many parts of society that are prohibiting the creation of a cohesive, functional and just state. I chose to look at the time period between 2009 and 2015 as in this time period we saw the installation of a government via an election that can only be described as corrupt and major increases in insurgent violence. We also saw regression in many areas that in the subsequent 5 years had exhibited signs of improvement. In answering the provided questions I researched many sources of information including but not limited to: Freedom House, Transparency International, RAND, Foreign Policy, Human Rights Watch, Amnesty International, Vice News and other mainstream media sources. In answering questions 4,5 and 6 I looked at the most recent 2009 election in which incumbent President Hamid Karzai secured another 5 year term when his opponent, ex-foreign minister Abdullah Abdullah withdrew in protest of the corrupt nature of the countries electoral system. I concluded that although a successful election had taken place, there were significant barriers in place prohibiting transparency. I also concluded that these barriers were not a creation of the regime rather a result of rampant corruption at all levels of government. It doesn't appear that to have been the result of coordinated effort and many issues can be localized. On the question of universal suffrage it became difficult to ascertain information that was to direct me to one of the given answers. I did conclude that suffrage does exist but due to violence, intimidation, societal beliefs and geographical factors significant barriers stand between citizen and electoral participation. Opposition parties do face significant barriers to gaining political power. Levels of political freedom are higher in urban centres, but violence, insecurity, and repression prevail nationwide. Critics have warned that the 2003 Political Parties Law's vague language could be exploited to deny registration to parties on flimsy grounds. In addition, analysts viewed the adoption of the single-non-transferable-vote system for the 2005 legislative elections as a disadvantage for new political parties. Afghan media is still subject to violent intimidation and physical attacks. A 2007 media law that was intended to clarify press freedoms and limit government interference has been somewhat negated as a growing number of journalists have been arrested, threatened, or harassed by politicians, security services, and other positions of power as a result of their coverage. Independent media does exist, but government and tribal warlords who do not stand for any anti-Islamic sentiment heavily monitor it. It appears that corruption works as an instrument to oppress rather free media rather than legislation. Access to political power is only available to those who are wealthy enough to afford it or those willing to fight for it. The parliament is made up of educated academic politicians, affiliated warlords and tribal leaders. The sectarian nature of the parliament has severe ramifications for its ability to produce legislation of quality and balance. The Rule of law is not applied consistently and the judiciary is viewed as one of the most corrupt organs of government. The judicial system operates haphazardly, and justice in many places is administered on the basis of a mixture of legal codes by inadequately trained judges. The Supreme Court, composed of religious scholars who have little knowledge of civil jurisprudence, is particularly in need of reform. Corruption in the judiciary is extensive, and judges and lawyers are often subject to threats from local leaders or armed groups. Traditional or mob justice is the main recourse for the population, especially in rural areas. Access to civil liberties is evident, though societal violence does prohibit the exercise of these liberties. The constitution guarantees the rights to assembly and association, subject to some restrictions, but they are upheld erratically from region to region. Police and other security personnel have occasionally used excessive force when confronting demonstrations. Afghanistan is notable for ignoring the rights of women. The track record they possess is utterly shocking and for the most part can be attributed to societal factors and an unwillingness to address these factors. Acid attacks, ruthless beatings and murder are common against woman and often spouses or family members commit these acts. The judicial system often ignores these acts of violence that further perpetuates the societal belief that it is somewhat acceptable. Some of my research suggested that some of the questions were not the correct questions to be asking due to the unique nature of the Afghan situation. Afghanistan is not so much an oppressive regime in the traditional sense like North Korea is, it is more so a developing country plagued by violence, corruption and societal beliefs that inhibit this process. It is better described as an oppressive society that is self perpetuating. Essentially Afghanistan is a failed state.

Justification: I will go through and justify my answers to each question starting from question four in a bullet point format: 4) There are consistent elections for the President as well as the legislature - the most recent was in 2009. These elections however are a complete sham, and according to reports by the BBC as well as Freedom House and Human Rights Watch, President Obiang and his Democratic Party are elected with figures of 95-99% of the total vote. Legally, only two political parties are registered - the Democratic Party, and the Convergence for Social Democracy (which is a puppet party which is under the control of Obiang to give the guise of political opposition. CSD won approximately 2.2% of the vote at the most recent election) . Obiang was reelected as President in 2009 with 95.4% of the total vote - and one constituency reportedly awarding him 103% of the regions vote. 5) There is unniversal sufferage with no restrictions on who can vote. However, in reality, votes from anyone who does not support Obiang are completely ignored. 6) Most of the justification for this answer is given above. Minor parties are allowed under the constitution, however they face serious legal and practical barriers to prevent them from ever making an impact on the political scene. Only two political parties are registered, both of which are controlled by Obiang. A report of the IBA Mission to Equatorial Guinea in 2002 noted that there was no visable opposition, and that there was the bear minimum of political pluralism. As such, any real opposition to the government regularly boycott elections which leave the playing field completely open for Obiang to firmly remain in power. In 2002, the European Union submitted a report condemning the recent election in Equatorial Guinea - specifically noting that '...the opposition was not represented in the elections in an appropriate way... opposition leaders remain convicted and in custody, or in exile.' 7) When Obiang was recently reelected as President, he reappointed the same cabinet ministers that had served under him for the best part of 20 years. Many of these were members of his own family, or members of the Fang ethnic minority. The main political tension in Equatorial Guinea, as reported by the BBC, is between Obiang's son Teodoro and members of the wider Nguema family who hold positions of power in the security forces and the military. It is this concentration of power amongst the ethnic Fang group and Nguema's family, in particular his son Teodoro, which justifies my answer. 8) All media is state owned apart from one small, private radio station - owned by the Presidents son. All journalists must be officially registered with the government and while freedom of the press is a constitutional right, there is high levels of government intervention and suppression of information. I decided to give a 0 for this question because in reality, there is no media allowed other than that which is controlled by the government or through the President's son. 9) IBA in their reports note that there is little adherence to the rule of law, and in particular this is evidenced by the severe lack of separation of powers of the state. The judiciary is furthermore unable to uphold any form of the rule of law because the courts are mired with corruption and are under the thumb of the government. In particular, the government partakes in acts of harassment which prevent the judiciary from functioning independently and therefore judges are too scared to uphold any form of justice. What is ironic is that the government in 2000 signed the Cotonou Agreement (a development treaty between the EU and other members of the African Union) which, in article 9 of the agreement, requires the upholding of the rule of law to be an integral element of sustainable development. Over the course of a decade leading up to 2009, the Equatoguinean government has consistency lapsed on its international commitments to the rule of law and justice. 10) The regime is not entirely totalitarian in completely banning political rallies or meetings, however there is heavy suppression. Political meetings are only allowed with the authorisation of the government beforehand, and face tight restrictions. Freedoms of association and assembly are suppressed, and the right to free speech and an independent media is spoilt through arbitrary arrests, torture by the President's soliders and detention. Nicholas Shaxson, a reporter for the BBC, details in his 2004 report into Equatorial Guinea 'Great Survivor' that individuals are brutally punished for engaging in their right of freedom of association and assembly. One political opponent to the regime described to Shaxson that the President's soldiers tortured him by cutting off his ears with scissors when he attempted to exercise his right to civil liberties. 11) IBA is most critical of the lack of an independent judiciary in their report 'Equatorial Guinea: At the Crossroads.' In their report they detail how it is clear how the government completely controls the judiciary. This is manifested in a number of ways: there is no separation between the Executive and the Judiciary, there is interference in the judicial system through political appointments by the government, and a prerequisite of 'loyalty to the government' for all judiciary clerks and officials. The judges act as military judges and wield military law over citizens to enforce the perceived power of the state. It is clear that the government has complete and unfettered power over nearly all elements of daily life. As such, it has been reported that there is virtually no civil society in Equatorial Guinea - there being a severe lack of basic societal cornerstones like libraries. The corruption and restriction of basic freedoms such as the freedom of speech and expression, as well as the endemic poverty, has stunted the growth of any civil society in Equatorial Guinea. Corruption is extremely pervasive and runs through all elements of life in Equatorial Guinea. Oil and petroleum exploration has resulted in an economic boom since the 1990's, however the President and other political elites have squandered the income from these reserves and crippled the economy. Civil society is stuck in a quagmire of corruption where nothing can be achieved without bribery or by nefarious means.

Justification: Kyrgystan Start date : As democracy requires 'free and fair elections,' I've opted to study Kyrgyzstan from the year 2000, as in this year presidential elections were held which violated this criterion: according to infoplease.com, 'allegations of fraud' were levelled at that election; Britannica.com lends greater credibility in reporting that Akayev, the 'winner,'firstly breached the 'constitutional limit of two terms'by running as a candidate in this year, and secondly, obstacles were erected by the Akayev's administration in order to inhibit the running of his closest rival for president that year. Thus these corruptions of democratic standards represent a first step along the path to dictatorship. End date : 2010, as this was the year in which presidential power was curbed 'in favour of the prime minister' according to bbc.co.uk. Moreover 'multi-party coalitions' have governed since 2010; this implies that state power is both more diffuse and more representative of (popular) interests -this aligns with the general expectations held of democracy. According to Freedom House, the media still face a number of challenges; however, slow progress has begun to develop. Free and fair elections for executive and legislature : I have chosen one point for this question, that there is 'there are elections but a low likelihood for [government] change.'This is because in 2000 (see above) a free and fair executive transition should have occurred given that the limit on presidential tenure was up for Akayev -furthermore his rival for the post was obstructed. My judgment of one point is further supported by subsequent 'elections'throughout the period I have chosen: In 2005, elections were again branded illegitimate, and even met with 'violent protests,' according to infoplease.com and the bbc.co.uk, which led to Akayev absconding. From these underhanded tactics, and the popular responses, I infer that these elections were unfree and unfair; they involved Akayev attempting to minimise the chances for an executive transition. The 2007 elections were also branded illegitimate amid arguments that President Bakiyev had attempted to unduly strengthen his position in the run-up, firstly by passing controversial new powers, and secondly by firing his Prime Minister, who had been sourced from the opposition, according to infoplease.com. This trend of self-serving authoritarian practices continued through 2009 when Bakiyev attempted to further concentrate his power through reforms. BBC.co.uk confirms Bakiyev's 'struggle with parliament.' From Bakiyev's tactics I infer again that he, like his predecessor Akayev, was attempting to protect his executive power at the expense of rivals, and parliament (and thus legislature) . In these ways presidents Akayev and Bakiyev aimed to undermine democracy, and prevent transitions. Universal suffrage : according to cia.gov, Kyrgyzstan has universal suffrage as is conventionally understood, for those over 18 years of age. Effective opposition and possibility to be elected to govern : I have chosen two points for this question, that during the period 2000-10 in Kyrgyzstan 'there was an opposition, but [that] it had little potential to gain power.'I reach this conclusion as -given the data I cited and discussed in question four -presidents Akayev and Bakiyev worked to ensure that the (ir) opposition didn't assume power at their expense during their reigns; Akayev in 2000 by defying time limits on the presidential office and obstructing his rival candidate, and in 2005 by further protest over alleged corruption (infoplease.com and bbc.co.uk) ; Bakiyev in 2007 by tussling with parliament for more executive power, and arbitrarily dismissing the opposition-sourced Prime minister in the run-up to that year's election (infoplease.com) . Are all people able to access political power : for this question I answer with one point as, according to a Silk Road study, politics is a tussle between 'patronage networks' ; furthermore, presidents Akayev and Bakiyev of my period of study both came from 'ruling families.' Is there a free and effective media to hold power to account : I have chosen one point for this question, as, according to Freedom House, throughout the noughties the Kyrgyzstan press experienced 'censorship, self-censorship and government intervention.'State pressures imposed both self-censorship and real-world penalties via 'harassment' and 'prosecution.' 2001 saw a law passed rendering the incarceration of 'critical reporters' easier. Despite apparently promising developments in 2004 harassment still occurred, and the state maintained legal and financial means of squeezing critical outlets. Under Bakiyev 'free and effective media'didn't fare much better: his administration had a 'significant level of control over broadcast media,' and critical outlets were still under threat, even physical threat. In this way throughout the period I have selected Kyrgyzstan experienced an inhibition of independent media's ability 'to hold power to account.'-The data for this question is all sourced from Freedom House. Does it uphold rule of law : I infer from the above data that rule of law in Kyrgyzstan was somewhat subordinate to the whims of power-hungry elites during 2000-10. Furthermore recent EU-initiated programmes for the country imply an unsatisfactory record during this same period. Further, the judiciary was subject to the executive, as I mention below, according to Freedom House. Hence I answer the question with two points, insofar as the Kyrgyzstan's leaders over this period of study exercised significant degrees of control over the media and judiciary, institutions which would in theory have held them accountable for violations of the law. Do its citizens have human rights, including freedom of Assembly, Speech and Mobility: to extrapolate from the data I cited earlier regarding the media, I infer that any politically threatening free speech or assembly was repressed or contained throughout Kyrgyzstan during this period. More specifically, according to Freedom House notes that free assembly in Kyrgyzstan was only partially permitted. In consequence I answer this question with one point, as freedoms of expression that were of real consequence met with suppression, according to Freedom House reports, in the censorship of official media, and the crackdowns that occurred in response to popular demonstration. Such violent state repression of protests also implicates Kyrgyzstan's protection of basic human rights throughout this period. Free, independent, fair judiciary : Freedom House reports that Kyrgyzstan's judiciary lacked independence; that venality among Kyrgyz judges was reported, and that 'defendants'rights'were often neglected. In this way judicial fairness, freeness and independence are patently lacking, though it is implied that the judiciary is not always and completely corrupt; hence I answer this question with one point. Institutions to hold executive to account : I answer this question with two points as the power balance between parliament and the executive, as noted earlier, appeared to oscillate as new measures/bills are passed or imposed. As noted above, the media was repressed, and the judiciary was non-independent; hence, overall, firm checks on executive power were lacking. Equal treatment for minorities : I answer with two points for this question as ethnic tensions have existed for decades in Kyrgyzstan, as I inferred from the bbc.co.uk source; furthermore; to make an educated guess I read into notes on the UN Human Rights site on the deployment of Human rights advisers in 2007 that general problems of ill-treatment and discrimination exist for Kyrgyz citizens. More specifically, Freedom House reports that several ethnic minorities have alleged discrimination in 'employment and housing.' Confidence in answers : I have used a variety of credible sources, especially the BBC and Freedom House; these sources conveyed consistent and similar picture of Kyrgyzstan from 2000-10. How corrupt was Kyrgyzstan throughout this period : Freedom House claims that general corruption in Kyrgyzstan was 'pervasive,' in its entry for 2010; more specifically, nepotism was also cited in regards to Bakiyev. Freedom House notes that Kyrgyzstan ranked a miserable 162 nd out of 180 in 'Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index' 2009. As a result I answer with zero points for this question. Types of corruption : I answer this question by ticking 'bribe-taking'based upon a general inference regarding the 'pervasiveness' of corruption mentioned above; that is, given the well-established place of bribery as a means of corruption, and 'special privileges granted to politically-connected people'as per the nepotism referred to above. Sources: http://www.infoplease.com/country/kyrgyzstan.htm http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/713516/Kyrgyzstan-in-2000 http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-16186907 https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/kg.html http://www.ohchr.org/EN/countries/ENACARegion/Pages/KGIndex.aspx http://bim.lbg.ac.at/en/kyrgyzstan-promotion-respect-rule-law-particular-emphasis-transparency-and-accountability http://www.silkroadstudies.org/resources/pdf/SilkRoadPapers/2011_07_SRP_Engvall_Kyrgyzstan.pdf https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2010/kyrgyzstan#.VV8V98Iw83E

Justification: For questions 4 and 6 I relied on the information provided by Nohlen, Dieter, ed. Elections in Europe: A data handbook . Nomos Verlag-Ges., 2010. In which elections were described as being competitive and open, with multiple parties gaining and losing seats in the legislature. For question 5. Horstman, Raymond, and Jan W. Van Deth. Dutch Parliamentary Election Studies Data Source Book, 1971-1989 . Steinmetz Archive, 1993. Showed that since 1971 elections were open to both men and woman above the ages of 18. Question 7 was difficult to answer, as there is not much information to understand who can run for election. However the following website displayed a vast, diverse spectrum of political parties, many of which were either satirical parties, or parties that stood for absurd issues, therefore showing that almost anyone with any idea can run a political party for such an election. http://amsterdamshallowman.com/2015/03/the-dutch-elections-2015-what-expats-need-to-know.html Freedom house answered question 8 and 10 by rating the Netherlands freedom of the media as one of the best in the world. While also stating that elections in 1989 were free and democratic. And that people had some of the best freedoms and rights universally. Schmeets, Johannes Josephus Gerardus. 'International Election Observation and Assessment of Elections.' (2011) . Indirectly showed public approval for the judicial system of the Netherlands by stating that over 60% fully trusted the system, one of the highest percentages in the world. While 90% trusted the legal system to uphold the law. Question 12 was difficult in that a direct article displaying the checks and balances for political institutions in the Netherlands could not be found. However, the Dutch Political Systems in a Nutshell article, http://www.nimd.org/wp-content/uploads/attachments/documents-T-the_dutch_political_system_2008.pdf, explained how the Netherlands has a constitutional monarchy, two houses, a legislature made up of multiple parties with no single majority, and a seperations of powers under the judiciary, executive and legislative institutions. Minority rights were not so easily understood in 1989, as there had not been a great increse in foreign immigration, therefore ethnic minority rights were not established until 1998, as well as sexual rights and protections. http://www.minorityrights.org/5246/netherlands/netherlands-overview.html Finally, questions 15 and 16 were answerable from http://country-corruption.findthedata.com/l/10/Netherlands which has consistantly placed the Netherlands in the top 10 for low corruption. In my opinion this is correct as the Netherlands has been universally noted on its merits for protecting the interests of its citizens without compromise or any form of corruption.

Justification: Political rights 1: Madagascar was given 2 points as the political parties can find it difficult to gain power. In 2009 Madagascar had presidential coup the President Marc Ravalomanana was ousted by Andry Rajoelina who had gained enough military support to make Ravalomanana resign. With issues such as these only 2 points were awarded to as governments do change but this does not always happen through the political systems in place. https://www.fas.org/sgp/crs/row/R40448.pdf Political rights 2: Voters are eligible to vote if they are 18 years of age on the day of the election, but as mentioned before these do not matter if a coup is to be made. Although in 2014 was the most recent election in Madagascar which was successful. There are also some restrictions as to those who cannot vote, such as persons convicted for crimes or offences; persons deemed insane and committed to a facility. http://www.ipu.org/parline/reports/2193_B.htm Political Rights 3: It is evident that there is opposition for political parties in Madagascar as with the coup in 2009, opposition TV and radio were being turned off. This lead to violent protests and opposition leader Andry Rajoelina to call the president to resign. Although this may not be through the electoral system we can see that there are groups who support different parties. Political rights 4: Madagascar is a very poor state and so people may find it difficult to run for elections if they do not have the money/ connections. Political rights 5: As mentioned before there is free media but with the government able to turn off opposition media. Restrictions on the media may be imposed as the government does not agree with what is being reported. Also corruption may play a vital role in this as transparency international reports of 19% people believing that the media is corrupt/ extremely corrupt. http://www.transparency.org/gcb2013/country/?country=madagascar http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-13864364 Civil liberties 1: Madagascar on the freedom house website scored a 4 with a 1 being best and 7 the worst we can see that Madagascar is in the middle of the rating. This indicates that there are violations of these liberties. It has been shown that Madagascar's suppression of media and opposition protests are acting against the liberties of the people. Civil liberties 2: As mentioned before during this period many liberties were taken from the opposition supporters. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2010/madagascar#.VV5V8_mSySp Civil liberties 3/4: Transparency international had reported that 89% of the respondents believed the judiciary was corrupt/ extremely corrupt which would indicate that there is not much belief in the system that is set up. Civil liberties 5: there does seem to be some equality in the rights of the minority groups but there is only small amounts of representation and in some cases no representation for minority groups in the National assembly. There are only two Chinese-Malagasy, six Muslims, and one Hindu and no Indo- Pakistanis which shows some if only little representation.

Justification: I chose these years at random because MAS has been in power since 2006 and the politics have not been changed dramtically between now and then. In hindsight I should have studied 2006-2015 because the election that has just happened in Bolivia might have shed some more insight into the MAS regime. According to the Bolivian Freedom house report (2010) [1], international observers have deemed Bolivian elections as 'free and fair' . However, 'free and fair'covers a lot of different dimensions. Human rights watch (2010) [2] states that in 2010 there was universal suffrage and New Internationalist [3] confirms that there has been universal suffrage since 1952 in Bolivia, although the US Human rights report (2010) highlights that many poor rural dwellers do not have access to the documentation required to vote [4] - there is no discrimination to inhibit voting. The elected government was/is the Movement Towards Socialism party (MAS) and the leading opposition party was/is the Progressive Plan for Bolivia (PPB), coming second in the 2009 elections. There is also a range of other opposition parties including Democratic Union, Green Party and Democratic Christina party. [5] There is a high chance of other parties gaining power as the constitution only allows for a party to remain in power for two consecutive 5-year terms [6] . However, Bolivia's constitutional court allowed Morales (MAS leader) to rule for a third term in the 2014 elections, because his first term predated the current constitution and it was therefore believed that his first term shouldn't count [7] . This shows that the law may be waived by the person in power, indicating the government's influence on the judiciary and unequal access to power between parties. Additionally, it has been said that Morales has misspent tax-payers money to fund his own campaign and instructed police to take down any campaigning from other parties such as billboards/signs. Opposition Mendina states that the whole electoral system is tainted to keep MAS in power, although citizens are chosen at random to count the votes on Election Day, indicating that there is no actual election fraud. [8] A question about election fraud may have been helpful in determining how democratic each country is. In regards to media and freedom of speech, Freedom house has characterised Bolivia's media as 'partly free.' Bolivia has a range of privately owned media companies, which are free to speak out against MAS and Morales. Many of these media outlets, especially newspapers feature opposition pieces rather than pro-government articles [9] . However, critics claim that the government encourages self-censorship. [10] Violent attacks against people who speak out against the government also lessened in 2010, but Morales still fought with the press. [11] An example of this is Morales stating 'the largest and the greatest opposition [to this government] are the journalists.' [12] Media that publish racist or discriminatory content can be heavily fined and some people claim that these provisions were so broad they could be used against government critics. [13] Additionally, a regulation was passed in 2013 that force media outlets to devote a section of their writing or radio/television time to the anti-trafficking agenda. One newspaper claimed that they already had to devote a large section to government content [14], signifying that the government can coerce private media. Human rights including the freedom of assembly, religion, and movement are generally upheld by the government. [15] The anti-discriminatory legislation described above works to protect people from discrimination based on race, sexual orientation etc. However, the extent to which these human rights are upheld are completely dependent on accountability to anyone who breaches them. While the state may respect human rights, they may not enforce this properly. There is an independent and impartial judiciary for civil matters and people are prosecuted for human rights abuses [16] . In 2010, a law was created to appoint 5 judges in the Supreme Court, selected by universal suffrage- decreasing biases towards the government. [17] There is an ombudsman that oversees the judiciary and writes reports of corruption and malpractice within the judiciary. They can resolve issues on human rights cases, which the government can enforce. A cabinet-level presidential appointee is empowered to investigate corruption at any level of the government [18] . However, these reports often resolve in impunity and immense corruption in the judiciary persists, with judicial enforcement often focused around opposition members, with the countries most prominent opposition politicians facing multiple charges. [19] Corruption is a huge problem in Bolivia. There are no limits to political donations and these are not transparent. Companies have to offer 'gifts'to civil servants to get things done. Corruption is apparent at the highest level of government with the 2009 scandal involving the state-owned hydrocarbon company Yacimientos Petroliferos Fiscales de Bolivia (YPFB) . Corruption is present in the judiciary, the police, organized crime, public administration and natural resources. [20] The options in the test did not cover the broad range of corruption that was present in Bolivia. I found the question about minority groups quite difficult to answer because MAS stands for the rights of indigenous populations and Bolivia is has a large indigenous population who supports MAS [21] . I therefore found it difficult to identify who the minority group was. Justification: Political Rights: Question 1: Media and many non- governmental agencies have described the electoral process in Argentina as generally free and fair. The constitution of Argentina allows citizens to exercise their right to change governments in a peaceful manor, through the process of free and fair elections. Question 2: The practice of free and fair elections in Argentina is based on universal suffrage -the age is 18-70 years universal compulsory and optional for 16-17 years in national elections. Question 3: Human Rights Report by the U.S. Government in 2010 (referenced as HRR, 2010 from here) indicated that Political Parties generally operate without restriction Question 4: There does not seem to be any evidence to suggest that any one person is excluded from the political process in Argentina -However, I would assume that like many countries the opportunity could be hindered due to socio-economic aspects of someone's life, such as lack of accesses to further education or funding/connections to enter the political sphere. Question 5: HRR, 2010 indicates that media and independent media are generally respected by the government. However, many media outlets were privatised at the time and cases of media skewering due to political influences has occurred. 'Some media conglomerates used media as a tool to generate criticism of government policies, while certain pro-government outlets consistently ran stories supporting the government's critical line against specific media organizations and individuals.' (HHR, 2010) . The American Press Association released a statement claiming that the Argentinian government had conducted 'campaigns against the right to inform'and had attempted to 'damage the credibility of the media'. Civil Liberates: Question 1: Although it is maintained in Argentina that no one is above the rule of law. There have been some cases of questionable actions by government or high ranking officials and business men. Such as the high profile cases against former vice-president of Argentina, Amado Boudou who was accused of money laundering, illegal enrichment and influence peddling to prevent bankruptcy of certain companies. The follow up of these allegations lead to the removal of a presiding judge and resignation of a prosecutor, who later had criminal charges brought against him by Boudou himself. Question 2: The Argentinian constitutions assure that generally, access to fundamental human rights is upheld in the country. The right to participate in actions regarding human rights is generally respected by the government. Question 3: The judiciary's transparency is questionable in Argentina, political influence seems to play a role in the actions of the judiciary. Question 4: There is an independent and impartial judiciary for civil matters in Argentina, citizens have the right to bring about lawsuit to protect their human rights which is under the constitution. The government also has an Ombudsman office that publishes yearly reports of all the cases it receives annually. Prisoners in Argentina also have access to similar processes, HHR 2010 states 'Authorities permitted prisoners and detainees to submit complaints to judicial authorities without censorship' Question 5: Although there does not seem to be an overwhelming of issues facing minorities in Argentina. HHR 2010, notes that a book released claiming that in 2008-09, there were 16 ethnic minority groups that suffered from the effects of historical prejudice. This affected that group's socio-economic opportunities such as, job opportunities, education, and housing. They were also vulnerable to modern-day stereotypical prejudice based on physical appearances. Although the government or executives does not seem to have any direct impact on opportunities for minorities to enter executive or government roles, there is only one indigenous person to serve in the chamber. No other know, indigenous, racial or ethnic minorities have served in cabinet, the national legislature or Supreme Court. Sources: The U.S. Department of State -Human Rights Report 2010. Published, April 2011 (This could be slightly bias) Transparency International -Argentina: Corruption by Country. Central Intelligance Agency - The World Factbook

Justification: For this case, I have elected to evaluate Bhutan based upon a timeframe of between 2006 and 2015. These dates correspond to the (contemporary) reign of King Jigme Khesar Namgyel Wangchuck, the fifth King of Bhutan. King Khesar succeeded to power upon the abdication of his father, King Jigme Singye Wangchuck, in 2006. King Singye was responsible for the transition of the Bhutanese government from that of an absolute monarchy, by which the King exercised supreme and ultimate authority, to that of a parliamentary constitutional monarchy, by which executive authority was relegated to the largely democratic Council of Ministers. King Khesar is thus the first Bhutanese monarch under this new regime. This time frame was chosen in part due to a lack of substantiating evidence by which to evaluate the nature of the regime prior to the succession of King Khesar, but also to accommodate the transitional nature of King Singye's reign, under which the political and civil practices of the Kingdom were in the process of adapting to a new and democratized constitutional regime, and thus cannot be considered to reflect a period of time in which the social and political policies of the Kingdom were stable. Consequentially, this timeframe offers us a point of reference by which to evaluate the success of the Bhutanese government's efforts to conform to modern socio-political practices as standardized by the international community. In our classification of the Bhutanese regime, many of the answers given are based upon evidence sourced from various international reports (see links below), including those conducted by the Inter-Parliamentary Union, the Human Rights Watch, Freedom House, and Amnesty International, as well as from the United States Department of State, which testify to the low level (or outright absence) of corruption, and which corroborate to the guarantee and general upholding of the rule of law and of constitutional human rights involving access to civil and political freedoms. Analysis of the Bhutanese constitution and of its political system expose a mostly free and fair electoral process, by which universal suffrage is afforded to citizens, and political parties are independent and may compete realistically for power; these facts are corroborated by international reports which indicate of the growth of the active number of political parties, as well as to a lack of electoral fraud in elections held during our timeframe. However, many answers were scored with a lower rating of 1 or 2 out of a possible 3 (with the lowest possible being 0) as a result of three predominant factors: the relatively poor and marginalized treatment of minority groups by the Bhutanese government, the practical restrictions imposed by the government upon the freedoms of religion, assembly, and speech, and the continued influence of the King in the judicial and legislative processes. We shall discuss each of these factors in turn. According to international reports, the treatment of minorities in Bhutan is considered to be poor. A Nepalese minority constitute a large portion of the Bhutanese population (a report by the University of Sydney indicates that Nepalese make up some 25% of the population) and are alleged to be subject to considerable discrimination and harassment, including in the obstruction of access to political processes by their continued denial of citizenship (as non-citizens are denied the right to vote, and Nepalese are denied the right to citizenship) . Religious minorities (including Hindu and Christian minorities) also reportedly face discrimination and harassment by authorities, and homosexuals are unrecognised under law and remain a cultural taboo (acts of sodomy are also punishable by imprisonment) . As a result of these reports, the question relating to the treatment of minority groups and to their effective access to political power has been given a lower rating, despite the relatively fair treatment of the majority. International reports and Bhutanese law also indicate that certain rights to religion, assembly, association, and speech, whilst guaranteed, are in practice violated or restricted by government policies. According to the constitution, Vajrayana Buddhism is the official state religion of Bhutan, and reports indicate that institutions belonging to this school receive considerable patronage by the government, including in the guarantee of financial subsidies and of political seats in parliament (10 seats in the National Assembly and 2 seats on the Royal Advisory Council are reserved for Buddhist monks) . The construction of non-Buddhist temples and the celebration of non-Buddhist festivals also require government approval, and this is reportedly sometimes arbitrarily obstructed by authorities. The freedoms of assembly, association, and speech are also reportedly limited by the government on occasion, as a result of the need for protests, trade unions, and non-government committees to seek government approval before being allowed to organize. The government may deny or revoke these rights on the basis of a perceived threat to national, political, and spiritual security, and in some cases, reports indicate that force and intimidation tactics have been used in an effort to prevent or halt demonstrations. Similarly, media, both independent and state-owned, is reported to come under occasional scrutiny should it seek to criticise either the King or the political system; although the media has generally been permitted to criticize other aspects of the government, as well as to discuss taboo subjects such as homosexuality, without censorship. Because reports indicate that civil rights are occasionally breached and the media occasionally censored, questions relating to the freedom of the media and to the guarantee and protection of human rights were given a scoring of 2. Finally, questions relating to the independence of the judiciary and to the effectiveness of political checks and balances were given a scoring of 2 as a result of the continued involvement of the King in judicial (as well as legislative) processes. Under Bhutanese law, the King retains the power to appoint a select number of members to the Council of Ministers, as well as to appoint members of the Supreme Court, and to amend legislation; although reports do not indicate that these powers have been misused in any way. Additionally, although the King is considered both sacrosanct and legally inviolable, provisions have been put in place which oblige the King to uphold the Bhutanese constitution, and which allow for parliament to initiate a forced abdication in the event that the King were to violate his constitutional obligations. However, despite this evidence of a system of checks and balances, the afore discussed reports which indicate that the government may arbitrarily censor opposition to the monarch and to the political system have resulted in a lower scoring in the questions relating to these matters. Sources: http://www.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/2036_C.htm http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/index.htm https://www.hrw.org/asia/bhutan http://www.amnestyusa.org/our-work/countries/asia-and-the-pacific/bhutan https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2013/bhutan#.VVuxK0Zp0vQ http://www.bhutanaudit.gov.bt/About%20Us/Mandates/Constitution%20of%20Bhutan%202008.pdf http://www.firstpost.com/world/the-ethnic-cleansing-hidden-behind-bhutans-happy-face-918473.html http://www.eastasiaforum.org/2014/05/29/finding-a-future-for-minorities-in-bhutans-emerging-democracy/ http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2007/90227.htm

Justification: The first country I was assigned for the Regime Classification exercise was Iraq, 1999. I chose the period of time from 1991, the year the Persian Gulf war began, upto 2003, when Saddam Hussein was removed from power. During this time Iraq was under considerable pressure from the international community, in particular the USA under president George H W Bush to cease conflict with Kuwait, and relinquish any nuclear and/or chemical weapons, and the 1999 Shia uprisings follwing the death of Mohammad Mohammad Sadeq al-Sadr. Saddam Hussein was the leader of Ba'ath party in Iraq. The Ba'ath party assumed dominance of the Iraqi political system in 1968. Due to the extended period of time with which the Ba'ath party held governance it is a assumption that no free or fair elections were held in Iraq, both before and during the specified time frame of the study. The country advertises suffrage to all individuals over the age of 18. However as no elections are held, there is no opportunity for Iraqi citizens to vote. There were a number of groups within Iraq opposed to the Regime of Saddam Hussein. While religious opposition groups could appeal to Iraqis because of the secular nature of the Ba'athist government, they could not gain power through an election, they would would have to rely on a Coup to overthrow Saddam Hussein's regime. Saddam coordinated the media and educational system to put heavy emphasis on Islamic identity. Religious academic institutions were opening up across the country, and Qu'ranic and Islamic studies were introduced into the curriculum at all school levels. A religious radio station, al-Qu'ran al-Karim Radio was set up to expand and promote Islam in Iraqi life . Media under Saddam Hussain's Ba'ath party was severely limited and strictly controlled by the state. There was one news network called Iraqi News Agency which functioned solely as a mouthpiece for the regime. Any media other than that under the purview of the government was barred. Satellite dishes were illegal. Although this may have been circumvented by some of Baghdad's elite, the fear of being turned in or found out made this an uncommon occurrence. The Ministry of Information was charged with control of the media during Saddam's rule. At this time, there were only five state-owned daily newspapers, one government TV channel, and four radio stations. Legislation was in place to assist in the control of the media by the state, and digressions were not tolerated. Expression was widely restricted, and there were no laws to protect journalists or media professionals. The top decision making body within the party was the Regional Command, in theory its members were responsible to the party congress, but in practice they led the party congress. The regional command also held considerable power over the National command. Religious freedom within the nation was allowed, but only as tool to gain support from the populace. During Saddam Husseins rule there were few processes in place for which citizens could hold the government accountable. There was also very little transparency with regards to government actions. Largely due to the fact that the Iraqi Ba'ath party was strongly affiliated with the Syrian counterpart, and decisions were made concurrently, at the narrow benefit of the party, rather than the wide benefit of the state. With regards to the classification questions, I am resonably confident with my assesment. Iraqi history and Saddam Hussein are two well known topics. However I found the question on universal suffrage difficult to answer as Iraq had not held a free and open election during this time frame, so those who could vote according to legislation were not provided with the opportunity to do so. Saddam Hussein's Ba'th Party: Inside an Authoritarian Regime https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=Kb82Pw-1_r0C&lpg=PA42&ots=CxpV1WrJTF&dq=saddam%20hussein%20discipline&pg=PA221#v=onepage&q=corruption&f=false

Justification: For Paraguay, I used several sources. First off, I read several summarys of recent history. Then we examine recent reputable NGO reports on the subject, notably in this case the Freedom House Index summary of civil liberties and political rights. For data on elections, the Central Intelligence Agency World Factbook was used, along with a summary of the electoral systems of Latin America provided by Georgetown University. Ensuring that descriptions of the electoral system matched from both sources means I consider electoral systems data as presented in questions 1-4 completley reliable. Discussing individual questions, question seven denotes that political power is available to most. I selected this option and points assignment to represent the fact that there is a signifigant socio-economic divide present in the country, and combined with corruption and systematic isolation makes it unlikley for a person of lower socio-economic standing to achieve real political power. Questions relating to the Judiciary proved the most difficult to choose, as although there is an independent judiciary, which has the capacity to conduct independent judicial reviews, several NGOs, notably Freedom House express concern at the level of corruption present in the judiciary, with FH noting that political pressures, though technically illegal, were quite common. Elections have only become 'free-and fair' in the more recent years, with the events that led to this forming the start of the study period. For this reason I decided to rate my confidence as 4/5, because although on the surface of research it appears these elections are free and fair, I am not confident that a sufficent sample size exists, with electoral terms being 5 years, and only two or three elections having taken place since the move to a more democratic system. Corruption is the most pressing issue in this country. To Directyly quote the Freedom House Index Assesment ' Corruption cases languish for years in the courts without resolution, and corruption often goes unpunished as judges favor the powerful and wealthy.'. This and other assesments are sufficent for me to conclude that there is signifigant systematic corruption, even if it does not frequently occur at the highest levels of goverment. Furthermore, I belive that this is sufficent example of minority groups facing barries to equality, with Freedom house noting that, while the constitution allows for equal rights and protections for indigenous persons, ' In practice, however, the indigenous population is unassimilated and neglected.' Although several summarys and other articles were read, the primary sources in establishing this data were: Freedom House: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2012/paraguay#.VV7dy0-eDRY Central Intelligence Agency:https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/pa.html Georgetown University: http://pdba.georgetown.edu/Elecdata/systems.html Human Rights Watch, Assorted Articles: http://www.hrw.org/search/apachesolr_search/Paraguay
