Justification: This period of study was chosen in order to evaluate the relatively stable regime under Dr. H. K. Banda in Malawi during this period. Banda's regime was considered repressive, a dictatorship, the most severe type of personal rule, a one-party, one-man system. According to Ihonvbere, Banda's Malawi was the most corrupt and repressive political system in Africa. I have found that reliable and relevant data was difficult to source. Websites such as Amnesty International, Transparency International and the Worldwide Governance Indicators did not supply data as far back as Banda's regime. Most academic sources were more focused on the transition from one-party to multi-party and thus only briefly described the regime. Some books based on Malawi, especially those who spent time in Malawi were extremely useful but were published in the 1970s and thus did not span the entire period of study. Some of the answers were more obvious than others. For example it was clear that Banda faced no opposition, but discovering whether there was universal suffrage was difficult. The 1961 and 1964 Constitutions included Universal Suffrage but data could not be found on suffrage in the 1966 Constitution. However, based on the MCP Women's League, I assumed that it had not changed and that there was universal adult suffrage. Any clear violations or large exclusions would have been obvious. Question 4 Elections after Malawi was declared a republic in 1966 were held every five years (or if the Assembly was dissolved), as stated in the new constitution. The process of electing the President was done in two stages. It involved the national electorate college selecting a candidate (who must of course be a member of the Malawi Congress Party) . A nation wide referendum would then be held, and if the candidate received a majority, they were elected. If they did not receive a majority, a new candidate was selected and another referendum would take place, until a candidate received a majority. There was no Vice-President. There were also Parliamentary elections. Despite the constitution outlining the electoral process, Banda become the President for Life in 1970 (written into the constitution), and Presidential elections were no longer necessary. Banda had the power to remove any MP from the Parliament. He could also chose the MCP candidate for each constituency, and as no opposition was allowed, they ran unopposed. Banda claimed that he dictated with consent ( Malawi News 1963, in A Monument to a Tyrant by Chirambo) . (Forster) Questions 5 There was universal suffrage until the 1966 constitution. MCP Women's league. The 1964 Constitution included universal adult suffrage (Pachai pg 244: Malawi: the history of the nation) Question 6 Under the Banda regime, Malawi was a one-party state, with only the Malawi Congress Party allowed according to the 1966 Constitution. Any form of opposition was suppressed and any dissenting ministers from within the party were removed. Security regulations against opposition included seven years in prison for consorting with 'rebels'or the death penalty for treason. (Williams) . Banda's regime has been described as a hegemony, (Chirambo), as there was absolutely no opposition or competition to become more powerful than Banda. As there was no opposition, there was no opportunity to be elected to govern, only those from within the MCP and selected by Banda could be given positions within the Assembly and Cabinet. (Williams) . Banda was known as 'Ngwazi'-the conqueror -from Ngoni praise poetry, as party of his political discourse. Any specks of opposition were based outside the country and had no hope of being elected. (Ihonvbere) . Venter claims that Malawi did not even qualify as a one-party state, it was in fact a one-man state. Question 7 Anyone hoping to compete in a parliamentary election had to be approved by Ngwazi, as well as a member of the MCP. Given that no one was able to oppose the idea of Banda, and had to follow his ideas, anyone in parliament did not have any real power in the one-man state. In fact it is said that the only thing the Malawi Parliament did was praise and glorify their leader. As Banda famously said in 1970 'We are here to govern, at least I am' . Question 8 According to Williams, Malawi had three main newspapers during the Banda regime (and no TV) . Two of these newspapers were owned and run by the MCP itself. Expatriates owned the third paper. It was subject to harassment from the government, had limited freedom to comment, and its workers could be detained or exported. If rumours were leaked to foreign journalists, the government would trace these back and charge or deport the person involved. Some reporters were sent to detention camps. In Septemeber 1973, it is suspected that the government took over all radio and press. The Ministry of Information and Broadcasting was disbanded. Banda passed a law stating that if anyone passed what he deemed false information, they would be given a life sentence. Question 9 Being a one-man state, Banda essentially had complete control over the state, and definitely did not uphold the rule of law. Many describe the his power as arbitrary, (Williams) as he was able to change the law without any difficulties or opposition. This including changing the constitution, such as in 1970 to make himself President for Life. Although data from programmes such as Worldwide Governance Indicators do not go back to the Banda regime, it is clear that he considered himself above the law. Banda would have dissidents assassinated. The Young Pioneers were used by Banda to suppress subversives and create terror. These groups were above the rule of law as they were able to use extreme violence (Banda by Short) without checks from the police or army. And as Banda said in 1965 of the Young Pioneers Amendment Bill, 'The Young Pioneers cannot be arrested by any policemen without my consent & If a Young Pioneer arrests anybody & and brings them to a police station, the police officer in charge of that station must not release them & if he does release them, he is committing a crime' (Williams 227) . Although Banda did not physically hurt these people himself, he gave the orders and encouraged it. Question 10 It is clear that there were many human rights violations in Malawi under the Banda regime. Particularly enforced were Freedom of Speech and Expression violations. Free speech was not permitted. Security regulation included seven years in prison for consorting with rebels and the death penalty for treason. There was no opportunity for dissent, and the Young Pioneers were there to enforce it. Harder to prove is Freedom of Assembly and Association. Banda created groups such as the MCP Women's League, but the opportunity for citizens to gather outside the MCP and talk freely was undoubtedly restricted. Freedom of Mobility does not appear restricted, although the MCP held all the power over land ownership, which would have restricted some mobility. Laws were passed forbidding women to wear short clothing, forbidding men from growing facial hair. Arrest without warrant and detention without charge were normal as was the seizure of property. (Chikaya Banda) . Defendants were denied the right to legal representation in court, and no right of appeal. Banda believed that lack of evidence is not proof of innocence. In 1992 when the Vice President of the United States visited, he said that unless human rights were improved in Malawi, donations would cease. Question 11 The 1966 Constitution stated that the President is both the head of state and government. Similar to what Banda claimed about democracy, he said that 'the judiciary in any country must reflect the aspirations, the desires, and the actual social, political and economic life of the people & we do things in our own way' . Banda wanted both the legislative and the judiciary to be under his control. In 1970 the Traditional Courts were given much greater powers. Members of the courts were chosen and dismissed by the government. A clear example of the judiciary not being independent is the Chilomoni murder case. Banda was unhappy with the acquittal and simply demanded that the accused not be released. The case was overruled. Question 12 None of the above appear to have existed during the Banda regime. No one but Banda had power and no one would be allowed to question him, without fear of deportation, imprisonment or death. In December 1972, he did say that if Parliament was not satisfied, it could undertake impeachment proceedings, but obviously nobody could. Question 13 Although there was some discrimination, African and non-African desires were reasonably well balanced. Banda wanted to create a new culture based on both Western and Malawi culture. Unfortunately he based this on tribal customs, which created resentment between some tribes. He used traditional vocabulary to attract natives, such as his title Ngwazi. A national language was declared in 1968 - ChiNyanja, renamed chiChewa after the Chewa people, this too created resentment from people who were not Chewa. The prinicipal language of the North was used less and created difficulties for those that did not speak chiChewa. Non-Africans and Africans in senior positions were the most excluded. Non-Africans were eventually withdrawn from politics during Africanization, (although this helped keep racial tensions out of politics and improved the situation) although many still had high ranking positions. Question 15 Corruption was rife in Banda's Malawi. According to Ihonvbere, Banda owned almost half the economy and it was the most corrupt regime in Africa. Intimidation, bribery and election fraud were the norm. In terms of public resources, it is claimed that the growth statistics for the period are bias. Large amounts of foreign aid and investment were donated into the economy, but the majority of the population remained in poverty. Banda owned media outlets and estates that were previously owned by Europeans. Those close to Banda benefited greatly while most of the population suffered without education, medical care or the ability to purchase simple goods. Question 16 From the research gathered, it is clear that bribe-taking, special privileges and misuse of public resources were common. However the threat of Banda and the regime was enough to suppress the people from the top down, and bribes were not necessary, as the population was aware of the power of Banda. It is unclear whether fraud was committed against the government, as many would not be willing to take the risk considering the possible outcomes. Banda could seize the property of any citizen, so although this is corrupt, it was not illegal for him to do so as he made it law. Justification: Freedom House reports of 1999, 2002 & 2005 were used to inform my answers. The confidence in which these answers were given varies; to explain this further the Political Rights and Civil Liberties sections will be answered separately. POLITICAL RIGHTS Question Two of P.R. was the most straight-forward to answer. Does this country allow universal suffrage? A country report done by the Federal Research Division ( http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Bolivia.pdf ) stated that shortly after the National Revolutionary Movement came to power through the 1952 Revolution, that universal suffrage had been instituted in Bolivia, which ended literacy requirements and racial restriction that had previously limited voting rights. Although two questions, were slightly easy to answer and find literature to provide evidence surrounding the question, the answers provided did not offer a wider range of possibilities therefore the answers given did not fit the Bolivian case too well. Question One was answered with: 'Voting is free but opposition parties face some significant barriers to gaining via elections' as this fits the Bolivian case the best, but at the same time is not very suitable. According to Freedom House (2002) national elections are free and fair, and citizens do have the ability to change their governments. But as well as this, the answer does not consider corruption within voting. In the Bolivian case, U.S. government officials say there had been evidence in the 2002 elections that drug money had been used to buy favour of government officials, including that of police and military personnel (Freedom House, 2005) . Question Five is much like this, and was answered with: Independent media may exist, but there is heavy censorship, self-censorship or government intervention in editorial processes. Freedom House (2005) stated that the Media was 'partly free', as although the constitution provides for press freedom, the ongoing political crisis in the country, economic conditions, and restrictive libel laws continued to impact reporting in 2000. As the Bolivian code stated that individual's found guilty of insulting, defaming or slandering public officials for carrying out their duties may be sentenced up to two years in jail, with longer sentences involving higher up officials e.g. President. Some answers were difficult in finding whether the laws put in place, were actually done in practice. Such as the Question Three : 'Is there an effective opposition and is there a possibility for it to be elected to govern?' Although the 2002 Freedom House report states that the Bolivian Constitution guarantees the right for the organization of political parties, it is hard to measure if in actuality, this is enacted freely by citizens. This was much like Question Four : Do all people have effective access to political power? This answer was more of an educated guess based off literature on the bribery and suppression of rights towards some minorities. CIVIL LIBERTIES Question One: 'Does this regime uphold the rule of law' was difficult to answer. And was an educated guess based off the information gathered on the Presidents between 1995-2005, their aims to fight governmental and judicial corruption, Freedom House (2002) also noted that Quiroga was highly respected by the citizens for his firm anti-corruption stance. Although, the judicial corruption was an important example of how although there may have be laws in place to fight corruption, that leaders of the state still had broad immunity from prosecution. Question Two was answered with: Rights are generally upheld, but there is still minor suppression. Freedom House (2002, 2005) reports state that the Bolivian constitution guarantees free expression, freedom of religion, and the right to organize political parties, civic groups and labour unions. But also highlights, that freedom of speech is subject to some limitations. Again, the possible answers were limited, an option between 1point and 2point, would be more suitable for this case. Question Three was answered with: Does this country have a free, independent and fair judiciary? This was a confident answer. Freedom House (2002) reports as well as Transparency International reports on Bolivia, highlighted the corruption that was rife in the judiciary within the years of 1995-2005 (and the corruption that continues today) . Freedom House (2002) state that, the judiciary, headed by the Supreme Court, remains the weakest branch of government and is corrupt, inefficient and the object of intimidation by drug traffickers. The judicial council has suspended dozens of judges and fined or placed on probation hundreds more because of incompetence or unlawful delays of the legal process. Question Four : 'Does this country have effective processes in order to hold the governing regime accountable& ' This answer was an educated guess as it was quite difficult to find whether processes had some real effectiveness. Freedom House (2002) noted that in 2001 President Banzer announced proposals to reform the constitution in order to decentralize and broaden political participation, and to also create 'national dialogue'as a means of creating policy consensus between government, the opposition, and nongovernmental organizations. Government-sponsored as well as independent human rights organisations exist, and the congressional Human Rights Commission was active and frequently criticized the government. However, it is also important to note that rights activists and their families were often subjected to intimidation. Question Five: Was answered with 'There are legal and statutory rights, but there is active social and procedural discrimination and inequality towards groups or minorities& ' Based of Freedom House (2002) reports there are laws in place to ensure the rights of minorities although these may not be enacted by the citizens. The report highlighted that Indian territories were often neither legally defined nor protected, thus coca growers and timber thieves exploited Indian lands illegally, and as well as this, some Indians were kept as virtual slaves by rural employers. Bolivia formed the 1994 Popular Participation law, which granted legal recognition to more than 520 indigenous communities, this guaranteed respect for the integrity of native peoples. Whether this law is enacted is difficult to know for sure, Freedom House (2002) highlights that despite the observance of customary law by indigenous peoples that was common in rural areas, that in the remotest areas, the death penalty, forbidden by the constitution, is reportedly sometimes used against those who violate traditional laws or rules. The languages of the indigenous population were also officially recognized, but the 40 percent Spanish-speaking minority still dominated the political process. Justification: The chosen time period given for Fiji is specific to the bloodless military coup in 2006 by Frank Bainimarama, through to the 2014 democratic elections in which he was elected the president of Fiji. However, much of the analysis is based on the democratic elections in 2014, while taking into account the nature of the Bainimarama regime since 2006 and its implications on the long promised 'democratic elections' . 'In 2006 Fiji endured its latest coup since independence in 1970. Promised elections for a new democratic government were deferred several times and finally settled for September 2014.' (Forum, 2014) Fiji's current political rights is moderate. Their political rights rating improved from 6 to 3 due to September general elections-the first since a 2006 coup-that were deemed free and fair. The democratic elections of 2014, according to Multinational Observers Group confirmed that the elections were free and fair. (House, 2015) I placed 2 for effective opposition, for the reason that prior to election, new candidates of parties had limited avenues to work with in comparison to Bainimarama who had total rule and authority for 7 years prior. The censorship of the media meant that Bainimarama used that to his advantage. 'Fiji does not have a free media, he says, with the government controlling TV, radio and newspaper outlets. 'He has media exposure which other parties don't -- they've complained but there's no action. He has used the advantages of incumbency to the hilt.'' (Hume, 2014) However, this may change as the years come, and the political avenues become extended for future candidates. The electoral process was open to everyone. Participation in the electoral process also encouraged, however when we take into account media censorship, this may limit the ability of a citizen to say more freely opinions of elections. This is particularly in the case if people offend Bainimarama's regime. This was also why I ranked them with a two. Prior to the democratic transition, civil liberties, to an extent were given on the condition that the regime was not threatened, insulted or offended. 'In January 2007, Bainimarama returned executive authority to former president Josefa Iloilo, a staunch Bainimarama supporter, who named Bainimarama the interim prime minister. Bainimarama also continued as the head of the military, and Iloilo granted him immunity. While the interim government undertook a number of reforms to address official corruption, public support for the coup quickly diminished when the government began intimidating its critics and suppressing the media through arrests and travel bans. Bainimarama also continued to ignore international appeals and pressure to return Fiji to civilian rule. The pledge for political reform lost credibility after the interim government cut wages in 2007 and 2008 for civil servants, but not cabinet members, and dismissals and appointments seemed largely a matter of opposition to or support for the interim government and Bainimarama.' (House, Fiji: 2010 Scores, 2010) Essentially, Bainimarama was able to uphold the law (his law) whenever it best suited his circumstances. Although, post-elections has seen the implementation of Fiji Independent Commission Against Corruption (FICAC) . 'Since the election of the new parliament, political transparency has increased through measures such as live internet broadcast of the inaugural legislative session, parliamentary sittings open to the public, official asset disclosures, and published meeting notes. The national budget is now subject to meaningful legislative review and public analysis, and is also posted online.' (House, Fiji: 2015 Scores, 2015) In terms of discrimination, Bainimarama has made it an initiative of his to remove all racial divides within the political government. Furthermore, ensure equal opportunity for all races to be politically competitive. This has seen much improvement from the past racially-motivated political coups. However, there may be minorities who are discriminated against such as gay rights activists etc. In ending, Freedom House confirms that Fiji has improved in implementing a democratic society, in comparison from their 2010 study under Bainimarama's military rule. Despite this, we can never guarantee that a government of such history can eliminate all corruption. Bainimarama may still be inclined to take advantage of his power in secrecy. I felt that it was important to rank Fiji in the context of the 2014 election, that it will justify a possible transition from military coup to democracy without violence. Furthermore, the possible transition of a 'dictator'or militant leader to a democratic president. Bibliography: Forum, C. C. (2014) . Discussion Paper 1 in CCF's Public Conversation Series on Free and Fair Elections. Suva. House, F. (2010, n.d n.d) . Fiji: 2010 Scores . Justification: Concering the fourth question, it is neccesary to consider that Serbia had gone through several dramtic upheavals and changes. (The third question was also relatively easy to answer) . In the given time period, Novemeber 2009, Kosovo achieved at becoming independant from Serbia. It is also neccesary to consider that relations, at the best of times, between Serbia and Kosovo have been tetchy. Although departing from the question in mind, in general Serbian citizen's, to an extent have fair elections. Fifth question - This has been of of the easiet questions to answer. Like most modern states worldwide, Serbians are allowed to vote at 18, with an execption (those who are 16 and employed are allowed to vote) . Sixth question - This question has been one which has required a bit of research, in order to understand it fully. The New Serb Democracy (NOVA), formed in 2009, focused on a civic orientated system, which would gain appeal, and also considering it had a varied and collective party backgroud, it would pose as a good opponent for incumbency in Serbian goverment in that time period. Seventh question - using Freedom House as grounding resarch, it is seen that across every spectrum, Serbian citizens have access to politcal power to an extent. Hoooowever, although having this in pace, minorities such as foreigners, Bosniaks and so on are misrepresented in Serbian parliment, despite Serbia being relatively liberal. 8th question - Although finding evidence, this has been a vague question to research/answer - but it was seen that media in Serbia in this given time period was free and restricted . Despite goverment officials and parties making threats to media/journalists from the SRP of the highly publicised court case of war criminal Radovan Karadaic,,practises of media control have never been enforced. 9th question - Research, or the lack thereof, have made answering this question a little difficult. From the information i gathered, as stated previously, upheavals in Serbia would have in one way or another, affected politicians/government accountability (due to Kososvo becoming independant, resulting in what would be called a blow to Serbian power etc..) 10th question - Despite upheavals during that period, and a dated a legal structure, Serbian citizens lead comfortable lives, socially wise, and have access to all rights . 11th question - During this period, to some extents, goverment officals still held power over the judicial system - resulting in what could be easily called as corruptive influence, creating potential discord, when hose in judical power spoke out and those who actually did their job properly, without fear of external and government pressure. 12th question - Information and research asked of this question have, at the best been vague and elusive. It has been apparent that accountability in this context, is not a focal point. Also during this period, there is little evidence proving if Serbian politicians were held accountable for actions. Considering the major changes during this given time period, lack of judical excecution (Failure to arrest accused war criminal Ratko Mladic) and major bouts of violence, accountability and judical power were clearly not a top priority. 13th question - Due to political violence, refugges and minorities were abandoned and 'left in the dust:' in this time period. On the behalf of the Serbian goverment, they did not make the effort to eleveate or bring a basic change to minorities whilst they were in the process of sorting out domestic problems. This stance was also adopted by Serbian citizens, with the collective ostracization of Romany gypsies as well. 14th question - In general, i felt relatively confident with answering these questions. Initally, with my lack of Serbian politics, i was a little daunted, but during the research process, i felt and also found that i found a lot of relative and benifical information, not only for this assingment, but for my personal knowledge as well. 15th question - Considering all the previous statements, we may easily say that yes Serbia was a corrupt state. It is absoloutely neccesary to consider that Serbia wa shifting towards becomg a democratic (practicallly a more fair/equal) state. Cause and reaction can be applied here - cause being people were dissatisfied with life - the reaction being government officals negatively consolidated their power and soon. Protection ofrights were, of course, not a priority and also actions taken by the governemnt at that time, were widely criticised in the West and by Serbian citizens as well. As explained, it would be easy to describe Serbia as being corrupt, but in reality, it was going through a process of change. 16th question - Only small acts of corruption were enacted during this time period. The lack of judical and political acocountability, example being a minimal sentence of 30 days for accused war criminals etc.. CONCLUSION Small breaches of human rights / corruptive influences were evident in Serbia at this time. As previously stated, it would be pointless calling it a corrupt state. Rather it would be best described that it was in a period of change - shifiting from a archaic and rather persecutive (socially wise) system to a modern and effetive ssytem it is today. Most of the answered questions relied on this article (http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136056.htm) summarises human rights in Serbia in 2009.

Corruption_types: "Bribe-taking by public officials","Special privileges granted to politically-connected people","Misuse of public resources by top officials"
Justification: Q4 - low likelihood of anyone expect the CCM gaining power because until 1992, Tanzania was a single party state. No one was allowed to compete with the CCM, and even though now multi-party elections are being implemented, corruption is rampant. Other parties do not have the resources that the CCM do - the ruling party uses money and other resources excessively to influence voters. The 'Traditional Hospitality Act,' introduced just before the 2000 elections, made it so that those competing for political posts could extend 'a vote of thanks' to their supporters - commonly called takrima - and it is extremely difficult to account for where the sources of money that many of these events held in the name of takrima came from. In 2010 there was widespread suspicion that the ruling party were working in tandem with electoral officials to change votes and ensure a CCM victory. ('In Re: Constitution of the United Republic of Tanzania,' accessed 21/05/2015, http://www.saflii.org/tz/cases/TZHC/2006/4.html ) ('Tanzania: Overview of Corruption and Anti-corruption,' acessed 21/02/2015, www.U4.no ) Q5 - universal suffrage (at the age of 18) has existed since 1958 when women were given the vote ('Women and the Vote,' accessed 21/05/2015, http://www.nzhistory.net.nz/politics/womens-suffrage/world-suffrage-timeline ) ('Feild listing: Suffrage,' accessed 21/05/2014, https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2123.html ) Q6 - Chadema ( Chama cha Demokrasia na Maendeleo - Swahili for the Party for Democracy and Progress) and its allies (CUF, NLD and NCCR-Mageuzi) are gunning for a new federal structure that they have hopes will end some existing arrangements which help the CCM keep its grip on power. The four parties have decided to unite to provide a challenge to the CCM in the 2015 elections, but the assembly is drawing up a new constitution which fails to push the opposition's demand for this new system of federalism and thus will most likely help CCM keep a firm grip on power. ('Fractured Tanzania Opposition Unlikely to Unseat Ruling CCM Party,' accessed 21/05/2015, http://www.worldpoliticsreview.com/trend-lines/15100/fractured-tanzania-opposition-unlikely-to-unseat-ruling-ccm-party ) ('Zanzibar: Tanzania Opposition Party Calls for Protests after Rejection of Federalist Reform,' accessed 21/05/2015, http://unpo.org/article/17551 ) Q7 - the only justification i have for this is an educated guess. As far as I can tell, there is no restrictions on who can enter politics - for example Tanzania works hard to promote gender diversity. It is more a case of getting into power once you are a part of an opposition party that is hard due to the CCM's seemingly iron-clad grip on party rule. Q8 - the media in Tanzania is technically free - 'article 18 of the constitution safeguards the freedom of expression and the rights to seek, impart, and receive information on important societal issues and prominent people,' but self-censorship is encouraged and reporters are sometimes intimidated and threatened with violence. A law administered during the single-party era gives the government discretionary powers, and this was used to threaten some newspapers during the 2010 election over what the CCM saw to be unfavourable coverage. ('Countries at thwe Crossroads; Tanzania,' accessed 21/05/15, https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2012/tanzania#.VV2A6NLNu70 ) Q9 - The police force and the judiciary are considered the most corrupt institutions in Tanzania by the East Africa Bribery Index. Constitutionally all citizens are subject to the law and the judiciary is considered 'free and independant,' but since the judiciary does not have an independant bugdet and all judges are presidential appointees it is very difficult to say that it is free from corruption. ('Tanzanian Police the 'most corrupt' in East Africa,' accessed 21/05/2015, http://www.africareview.com/News/Report-says-Tanzanian-police-the-most-corrupt-in-East-Africa/-/979180/2051704/-/dc2egd/-/index.html ) ('East Afrian Bribery Index,' accessed 21/05/2015, http://soea.sidint.net/data/picture-of-now/east-africa-social-context/east-african-opinions-of-their-governments/ ) Q10 - freedom of association and assembly is guaranteed in the constitution, but the ruling party weilds considerable power with regards to moderation and suppression of their activities. Again, while the constitution guarantees of the freedoms of expression and speech, there is fairly heavy government suppression of those it perceives as being averse to their cause - for example in 2012 a reporter was killed by police after he questioned them about the arrest of a fellowe reporter; one junior officer was arrested but six others thought to be involved were not pursued. Freedom of association, assembly, speech and expression are ensured up to the point of opposing the ruling party. ('Freedom in the World: Tanzania,' accessed 21/05/2015, https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2013/tanzania#.VV1_cdLNu70 ) Q11 - as mentioned earlier the judiciary is heavily influenced by the executive by way of appointing judges, and bribery is a large part of its day-to-day functionality. Q12 - there doesnt seem to be a whole lot of checks and balances on power in Tanzania. The most I could find is the system of accountablity at the elctorate level, whereby MPs are accountable only in that the wish to be re-elected. There is a public ethics secretariat, but the position is all but superfluous as it is accountable to the president not to the parliament. ('United Republic of Tanzania President's Office - Ethics Secretariat,' accessed 21/05/2015, http://www.ethicssecretariat.go.tz/ ) Q13 - Tanzania is fairly good with relation to minorities as there seems to be little of the groups to begin with. The government on paper is committed to gender diversity which seems to measure up in real life when the male/female split in government is considered. The 2013 first draft of the new constitution for the Federation of the United Republic of Tanzania recognised minority hunter-gatherer groups for the first time since the Independance. ('Tanzania's forgotten minority groups win rights,' accessed 21/05/2015, http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/news/Tanzania-s-forgotten-minority-groups-win-rights-/-/2558/1876206/-/cc7pgv/-/index.html ) ('Tanzania: Women's repesentaion quotas,' accessed 21/05/2015, http://www.content.eisa.org.za/old-page/tanzania-womens-representation-quotas ) Q14 - I'm fairly confident, it's hard to tell with Tanzania because while in theory and on paper they have a functioning constitutional democracy, there is so much corruption going on under the radar to take into account. Q15 - I would say - educated guess - that corruption is pervasive at all levels of the state (as indicated by the East India Bribery Index) right from the institution of takrima, to bribery in citizens' everyday lives to go about their business and get things done when interacting with government officials.

Justification: The given Country of Georgia was plunged into civil war in 1993 as a consequence the internal turmoil of this period provided a context for the answers to the questions above. The questions concerning the political rights within Georgia were largely based on the findings of Freedom house with their 2003 report that ranked it as partly free and highlighted the dominance of Eduard Shevardnadze following the crushing of the Gamsakhurdia revolutionaries: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2003/georgia#.VV1SL_mqqko The political rights questions were largely educated guesses based on what little information there was on the electoral process, all of the presidents were democratically elected following the collapse of communism in 1990 within Georgia. The questions concerning access to political power and having an effective opposition are largely undermined by the dominance of one party that has the ability to assign people to the judiciary, legislature and executive. However the question concerning the freedom of the press as a check and balance to power was covered to an extent in the later years of the research period quite well by http://ejc.net/media_landscapes/georgia . The civil liberties Questions are that concern the rule of law and independence of the judiciary are portrayed as being heavily influenced by the president and the ruling party in that appointment and pressure is applied constantly according to Freedom house. The widespread corruption of the Judiciary and policing system has allowed the suppression of human rights and the persistent persecution of minority groups such as Chechnian, Abkhazian and Gamsakhurdia supporters. Transparency International's 2002 Corruption Perceptions Index ranked Georgia 85/102 countries due to its endemic nature http://www.transparency.org/research/cpi/cpi_2002/0/ .As well as this there has been a publication of recommendations by the OECD for Georgia with specific regulations and laws that should have been implemented to combat corruption as detailed in this report http://www.oecd-ilibrary.org.helicon.vuw.ac.nz/docserver/download/2805041e.pdf?expires=1432183542&id=id&accname=oid006392&checksum=5998EDC52CA564AF5F4013E401CE435A . The was some difficulty in translating the effect of Civil war into the given options within many of the questions, for example prior to the civil war the president was democratically elected yet military intervention resulted in widespread ethnic conflict, not to mention the interference of Russia within the internal politics and security of Georgia.

Justification: On February 2011, President Mubarak announced his resignation and handed over Egypt's government to the military that promised to work towards a transition to a new regime. It was clear that neither political institutions nor the economic policies met the aspirations of the masses of people in Egypt and the whole Middle East region, and that was answer for the reason why people marched down the streets and sparked a revolution. Security is a major task that should be performed by the state. Egypt has been under an official state of Emergency which provided police and security agencies with powers to get demonstrations prohibited, newspapers censored, personal communications monitored, people detained at from their will, defendants sent before special military courts to which there is no appeal and prisoners were being held indefinitely without charge. In this section, I am trying to justify my answers to the above seventeen questions, which includes the political rights and civil liberties under Mubarak's regime. My answers covered the period in Egypt between 1981 until February 2011 when the January revolution provoked. There are five basic issues regarding Egypt's political rights such as elections, universal suffrage, opposition parties, people's access to political power and finally the media status within this era. First, for elections and opposition parties, voting was free under this regime but the opposition parties usually face significant barriers to achieve power through elections. Under Mubarak authoritarian regime, political parties and interest groups allowed to be established but they kept under tight control. No parties allowed to be based on gender, ethnic origin or religion background. Egypt has multi-party system that was allowed by its constitution. However, the national Democratic Party was the only long time ruling party that dominated the political sphere up until the Egyptian revolution occurred. Under Mubarak, opposition parties have no chance of gaining power for example the Muslim brotherhood party that was the most popular opposition party was excluded from running in the elections. Additionally, the rigged elections of 2005 when Muabarak won six-year term in office with 88.6% of total vote is another brutal example to show how elections were not fair or independent. Mubarak opponent 'Ayman Nour' who established the 'El.Ghad party', after facing him in the presidential election, he was sentenced to five years in jail on forgery charges. Rights groups say Egyptian elections, which consistently reproduce NDP dominated parliaments, are routinely spoiled by fraud at the ballot box, a claim denied by the government, which has pledged to hold a fair vote (Aljazeera) . Thousands of requests were also rejected to monitor the vote and count. Therefore, despite the eligibility of giving votes and involving in elections, Mubarak authoritarian regime had strong influence upon elections to keep opposition parties away from the political involvement to protect their positions, and the reason why people were not encouraged to vote in these unfair election. Universal suffrage and the lack of people's access to political power are another problematic issue within this period. In Egypt every adult can vote and it allow the universal suffrage. Elections are normally held for the president and unicameral legislature. Suffrage is universal and also obligatory for all Egyptian citizens over 18 years and that did not change under Mubarak corrupted system. Additionally, those who fail to vote should pay a fine and sometimes get imprison. But in Egypt there are large percentages that considered eligible voters do not usually vote. This returns back to people's beliefs towards the regime that made them assure that their votes will not count, and the corrupted system always rigged the elections and change votes for their own advantage. Thus this could also be an example to show the decline of political participation within this period and why the majority of people do not have any access to political power under Mubarak's regime; power is concentrated within the ruling elites. Under Mubarak regime, there was a huge criticism for cracking down on the local media, freedom of speech and expression. Despite some little achievements, media including theatre, cinema or press become such bolder in getting close on any topics once it considered taboo such as issues linked to the government or criticism for the ruling party. There was a red line in the area of critiquing the president (Muabrak), and those who exposed themselves to such issue; they ended up tortured or jailed. For instance, In September 2007, several opposition journalists and editors were arrested for 'harming the public interest' by publishing articles, which a judge said, implied that the NDP was dictatorial (Aljazeera) . This shows why there was a partial right and heavy suppression and monitoring for citizens to express their opinion and criticise the current authoritarian regime. Media was the tool that served the regime's interest and anyone could critique their way of exploiting people usually face charges of incitement to violence such as 'Tawfiq Okasha' who is a television host, and has had his own channel but it was temporarily shut down for being accused of insulting the president (Khalil, 2015) (world time) . Moving to the second part, which is the Civil liberties under Mubarak regime and starting with 'Does the regime uphold the rule of law? Generally, the rule of law upheld, but notable and some breaches do occur. The rule of law necessitates that law is accessible and clear so citizens of a state are aware of the boundaries of the law, which they must obey. The rule of law also applies to government and guarantees certain basic rights such as (presumption of innocence until proven guilty, not to be arbitrarily detained without due process and right to fair trial in an independent court) . Also, all the executive and judicial organs of a state must uphold the rule of law because nobody is above the law. That has existed under Mubarak's ruling time, but still significant diversion exists. For example, the case of 'Khalid Said' the Egyptian guy who was tortured to death at the hands of police officers and became the symbol for many Egyptians who want to see their country free of brutality and ill treatment. Khalid was killed after he posted a video on the Internet of officers sharing spoils form a drug bust among them. The authorities after his death refused to reveal the truth, beside no investigation has done saying that his death because he swallowed 'Marjuana' . Therefore, despite his calls for mercy and asking them why they are doing this to and the rule of law, they continued their torture until he died, and became main reason behind the causes of the demonstration in 2011. I believe that the Egyptian judiciary is independent of political influences, but there are some pre revolutionary challenges. There are some hardships while performing its role, not only as judicial institution, but also as constitutional authority that work alongside with the executive and legislative sectors. These problems included in the process of recruiting new judges. This process has characterised by the idea of favouritism and nepotism instead of the fair and equal opportunities that based on merits. Another challenge was the 'slow justice' and inefficiency. For instance, there were nearly 20 million cases waiting adjudication, and at the same time the number of judges did not exceed 9,000. Another major problem is related to the independence of the judiciary from the executive branch. Such interference could be seen in the authority of the president to choose the heads of judicial institutions with no regard for the principle of seniority. The minister of justice has the power to be involved in the judiciary affairs and control its budget (Mideast) . In 2003, in 'Yahya al-Refai' one of the judges in his resignation revealed the methodical campaign to corrupt and divide the judges by the ministry of Justice. He talked about the handing out of bonuses to compliant judges while others struggle with their basic wages, and the requirement that judges provide the ministry with copies of civil and criminal suits against prominent officials. Since then, judges started to talk about the political interference and corruption in the judicial affairs ( Transparency International, 2007) . Therefore, I believe that under this period there was some challenges that stand in the way of Egypt's judiciary and now there are some efforts to improve its efficiency and to achieve full independence and to be a professional institution. Without a doubt Egypt ensure religious liberty and its free exercise to its nation. Although the country upholds some equal rights and equal treatment for some minority groups, there are a level of discrimination, repression and inequality. Egypt has a number of religious minorities living there and reached to ten per cent of its total population (minorityrights.org) . For example, the Muslim brotherhood was founded by 'Hassan al-Banna' in 1928 and considered as an Islamic, political and social movement was officially banned by Egypt's government. The regime exerted some attempts to suppress the organisation during its 30-year rule. Undoubtedly, such influence has its role in sparking the Egyptian revolution in 2011. Yet the experience of some Copts in the recent years under Mubarak has been struggle. Coptic Christianity is Egypt's largest religious minority. Despite their safety that was guaranteed under Mubarak, there is some level of violence against Copts that were cites. For example attacks on Churches including the Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria and the bomb that killed 21, which is the latest assaults. People had bad experience and believed that Mubarak failed to provide them protection in their country, and many Copts took place in the streets during the mass demonstrations opposing Mubarak and his regime. Last point is the corruption and the misuse of Egypt public resources. I believe that under this regime there were no checks or balances. Under this regime, officials were free and not restricted and corruption was pervasive from the head of the government to low level government, and that was clear in the matter of the misuse of public resources. For instance, exporting the gas to Israel. There was a massive loss incurred in the course of Egypt's natural gas that was exported to Israel. Under such case, 'Sameh Fahmy' who was the minister of petroleum and other petroleum officials were sentenced to 15 years imprisonment on charges related to the misappropriation of the public funds (Masr, 2015) . He was accused of signing a Memorandum of Understanding with the Israeli government that paved the way for exporting gas to Israel for 15 years at low prices, which minimum limit did not exceed the cost of production and maximum limit was not even corresponding in the same size with the international prices. Thus, this is a clear example to illustrate how this regime was completely exploitative and corrupted especially in the sense of using the country's resources. Therefore, I can say that I am completely satisfied with my justifications, and believe that despite some advantages that Mubarak had given under his power, there are huge disadvantages and its most important cause was corruption, dictatorship and the full authority to the extent of tyranny and absolute repression in many times. Justification: Question 4: After overthrowing David Dacko in a coup in 1981, Andre Kolingba suspended the constitution in the Central African Republic, ruling with a military junta until 1985. In 1986 (the beginning point to my research) he introduced a new constitution that was ratified by a nationwide referendum. He declared his membership in the one-party state Rassemblement Democratique Centrafricain (RDC) and formed a National Assembly, naming himself president for a period of six years. Though legislative elections were staged in July of 1987, Kolingba effectively held all executive and legislative power in the nation. He prohibited his two major opponents from participating (Abel Goumba and Ange-Felix Patasse) and the elections were only semi-free. Considering these significant limitations, it is fair to conclude that there was minimal likelihood of government change via the electoral process. Kalck, Pierre. Historical Dictionary of the Central African Republic. 3rd ed. Trans. Thomas O'Toole. Metuchen, N.J. & London: The Scarecrow Press, 2004. Question 5 Justification: Universal adult suffrage was a part of the constitution that was promulgated in 1981, however this was suspended in the coup later that year. In 1986 when the new constitution was introduced, universal suffrage was present. This meant that anyone over the age of 18 was able to vote. However, as a single-party system with ineffectual elections, no opposing parties, the abolishment of term restrictions and a set presidency of 6 years, it is important to acknowledge that the notion of 'universal suffrage' was somewhat erroneous. It was not until 1993, when Kolingba was officially voted out, that the peoples'right to vote was actually practiced and thus validated. Kalck, Pierre. Historical Dictionary of the Central African Republic. 3rd ed. Trans. Thomas O'Toole. Metuchen, N.J. & London: The Scarecrow Press, 2004. Question 6 Only in 1991 did President Kolingba announce the creation of a national commission to rewrite the constitution to provide for a multi-party system. Until then, all opposition was persecuted. Kolingba also drafted the constitution so that it abolished term restrictions, allowing him a set presidency of 6 years. Therefore, no opposition was enabled during this time period. Kalck, Pierre. Historical Dictionary of the Central African Republic. 3rd ed. Trans. Thomas O'Toole. Metuchen, N.J. & London: The Scarecrow Press, 2004. Question 7 The National Assembly under Kolingba was made up of 52 elected deputies. Kolingba explicitly favored a subgroup in society in regards to who was allowed access to this political power. He was from the Yakoma group, which is part of the Ngbandi ethnic group found on the banks of the Obangui river in the south who make up approximately 4% - 5% of the population. Upon gaining presidency, he initiated a tribally-based recruitment policy for his administration. Members of Yakoma were given all key positions in administration, and came to make up the majority of the military also. It is fair from these recruitments to say that only few people were granted access to political power, and these requirements were discriminatory, despite membership being voluntary. http://www.preventgenocide.org/prevent/news-monitor/2001june.htm Question 8 The nation's first daily newspaper, the state-run E Le Songo, began publication in 1986. Several private daily and weekly newspapers were published, some of which criticized the president and the government. The country's main publications include Le Novateur, Le Citoyen, and L'Echo de Centrafrique . However, the most important means of mass communication in the country -radio - was owned and controlled by the government, and still is today. Although independent media existed, the primary means of communication was not an adequate check and balance on power. http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/102152/Central-African-Republic/214025/The-arts-and-cultural-institutions Question 9 Kolingba concentrated all executive and legislature power unto himself. This is evident throughout the second phase of his regime, which was marked by all sorts of fierce social protest movements that were often simply met with repression. By May of 1990, thousands had marched and united to strike for government reform. The government publicly rejected the demands for a multi-party national congress, and between May and August, detained supporters of the resistance, effectively denying their basic right to peaceful protest. This sort of action is symptomatic of the state's longstanding failure to afford the civilian population protection and uphold the rule of law. Kolingba and his allies were effectively above the law, and exercised power in their own favour as opposed to adopting their policies to fit with the existing law. http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/car-6.htm Question 10 Human rights such as freedom of assembly and association, freedom of speech and expression and freedom of mobility were all heavily suppressed under Kolingba's government. The government implicated heavy prosecution toward any resistance. On 12 September 1990, the regime arrested twenty-three Coordinating Committee members, who were meeting at the house of Aristide Sokambi. They had gathered to organize a demonstration planned for 20 September. Police also arrested Timothee Malendoma who expressed sympathy with the Committee. The next month thousands of teachers and health workers went on strike for a pay raise. Another source states that they also demanded a multi-party governmental reform. The government refused to acknowledge the demands, because they claimed that the negotiation had not followed legal process. Kolingba refused the payrise, and the strike ended on 4 December. http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/war/car-6.htm Question 11 The president had wide powers, and the executive branch of government predominated over all legislative and judicial branches, effectively rendering the judiciary weak and strictly controlled. Kalck, Pierre. Historical Dictionary of the Central African Republic. 3rd ed. Trans. Thomas O'Toole. Metuchen, N.J. & London: The Scarecrow Press, 2004. Question 13 There was minimal information on the rights of minority groups, however it can be ascertained from the nature of Kolingba's rule that minimal attention was given to such priorities. Many of the questions were very difficult to answer and to garner information on, given there is little information on the CAR during this time, and also presumably because Africa has faced so much political turmoil Kolingba was probably pale in comparison. Some of my answers were educated guesses, hence my lack of academic justification. Some of the questions were also relatively similar or the same but just phrased differently.

Justification: When I was researching Ghana, I was given the year 2005 so I decided to conduct my research for the years 2004 through till 2008 as this was the two closest election years to my given date. The 2004 election was won by the incumbent President from the NPP party, with a register voter amount of 10,354,970 in a country of roughly 20.8 million shows a great deal of suffrage as you can expect a large portion of that public to be under 18, although not all over 18s would be registered. That's why I marker Suffrage the way I did because a similar percentage or registered voters was mirrored in the 2008 election. The incumbent government won by roughly 8% and continued to govern until the next election. In 2008 the election results saw the incumbent president step down already serving two terms then lose the election and successful hand over power to the opposition NDC party. This shows the opposition worked in Ghana as they were able to successfully able to have a transition of power between two opposing governments while remaining a stable country. Using the Interparlimentary Union website (IPU.org) I was able to discover this information as well as filling in the gaps by using the BBC reports covering the 2004 and 2008 elections in Ghana. They are a democratic government which is shown by the way the election process is conducted. Even in 2008 when there was a victory by a margin or less than 1%, both sides appealed to the courts claiming the other side in election fraud, with a fair judicial system at a high level they were able to determine neither side had committed fraud and the incumbent government accepted the result and allowed a change in the governing body. The freedom of the press is very real within Ghana, much like the freedom of expression and other civil liberties they're protected within the law. But there was still attempts to stifle the freedom of expression within the media. As shown on the Freedom house website, there has been examples of MPs looking to sue the press for libel, as well as the Ghana Broadcasting Corporation deciding to fire 4 journalists for their work in a Ghana airways news article. This brought forward questions as to the legitimacy of their freedom of press, something is also challenged by the lack of money invested in it, meaning there is often cases of corruption amongst the integrity of the journalist's stories. Even with low corruption rates (ranking 64th in 2012 on the Transparency international Corruption Perceptions index) they show low levels of corruption especially with business partnerships. This is prominent with government officials asking for favours so that they can conduct their business within Ghana. The governments from 2004 onwards have sought to fight against corruption like this, seeing some success but Ghana still experiences corrupt government employees. The final part of the investigation was on the civil liberties of Ghanaians. They have all their full rights protected in their law, with a freedom house ranking of 2 in both civil liberties and political freedom. The reason that they can be considered as only a 2 is because despite having equal representation under the law, they still have significant discrimination, especially against women in rural regions. With access to education and employment significantly lower in these regions, it can't be considered an equally free country despite the best intentions to uphold the law by the government.

Justification: Are there free and fair elections for this state's executive and legislature? Albeit currently dominated by two major political parties (The Indian National Congress (INC) and the incumbent Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) ), many minor parties have emerged as coalition parties, particularly since 1996. This is due to strong regional parties becoming popular within their respective regions. Currently, the 2014 incumbent government led by the BJP needed the support of the National Democratic Alliance to obtain a simple majority and assume power. In the 2014 election the results were as follows for the six leading parties (in percentage of votes) : BJP -31%, INC - 19.31%, All India Anna Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam -3.27%, All India Trinamool Congress -3.84%, Shiv Sena -1.85%, Biju Janata Dal -1.71%. Sources ( http://eciresults.ap.nic.in/, http://www.ipu.org/pdf/publications/free&fair06-e.pdf ) 'The Article 326 of the Indian Constitution grants universal adult suffrage, according to which, every adult citizen is entitled to cast his/her vote in all state elections unless that citizen is 'convicted of certain criminal offences' or 'deemed unsound of mind.' As per this concept, the right to vote is not restricted by caste, race, sex, religion or financial status.' ( http://www.elections.in/political-corner/universal-adult-suffrage/ ) Since 1999 there has been four elections (elections are held every five years) and through this time, the BJP and INC have each served two terms. It is very possible for the Indian Government to change hands due to strong opposition. ( http://eci.nic.in/eci_main1/statistical_report.aspx ) It is possible for anyone to create a political party or run for political power in india. All that is required is the payment of ten thousand rupees and the completion of an application form. ( http://eci.nic.in/eci_main1/RegisterationPoliticalParties.aspx ) Although the Indian Constitution guarantees freedom of speech, there are exceptions and anything that 'threatens the unity, integrity, defence, security or sovereignty of India, friendly relations with foreign states or public order' will be subject to censorship. (http://www.telegraphindia.com/1111207/jsp/nation/story_14848886.jsp#.VV6emfmqqko) However, India was ranked 136 th in the world within their Press freedom Index ( https://index.rsf.org/#!/index-details/IND ) and were described as 'Partly Free' by Freedom House. There are laws in place that deliberately restrict what the media can report on: 'The sedition law, formally Section 124A of the 1860 penal code, outlaws expression that can cause 'hatred or contempt, or excites or attempts to excite disaffection' toward the government. The 1923 Official Secrets Act provides authorities with the right to censor security-related articles and prosecute members of the press. ' ( https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2014/india#.VV6jLvmqqkp ) The Rule of Law applies to the Indian Government. In India, all are subject to the same treatment under their laws and the government nor its officials and servants are immune or exempt from this. 'The Judiciary, under the Rule of Law system, like the system in India, is empowered to apply the same law to a government official, as is the case with a private citizen. The Rule of Law being the basis of treatment of private and official citizens in India, the equality of legal personalities of all citizens is an important basis of dispensing justice in India' . (Hoveyda, A. (2011) . Indian Government And Politics. Pearson Education India.) Many fundamental human rights such as freedom of speech, mobility and expression are upheld in India however, India struggles to quash many violations such as torture, discrimination against the LGBT community and women and continuing to censor media. It is hard to give this question one of the four choices as it does not fit neatly in any. I felt that number two was the best as rights are generally upheld however I feel that there is more than just 'Minor' suppression of rights. This belief is perpetuated when events such as the criminalisation of homosexuality was reinstated in 2013. The Indian government perpetuates how imperative it is for the judiciary to be an independent organ of the justice system. 'The Constitution of India secures justice to all its citizens apart from securing liberty, equality, and promoting fraternity. Indian democracy the Supreme Court plays important role of safe­guarding the fundamental rights of citizens which includes provid­ing fair justice also. Justice which is the soul of a democratic society must be administered without fear or favor. Integrity, Impartiality and Intelligence are some of the important characteristics of the in dependent judiciary in a democratic setup. ' ( http://www.preservearticles.com/201103034384/essay-on-indian-judiciary-system.html ) . Private and official citizens are able to be judged in a court of justice without fear of corruption or political influence. Within the Indian Government, there ae three separate branches which are used to as checks and balances against the powerful central government. Similar to many other ex colonies, it is set up in a manner similar to the United Kingdom, New Zealand and Australia. There is an Executive branch which is led by the president, a legislative branch and a judicial branch. Each acts to ensure that that each branch is acting in a way that is in accordance to their constitution and in a way that assures a democratic process. ( http://www.india-in-your-home.com/india-government.html ) It is interesting as India boasts that 'The Indian Constitution ensures 'justice, social, economic and political' to all citizens. ' However, the LGBT community suffers great discrimination as there are no legal protections for their employment or things such as hate speech. There are also many articles within their constitution that aim to protect minorities however, there has been a lot of religious and gender specific aggression that has not been dealt with appropriately by the Indian government. It is my educated guess that this is more for show rather than practice. Corruption appears to be rife throughout the Indian Government, with bribery and extortion being a common practice within institutions such as the police force. 'Under the PCA, bribery is punishable by a fine and up to five years imprisonment. But many analysts believe India's sprawling bureaucracy and weak institutions-the police and judiciary were ranked as the second and third most corrupt institutions in India, respectively, after political parties-have thwarted convictions, and arguably increased incentives for bribery. In recent years, graft pervaded society from small-scale 'harassment bribes' (payments for essential social services) to scandals on a national level. At least 42 percent of young Indians have paid a bribe, according to a 2012 Hindustan survey. ' ( http://www.cfr.org/corruption-and-bribery/governance-india-corruption/p31823 ) As said before, corruption is rife and has been concentrated in many acts, particularly bribery.

Justification: Egypt from 1990 to 2011 was a debately corrupt led Government. Honsi Mubarak became President in 1981, following assassination of the previous President, and continued to rule up until 2011, following the Egyption Revolution. International non-governmental organizations (E.g. Amnesty International) repeatedly criticized his administration's human rights stats. However, Egypt was continued to be called a 'Republic'. There was substantial and accurate concerns regaring political censorship, police brutality, arbitrary detention, torture and heavy restrictions towards freedoms of speech, association and assembly. According to Freedom House, Egypt's 2004 score for 'freedom' was a 6 out a rating of 1 = best 7 = worst. Egypt's score of civil liberties was also a 6, and so was the political rights of the country. Looking specifically at the time period between 1990 to 2011, Egypt was a heavily controlled and corrupt Government, seen from the world outside. Political reform was extremly difficuly during this period. Previous to 2005, opposition candidates were not allowed to run for Presidency, extremely limiting change to the political society. The elections were exclusively held for the rich and politically influenced. Eqypt has an Emergency Law, and from 1967 has continued to exist. This Emergency Law allows police and their power to be much more than previously. Constitutional rights were suspended and censorship (of all kinds) was legalized. This consequenetly meant that non-governmental political activity such as street demonstrations, or non-approved political gorups or organisations. The numbers of people arrested over this law is up to 17,000, and political prisioners of the country run as high as 30,000. Critisism of the President in media could be punishable by fines or prison sentences. Journalists faced harrassment, and media platforms felt heavily influenced and pressured to write certain information over other. Egypt has universal sufferage. During this period (1990 to 2011) there was little opposition - with the regime winning elections with 88%+ every time, both Presidential and legislature elections. In 2011 ABC reported the personal wealth of Hosni Mubarak and his family was in excess of $70 million funded by bribery and corruption. Only Mubarak and his immediate family were given the keys of power and influence at the top of the Egyptian. Freedom of the press is limited - the government owns and operates all television stations and newspapers. Certain radio stations are private but must report to the government regime in order to receive their broadcasting liscences. A station that offered political commentary Dream TV - the government shut down the station in October due to objection by government officials. All independent rights are heavily suppressed - any political gathering, meeting or rallies must achieve government approval beforehand via the Minister ofthe Interior. Mosques are the most common site for Egyptian muslims to meet en mass, and the government controls all Mosques. Sermons are dictated and monitored by the state.

Justification: I examined the period of Angolan history from 1992-2002. I chose this period because it was the second Angolan civil war, between the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA) and the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola (UNITA) . This caused hundreds of thousands of deaths and many displaced persons. I considered extending the research period out to 1975, when Angola gained independence and the first civil war started, but the fact that the two remain separate in academic literature led me to the conclusion that focus on the second would provide more cohesive data. The source I used for this was ' Angola: Second civil war (1992-2002) ' by EISA. When determining if Angola had free and fair elections, I used the source 'Angola: 1992 Election Results and Aftermath'as well as ' Angola: Second civil war (1992-2002) ', both by EISA. Angola only had one election in the period examined, in 1992. This election was supervised by the United Nations Angola Verification Mission, and was deemed to be free and fair by the international community. There were instances of irregularities, but the mission ascribed these to the inexperience of the electoral system more than any perversion of figures by state officials. In the 1992 election there was 92% voter turnout, as shown in ' Angola: Second civil war (1992-2002) '. This is a good indicator that there is universal suffrage in the country. In the 1992 election, there was significant opposition to the winning party, MPLA, in the form of UNITA. In the presidential election, leaders respectively gained 49.7% and 40% of the vote, whilst in the parliamentary election the numbers were 54% and 34%. As the elections were free and fair, it can be reasonably assumed that the opposition to the MPLA was very strong and had a good chance of winning power through election. This information came from 'Angola: 1992 Election Results and Aftermath'. I struggled to find information on how many people have access to political power. From what I could find out, to rise to power in this period meant falling in with either MPLA or UNITA. The two parties appointed their own leaders, who had historical ties to the party. The fact that the two figures of Jonas Savimbi and José dos Santos dominated the two parties for the entire period, and the death of Savimbi ended the civil war makes it difficult to ascertain how power moved around, as it did not move at all. However, the ability of many parties and people to contest the 1992 election, despite having very mediocre success compared to the two major parties, indicates that whilst unlikely to result in a power shift, other people could at least contest in elections. This information came from 'Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola'and 'UNITA'by Britannica, as well as 'Angola: 1992 Election Results and Aftermath'. Angola did have some independent media, but most of it was state owned. However, there were heavy controls over how independent media operated. Defamation cases would be brought against those criticising people in power, coverage of the civil war was outlawed, and many newspapers began self-censorship to avoid lawsuits. This information came from 'Jose Eduardo dos Santos: Angola's shy president'by Louise Redvers of BBC. Concerning rule of law, I was torn on whether to give Angola 1 or 2 points. In the constitution, any member of the government can be prosecuted, even the president provided it is after his term has ended. However, severe problems with the justice system, such as a lack of lawyers and low access to the courts means this has little effect in practice, and crimes from bribery to rape go unpunished in government forces. This information came from the KAF Democracy Report 2006 and the 1999 Freedom House entry for Angola. There is a lack of fundamental human rights in Angola. From controls on freedom of the press, limitations on freedom of association, a lack of access to the courts, forceful recruitment of minors into the army and many other breaches, Angola has a poor record on this front. Thin information came from Freedom house and the KAF report. On the issue of independent judiciaries, officially the courts were independent during the second civil war. However, a lack of adequate pay for judges, as well as very limited access to courts meant that in reality this system was actually susceptible to corruption. This information is in the KAF report. During the civil war there was no system by which to hold the government accountable. There were no government bodies, such as an upper house, to check power, and decision making was often left solely to the president. Courts officially were able to prosecute government -however, access to courts, lawyers, and funding for such cases was never a real possibility for citizens. In the period following the civil war, this problem was addressed with an ombudsman being appointed, but before this there was no way to hold the governing regime accountable. This is from the KAF report. I struggled to determine how minority groups were treated during the civil war. However 'Angola Overview'by World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples helped me. The government made efforts to include all ethnic groups in the army, and had radio broadcasts in all major languages. However, disparity arising from oil and diamond trade labour conditions meant that many ethnic groups in the central regions of the country suffered during the civil war. In fact, a lack of human rights and due process was an affliction of the entire country. So in reality, minority groups were not treated well in Angola. Almost no groups were. I am confident in my answers, as the evidence I have seen is all corrobatory, proving the claims I make. Corruption in Angola is an interesting question. During 1997-2001, $1.7 billion US went missing from state accounts. There is evidence of patronage and clientelism, supplemented by thinly veiled bribes to companies owned by government officials. President dos Santos would regularly roate officals, putting his own supporters into power. Through the military, war crimes and bribery were rife during the civil war. There were many extra-judicial executions as well. Blood diamond trade and corrupt influence over the oil industry are also rife. All of this led to the conclusion that Angola is an extremely corrupt state. Information on this came from 'Angola's Political and Economic Development'by Council for Foreign Relations, 'Angola country profile -Overview'by BBC and the KAF report.
