Justification: Regime Period My reference year to study is 2003, and the period I chose as my regime parameter in Chile is from 1990-2004, which encompasses a period of minimal significant political change, in-between Pinochet's Dictatorship, and fully functioning democracy. A policy paper published by the Center for Strategic and International Studies titled 'Road to Development' focuses on the period between 1990-2005 as a period in between regimes, which reinforces my reasoning. 1990, is what some determine the completion of Chile's transition to democracy, marked by the election of Christian Democrat Patricio Aylwin in December 1989. Prior to this, Augusto Pinochet ruled under a military dictatorship from 1973. Pinochet introduced a new constitution in 1980 in order to initiate a democratic transition, in which he expected to be reelected. I have selected 2004 as my end date, due to the 50 extensive Constitution reforms conducted by President Ricardo Lagos in 2005, which saw to a removal from the Senate of 9 appointed seats, 4 representatives of the armed forces and also lifetime positions for former presidents, as well as reducing the presidential term (from 6 years down to 4) . Lagos controversially classified 2005 as marking Chile's full transition to democracy. I can understand his reasoning, as the period prior to this represents most elements of a stable democratic regime; however aspects of Pinochet's 1980 constitution and the nature of the democracy he intended left remnants of his brutal dictatorship yet to be reformed. Political Rights As introduced in Pinochet's 1980 constitution, Chile has a binomial electoral system. Under this system, a candidate needs a 50% majority +1 to avoid a run off election. Two candidates are elected in each district, which results in an over-representation of the second majority list. This excludes the voice of minority parties, as it makes it harder for one bloc to get the upper hand. In 'Road to Development' Arturo Valenzuela claims this system to be flawed democracy, as it doesn't singly elect the candidate with the most votes. This system does grant Universal Suffrage; men and women aged 18 and over were eligible to vote. However, due to major inequality issues, 41% of the population did not partake in elections prior to 2005. A 2004 National socio-economic survey suggested the presence of an overall income gap of 33%. The Road to Development report suggested this means women cannot fully participate in the system. Accountability While Chile technically had an independent and reformed judiciary that promoted the rule of law, over this period, the Chilean government struggled to alter the existing rules in the Code of Military Justice in order to reform its judicial branch. The constitution meant that 10 of 17 Supreme Court Judges were those appointed during Pinochet's regime; which made actually conducting reforms highly difficult. Faced with a history of unprosecuted war crimes, the Truth and Reconciliation Commission was introduced to address this in 1990, and its resultant report was released in February 1991 which identified 3,428 cases of disappearance. In order to address this, the report recommended the strengthening of civilian authority in Chile's society and judiciary system. The Military Code gave military tribunals jurisdiction over crimes committed by military personnel; basically meaning the judge and victim for war crimes under Pinochet's rule was one in the same. Pinochet was eventually arrested, under Lagos, however he died before conviction; his immunity through the constitution made the prosecution very difficult. There was a continual struggle with the civil-military divide. However, despite this, the Congress and Executive worked together through a network of linkages to track the government agenda through ministries and committees in congress, in order to bring light to these issues and deal with them accordingly. Civil Liberties The 1980 constitution encompassed a greater protection of Human Rights, and therefore these were generally upheld. However, discrepancies were reported in regard to Freedom of Assembly and Freedom of Speech. While the Government often permitted protests, there were frequent cases reporting police brutality and management. Freedom House's 1998 Report referred to a case where the police force dealt with protesters via the use of water cannons and tear gas in order to forcibly detain protestors. Human rights violations were reported over this period in regard to land ownership of minority groups. Native American groups, particularly the Mapuchas were vocal about their rights to ancestral lands. This was something that Alywin and Lagos Administrations Addressed; the Indigenous Law was promulgated in 1993, Aylwin developed a Special Commission of Indigenous People, however this didn't bring about any significant changes to accommodate the needs of minorities. Freedom of Speech and Expression also appeared be considerably suppressed in regard to the press. Technically speaking, there was independent media present during this time, however the ownership of media companies was highly concentrated; 95% of all print media was owned by two companies, of which both were the sole recipients of government subsidies; indicating media from these companies did not have a broad research base, and government subsidiaries provide an incentive to produce content to their liking. The press was an area that received very little reform following 1990, and according to an article released by Reporters Without Borders, there has never been a legal framework to ensure a fair distribution of frequencies among different types of broadcast media. Consequently, the State Security Law and 1984 Anti-Terrorist Laws had not been amended from Pinochet's 1980 constitution, and were frequently reported to be used against journalists who investigated the dictatorship. A press law reform was implemented in 2001, which did remove certain provisions on Article 6b of the State Security Law, however other amendments were made, such as the restriction of a journalist's right to report on a person's private life; prosecution for this act could now take place under the Penal Code, which continued to occur. Between 1995-2005, a stud by the Office of Special Rapporteur for freedom of expression on murder of journalists and media workers between 1995-2005 concluded that Chile had tighter press restrictions than any other Latin American country, apart from Cuba (The Economist, 'Chile Unfree' ) . In regard to Corruption as the private misuse of public resources, there were very limited reports of corruption amongst the top governing elite from what I could research across this period. The 'Road to Development 'panelists underscored the importance of transparency and good governance made the state effective between 1990-2005. Transparency international ranked Chile to be the least corrupt country in Latin America in 2003. However, Freedom House identified corruption amongst lower ranked officials to be a relatively common occurrence. In 2003, police peddling, insider trading and a report of kickbacks resulted in the Head of the Central Bank and two cabinet members leaving their job. Dozens of lower-ranked officials and several members of congress from the ruling coalition were indicted in this particular incidence. Research Evaluation In regard to research, I found it quite difficult to find specific details and information, especially in regard to question 12, whereby I had to make somewhat of an educated guess based on the general knowledge I had gained about the regime. I found some of my research didn't fit entirely with the options given, considering the complications Pinochet's Constitution had left on some aspects of the regime, which was not a direction followed by Governments after 1990 (in regard to question 11 in particular) . I found the Freedom House website to be very useful as a starting point for my research as it provided a broad overview concerning most issues relevant to my research, broken down by year. The only issue I encountered was their research didn't extend earlier than 1998. Another source of particular value was a policy paper published by the Center for Strategic and International Studies titled 'Road to Development', which helped me to identify my regime period of study. This is a compilation of presentations from different political science and economic experts identifying elements of government that helped and hindered development leading up to 2005. Also, I found an article titled 'The Dirty Legal War- Human Rights and the Rule of Law in Chile from the Tulsa Journal of Comparative and International Law to be particularly helpful as it identified possible issues associated with the judiciary in regard to the military. I did find a discrepancy of information between Freedom House and an article published in the Economist in 2001 on Free Speech; Freedom house stating it to be widely free, while the economist article claimed it to have tighter legal restrictions than any other Latin American country in regard to the press, which indicates perhaps Freedom House's broad brush approach to issues isn't the most accurate research base. Here is my full list of references used to formulate the above summaries on political rights and civil liberties in Chile from1990-2004: 'Road To Development' by Peter DeShazo http://csis.org/files/media/csis/pubs/pp_0508deshazo.pdf http://www.wider.unu.edu/publications/working-papers/research-papers/2006/en_GB/rp2006-13/ Freedom House Reports, 1998-2004 https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2006/chile#.VV0GGGSeDGc 'The Dirty Legal War -Human Rights and the Rule of Law in Chile by Edward C Snyder. 1995, Tulsa Journal of Comparative and International Law https://cyber.law.harvard.edu/evidence99/pinochet/HistoryGeneralArticle.htm - 'Chile Speech Unfree' . 2001 http://www.economist.com/node/569338 - unfree speech 'Freedom of Expression in Latin America' Catalina Marino and Michael Camilleri, 2011, ReVista Harvard Review of Latin America. http://revista.drclas.harvard.edu/book/freedom-expression-latin-america Published Truth Commission Report 1990 http://www.usip.org/publications/truth-commission-chile-90 -

Justification: The 2007 Kenyan Presidential election was largely influenced by the stealing of votes. However it is alleged that this occurred from both parties. This has lead to the 2007 election being labeled as impossible to tell who actually won the presidential election -the incumbent Mwai Kibaki or opposition Raila Odinga. Radiographer Julius Melli witnessed the tallying of votes in the Maragua District said: 'both sides stole votes, but Kibaki stole more, and they stole it inside the tallying centre.' Sources: www.theage.com.au/news/world/kenyans-riot-after-rigged-election uk.reuters.com/article/2008/09/18/uk-kenya-election-idUKLI38786120080918 www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/kibaki-stole-kenyan-election-through-voterigging-and-fraud www.mcclatchydc/2008/01/31/25830/how-kenyas-election-was-rigged.html 5. The CIA World Factbook labels suffrage as universal in Kenya. Source: www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ke.html 7. The access to political power in Kenya in the years 2007-2010 was severely hampered by the incumbent government led by Kibaki. After being elected in 2002 the National Rainbow Coalition (NARC) government attempted to make reforms trying to stop corruption and setting up independent human rights agencies. However infighting between different factions over power collapsed the coalition and caused the reforms to be abandoned. They began securing power for the leaders. Ethnic elites close to Kibaki abandoned the reforms. The political environment was then manipulated to secure power, they changed the constitutional review process and preferred a constitution that 'favoured their desire to secure a hold on power.' Source: Kenya: Democracy and Political Participation, Karuti Kanyinga, 2014. www.refworld.org/pdfid/53aa8a954.pdf 8. Throughout 2006-2010 the state in Kenya does little to suppress the media. However there is a degree of self censorship by the media. Ron Singer writes 'press suppression and violence against journalists represent fairly isolated events in recent Kenyan history.' Singer continues that the main limitations in Kenyan media come from corruption and an ethnic bias towards Kikuyu. Kikuyu being the largest ethnic group in Kenya in 2009 with over 6,622,576 or 16.9% of the population. President Mwai Kibaki is also an ethnic Kikuyu. Source: www.opendemocracy.net/ron-singer/how-free-is-free-press-in-kenya 9. The rule of law is present in Kenya. However as Karuti Kanyinga writes: 'the culture of the rule of law itself is generally weak.' Source: Kenya: Democracy and Political Participation, Karuti Kanyinga, 2014. www.refworld.org/pdfid/53aa8a954.pdf 10. Human Rights in Kenya are in place via the constitution however the government sometimes represses these rights. In terms of Freedom of Assembly, The US Department of State 2009 report on Kenya claims that 'the constitution and law provide for freedom of assembly, but the government frequently restricted this right in practice. Organizers must notify local police in advance of public meetings.' Similarly Freedom of Association is monitored by authorities. The Kenyan societies act states 'Every society which is not a registered society or an exempted society is an unlawful society.' Therefore in the time period, association and assembly were allowed but were monitored. Source: www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/af/135959.htm www.kenyalaw.org:8181/exist/rest//db/kenyalex/Kenya/Legislation/English/Acts and Regulations/S/SocietiesAct 11. In 2006-2010 the Kenyan judiciary was recognized as not being impartial or fair. Edwin Odhiambo writes: 'Courts in Kenya do not have a reputation of fairness or independence.' He continues that 'courts in Kenya cannot discharge their mandates impartially and independently. Finally he quotes the Fund for Peace in a 2008 report stating that the judiciary in Kenya was 'weak' . Source: The role of the Judiciary in Promotion of free and Fair Elections, Edwin Odhiambo Abuya. www.juridicas.unam.mx/wccl/ponencias/1/1.pdf 13. As mentioned previously, there is ethnic tension in Kenya. The Kikuyu ethnicity is the largest ethnic group and the parliament leading into the 2007 election had a Kikuyu elite.

Justification: Question 4: Following a decade of a military dictatorship, multi-party presidential elections were held in Guinea for the first time in 1993. Lansana Conté, who had been leader of the military dictatorship, was elected president with 51.7% of the vote. However, his win was tarnished by claims of tampering by his opponents and concerns over a general lack of government transparency. These claims were strengthened by the Supreme Court's invalidation of the votes in the Kankan and Siguiri prefectures, two regions were Conté had won over 90% of the vote. During the next presidential election in 1998, Conté's period of authoritarian rule continued as he again won the election with 56.1% of the vote. Although there were fewer concerns regarding fraud than the 1993 result, many opponents and outsiders were still apprehensive over the legitimacy of the result. Two days after the 1998 presidential elections Alpha Condé, a prominent political opponent of Conté and future president, was arrested for attempting to illegally leave Guinea. Conté's last election before his death in 2008 was in 2003 and was the most notably unfair of Guinea's presidential elections. The election was boycotted by Conté's main rivals over concerns of voter manipulation, resulting in a landslide victory for Conté with 95.6% of the vote. Voter turnout was estimated by the opposition party to be as low as 15%, and shortly after the election an opposition spokesman was arrested for criticising Conté's win in a radio interview. This research shows that while Guinea underwent a formal constitutional change in 1990 in an attempt to legitimise a democratic government, there were still major concerns regarding the fairness, transparency, and legitimacy of the election results. Elections were often marred by occasional violence, political protests, and the intermittent arrests of political dissidents. For this reason, I have stated that while there are indeed elections for the executive and legislature of Guinea, between 1993 and 2007 there was a very low likelihood of a change in government. Question 5: According to the CIA World Factbook, Guinea has universal suffrage for citizens over 18 years of age, which is guaranteed in the Article 2 of the 1990 Constitution. However, according to a Freedom House report, there are many societal practices that discriminate against women and constitutionally protected rights are often unrealised. Political participation is also divided primarily among ethnic groups. However, there is little evidence to suggest that suffrage is actively denied to people based on gender or ethnicity. Question 6: Opposition parties are allowed in law and several exist. However, during this period there was a major lack of credible opposition, and Conté was strongly backed by governmental institutions and media. Combined with this was a significant neglect of the constitution and rule of law as many of Conté's political opponents were harassed and even arrested. This clearly shows that while political opposition was allowed to exist in Guinea during this period, there were significant barriers stemming from the incumbent to allow a change in regime. Question 7: According to Article 10 of the 1990 Constitution 'All citizens have the right to form associations and societies to collectively exercise their rights and their political, economic, social or cultural activities.' Despite this, power was centred in the hands of Conté and his small collection of followers, and access to such power is strongly limited by corruption, nepotism and ethnic biases. Question 8: A 1998 Freedom House analysis of Guinea's freedom of the press shows that there were many significant barriers to a free media. All broadcasting, including the country's only newspaper, was state-owned and offered little criticism of government policy. The government was permitted under various laws to censor and supress speech critical of the president, or speech that 'disturbs the peace' . The small amount of independent media that existed and offered any dissention was routinely harassed by the government and was heavily censored. The political persecution of dissenting media, combined with extensive state control over the major media outlets resulted in the nearly complete absence of a free press to act as a check on power. Question 9: President Conté retained a large amount of political power and was able to use his influence to subvert the rule of law as well as retaining decree power that could completely undermine the parliamentary process. The rule of law was routinely breached to harass and actively persecute political opponents. A State Security Court was established in 1997, which was permitted to operate in secret with verdicts that were not allowed to be repealed. Arbitrary arrests were common and prisoners were often subjected to torture and poor treatment by authorities. Question 10: An array of civil liberties including the freedom of assembly and association, freedom of speech and the freedom of mobility were outlined in the Guinean Constitution. However, in practice these civil liberties were rarely respected by the government, which passed laws allowing for the suppression of speech, and also giving powers the ability to ban any assembly that threatened 'national unity' . Question 11: While by law the judiciary is independent, in reality the judicial system is plagued by extensive corruption, nepotism, and political interference. This judiciary was considerably underfunded and suffered from a lack of resources and trained experts. Question 12: The only supposed check on the powers of the executive came from the judicial branch, which under law was nominally independent. However, this judiciary was subject to a significant amount of political interference. The primary check on government power came in the form of elections, however as mentioned earlier these were often highly corrupt and subject to fraud and voter suppression. Question 13: Discrimination towards minorities was forbidden in the constitution, yet in reality there was active social discrimination towards minority groups, in particular women. A 2003 report by the Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labour revealed that at one local hospital more than 20% of female patients were there as a result of sexual violence. Despite its illegality, a Demographic and Health survey determined that 96% of women had been subjected to female genital mutilation. Combined with this, Guinea had and continues to have no legal protections for homosexuals and homosexuality was actively punished by law. Ethnic tensions were substantial, and during elections racial rhetoric featured prominently, in some cases even resulting in violence. Question 14: I am confident in the sources of my research and my ability to answer the questions wholly and accurately. Freedom House provided a wide range of years of reports that I was able to use to collect information from over the time period. Question 15: According to Transparency International, Guinea is currently in the bottom 8 th percentile for control of corruption and is ranked 145/175 on the Corruption Perceptions Index. During the regime of Lansana Conté, high levels of corruption were a fixture of government activity. Guinea's justice system during this time was notoriously corrupt and suffered from a complete lack of independence between the government and the judiciary. Public funds were often used in the persecution and arbitrary arrests of Conté's political opponents. This level of corruption is not just limited to the highest levels of the executive branch and public officials often took bribes in exchange for various public services including water, electricity and health care. An investigation by the FBI also determined that government employees had taken bribes in exchange for the mining rights to Simandou, an extremely rich undeveloped mineral deposit. Question 16: The most common instances of corruption during this period were the complete lack of transparency around the government's use of public resources and large amounts of bribe-taking by public officials. Drug traffickers also took advantage of Guinea's poorly-run justice system and according to Guinean law professor Barry Saifoulayue traffickers often bought impunity from the law.

Justification: For the following responses, I will be outlining the research that enabled me to come to the conclusions that I did in regards to regime and corruption classification in Yemen around 2000. I will separate the explanations to each question by an indentation in the paragraph and the number of the question that it is referring to and the subsequent point that was allocated to the country for the question. I will follow this with the resources used to answer each of the questions. I chose the date range of 1998-2002 for the focus of my study because it encompassed the 1999 Yemen Presidential Election and allowed for studies about the reinstated governance of President Saleh to be formed. 4) 1 point: The reason that I chose to apply 1 point to the question of free and fair elections in Yemen is based through Freedom House Reports. As expressed by Freedom House, the Presidential elections of 1999 were not free nor fair. The party in power at the time blocked the only main opposition that was participating in the election who, it is seen, had their campaign financed by the pre-existing government. Freedom House expresses this election as 'more a referendum than an election' and I think that the lack of a credible opposition strongly points towards the elections being pre-determined. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2001/yemen#.VVvXLvmqqko >) 5) 2 points: It is expressed by Freedom House that the relevant 1999 Yemen Presidential Election was based on universal suffrage and those above the age of 18 were able to vote upon registration. This is agreed upon by Human Rights Watch, although they question the monitoring of voter registration and election monitoring. An issue in the culmination of my data for this question is that I have found no research that outlines the ability of women to vote in elections and I believe that this would be key to the changing of my point allocation. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2001/yemen#.VVvXLvmqqko & http://www.hrw.org/legacy/backgrounder/mena/yemen-bck-0201.htm ) 6) 1 point: Yemen was ruled by President Ali Abdullah Saleh at the time of focus for this study. As mentioned before, the only key opposition party to Saleh's was banned from participating in the 1999 Presidential Elections. This points to the presence of opposition but the lack of opportunity for this opposition to gain any power. An APS Review in 2002 highlighted a referendum passed in 2001 that allowed Saleh to have the power to dissolve parliament, leaving himself as the sole leader. This further expresses the notion that although opposition may exist, they have little potential to gain power because Saleh is also willing to restrict the gaining of power to the people below him in his own government. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2001/yemen#.VVvXLvmqqko & http://go.galegroup.com/ps/retrieve.do?sgHitCountType=None&sort=RELEVANCE&docType=Article&prodId=AONE&tabID=T004&searchId=R2&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&searchType=AdvancedSearchForm&contentSegment=&currentPosition=1&searchResultsType=SingleTab&inPS=true&userGroupName=vuw&docId=GALE%7CA89370799&contentSet=GALE%7CA89370799 ) 7) 1 point: Both Freedom House Reports and APS Reviews on Yemen point to the members of government being chosen by a small group of leaders, notably the President. Freedom House states that the ability of citizens to change the government is restricted by the concentration of political power in the hands of a small group. APS Reviews shows that in late 2000, Saleh enhanced his political position by replacing many civilian and military figures with younger ones that would be more loyal to him. This included his son Ahmad Ali and numerous 'half-brothers.' As is common in technocratic regimes, Saleh surrounded himself with loyal relatives that he believed could be trusted. This is why I chose to place Yemen at 1 point for this question, the information seemed unquestionable. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2001/yemen#.VVvXLvmqqko & http://go.galegroup.com/ps/retrieve.do?sgHitCountType=None&sort=RELEVANCE&docType=Article&prodId=AONE&tabID=T004&searchId=R2&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&searchType=AdvancedSearchForm&contentSegment=&currentPosition=1&searchResultsType=SingleTab&inPS=true&userGroupName=vuw&docId=GALE%7CA89370799&contentSet=GALE%7CA89370799 ) 8) 1 point: Information gathered from Freedom House and Human Rights Watch regarding Freedom of the Press in Yemen is what formed my answer to this question. If independent media is allowed and attempts to act as a check or balance on power then they are frequently arrested and tried in Court on the basis of defamation charges. Human Rights Watch highlights that in 2000, defamation suits were placed against at least seven opposition and independent papers, one opposition paper was suspended for more than a year during this. Article 103 of the Press and Publications Law 25/1990 of Yemen legislature outlaws criticism of the head of state and anything that spreads word against the Yemen state is illegal. These constraints restrict the reliability of media produced in Yemen and diminish the ability of the media to highlight the truths of what is occurring in Yemen. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2001/yemen#.VVvXLvmqqko & http://www.hrw.org/legacy/backgrounder/mena/yemen-bck-0201.htm ) 9) 0 points: I found it difficult to find information in direct relation to this question so my answer is somewhat an educated guess. This is based off information from Freedom House which quotes an Amnesty International report that stated that torture, disappearance and arbitrary detention frequently occur in Yemen. The same report states that the government has failed to investigate hundreds of disappearances since the late 1960s and although not directly stating that leaders of the state are not subject to the rule of law, I think that it is fairly clear that leaders would not be unless it was in direct insult of President Saleh. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2001/yemen#.VVvXLvmqqko ) 10) 1 point: Although technically allowed the fundamental human rights of Freedom of Assembly and Association, Freedom of Speech and Expression and Freedom of Mobility, people living in Yemen can only do so under strict observation of the government. Freedom House reports that permits are required for public gatherings which are monitored by government informers, workers unions are allowed although government personnel are often placed in influential positions within these and permission to strike must be obtained from the union federation which is controlled by the government. Independent organizations must register with the government and face harassment and arrest. Human Rights Watch documents that in May 2000, six activists were charged with 'disrupting public order by calling a demonstration and dispersing material critical of Yemeni unity.' The extent of the control is widespread but tries to hide under the guise of conforming to human rights. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2001/yemen#.VVvXLvmqqko & http://www.hrw.org/legacy/backgrounder/mena/yemen-bck-0201.htm ) 11) 0 points: Freedom House clearly states that the Yemen judiciary is not independent and judges are frequently poorly trained and susceptible to bribery and government influence. The government is reluctant to carry out sentences and courts are governed by Sharia in which there are no jury trials. The lack of jury trials and the susceptibility of judges to be influenced by the government points to the immense lack of an independent or free judiciary. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2001/yemen#.VVvXLvmqqko ) 12) 0 points: The power of the government in Yemen rests in the authority of the president who has the authority to rule by decree and override decisions put forward by parliament. As stated previously, an APS review on Yemen in 2002 shows that a constitutional amendment has given the president the ability to dissolve parliament without any other consent. This obviously negates the accountability of the government as the president can override anything put towards parliament. It seems to me that the existence of a parliament in Yemen is an attempt to promote and conform to 'democratic ideals'but with the overriding capabilities of the president, it is misinformed. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2001/yemen#.VVvXLvmqqko & http://go.galegroup.com/ps/retrieve.do?sgHitCountType=None&sort=RELEVANCE&docType=Article&prodId=AONE&tabID=T004&searchId=R2&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&searchType=AdvancedSearchForm&contentSegment=&currentPosition=1&searchResultsType=SingleTab&inPS=true&userGroupName=vuw&docId=GALE%7CA89370799&contentSet=GALE%7CA89370799 ) 13) 0 points: It is reported by Freedom House that minority groups are not held equal with the majority of society in Yemen. Followers of religions other than Islam (which makes up about 99% of the country) are allowed to worship freely but are unable to try and convert others to their religions nor are they able to construct new places of worship without permits. Women also face harsh restrictions and discrimination. Those convicted of 'moral offenses' can be detained for indefinite periods under the penal code and 'honour killings' still take place, although the number of such cannot be determined for lack of investigation or reports. These examples point to the government being the institution that restricts minorities the most and are the ones that enforce (either by submission or direct action) this discrimination. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2001/yemen#.VVvXLvmqqko ) 15) 0 points: My response to this question was a relatively educated guess and I found it difficult to find resources pointing to the private misuse of public resources in Yemen although I'm fairly certain that it would have occurred. The overriding power of President Saleh and those he surrounds himself with and the continued lack of a good standard of living for the majority living in Yemen points towards corruption through the redistribution of public resources towards private benefit. 16) Bribe-taking by public officials: Middle East News Online highlighted in an article in 2002 that favouritism plays a key role in recruitment of government officials and bribes and corruption remain a major obstacle for the effectiveness of the government. Special privileges granted to politically-connected people: An APS Review on Yemen in 2002 shows that companies such as Hunt, Nexen and TotalFinaElf who had the ability to get in direct contact with President Saleh were much more successful than others. (Reference: http://go.galegroup.com/ps/retrieve.do?sgHitCountType=None&sort=RELEVANCE&docType=Article&prodId=AONE&tabID=T004&searchId=R2&resultListType=RESULT_LIST&searchType=AdvancedSearchForm&contentSegment=&currentPosition=1&searchResultsType=SingleTab&inPS=true&userGroupName=vuw&docId=GALE%7CA89370799&contentSet=GALE%7CA89370799 )

Justification: Q2. & Q3. The timeframe chosen (1991-1999) represents the period of democratic rule under Boris Yeltsin in his title of the first President of the Russian Federation. Q4. As Yeltsin was elected through democratic election as an establishment of Russia's first democracy, and dissolution of the Soviet Union, this was the first example of a free and fair election in the years of 1991-1999. An example of a rapid legislature change was Yeltsin's rise to power, going from a communist state to a democratically functioning country. In the 1996 election, with the growing popularity of the Communist Party, the legislature and executive could very easily have been dramatically converted back to Soviet-style policy, government, and way of living. -Yeltsin's Russia and the West . Andrew Felkay, 2002. USA: Praeger Publishers Q5. Universal suffrage was first established in Russia under Soviet rule in 1918; an update to this constitutional agreement was during the reign of Stalin in 1936, where the voting age was lowered to 18. These was no change in this constitutional right, from when it was first initiated, through the 1991-1999 period examined. -1991: Autocracy and Dictatorship . Stephen J. Lee, 2006. USA & Canada: Routledge -CIA World Factbook: Russia. https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/resources/the-world-factbook/geos/rs.html Q6. During Yeltsin's second term campaign, his popularity had widely diminished (due to failed privatisation attempts and a falling economy; speculated as more detrimental than the Great Depression of the 1930s) . A nationalist communist rival party had risen in status ('Russian Communist Party') since Yeltsin's first term, led by Gennady Zyuganov. Through massive efforts in campaigning and realistically unattainable promises made by Yeltsin, the election was exceedingly close; the former president achieving a 53% victory over his left-wing rival, claiming 40.4% of the popular vote. This is an example of an opposition party seizing the potential opportunity to overthrow the current regime. -Washington Post (Foreign Service) . Lee Hockstader, July 5 th 1996. Q7. Under the amended constitution of the Russian Federation of 1993, every citizen has the right to form political groups, and any citizen can register a party within the official governmental elections (held every four years between 1991 and 1999) . Article 36 supports this, stating: 1. Citizens of the Russian Federation shall have the right to participate in managing state affairs both directly and through their representatives; and 2. Citizens of the Russian Federation shall have the right to elect and be elected to state bodies of power and local self-government bodies, and also to participate in referenda. -Russian Ministry of Justice. minjust.ru/nko/gosreg/partii/spisok -Federation of Russia - Constitution, 1993. http://www.constitution.ru/en/10003000-02.htm Q8. Only several years prior to the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the policy of Glasnost ('Openness/Freedom of Speech' ) was introduced. This condition allowed the news media and press more opportunities to critique leaders and inform the public of governmental decisions (eventually opening the eyes of the oppressed under the communist regime, and assisting the fall of the Soviet Union) . When Yeltsin took charge of the country, he took it as his democratic duty to abolish remaining censorship laws of the media. This contributes to the overall freedom of the media, but there were several instances in which the media demonstrated 'forced loyalty'to the government. An example of these times was the compliance in not revealing the extent of Yeltsin's health issues to the public. 'Even with the media's elite bias towards Yeltsin, the flow of information and advocacy& was quite large and diverse.' -Yeltsin: A Life . Timothy Colton, 2008. USA: Basic Books -NY Times. Marilyn Berger, 2007. http://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/24/world/europe/24yeltsin.html?pagewanted=all&_r=1& Q9. By the Russian constitution, government elites are subject to law, and can be held accountable (with consequence) for misconduct. Article 93 is relevant to the consequences of major political transgression, stating: '1. The President of the Russian Federation may be impeached by the Council of the Federation only on the basis of the charges of high treason or another grave crime, advanced by the State Duma and confirmed by the conclusion of the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation, on the presence of the elements of crime in the actions of the President of the Russian Federation, and by the conclusion of the Constitution Court of the Russian Federation, confirming that the rules of advancing the charges were observed.' An example of a breach of this law was the Boris Berezovsky case; a rising oligarch during Yeltsin's reign, who was charged with embezzlement and fraud in 2000, but was accused of committing these crimes while Yeltsin still reigned. The lack of jurisdictive consequence, and his association with Yeltsin's inner circle, gave critiques room to criticise the degree of validity in the former President's regime. -Federation of Russia - Constitution, 1993. http://www.constitution.ru/en/10003000-02.htm -Boris Berezovsky -Wikipedia. -'The Yeltsin Family Took Bribes.' Philip Willan, 1999. The Guardian. http://www.theguardian.com/world/1999/aug/26/russia.philipwillan Q10. Civil liberties including freedoms of expression (Art. 29), assembly (Art. 31), education (Art. 43), free trial (Art. 19, 49), and religion (Art. 28) were all guaranteed under the 1993 amendment of the Russian constitution. There were no outstanding instances during this time period (that I came across) in which these liberties were violated by government personnel, or any cases in which a particular liberty was oppressed. -Federation of Russia - Constitution, 1993. http://www.constitution.ru/en/10003000-02.htm Q11. According to the Russian constitution, the judicial system is free and independent: Article 120 'Judges shall be independent and submit only to the Constitution and the federal law' ; and Article 124 'The courts shall be financed only from the federal budget, and the possibility of the complete and independent administration of justice shall be ensured in keeping with the requirements of federal law.' Throughout Yeltsin's reign, this was kept relatively close to the guidelines. An article of concern however, which could allow for the impact of political influence is Article 128, stating '1. The judges of the Constitution Court of the Russian Federation, the Supreme Court of the Russian Federation, the Higher Arbitration Court of the Russian Federation shall be appointed by the Council of the Federation upon the proposals by the President of the Russian Federation . 2. Judges of other federal courts shall be appointed by the President of the Russian Federation according to the rules fixed by the federal law.' With selection process of the country's judicial system so heavily reliant on the word of the president, there leaves a potentiality for this democratic function to lose credibility through potential influence and bribery/corruption. I did not find any severe examples of a democratic breach of this condition, however the room for error was allowed by fine print, and there undoubtedly would have been instances in which this concept was taken advantage of. -Federation of Russia - Constitution, 1993. http://www.constitution.ru/en/10003000-02.htm Q12. In 1994, after years of promise on the updates of human right mandates, an official ombudsman was established in the Federation of Russia. An example in which this role contributed to the success of Russian democracy under Boris Yeltsin was the counsel provided during the President's deployment of military force in Chechnya (beginning the First Chechnya War, 1994) . Without this intervention, and the pressure to call for ceasefire with Russia's neighbour, the death-toll for both Russia and Chechnya's forces would have increased dramatically, and would have lost Yeltsin even more favour from his people. -Politics Russia . Catherine Danks, 2009. USA, NYC: Pearson Education Limited. -Promoting Democracy and Human Rights in Russia . Sinikukka Saari, 2010. USA & Canada:Routledge -World Affairs Board: First Chechnya War -1994-1996. http://www.worldaffairsboard.com/showthread.php?t=1965 Q13. The rights of minorities are ensured by the Russian constitution under Article 19: '2. The State shall guarantee the equality of rights and freedoms of man and citizen, regardless of sex, race, nationality, language, origin, property and official status, place of residence, religion, convictions, membership of public associations, and also of other circumstances. All forms of limitations of human rights on social, racial, national, linguistic or religious grounds shall be banned. ' I could find no outstanding evidence that signalled any controversial/game-changing disregard for the rights of minority groups between the years of 1991-1999, such as mass oppression, genocide, or mass appeals by the Russian people for inequality. Minority groups are issued universal suffrage under the 1993 constitution also, (technically) granting political and social equality. -Federation of Russia - Constitution, 1993. http://www.constitution.ru/en/10003000-02.htm Q14. I am relatively confident with the answers provided as the information used to make conclusions on the political nature of Russia during 1991-1999, was recorded just over twenty years ago, so research material was exceedingly difficult to come by. I do signal small doubt in my answers however, as do to the rocky nature of the recently-dissembled communist country, it was hard to gauge (through media and literary accounts) the successfulness of early democratic functions, and to evaluate their potential likelihood to succeed in such a broken country. Q15. & Q16. Boris Yeltsin's regime was relatively sparse of corruption, but there are certain instances when government behaviour communicated otherwise. The rise of the oligarchs in Yeltsin's Russia was considered an example of corruption, where a small number of wealthy elites (some members of Yeltsin's inner circle, such as the infamous Boris Berezorsky) took advantage of the privatisation scheme projected by the President during 1992-1994, and made millions through the exploitation of the 'voucher privatisation' system; many accredited this new accumulation of wealth among few to Yeltsin himself (this was also considered a misuse of public resources as the voucher system was offered to the citizens of Russia, and was exploited by those in close connection with the president) . A secondary instance in which Yeltsin and his government were associated with bribery and corruption claims, was the alleged credit card scandal of 1999, in which millions of dollars were being funnelled into secret renovations of the Kremlin and the reparation of the Moscow Parliament (post-Yeltsin's shelling saga of 1993), in the name of Yeltsin (and his two daughters) on various credit cards. -'The Yeltsin Family Took Bribes.' Philip Willan, 1999. The Guardian. http://www.theguardian.com/world/1999/aug/26/russia.philipwillan -Voucher Privatisation in Russia: Structural Consequences and Mass Response in the Second Period of Reform . Hilary Appel, Vol. 49, No. 8, December 1997. Pg. 1433-1449. Taylor & Francis, Ltd.

Justification: Political Rights Q1: Are there free and fair elections for this state's executive and legislature? (3 possible points) Voting is free and there is the potential for opposition to be elected however, given the high number of independant elected polititions, averaging around 35, the power of collective opposition is severly decreased. Also the ability of the current government to use public media oulets creates an unfair advantage. The elections are far from transperent preventing Malawi from gaining three poitns and the potential for regime change is slighty higher than the qualifiers for a single point, leaving 2 points as the remainig result. Q2: Does this country allow universal suffrage? (3 possible points) Adults over the age of 18 can vote provided they are a mentally conpitant citizens and not under death sentence administed by the judicary or previously convicted of a voting related offence. As not every adult can vote, two points is the maximum allocation. Q3: Is there an effective opposition and is there a possibility for it to be elected to govern? (3 possible points) There is effective opposition existing currently, particularly as political parties become less regionally based and voter support is therefore able to becoem more widespread natioanly based on the party rather than its region of origin (BTI) . Furthermore opposition is also able to play a role in the executive as shown by Joyce Banda's selected cabinate and the high rate of cross-floor support generally (BTI) . However there is also a relativly high level of interfearence in the elctoral commision and pultiple cases of attempted prevention of power exchange, as seen in former vice-president Joyce Banda's rise to power, where the existing cabinate attempted to prevent consitutional process from taking place following the presidents death. Because there is not a significant likelyhood of the oposition gaining power, but it remains more than a little potential it is difficult to select one of the avaliable criterea. Given that it is beter to have a too low rather than too high score, this leave Malawi with a score of 2. Q4: Do all people have full electoral rights and opportunities to participate in the electoral process? (3 possible points) The vast majority of adult citizens are able to participate in the electoral process and have electoral rights, however the quality of participation is extremely limited in rural areas due to extrmemely limited accress to the features of civil society. Also generally low levels of education hinder participation. Furthermore local goveranance is ofter conducted without electons due to limied resource access and sustainable infrustructure. Therefore there are sufficant rights to qualiy Malawi for 2 points. Q5: Is there are free, independent and well-resourced media that is able to act as a check and balance on power? (3 possible points) There are numerous media outlets and although the vast majority are governemnt owned and managed there is also an increasing number of private radio stations with widespread coversage which are well regarded for their unbiased journalism. There are also a number of private newspapaer outlets. However exclusive government and supprotive institution sourced adveritisng is used to put pressure on private outlets through an attempt to reduce funding. Following the death of President M inconstitutional legislation was repealed increasing freedoms of opinion and the press. The increasing freedom of the press goes significanlty towards a score of 2, however it is not sufficant leaving malawi with a score of 1. 10.3/15 possible points for Political Rights Civil Liberties for citizens Q1: Does this regime uphold the rule of law and democratic principles? (3 possible points) There is an excess of power held by the executive. And although the judiciary is essentialy independent it is also often ignored due to a lack of execuive support. Furthermore rapid changes in power mean that more often than not when office holders are investigated for crimes the investigations are not followed through on. Also office holders are usually not investigated until after they are out of office. The anticorruption bureau also has rapid changes in leadership lead by political interfearence. Therefore although rule of law is inherent in the constitution and legislatire and investigations occure fairly regularly they are very rarely actualised. Given the lack of repercussions for political leaders Malawi is only able to score 2 point. Q2: Do all citizens within this regime have access to fundamental human rights, including: Freedom of Assembly and Association; Freedom of Speech and Expression; Freedom of Mobility? Although human rights are affirmed both constitutionally and leiglatively, there is minimal access to restitution and even knowledge of human rights in rural areas, which encompass 80% of the population (BTI) . Furthermore when directed at the government protests are often repressed reducing access to freedom of expression and assembly. Also although citizens have the abilty to appeal to breaches of human rights through the judiciary and decisions are usually in their favour the government tends to ignore these decisions. In terms of suppression I do not feel that a lack of access qualifies as active supression, however there are rights established both in legsislature and practice. Despite this Malawi does not met the criteria for 2 points leaving it with a single point. Q3: Does this country have a free, independent and fair judiciary? There is an majoritivly indenpendant, free & fair judiciary in Malawi, however it has compariatively little power and is therefore unable to enforce constitutional rights. The multii teired system allows for appeals and minimises oportunies for judicial corruption. Because of its limited inluence executive interfearnece in judiciary leadership is also minimised. Although the judiciary lacks power it is generally concidered to be faily independent and therefore qualifies sufficiently for 2 points. Q4: Does this country have effective processes in order to hold the governing regime accountable? These could be measures such as independent Ombudsman, inquiries, parliamentary question time, an upper house of parliament, select committees, etc. Although the legislature and judiciary have some power they are unable to act as a check on the executive. Parliament connot even adssemble without executive permission (BTI) . However there are social and legal constructs capable of reviewing and publicising executive misuse of power which provides valuable information access to the voting public enable minor checks to be created. Also due to a high reliance of external aid there this information when avaliabel internationally creates a pressurised environemtn in which the executive must opperate in order to retain foreign investment. The ineffectual seperation of the powers would reduce Malawi to 1 point without the somewhat effect results of international pressure and increased civil society & judicial influence elevating it to 2 points. Q5: Discrimination? (the right to equal treatment and due process for minority groups) 2.4 There are legally established rights and freedoms regardless of qualitative or quantitative poluation features. Due to a fairly homogenous populaition which feads the accepted perception of a national state there is minismed discrimination (BTI) . However there is extensive rural-urban disparity and lack of resources access. Gender discrimination is minial at a social level but with political represtnation at around 10% (BTI) of elected officials more work needed to reduce glass celling inquality, although the situation is moving in the right direction with the former President being a woman. However there is a heavy empahsis on family and power is often distributed based on nepotism rather than quantifiable merit. Although there is not fair representation for minority groups, there is a distrinct lack of social and procedural discrimination elevating malawi to a 3 point status. Main Source Bertelsmann Stiftung. (2014) . BTI 2014 | Malawi Country Report. Bertelsmann Stiftung. Bertelsmann Stiftung.

Justification: Croatia - 1993 Q2) I chose 1990 because it was the year Franjo Tudjman gained power. Q3) I chose 1999 because it was the year Franjo Tudjman, the Croatian president died. Q4) HDZ won power in a free and fair election in 1990. Subsequent elections were free but not fair until Tudjman's death in 1999 Q5) Every adult over the age of 18 can vote. 16 year olds can vote if they are employed. Q6) There was little potential for the opposition to gain power during Tudjman's time in office because of unfair restrictions of the media and campaigning practices. Q7) All citizens had access to political power, but it was unfair for anyone who opposed Tudjman as there wasn't a level playing field for the opposition Q8) The Croatian media was limited to one station, which restricted the sources of information available to the public. That station was closely controlled by the Tudjman regime to restrict the opposition's campaigning. Q9) I could not find information on the rule of law Q10) Freedom of assembly and speech were limited for Serbian protesters during the war as they presented opposing perspectives. The media faced difficulties with freedom of speech both during and after the war due to heavy control and censorship of the information released. Q11) The judiciary had some issues with operating independently from the government. These issues were rectified in a convention published by the government in 2010. Q12) I could not find a definitive answer about the checks and balances of Croatia's parliament/executive. I can only make an educated guess that the checks and balances employed (if any) were fairly ineffectual due to how much power Tudjman's government had. Q13) Ethnic Serbs were faced with widespread discrimination as a minority due to their opposing political views. They were not protected by the government and encountered brutal violence at the hands of the Croatian public and security forces. Q14) I am fairly confident in my answers, although I have found conflicting sources that reflect opposing attitudes on Tudjman and his positive/negative role in Croatia during the 1990s Q15) Corruption was more common in the top levels of the government during this time rather than in the lower levels of the sector. Q16) Special privileges were given to associates of Tudjman's government due to pervasive cronyism. I considered journal articles, news reports and timelines of the War of Independence in my answers. I had difficulty finding answers for the rule of law and checks and balances. I took educated guesses at those questions. The answers fit well with the questions generally.

Justification: Q . 2 & 3: The period of 2003 to 2011 was chosen because of the important political events that took place within this timespan. President Ismail Omar Guelleh was first elected in 1999, taking over from his uncle, dictatorial President Hassan Gouled Aptidon (BBC News, 2015) . However, 2003 held the first multi-party parliamentary elections, where although the opposition coalition, the Union of Democratic Alternative (UAD) won 37% of the votes, the ruling Union of the Presidential Majority ( UMP) received all 65 seats, resulting in unfair representation within parliament (Freedom House, 2006) . Three other significant political events occurred up until 2011 that also contributed to the time range chosen. In 2005, Guelleh won his second six-year term as president as the sole candidate in the election. In 2008, the parliamentary elections were once again won by the UMP, after the three other opposing parties withdrew stating manipulation of the electoral process and abuses from the current government as their reasoning for withdrawing. Finally, marking the end of the time span, in 2010, President Guelleh amended the Djibouti constitution to allow his to run for president for a third time, after previously stating he would retire after two terms. Guelleh was reinstated as president in 2011, after the opposition once again boycotted the election (BBC News, 2015) . These events are the reasons I chose my time span, as the various elections occurring within Djibouti all suggest biased and unjustifiable results, where a manipulation of policies, institutions and rules of procedure has allowed President Guelleh to abuse his position to sustain power. Q. 4: Although there are parliamentary and presidential elections within Djibouti, evidence suggests there is no chance of change. Dominated by the ruling coalition of UMP, lead by President Guelleh, Djibouti is a single party semi-presidential republic, so there is little chance in a democratic change in government. Opposition groups such as the UAD have repeatedly tried to provide challengers but have faced an 'inability to campaign effectively as a result of government control of the media and repression of the opposition's activities' (Freedom House, 2006) . Even when an opposition has participated in the elections, for example in the 2003 legislative elections, results have been debated by the opposition who alleged that the UMP used widespread election fraud such as double voting and the absence of blank ballots of those who did not want to vote for UMP (U.S. Department of State, 2007) . The electoral processes within Djibouti, although give citizens the right to vote, have essentially no effect on the distribution and exercise of power. Q. 5: Suffrage is universal at 18 years of age (Washington: Superintendent of Documents, 2012) . Although the only restriction is the age constraint, the political system within Djibouti is constructed so opposition parties have to register with the government, leading to many boycotting the elections all together. This results in a one-party dominated state, with voters often having only one choice of vote. Voter turn out is often low, only 48% in the 2003 parliamentary elections (Freedom House, 2006) . Because there is often only one party to vote for, citizens are not exercising their right to vote as they realise there is no chance of a change in regime through voting. Q. 6: A multiparty system exists within Djibouti, and as there is universal suffrage, on paper it is possible for anyone to be elected to govern (U.S. Department of State, 2007) . However, the chance of any other party asides UMP receiving representation is low. This is because there is an election law which states 'that the majority victor in each of the country's five electoral constituencies be awarded all seats in that district' so even if a opposition party wins even a minority of the votes, they can receive no representation. (Freedom House, 2006) . The system within Djibouti is constructed as to look democratic, but in actual fact is continually dominated by President Guelleh and the UPM coalition, who consistently ignore demands for electoral reform for opposition parties (U.S. Department of State, 2007) . In 2010, Guelleh amended the constitution, removing the two-term limit for presidents. This allowed him to run for a third term as president, effectively showing how he has used his power and state connections to ensure that there is little possibility for any other party to gain power whilst he is in charge (Freedom House, 2011) . Q. 7: As stated above in question 6, it is possible to try and be elected to govern, but the actual chance of actually getting elected is almost none. Power is concentrated highly amongst Guelleh's own family, with family members holding positions of power in both cabinet and government (Notable Biographies, 2006) . Citizens have the ability to try but the dominance of Guelleh's regime has withstood all opposition parties since he came to power in 1999. Fraudulent elections and strict entry for opposition parties have contributed to the dominance of Guelleh's regime, making access to power for other's extremely difficult (U.S. Department of State, 2007) . Q. 8: Freedom of the media is very restricted, as the Government owns the primary newspapers, radio and television stations such as La Nation (Freedom House, 2011) . This regulates the criticism and backlash that can be published about the Government and although the Djibouti constitution provides freedom of speech and press, the government does obviously not follow these laws (U.S. Department of State, 2007) . 'The Government has used several tactics to intimidate journalists including surveillance and the removal from newsstands of publications that criticized the Government. On February 1 st 2007, police seized printing equipment from the opposition political party Movement for Democratic Revival, publisher of the newsletter Le Renouveau. Houssein Ahmed Farah, the acting director of the newsletter, and three of his editorial staff were arrested and charged with defamation of character for publishing a report of a sex scandal, detained for 2 days, and released. A court ordered Le Renouveau to halt production for 3 months' (U.S. Department of State, 2007) . This shows how an attempt from an independent media source was stopped, showing how difficult it is for internal media outlets to provide checks on power. Q. 9: As the questions progressed I found they were harder to answer/needed more research. The rule of law within Djibouti was reasonably hard to analyse. However, using the World Governance Indicators, regarding the dimension of the rule of law, Djibouti's percentile rank was 22.97 in 2002, 23.92 in 2006 and 24.88 in 2011 (The World Bank, 2014) . This essentially means that the rule of law within Djibouti is weak, and ranks in the bottom 25% on a world scale. However, although this tells me that the rule of law in weak within Djibouti, this answer doesn't really fit any of the option available. So, more research was needed. There are many examples of the rule of law not being upheld by government officials and Guelleh himself. The law itself within Djibouti is everyday law based on the French civil law system, traditional practices and Islamic Law. However, President Guelleh and government officials within this regime do not let the law impede them. F or example, 'security forces often make arrests without the proper decree from the judicial magistrate' (Freedom House, 2012) . Also, 'the law requires arrest warrants and stipulates that the Government may not detain a person beyond 48 hours without an examining magistrate's formal charge' (U.S. Department of State, 2007) . This law is often not enforced, government officials continuously holding prisoners for extended amount of time. Many breaches to constitutional rights also exhibit the rule of law not being followed. The constitution states the right to a fair trial, the prohibition of arbitrary arrest and the protection of human rights just to name a few. However, infibulation (an obvious breach of human rights) consistently occurs in rural areas, yet nobody has ever been convicted of this crime (U.S. Department of State, 2007) . President Guelleh amending the constitution to get rid of the two-term presidential limit is also evidence that he is not subject to the rule of law, as this section of the constitution was aimed to constrain government power. By amending this to continue his authoritarian rule, Guelleh demostrated that there are little checks on his power and the rule of law will do little to impede him. Q. 10: The Djibouti constitution provides freedom of assembly and association, however this is not followed by the government (indicating a breach of the rule of law) (U.S. Department of State, 2007) . The Government only permits peaceful assembly, essentially forcing its citizens to refrain from protests, as they fear the repercussions that will follow. It is a similar circumstance regarding freedom of speech and expression, stated in the constitution but not followed. For example, 'In May 2006 the Government suspended Kaltoum Ali, a journalist for Radio-Television Djibouti and a correspondent of the BBC Somali service, for broadcasting a report that the Ministry of Health falsely claimed a case of avian flu to obtain foreign aid.' (U.S. Department of State, 2007) . The constitution and laws allow for freedom of movement, internally and externally, however once again, the Government sometimes restricts this practice (U.S. Department of State, 2007) . A pattern occurring is that the Government provides all the aspects of democracy in its constitution; yet in practice they are not following these laws. Q. 11: The judiciary is not independent of the executive, supreme courts can overrule lower courts and magistrates are often given life terms. 'Security forces can also arrest Djiboutians without proper authority, despite constitutional requirements that arrests may not occur without a decree presented by a judicial magistrate' (Freedom House, 2006) . This is another instance of the rule of law being breached. For example 'Allegations of politically motivated prosecutions surfaced in 2010 following the conviction of Djibouti's richest businessman, Abdourahman Boreh, on charges of terrorism. A friend-turned-critic of the president, he was accused of directing a grenade attack in Djibouti City. He was not represented by a defence lawyer. Boreh claimed that his 15-year sentence was intended to derail a potential presidential bid in 2011' (Freedom House, 2011) . The judiciary is clearly not independent or free. Q. 12: Regarding effective processes in order to hold the governing regime accountable, this was relatively hard to find information on. I did find this extract from the US Department of State reporting that 'There were no laws to provide public access to government information, and it was unclear whether persons would be granted such access if requested', indicating that there are not any particularly useful checks on power within Djibouti. I therefore made an educated guess that there are likely little to no checks on power, but public dissent would likely cause larger breaches to be investigated if they received international media attention. Q. 13: Djibouti is primarily made up of two ethnic tribal groups, the Issa and the Afari. President Guelleh, who originates from the Issa tribe, rules an Issa dominated government. Members of the Afari tribe do hold majority in the executive, including the Prime Minister and Defence Minister. The Issa's have control the military, civil and security services, and the ruling party. The Afari people, Yemeni Arabs, and non-Issa Somali suffer from social and economic discrimination and marginalisation from many members of the Afari tribe (Freedom House, 2006) . Unofficially, Yemeni Arabs are limited unofficially to one ministerial post each and there are also informal limits on the number of seats in Parliament for each group to preserve balance (U.S. Department of State, 2007) . Although members of the Afari tribe has constitutional rights, the social and economic discrimination they receive signifies that equal treatment is not always used for minority groups such as these. Q. 14: As my timespan is relatively recent, it was reasonably easy to find adequate sources and information on Guelleh's regime. The answers I am not so confident on are those concerning the analysis of the processes that hold Djibouti's regime accountable, as I couldn't find a lot of information on that particular subject. Also, the type of corruption occurring in Djibouti was hard to define, as although there is obvious misuse of public resources occurring, the political corruption occurring within Djibouti more concerns the manipulation of policies to ensure power. Q. 15, 16: There are various methods I used in assessing the level of corruption in Djibouti. The Corruption Perception Index ranks countries on how corrupt their public sector is perceived to be, a low score indicating highly corrupt, and a high score indicating very clean. Djibouti had a score of 2.9 in 2007 and 3.0 in 2011 (out of 10) (Find The Data, 2015) . Similarly, there is also the Control of Corruption score, which 'reflects perceptions of the extent to which public power is exercised for private gain' (Transparancy International, 2015) . Using the range of -2.5 to 2.5, where higher values equal better governance, Djibouti's score in 2011 was -.309. From President Guelleh to government officials, corruption is undeniably present within Djibouti. Concerning corruption from government officials, 'there have been reports in the past of government officials applying pressure on smaller investors to become their 'partners' or to obtain sub-contracts. Despite a substantial improvement in customs transparency under Dubai World's management, there are still reports of business owners attempting to bribe officials to evade import taxes' (Bureau of Economic, Energy and Business Affairs, 2011) .'Corruption as the private misuse of public resources', although a viable definition of corruption, is too narrow to define the corruption within Djibouti. Although the private misuse of public resources does contribute to the level of corruption in Djibouti, there are also a lot of different types of corruption occurring as well. Misuse of public resources, such as President Guelleh consistently issuing large political contracts to his political allies or members of his family shows how corruption is pervasive and entrenched in the Executive (The Economic Intelligence Unit, 2007) . I would use the broader definition of 'Political corruption is a manipulation of policies, institutions and rules of procedure in the allocation of resources and financing by political decision makers, who abuse their position to sustain their power, status and wealth' (Transparancy International, 2015) to defined the type/s of corruption occurring in Djibouti. President Guelleh changing the constitution in 2010 to ensure he could run for an unprecedented third time for President is a primary example of him abusing his position to sustain power (the 'other' category) . Guelleh's entire regime is full of corruption, from almost entirely disregarding the constitution to repress Djibouti citizens the right's of freedom of speech, assembly and expression, to concentrating power within his close circle of friends and family (Special privileges granted to politically-connected people) . Djibouti is very much not free from corruption. Bibliography BBC News. (2015, May 6) . Djibouti profile - Timeline . Justification: Peter Lamour argues that the defintion of corruption is subjective and therefore there can be different in different cultures, and also that corruption largely lies within the political system rather than outside of it. The Iran-Contra Affair was one of the main sources of corruption from this era, and it involved the Reagan administration selling arms to Iran, and funnelling profits into undercover operations. Many people have argued that Reagan's administration was the most corrupt of any American president, due to the large amount of scandals that arose during his two terms (Brown University) . As well as the Iran-Contra Affair, there were scandals within the EPA related to perjury. Despite this, the United States is still definitely democratic, and less corrupt than many other states. I found some of the questions quite difficult to answer, due to a lack of accessible information, and that the questions were slightly open to interpretation. For example, I though question six could be either one or two points, depending on whether you would need more than one opposition member that could realistically gain power. The Democrats are the only other party that could take over, as while there are other groups they are far too small to ever come into government. I also struggled to find any information that related directly to the freedom of the press in this era, so I interpreted the mentions that I could find to mean that the press was generally free, although there would be some exceptions that were government influenced (however these would be the outliers) . I also ended up relying a bit on my general knowledge of the States to answer some questions. The United States does not have universal suffrage, as several groups are legally prevented from voting. For example, if you are under 18 were unable to vote. Homeless people also faced issues in being able to register to vote, as they were unable to provide an address to do so. There were varying restrictions across states regarding voting rights of prisoners. Some states prevent anyone who has ever been incarcerated from voting, whereas others allowed those that are on probation to vote. There are also restrictions on the ages of people who are able to run for president, as you must be at least 35 years old to do so. In question 13 I thought it was interesting to note Ronald Reagan's determination to appoint women to the judiciary, however this did not (and still doesn't) equate to equal gender representation at this level. Also, in question 12, the judiciary is appointed by the president, and therefore is susceptible to political influence, reducing its effectiveness as a check and balance on the legislature. Therefore I think this answer is slightly questionable, as it is possible for someone to be appointed by the president and be impartial, but also just as possible and likely for them to be biased and corrupt. The Washington Times argues that Reagan was particularly committed to maintaining an effective judiciary that upheld the rule of law. America also has a continual overrepresentation of people of colour within the justice system, evidence of systematic discrimination based on race and class. While the United States did have checks and balances they clearly were not effective in preventing corruption in the government. Power is restrained because while there were scandal and corruption within Reagan's regime, there were investigations that followed. Works Cited Ceaser, James W. The Enduring Reagan . Justification: In determining these answers I chose a time scale that does not include the transitional 1990s period before, during and immediately after the Rwandan Genocide. This allowed me to consider Rwanda 'afresh'as the country it is today, as opposed to the country it was at the time of those horrific events. Beginning with Paul Kagame's 2000 assumption of the Presidential office, which he still holds, is a good place to begin. Rwanda comes in at 41/150 on the 2014 World Audit Corruption index, which is a fairly middle-of-the-road score -close to states such as the Czech Republic and Namibia, and Saudi Arabia. Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index ranks Rwanda ranks similarly, at 55/175. This reflects a general 'somewhere in between'situation across most of the country in regards to corruption -there are some areas where Rwanda can be viewed negatively, but some where Rwanda can be viewed in a positive light. For this reason, I was not entirely satisfied with some of the answers I gave to the questions, as the generalized nature of the test doesn't cater for the nuanced variables of Rwandan politics. Rwanda has universal suffrage -has done, according to womensuffrage.org, since 1961 -and in the last election became the only country in the world where parliament consists of a female majority. Participation through the form of submissions is easily accessible on the Rwandan parliament website. There are Presidential elections every seven years, and parliamentary elections occur (though the President appoints his own cabinet and Prime Minister) . The current President, Paul Kagame, incumbent for 15 years, has however been criticized for allowing himself wide-ranging jurisdiction over governance, and making it difficult for opposition to gain any traction in political campaigns. Human Rights Watch has called into question Kagame's policies of harshly stamping out dissent, often justified as an attempt to avoid another Rwandan genocide -freedom of expression is a concern in Rwanda, and is reflected through a low rank on the World Press Freedom index (162 nd out of 180 countries ranked) . Rwanda cannot be said to have a media that satisfactorily acts as a check and balance on power. Rwanda had a score of -0.3 in the 2010 Transparency International corruption index 'Rule of Law'section, meaning Rwanda is again placed in the 'middle-of-the-road'grey area: the score hints at probable minor breaches of legal integrity, but shies away from claiming any major incidences. Certainly a brief online search did not uncover any major Rwandan political scandals or controversies in recent history. The score is likely more reflective of the iron grip with which Kagame holds most of the power in Rwanda -the legality of this grip can be called into question.
