Justification: My first country of research is Portugal in the time period of 1995 to 2002. The Portugese governmental system is said to be Parliamentary Partidocracia, which is said to be a pseudo democracy where the citizens only vote for the party and not for the individual person. The parties put forward their representative from a pre-formed list. In 1974 there was a bloodless military coup and broad democratic reforms were implemented. The current constitution was adopted in 1976 and since 1974 to 2014 Portugal has had 25 different governments. Question 4 discusses whether Portugal has free and fair elections. According to my research as to whether this is the case, I came across many articles which described elections in Portugal coupled with the words 'free' and 'fair'. One such article is a case study by Marina Costa Lobo called 'Portugal: extended voting rights and decreasing participation,' this stated that since the fall of dictatorship there has been free elections. Question 5 is about the country's level of universal suffrage and according to the Governo de Portugal website, states that everyone over the age of 18 has to vote and that all people can vote. There is universal suffrage for all. Question 6 is asking whether there is effective opposition and possibility for them to be elected. Upon researching it is clear to see that there is in fact very clear opposition as there have been many different parties in power. As previously stated there have been 25 different governments. Question 7 is about the access to political power and who is able to run for government. There seem to be some restrictions based on the fact that the citizens aren't elected to From my research into the idea of a free and independent media in relation to question 8 it was discovered that there seems to be a degree of self censorship and government control. Upon reading an article from Press Reference about the Portuguese media, they state that all of the media used to be controlled by the government and heavily censored until the coup in 1974. The new incoming government abolished censorship and implemented a free and fair media. The state however did continue to own media companies but they were to elect a board to run the company on their behalf. In 1999 there was only one newspaper O Correrio da Manha that was exclusively owned by journalists. During this time period there were a few censorship scandals including one in 1995 when a reporter published some scandolous articles about society's rich and famous which resulted in bomb threats and the like. However the author was writing under a pseudonym and was subsequently suspended by the company and this led to claims of self censorship. Questions 9-13 bring us to the civil liberties available to citizens in Portugal between 1995-2002. This part was slightly more difficult to research as it requires a lot more a judgement call based on evidence. There are ways to measure some forms of civil liberties but they might not always be the most accurate ways of measuring. I chose to use Freedom House to provide answers to most of these questions as they provide a good comprehensive idea of these concepts based on extensive research. The Freedom House measurements are only taken back to 1999 but it would be reasonably safe to assume that based on the steady position of Portugal from there until 2002 that the previous 4 years would have been much the same. Portugal's rankings by Freedom House classify it as a Free nation with scores of 1 which is the best possible to be achieved. Therefore based on this evidence it would be safe to assume that civil liberties were well protected during this time period. It also notes explicitly that the independence of the judiciary and the freedom of speech are well protected. Question 12 referencing whether there are processes to hold the government and regime accounted for I found exceptionally hard to research. In this case I have decided based on what I already know about the political situation in Portugal to take an educated guess and state that there are in fact effective processes for checks on power. I have made this decision based on the fact that the constitution was enforced in 1974 a good 20 years before my time period of study and therefore it would be reasonable to assume that it would be well enough established that the government could be held accountable. This coupled with the excellent freedom house ratings at the time provide the basis for this decision. Question 13 asks whether there is equal treatment of minority groups. This was also hard to find accurate information about relating to the time period so I was therefore forced to deduce a decision based on some articles which discuss the problem but not in specific reference to this time. The source I based this on was by World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous People. This provides a historical analysis of the lives of indigenous people in Portugal and their treatment in history. It states that in the 1990's there was a tightening of immigration laws but this failed to check the new wave of immigrants. Therefore skipping to the analysis of the present day it is stated that there is an exceptionally diverse culture and a high number of immigrants. There are significant issues with discrimination which is despite anti-discrimination laws and that this discrimination has been underpinned for decades. This therefore provides a basis to make a judgement that at the time of study that there would have also been issues of discrimination of such minority groups. The final two questions are a discussion of the levels of political corruption seen in Portugal. Upon assessing the Corruption Perceptions Index which is available from it's inception in 1995 we can see that Portugal seems to maintain a fairly standard world ranking in the range of 20-30 over this time period and an average score of about 6.5/10. From these results it seems safe to draw the conclusion that corruption does exist in some forms in Portugal over this time but it was ultimately not exceptionally prominent. For the final question I relied on some research from Global Secruity.org which states in the past there have been scandals involving bribery of officials. Prime Minister Jose Socrates who was the Environment Minister from 1995-2002 it is speculated that he took bribes to waive environmental regulations to build a shopping mall in Lisbon and the payouts were given to his family. There was also a letter sent to the Portuguese government that the UK Serious Fraud Office was investigating 6 individuals for suspected bribery and fraud. This alongside with other examples in the article provides evidence of the types of corruption seen in Portugal. Sources: Anglo Info, 'Voting in Portugal,' http://lisbon.angloinfo.com/information/moving/voting/ (Accessed 20 May 2015) Freedom House, 'Freedom in the world: Portugal,' 1999, http://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/1999/portugal#.VVwCGv1J36Y (Accessed 18 May 2015 Governo de Portugal, 'The Assembly of the Republic,' 2015 http://www.portugal.gov.pt/en/portuguese-democracy/a-assembleia-da-republica/a-assembleia-da-republica.aspx (Accessed 19 May 2015) Isaac, Armando, 'Portugal Overview,' 2010 http://www.minorityrights.org/1816/portugal/portugal-overview.html (Accessed 20 May 2015) Lobo, Marina Costa, 'Portugal: extended voting rights and decreasing participation,' http://www.idea.int/publications/voting_from_abroad/upload/chap3-port.pdf (Accessed 19 May 2015) Portugal.com, 'Portuguese Government', 2015 http://www.portugal.com/information/government (Accessed 19 May 2015) Press reference, 'Portugal,' 2015 http://www.pressreference.com/No-Sa/Portugal.html (Accessed 19 May 2015)

Corruption_types: "Bribe-taking by public officials","Misuse of public resources by top officials","Condoning illegal business dealings"
Justification: Justification for Ratings I selected 2005-2015 as the period of time around my reference year because it represents the entirety of Mahinda Rajapaksa's presidency (Sinhala), the regime that both defeated the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) in 2009, thus ending the 26 year civil war, and was also accused of war crimes, corruption, and increased repression of rights (Freedom House, 2008) . Political Rights Q1: Judging the freeness and fairness of Sri Lanka's elections during this regime was a difficult task. Whilst the country has a post-independence history of genuinely competitive elections with a frequent change of government (Encyclopaedia Britannica, 2015), there were, as Freedom House pointed out in 2008, a few 'irregularities'which compromised its status as fully free and fair. One thing in particular led me to allocate 2 rather than 3 points here. The LTTE, who controlled certain parts of the North and East of Sri Lanka (before their defeat in 2009), actively prevented citizens in those areas from voting in the executive elections. Many of the citizens in those areas were and are Tamils, and would likely have voted for the opposition leader Ranil Wickremesinghe of the United National Party in the 2005 elections, rather than Rajapaksa. Since the race was tight, with Rajapaksa winning by less than a two per cent margin, it is quite possible that the LTTE's actions changed the outcome of the elections. There were also accusations that Rajapaksa himself conspired with the LTTE, paying them to suppress the Tamil vote (Freedom House, 2008) . If found to be true, serious doubt would be cast on the proposition that Sri Lankan elections were wholly free and fair. In the 2010 election, Rajapaksa won by a landslide, however the opposition seemed to have been disadvantaged in that the state shut down all independent Sri Lankan news websites including Tamil language sites in the days leading up to the elections (Sify News, 2010), thus limiting access to opposition material. This kind of manipulation further compromised the status of Sri Lankan elections as free and fair. In the 2015 election, Rajapaksa was defeated by opposition leader Maithripala Sirisena, by nearly a four per cent margin (The Guardian, 2015) . Rajapaksa reportedly attempted a coup d'etat, however the military refused and the new government took over. In sum, I judged elections between 2005 and 2015 to be largely free, but with the opposition facing some obstacles to election. This situation warranted an allocation of 2 points, rather than 3. Q2: Sri Lanka has universal suffrage (CIA World Factbook) . All adults aged 18 or over are allowed to vote in elections. Therefore, 3 points are awarded. Q3: It is safe to say that Sri Lanka has always had an effective opposition, post-independence. There have been regular changes of government since 1948 (WWW Virtual Library -Sri Lanka), and although matters for the opposition were complicated during Rajapaksa's regime, as articulated in Q1, the 2015 elections demonstrate that the United National Party never lost its ability to win. The effectiveness of the opposition may have been a little lower between 2005 and 2015, but on a three point scale using integers only, I find it acceptable to award 3 points. Q4: Many people had theoretical access to political power in Sri Lanka from 2005-2010 -in 2013 for example, the Tamil National Alliance won Sri Lanka's Northern Provincial Council elections (The Diplomat, 2013), despite the Sinhala hegemony of Rajapaksa's regime - however Freedom House (2008) documented complaints from Tamils about discrimination against them in hiring for government jobs, and indeed the aggressive campaigns of Rajapaksa's Sinhala government against the Tamil LTTE and thousands of innocent Tamils alike likely reduced the political potency of that major minority group overall. I cautiously award 2 points here. Q5: Sri Lanka, particularly under Rajapaksa, was notorious for having a heavily censored, non-free media environment (Freedom House, 2008), and Reporters Without Borders has described the press situation in Sri Lanka as 'difficult', ranking the country 165 out of 173 in 2008. Various surreptitious mechanisms such as the Official Secrets Act, anti-terrorism regulations and defamation laws made systematic repression of independent media possible, with numerous journalists being threatened or even jailed (Freedom House, 2008) . I award 1 point. Civil Liberties Q6: On the question of the rule of law, I found Sri Lanka's standards to have degraded significantly during Rajapaksa's tenure. Many abuses of human rights were associated with the civil war, many against Tamil citizens suspected of being involved with or supporters of the LTTE (Freedom House, 2008) (Human Rights Watch, 2015) . Both Rajapaksa's regime and the LTTE were responsible for numerous arbitrary detentions, abductions and killings. Whilst not totally arbitrary and rogue, Sri Lanka's rule of law became very shaky under the guise of anti-terrorism. Only 1 point is merited. Q7: Many human rights were abused under Rajapaksa's government, especially before the end of the civil war (Amnesty International, 2015) (Freedom House, 2008) . As articulated in the above, freedom of speech and expression, right to due process, freedom of association and other rights were abused. Loss of rights was not total, but certainly considerable, so I allocate 1 point. Q8: In pages 275-278 of the Global Corruption Report 2007 by Transparency International, the Sri Lankan judiciary is evaluated, and corruption is well documented. Judges were expected to toe the political line or risk being dismissed, and corruption in the form of bribes or even sexual favours has always been common in the lower court. These factors compromise the independence and fairness of the judicial system, so I am inclined to award only 1 point. Q9: Any measures that were in order to hold the regime accountable, such as the National Human Rights Commission (NHRC), became increasingly compromised during Rajapaksa's tenure. One obvious manifestation of this was that investigators at the NHRC and the National Police Commission were appointed by the executive (Freedom House, 2008) ! Investigations were still conducted, however the questionability of independence coupled with a lack of resources (Freedom House, 2008) severely compromised the ability of these organisations to do their jobs well. 1 point is awarded. Q10: There was discrimination against minority groups such as Tamils, particularly during the civil war, as discussed above. Because of the LTTE, many innocent Tamils were regarded with suspicion and in many instances detained and maltreated without due process. (Freedom House, 2008) . Also, Sinhala only legislation introduced in 1956, which made Sinhala the only official language of Sri Lanka, continued to be an area of concern for Tamils. Access to university education, the justice system and government employment favoured Sinhalese Sri Lankans (Freedom House, 2008) . I find 2 points to be a reasonable score here. Corruption Q11: Corruption is quite common in Sri Lanka, especially at lower levels. According to Business Anti-Corruption Portal (2015), almost one fifth of companies in Sri Lanka expect to pay some kind of bribe in order to secure government contracts. And as discussed previously, the justice system is known to be rife with bribery, with citizens paying officials to investigate claims. Transparency International ranks Sri Lanka 38/100 on corruption, which is certainly a poor score. I award 1 point. Q12: Corruption under Rajapaksa was evident in several forms. Firstly, the government not only condoned but was involved in illegal business dealings. One example of this was the illegal privatisation of public enterprises (Whistleblower.org) . Secondly, as just mentioned, officials were known to take bribes (Business Anti-Corruption Portal) . And thirdly in the 2010 elections, Rajapaksa's government was accused of misusing public funds to boost campaign advertising and gain an unfair advantage in the polls (The Guardian, 2010) . This was almost certainly not the only instance of misappropriation of public resources. Summary of results: Political rights: 11/15 (relatively democratic) Civil liberties: 6/15 (essentially non-democratic) Total: 17/30 (semi-democratic) Corruption: 1 point (quite corrupt) Bibilography Amnesty International: http://www.amnestyusa.org/our-work/countries/asia-and-the-pacific/sri-lanka Business Anti-Corruption Portal: http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/south-asia/sri-lanka/business-corruption-in-sri-lanka.aspx CIA: https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2123.html Diplomat, The: http://thediplomat.com/2013/12/sri-lanka-tamil-struggle-continues/ Freedom House: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2008/sri-lanka#.VVUcAfmqqkp Guardian, The: http://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/apr/08/sri-lanka-election Guardian, The: http://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2015/jan/09/sri-lanka-election-president-mahinda-rajapaksa-concedes-defeat-live Human Rights Watch: https://www.hrw.org/news/2015/01/29/sri-lanka-rajapaksa-legacy-abuse Lanka Library: http://www.lankalibrary.com/geo/postcolonial_history.htm Reporters Without Borders: http://en.rsf.org/sri-lanka.html Sify News: http://www.sify.com/news/8203Sri-Lanka-blocks-websites-hours-before-election-results-news-kb1kIGhbbda.html Transparency International: http://issuu.com/transparencyinternational/docs/global_corruption_report_2007_english?e=2496456/2664845 Whistleblower: http://whistleblower.org/sri-lanka-corruption

Corruption_types: "Special privileges granted to politically-connected people","Other"
Justification: I chose this time period using the scales on freedom house to determine the period of time including the reference date of 2006, that elements of democracy were similar. Here is my justification of my answers - I tried to choose the most accurate out of the choices available. Question 4 - The elections for places of government have sometimes been recognised on an international stage as free and fair. In 2003, they were regarded as the most represented in the country's history. However it is a monarchy based on the foundation of Islamic religion. The king is recognised as the highest power and therefore has the power to corrupt the elections - this place of power does not work through democracy but is hereditary and therefore no 'free and fair' elections exist for head of state. As well as this, he has the power to appoint PM and other political positions. Hence the elections have corruption from the government in power - see explanation for Q6. Question 5 - It does recognise universal suffrage - however it is questionable as of the effectiveness of their votes. Question 6 - In 2003, the Islamist Justice and Development Party was forced by the government into entering less candidates into the elections - however they do create competition in the elections. Question 7 - It is a monarchy - so the head of state power is only available to one particular line. Many significant positions of power are either directly appointed by the king or heavily under the influence of the king. MORE Question 8 - more like 1.5 - There is lively independent media but a lot of it is still state controlled. The only media with nationwide coverage is heavily kept a close eye on. Moroccans have access to about 2000 media outlets. Laws that can hold journalist liable are in place with few exceptions - In 2004, king pardoned 6 journalists who were convicted of treason (insulting the king in the media) . Some media does show opposition to the king but this is exercised with extreme caution and only to a minimal extent. Question 9 - In 2004 the law reform meant that the rule of law was enforced more greatly. However issues with enforcing rule of law stem from the king having power of the judiciary and a lack of adequate policies for procedural standards. Since the king is seen as the 'Commander of the Faithful' - tasked with protecting the liberties of his people, he can be exempt from the law because he has the power to reform the law. This lack of accountability, and centralisation of power goes against the promotion of the rule of law. Question 10 - basic human rights are upheld however there are significant restrictions to activities that represent government opposition. For example trade unions are active but only because they are consented to be from the king - the right to assembly is on the strict basis that the assembly is approved by the king. Question 11 - Although it has an active judiciary, the king is head of the supreme council. Therefore there is a lack of checks and balances from the executive and legislator towards the judiciary. Question 12 - No effective checks and balances exist because no-one can question the kings reign - he holds an extreme concentration of power. The king appoints the ministers and can dismiss them. As well as this, he also has the power to dissolve parliament, call for elections, issue decrees, control the armed forces, be the chief religious leader, and appoint the Supreme Court judges. Question 13 - The king is wary of minority groups such as extremist islamics. Post 2003, Casablanca bombings - their behaviour has been closely monitored and restrictions have been put into place - especially since Morocco's foreign relations with the War on Terror's frontmen: the USA, have grown. However there are freedoms for minorities - e.g. the very small minority of Jews amongst a heavily Islamic population (and Islamic head of state) have freedom to worship.

Corruption_types: "Other"
Justification: Between 1993 and 2003 Burundi was wrapped up in an incredibly violent civil war. Because of this, the political situation is incredibly difficult to analyse. There is also the strong political divide in Burundi that must be taken into consideration. Two main ethnic groups make up Burundi's population. There are the Hutu who make up over 80% of Burundi's population, and the more politically dominant Tutsi. In 1993, the Hutu president Melchior Ndadye was assisnated during a military coup undertaken by the heavily tutsi-dominated Burundian army. It was Ndadye's assisination that sparked an array of conflicts between the Tutsi and Hutu, ultimately leading to a civil war that lasted over a decade. It was due to the widespread conflict across Burundi, as well as neighbouring Rawanda, that information on the political environment between 1993 and 2003 was difficult to evaluate. In 1999, Burundi was struggling to establish a stable political system. The civil war was making it incredibly difficult for Burundi to hold elections as many citizens were caught in the violence between the Hutu and Tutsi. The options that we were given in this regime classification system really relied on some form of stability within the country. The issues that arise with Burundi is that even though there were levels of political and civil freedoms, the civil war made it hard for people to express these freedoms. My issue with the questions is that they are looking to evaluate the GOVERNMENTS involvement in rgiths restrictions while a large proportion of this restriction in Burundi was caused by guerilla groups. With 2 presidents assisnated and one overthrown in a period of 3 years, Tutsi president Pierre Buyoya took control of the country forhis second term. Although he was not elected to his position, and he saw the suspension of the countries existing constitution, Buyoya did begin to draft new political moves that saw Burundi taking steps towards democratic rule. Government was expanded and two vice presidential positions were created (with the idea to bring on one representative from the Hutu group and another from the Tutsi) . Even without democratic eleciton Buyoya was undertaking policies to help support Burundi during it's transitional period. 1993 - 1999 saw Burundi's civil rights slowly and steadily cut down. This began to change as the civil war started wrapping up. 2000 - 2003 saw a reintroduction of many civil rights from the media coveying a more balanced viewpoint, to the countries labour code continuing to protect workers union membership and even union strikes. Other freedoms, such as religion, are also observed. Negotiations to end the civil war were being undertaken between 1998 and 2002 before some resolution was finally reached. These negotiations kept being placed on hold due to continuous bursts of violence from both Tutsi and Hutu militant groups. After negotiations finally begin to wrap up in 2002, Burundi is well and truely transitioning towards a omre demorcracy focussed political system. With a new constitution and new voting system in place, Buyoya stood down as president in April 2003. Buyoya's Hutu vice president was elected and focussed his government on closing the gap between the two warring factions within Burundi.

Corruption_types: "Condoning illegal business dealings"
Justification: It is important to note that roughly the first half of the time frame I have studied was a time of civil war. This means that some data was hard to come by, and many institutions such as elections were non-existent. I chose the timeframe of 1991 -2012 to take into account the effects of the civil war upon Nigeria, as well as the recent civil unrest occurring around the same time as the Arab Spring in 2011/2012. In regard to whether Nigeria has free and fair elections, whether effective opposition is able to be elected, and whether all citizens have access to power, the following information is relevant. From the period of 1991 -1999 no elections occurred at all because Nigeria was in a period of civil war. The first election occurred in 1999 (which is actually regarded as being before the end of the civil war) . The election was regarded as so fraudulent by society and the other candidates that most withdrew from the election in protest, meaning an easy rise to victory for the military-backed Abdelaziz Bouteflika. Frequent elections began to be held in post-civil war Nigeria. However, there are ulterior powers who control the composition of government much more than actual votes. These are mainly powerful political actors in the military or intelligence services. This means that not al citixens have equal access or meaningful access to political power. Moreover, in 2008 the Constitution was amended to give the president greater powers, and to repeal the two-term limit on presidential incumbents. This led to Bouteflika being re-elected for his third term in 2009. Candidates also withdrew from the 2009 presidential election following this amendment to the constitution because they believed it was clear that Bouteflika's re-election was a done deal. Despite there being universal suffrage for Algerians over 18, there is low public faith in the power of voting to change things and this is reflected by dismally low voter turnout statistics (below 50% of eligible population) . The media is not entirely free. While independent forms of media do exist (mainly newspapers) they are reliant upon the state to be published and printed, which leads to self-censorship to ensure they are published. Also, state sponsorship favours forms of media which are pro-government further encouraging self-censorship. The Government in 2009 passed legislation allowing the state to block websites which were seen as antagonistic towards public order, meaning the internet is monitored by the State. Access to fundamental rights is inhibited by the State. Many organisations such as trade unions, are aligned with the State meaning they are not truly independent and do not necessarily carry out their intended function, particularly if that function is contrary to the State's objectives. Any non-government organisations require state approval and many Islamic-focused organisations are treated as highly suspicious, probably a deeply held prejudice resulting from the civil war. As noted earlier, freedom of expression is inhibited by the lack of freedom of the press, but also by the need for citizens to self-censor in order to avoid defamation charges or other consequences. In 2011/2012 when protests became more widespread and frequent it also became clear that the Government had little regard for the rights to protest and to freedom of assembly, when many protests turned violent and many protesters were imprisoned. The judiciary is heavily influenced by the government, meaning the judiciary is not independent. There are few checks and balances on those in power in Nigeria. Despite having a bicameral parliament, the President appoints roughly a third of the members of the upper house. Whilst the lower house is elected, elections are questionable and it is likely electoral fraud is rampant as outlined earlier. Minorities do not seem to face systematic discrimination. However, being a predominantly Muslim nation, non-Muslims can only gather at state-approved locations. It may seem strange, but the State is more concerned about monitoring the Islamic communities for radical activities again most likely as a result of the civil war and seeking to prevent anything similar. Corruption most commonly occurs as a part of private business. It is quite difficult to gauge the severity of the issue of corruption in regard to State dealings. I primarily used data from Freedom House in order to answer these questions.

Justification: 'He Killed my ma, He Killed my Pa, but I shall vote for him'. Charles Taylor's electoral slogan in 1997 more or less summed up the form his rule would take. After 20 years of chaos in Liberia, of which Taylor played a prominent part, he was elected president by a landslide in 1997 on a promise of resuming the civil war should he lose. Whilst the voting itself was judged free and fair by international observers, its pretty damn obvious that theres a problem here. Enlisting former Paramilitaries from the former Yugoslavia, General Butt Naked and Children from the age of four (who have been filmed canibalising enemies and charging into battle armed only with pool noodles) into his armies, Taylor's rule was characterised by him launching proxy wars against his neighbours, and raising revenue almost exclusively from illegal means (the one exception being in the Liberian ship registry) . The legacy of Charles Taylor's rule has left Liberia described by Vice news as quite possibly 'The Most F***ed up place on earth'. According to the Guardian, Legal Judgements were sold to the highest bidder and Police and Judges had their salaries withheld if they refused to execute Taylor's will. With the country operating a common law system based upon that of the United States, this has left Liberia's system of precedent in shambles. Despite strong constitution and a history of democracy, it was reguarly violated. When Sanctions were imposed by the UN, Taylor turned to blood diamonds to fund his rule. Whilst some media outlets, did exist, Liberia's low literacy rates and low television/radio ownership meant that no fourth estate as we know within the first world, had not developed substantially by the time of his rule. Nonetheless, he had taken over the main radio station in the run up to his election. In a country wrecked by ethnic conflict (Liberia was established as a colony for Freed African American Slaves, who found themselves at odds with the population already living there), Taylor exploited it further, relying upon such divisions to maintain his power. Peoples of certain tribes were purged from positions of power. After losing control of the Capital Monrovia after a four year long civil war in 2003, Taylor fled to Nigeria. He was later extradicted to the hague after trying to slip accross the border to Cameroon in 2006 carrying large amounts of Heroin and Cash. In 2013 he was found guilty on all 11 counts by which he was charged with crimes against humanity. Interestingly, it is worth noting that he was at one point a CIA asset. Note: Perhaps in a reflection of how chaotic and corrupt Taylor's rule was, Transparency international were not able to conduct their surveys in the country under Taylor.

Justification: I choose the time period of 1999-2012 because this is when Putin first came into power and started to consolidate his power and move Russia into a more authoritarian, corrupt system. Russia has processes to hold the government accountable such as the legislature that consists of the Duma or lower chamber and the Federation Council or the upper chamber and the courts but these are not effective in practice. Russia's problem is superexecutivism, a bloated, muscle bound executive that is neither balanced nor monitored by the legislature or the courts. The Russian constitution means the President has the power to appoint and dismiss the Prime Minister which Putin has used to consolidate his power. Also half the members of the upper chamber are appointed by governors who are appointed themselves by the President. Therefore, Putin can use this to his advantage. The 1993 Consitution provides the citizens for freedom of speech and expression, freedom of mobility and freedom of assembly and association but there is heavy suppression and monitoring. In 1999 the government exerted pressure on the media and Russia's powerful financial groups acquired control of most major media outlets which has connections to the government or other political figures. Therefore, there was no editorial indpendence. In 2003, the government had controlled all of the national television networks and at least 19 journalists have been killed since Putin came to power. Freedom of expression has been limited further with laws passed on extremism making it possible to crack down on any speech, organisation, or activity that lacks offical support. In 2011 as Duma elections approached businessmen close to Putin purchased additonal television, radio and newspaper assests. Therefore, the media is subjected to heavy censorship, government intervention and self-censorship with the threat of being murderd so can no act as a check or balance on power. Freedom of mobility is restricted because adults must carry internal passports while traveling and to obtain many government services. In regards, to freedom of assembly in 1999 the government largely respected this with numerous political rallies and other demonstrations which occurred throughout the year. However, the governmnet has consistently reduced this with overwhelming police repsonses, the use of force, and routine arrests have discouraged unsanctioned protests. A 2006 law imposed new reporting requirements on NGOs, giving bureuacrats exensive discretion in deciding which groups could register and it also placed tight controls on the use of foreign funds. Russia does not uphold the rule of law with arbitrary power wielded by the state with the use of the judiciary to prosecute any threat to state power. The judiciary is clearly not independent and is subject to political interference, corruption and chronic under-funding. Police routinely use torture against detainees to force confessions but are rarely prosecuted for committing these abuses. The circumstances surrounding the 2009 death of lawyer Sergei Magnitsky in pre-trial detention, after he accused government employees of embezzling millions of dollars, suggested that the authorities had deliberately denied him medical treatment. Also, judges will accept as evidence confessions made during torture. Career advancements within the criminal justice system are tied to compliance with Kremlin preferences and the justice system is effectively a tool of the executive branch. The case of Mikhail Khordokovsky is an example of this; he was jailed on dubious charges and his prison sentence extended apparently on the instructions of superiors at the Moscow City Court. Since 2003, jury trials have been allowed for serious cases and are more likely to acquit defendants. However, these can be overturned by higher courts which can order retrials until the desired outcome is achieved. Russian citizens often feel that domestic courts do not provide a fair hearing and have increasingly turned to the European Court of Human Rights. Minority groups have minimal rights and the government often violates these. The violation is mostly through residence permits which severely hinders the ability of outsiders to register to live or work in certain regions. These limit the right of citizens to choose their place of residence which targets mainly the ethnic minorities and migrants from Caucasus or Central Asia. Immigrants and ethnic minorities particularly those who appear from the Caucasus or Central Asia face governmental and societal discrimination and harassment. Sexual minorities also encounter discrimination and abuse, and gay rights demonstrations are often attacked by counterdemonstrators or suppressed by the authorities. Elections in Russia are not free and fair although everyone in the country can vote that is over 18. Therefore, Russia is not an electoral democracy. In the 2008 presidential election, state dominance of the media was on full display, debate was absent and Putin was able to pass the office to his handpicked succesor, Dmitry Medvedev. In 2011 the Duma elections were deeply flawed with limited political competition, a lack of fairness and convergence of the state and overning party according to the OSCE. There is an opposition but there is little chance it will ever gain power. The tightly controlled media, misuse of adminstrative resources including the courts make it extremely diffcult for genuine opposition parties to win representation. Also, beginning with the 2007 elections parties must gain at least 7 percent of the vote to enter the Duma, parties cannot form electoral coalitions and would-be parties must have at least 40,000 members. This makes it extremely diffcult for any oppositon party. People do not have equal access to political power with women in particular who have particular difficulty in achieving this. They hold 13 percent of the Duma's seats and less than 5 percent of the Federation Council's. Only three of 26 cabinet members are women. Corruption is defined as the private misuse of public resources this is common but only at some levels of the state which tends to be the elite where the power is concentrated. However, this question suggests an answer that does not fit well with Russia as corruption in Russia is pervasive throughout the government and business world but it takes other forms. For example, Russian authorities are rarely able to obtain successful prosecutions of influential businessmen and politicians. Also, members of the old Soviet Communist elite use underhand tactics to obtain control of key industrial and business sectors, therefore there is no equality of opportunity in Russian government. This lack of accountability enables bureaucrats to act with impunity. However, the other common forms of corruption that occurred were bribe taking by public officials and special privileges granted to politically connected people which is common in Russia. In April 2011, Medvedev ordered all government officials to leave any positions they held on the boards of state-owned companies but despite these formal changes the state still has extensive control over important firms. Also, large tax penalties imposed on select companies have illustrated the corruption involved. References: Bonnell, Victoria E., & Breslauer, George W. Russia in the New Century, Stability or Disorder? United States of America: Westview Press, 2001. Bacon, Edwin., & Wyman, Matthew. Contemporary Russia. United States of America: Palgrave MacMillian, 2006. Herpen, Marcel H. The Slow Rise of a Radical Right Regime in Russia. United States of America: Palgrave MacMillian, 2013. Harding, Luke. Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe. http://www.osce.org/odihr/elections/88661

Justification: It was difficult to decide whether to give Myanmar 0 points or 1 point for the first classification question of whether or not there were free and fair elections for the state. In the end I decided to go with 0 points as the only election that was held during this time was right at the beginning of the time period chosen in 1990. The State Law and Restoration Council (SLORC) held Multi-party elections in May 1990, the outcome being that the Aung San Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy Party won 392 of 485 seats. (Author Unknown, 'Burma: a brief political history ', ABC News, 2010, www.abc.net.au ) . However, although The National League for Democracy Party took out the majority of vote the SLORC refused to acknowledge the result and retained its repressive grip of power ever since. (Author Unknown, 'History of Burma ', CFOB, 2004, www.cfob.org ) Therefore I chose to give Myanmar during this time 0 points because only one election was held, however it had no influence on the composition of the government at time. My answer to question 5 sort of contradicted my answer to question 4, however I gave Myanmar 3 points for universal suffrage because when elections have been held within Myanmar, every adult over the age of 18 has been eligible to vote, with the voting day for the election of 1990 being relatively free and fair. (' Q&A on Elections in Burma', Human rights watch, 2010, www.hrw.org ) . Question 6 was an easy 2 points. Within Myanmar, there is an opposition called The National League for Democracy, leg by Aung San Suu Kyi. However, with the extent of repression within the country there is little potential for this party to gain power. This was specifically seen in 1988 when a multi-party election was being held and it was observed that the National League for Democracy were gaining too may supporter, a group of the army sparked a military coup which created SLORC, which remained in control of Myanmar through the 1990s. Aung San Suu Kyi was placed under house arrest by the SLORC and was cut off from any communication from the outside world, remaining this way until she was released in 1995. ('Profile: Aung San Suu Kyi', BBC News, 2014, www.bbc.com ) In 1995 when she was released, she endured continual harassment from the military and her political activity was restrited, showing the extent to which the SLORC within Myanmar had constructed a system where there was little potential for opposition to gain power. ('Aung San Suu Kyi Return to Burma', Bio, www.biography.com ) . In terms of access to political power, I gave Myanmar 0 points because the military in charge of the country at the time had massive restrictions on opposition parties. Aung San Suu Kyi was put under house arrest as she posed too much of a threat to the SLORC and this is a prime example of how the majority of people do not have any access to political power; because the SLORC represses it. It was difficult tossing up between whether to give Myanmar O points or 1 point because through doing research on this topic, it was obvious that Ann San Suu Kyi gained a lot of support through her leadership of The National League for Democracy, however in my opinion the reason her voice was heard in the first place, was because she was the daughter of Bogyoke Aung San, who was a Burmese revolutionary and lead Myanmar to independence in 1948. Although she was promoting beliefs in support of societies interests, the fat that she was daughter of a Burmese hero, would have definitely made an impact. However, I went with 0 points because although she won the election she had been put under house arrest and the votes were not acknowledged, meaning that the military remained in power. In 1990 after the election was held, the SLORC formed a National Constitution Convention rather than a parliament. This constitution provides for freedom of speech and the press, however the government prohibited the exercise of these rights in practice, hence why I gave Myanmar 0 points for free, independent and well-resourced media. Going into the 90's, the number of news papers had decreased from 30 to 8 and as well as this, journalists are often tormented and threatened out of posting unfavourable news for the country and regime. As well as newspapers, all other forms of communication, including domestic and foreign books and periodicals, stage plays, movies and musical recordings, were subject to government control and censorship. This just shows the extent to which media was in no way free and unrestricted. ( (' Q&A on Elections in Burma', Human rights watch, 2010, www.hrw.org ) . ('Media -Control of Media in Burma', Online Burma/Myanmar Library, 2012, www.burmalibrary.org ) . In a report done by Freedom House, it is said that during this time Myanmar had severe restrictions on freedom of speech, press, association and other fundamental rights. ('Burma -Freedom in the World', Freedom House, https://freedomhouse.org ) . In doing research it became obvious that this was accurate information as the human rights violations during this time were immense. The army was responsible for the beatings and killings of civilians and the miss-treatment of people within society in general. The SLORC also arrested people who advocated democracy and human rights. ('Myanmar Profile -Timeline ' BBC News, 2015, www.bbc.com ) . I gave Myanmar 0 points, as the citizens unfortunately did not have access to any of the fundamental human rights mentioned. As well as this, during this time the rule of law was non-existent and the Junta controlled the judiciary. ('Burma -Freedom in the World', Freedom House, https://freedomhouse.org ) . Question 12, which was on whether the country has effective processes in order to hold the governing regime accountable, was a question I struggled with, however, I made an educated guess giving Myanmar 0 points. This was because I know there was no upper house of parliament, no ombudsman and no select committees, therefore I can happily assume there were no checks and balances on power and certainly no independent bodies establish to investigate misuse of power. Therefore, there were no checks and balances on power occurring at the time. For minority groups, there was no representation within the regime and this continued throughout the whole time period. The constitution that was active from 1990 through till 1997 did not acknowledge different ethnic minorities within Myanmar, therefore I gave Myanmar 0 points as there were no effective rights or measures put in place to empower and protect these minority groups. ('The will of the people; Human Rights and Constution making in Burma', Janelle M. Diller, 1991 Oxford, England, www.ibiblio.org ) . In terms of question 15, from 1990 to 1997, corruption was present within Myanmar. Geographically Myanmar has a lot of natural resources including minerals and oil and despite this mineral wealth, Myanmar was (and remains) one of the least developed countries, mainly due to the corruption within the country. ('Myanmar ', Natural Resource Governance Institute, www.resourcegovernance.org ) . I struggled in which category to put Myanmar's corruption into, however in the end I went with 'misuse of public resources by top officials' because the country made billions of dollars yearly from its natural resources, however society was never able to enjoy these benefits as profits went directly to the military.

Justification: Justification- Kazakhstan regime from 1999-2015 Since the fall of the Soviet Union in 1991, Kazakhstan has been under the same authoritarian style regime until today. President Nursultan Nazarbayev has been in power since 1989, today he remains the last president of the Soviet Era; however, my research focuses on his regime from the 1999. I have conducted my research across this long period of time mainly because his regime has not undergone any substantial change. Since the collapse of the Soviet Union the Nazarbayev regime has not been challenged. This is evident through his election triumphs over the years. In 1999 election he won with a majority of 80%, furthermore, in 2005, he won 90% of the vote and more recently in 2011 he was re-elected with 97.7% of the nationâ<U+0080><U+0099>s vote. Although evidence suggests that Nazarbayev has received popularity in Kazakhstan through his economic success in foreign trade deals and through â<U+0080><U+0098>stabilisingâ<U+0080><U+0099> ethnic relations. However, the government has attracted much criticism due to accusations of corruption in all aspects of society, which further restricts civil liberties. The authoritarian regime in Kazakhstan is a complex one. Elections are held to make the government seem legitimate; however, overwhelming evidence suggests that these are corrupt. Nazarbayev claims that Kazakhstan will eventually become democratic, however, if this occurs to quickly Kazakhstan runs the risk of instability. As a result civil rights abuses continue, and media and religious groups continue to be suppressed, and this will be discussed in more detail below. Kazakhstan does hold elections; however, it is evidently not an electoral democracy. Furthermore, the constitution allows for Nazarbayev to monopolise control over all branches of government, thus he is not subject to the rule of law and there are no checks and balances on the executive branch. Furthermore, evidence from various sources suggests that the elections held are illegitimate due to a combination of reasons. This is largely evident in the 2005 election. BBC reported that the OSCE (Europeâ<U+0080><U+0099>s main poll monitor) observed ballot box stuffing, intimidation of the opposition, and media bias during the election period. Furthermore, during this term in 2007, he amended the constitution to allow a president to be elected for an unlimited amount of terms. Nazarbayev not only wields power through his unlimited controls over the state that is enshrined in the constitution, but a corrupt electoral system allows him to retain his presidency. Civil liberties are increasingly suppressed in Kazakhstan by the state. Firstly, laws and restrictions are increasingly imposed on independent media and journalist groups. The Freedom of house continuously reports on the frequent arrests and attacks on journalists, and accounts on the methods the states use to do so. This was evident through in 2012 the Ministry of culture and Information expanded powers to combat â<U+0080><U+0098>unofficial or negative informationâ<U+0080><U+0099> about any crisis. Moreover judges, who are exposed to constant corruption, have shut down independent television channels, news website and newspapers based, on the grounds of â<U+0080><U+0098>extremismâ<U+0080><U+0099>. Secondly, the rights of freedom of religion have become increasingly supressed over time. Despite freedom of religion being enshrined in the constitution, in 2005 the government outlawed organisations if they were considered â<U+0080><U+0098>extremismâ<U+0080><U+0099>; however, this evidently includes any groups that are not the mainstream religions. Nazarbayev has achieved much economic success due to energy ties with Europe, China and Russia. During the time period I have examined and this largely contributes to their positive ties with the Europe despite the major human rights abuses. Over half of Kazakhstanâ<U+0080><U+0099>s total trade today is with the European Union; in 2013 an estimated $53.4 billion was generated through this. Kazakhstanâ<U+0080><U+0099>s foreign policy included energy ties with China, which continued to expand its oil and gas pipeline network in Central Asia. Since the 2000â<U+0080><U+0099>s Kazakhstanâ<U+0080><U+0099>s economy has grown rapidly and this has reflected a stable economic society, where unemployment is rare. This has helped the Nazarbayev government to gain legitimacy, as the country although suffers from problems with distribution, does not have high poverty rates. This brings in the notion that authoritarian governments are able to maintain power more easily for long periods of time, if people have acceptable living standards. Nazarbayevâ<U+0080><U+0099>s long reign suggests there is some truth to this. Furthermore, despite the arguable increasingly worse human rights abuses in Kazakhstan, the country has reasonable good relations with the European Union. These relations arise from foreign investment deals, attributed to the vast resources in Kazakhstan. It is clear that the authoritarian regime held by Nazarbayev is able to monopolise power through corrupting the governmental system. Furthermore, he increasingly is placing restrictions on civil liberties. However, his success economically has avoided any major upheaval from the public and from the international arena. The evidence above, which allowed me to answer the questions confidently, was easily found and not largely disputed among my sources. Bibliography Freedom House, Freedom in the world 2015, Kazakhstan https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2015/kazakhstan#.VV5bb0-eDGc BBC News â<U+0080><U+0098>Kazakhstan country profileâ<U+0080><U+0099> http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/country_profiles/1298071.stm Nursultan Nazarbayev,Â â<U+0080><U+0098>The Next Chapter in Kazakhstan-EU Relationsâ<U+0080><U+0099> The Wall street Journal http://www.wsj.com/articles/the-next-chapter-in-kazakhstan-eu-relations-1412703767

Justification: I chose the time period 2013-2015 because that was when the current president, Hassan Rouhani was elected in, with 2015 being present time. To get my answers for the questions above i used websites such as freedomhouse and similar but also got information from news articles. I found it some what difficult to answer some questions as sometimes they would clash with other answers. For example, i know that people over the age of 18 can vote in their elections, but i also read that women are 'valued' only half as much as men. That bit made me wonder more about voting. Voting is relatively free in Iran but there are some restrictions and barriers. Candidates must first be approved by the council of guardians and the president has to be appointed by the supreme leader. I got this information from the CIA fact book. With who can vote, i answered that any Iranian citizen over 18 can. I was a little hesitant with this answer as i know that men and women are not really equal in the country. There are opposition parites in Iran but again, anyone who run has to firt be approved by the council of guardians. Some parties are also banned in the country. The media in Iran is censored and only approved material is allowed, though there are privately owned media companies, there are restrictions on how they can run. Corruption is a big issue in Iran, but mostly on the lower level. There are sometimes breaches higher up but that is stamped out quickly with investigations. There is not much freedom in Iran as there are heavy restrictions on the people with religious, ethinc and gender issues being the biggest. The courts are based on Islamic law and the judiciary has to be approved by the supreme leader. The sumpreme leader has most of the power and makes most of the decisions but can be removed by the council of experts.

Justification: Are there free and fair elections for this state's executive and legislature? Arguably, yes. Since the establishment of a constitution and elections and 1992, Ghana has incorporated a well contested multi-party system which appear to be free and fair, with transitions between contesting parties occurring consistently and comparatively smoothly when compared with other African democracies. http://forums.ssrc.org/kujenga-amani/2013/07/18/the-2012-ghanaian-election-implications-for-the-consolidation-of-democracy/#.VV6S2_mqqko Party Systems and Democracy in Africa: Renske Doorenspleet, Lia Nijzink ; Palgrave Macmillan, 3/12/2014, Page 34 Does this country allow universal suffrage? With limitation on those under the age of 18 and those 'of sound mind', universal suffrage does exist in Ghana, however there have been issues in the biometric methods utilised in validating voters. Section 42 of the Constitution of the Republic of Ghana - http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/republic/constitution.php?id=Gconst7.html Is there an effective opposition and is there a possibility for it to be elected to govern? Yes, historically party transitions have occurred multiple times in Ghana and are cited to have been effective due to 'an independent Electoral Commission and transparent electoral processes, integration of the political elite alongside the creation of norms and institutions structuring elite behaviour, and the institutionalization of political parties.' Transitions have occurred between different popular parties such as the NPP and NDC. 'Change for a Better Ghana': Party Competition, Institutionalization and Alternation in Ghana's 2008 Elections - Lindsay Whitfield - Afr Aff (Lond) (2009) 108 (433) : 621-641 first published online August 12, 2009 Do all people have effective access to political power? There does exist some inherent institutional discrimination against particular demographics; eg: women, particular religions, lower socio-economic class in attaining political power. For example; in 2007 women only held 10% of the roles of governance in local Ghana. These factors are largely derived from cultural influence rather than the structuring of government itself. Human rights, Power and Civic Action research project, Universities of Oslo, Leeds and Ghana: Political Context Study-Ghana - Abdul Gafaru Abdulai - http://www.polis.leeds.ac.uk/assets/files/research/research-projects/abdulai-ghana-political-context-study-jan09.pdf Leadership Dynamics and the Politics of Representation in Africa - http://www.iahr2015.org/iahr/2687.html Is there a free, independent and well-resourced media that is able to act as a check and balance on power? Ghanian media is classed as 'free' by freedom house publishers, and ranked 27th of 175 by reporters without borders in terms of media freedom. The constitution also protects freedom of speech and prohibits censorship of the media. Section (s) 2 and 12 of the Constitution of the Republic of Ghana - http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/republic/constitution.php?id=Gconst7.html Worldwide Press Freedom Index - 2009 - Reporters Without Borders. Does this regime uphold the rule of law? Though it does possess the same constitutional elements as many other contemporary democracies in asserting the separation of power and rule of law, the Ghanaian executive has had multiple cases of abuses/select uses of power in executing law. Issues around which laws in particular are passed and the passing of executive pardons raises questions around the effectiveness of the rule of law in Ghana. Ghana: Justice Sector and the Rule of Law - A Discussion Paper: A review by AfriMAP and The Open Society Initiative for West Africa and The Institute for Democratic Governance - 2007 http://www.afrimap.org/english/images/report/AfriMAP_Ghana%20JusticeDD.pdf Do all citizens within this regime have access to fundamental human rights, including: Freedom of Assembly and Association; Freedom of Speech and Expression; Freedom of Mobility? Chapter 5 of the Ghanaian constitution asserts the maintenance of all of these fundamental rights, and since the emergence of democracy in 1992, these rights have gradually become increasingly enshrined in governance, with freedom house formally defining the nation's people as 'free' in 2001. However, there are still recorded abuses of some key human rights in the nation, which prevent it from reaching a higher ranking under freedom house. Freedom House (2012) . 'Country ratings and status, FIW 1973-2012' Ghana 2013 Human Rights Report - http://www.state.gov/documents/organization/220329.pdf Does this country have a free, independent and fair judiciary? Ghana's judiciary is arguably more independent than most in that it possesses autonomy in the preparation, administration, and control of its own budget. However, whether or not this actualizes into a fair judiciary is debated. Constitutionally the judiciary is completely independent of other branches of governance and can be instigated into checking any executive or judicial action by any aggrieved citizen. A New Jurisprudence for Africa - K. Prempeh Journal of Democracy Volume 10, Number 3, July 1999 pp. 135-149 https://muse.jhu.edu/login?auth=0&type=summary&url=/journals/journal_of_democracy/v010/10.3prempeh.html Does this country have effective processes in order to hold the governing regime accountable? Since the democratisation of Ghana in 1992, initiatives such as the 'Peoples'Assembly'concept - a platform for citizens to interact with the executive President on a one-on-one basis - have emerged to increase. An annually held public forum, the Peoples'Assembly is designed to allow the executive explain its policies to the people, and respond to questions from the public on key issues. In addition to this, the Ghanaian judiciary - like that of New Zealand's and other contemporary democracies - possesses sufficient political independence so as to be able to hold the executive accountable for significant breaches of fundamental rights and freedoms. Political Context Study-Ghana - Abdul Gafaru Abdulai - http://www.polis.leeds.ac.uk/assets/files/research/research-projects/abdulai-ghana-political-context-study-jan09.pdf Does this country uphold the right to equal treatment and due process for minority groups? Though reparation efforts are being actively made towards groups subjected to discrimination under previous regimes, and constitutional safeguards have been created to prevent discrimination, culturally ingrained discrimination remains a recurring feature in Ghanaian society. http://www.minorityrights.org/4159/ghana/ghana-overview.html The Overwhelming Minority: Traditional Leadership and Ethnic Conflict in Ghana's Northern Region: Julia Jönsson - CRISE WORKING PAPER No. 30 February 2007 - Department of International Development, University of Oxford How corrupt was this state during the period of study? Significant government markers demonstrate that Ghana has accomplished a notable advance in recent years as far as government viability, transparency of the administrative system and control of corruption are concerned. In any case, despite the fact that it not as prevalent as in most other African nations, corruption remains a huge issue in the nation. Small-scale corruption consistently emerges as an issue and there is evidence of types of political corruption including misuse and taking of state resources. Corruption affects sectors such as the police force, political gatherings, and management of public finances - specifically concerning taxation and customs administration. With the recent discovery of offshore oil fields, the country's past record in managing its mineral wealth has raised concerns over its ability to manage oil revenues transparently. The government has a strong anti-corruption legal framework in place, but faces challenges of enforcement. The creation of anti-corruption institutions such as the Commission on Human Rights and Administrative Justice, the Serious Fraud Office, and the Public Procurement Authority acted to reduce its prevalence in Ghana. The Serious Fraud Office has recently been replaced by the Economic and Organised Crime Office with additional powers to investigate and prosecute corruption cases. Despite this, recommendations are being made to significantly extend the powers of these bodies so as to adequately prevent corruption further developing in the country Political Context Study-Ghana - Abdul Gafaru Abdulai - http://www.polis.leeds.ac.uk/assets/files/research/research-projects/abdulai-ghana-political-context-study-jan09.pdf OVERVIEW OF CORRUPTION AND ANTI-CORRUPTION IN GHANA - 22 February 2011 - Transparency International - http://www.transparency.org/files/content/corruptionqas/271_Corruption_and_anti_corruption_in_Ghana.pdf

Justification: Benin, currently is one of Africa's most stable democracy's. But it is still heavily corrupt, not so much politically but it is heavily underdeveloped and corruption is rife. Economically Benin is struggling which leads to more issues within the country such as education and health supplies not being available. During the time period that I have chosen 1995- 2005 Benin was going through some strong positive political changes, changes that were making the government more transparent. But although Benin has a strong democracy it was also on thin ice due to the state being incredibly corrupt. During this time period as well Benin was experiencing a large amount of refugees flooding in from neighbouring countries that they didn't have the facilities or economy to deal with, which lead to a larger problem of Benin having to borrow money to support these people. Because of Benin's placement in Africa and its neighbouring countries being quite corrupt it is difficult to develop Benin when corruption is quite high and the government is under threat from the civilians of the state. So although politically Benin is not corrupt, culturally and within society it is. I found this difficult when answering some of the questions because it's not a stable democracy if it could be under potential threat. Benin adopted a new constitution in 1990 in order to open up and liberalise the political system and economy. Its chief aims were to enshrine in law accountability, transparency, and freedom of religion, freedom of the press, separation of governmental powers, the right to strike, universal suffrage and independence of the judiciary. Mathieu Kérékou, was President of Benin from 1972 to 1991 and again from 1996 to 2006. After seizing power in a military coup, he ruled the country for 17 years, for most of that time under an officially Marxist-Leninist ideology, before he was stripped of his powers by the National Conference of 1990. He was defeated in the 1991 presidential election, but was returned to the presidency in the 1996 election and controversially re-elected in 2001 . The fact that it was seen as suspicious that Mathieu was re-elected because of his Marxist approach makes the state look very corrupt, which made it difficult to answer a few questions because it's unknown if it was a genuine election at the time or if it was planned. Although he did then take a democratic view on the state and put some beneficial policies in place. Justification: Emir Isa bin Salman Al-Khalifa had ruled Bahrain for 38 years when he died on the 6 th of March, 1999. Kofi Annan of the UN described him as 'a force for stability' within the Middle East. [1] Emir Isa had, in fact, been an exceedingly passive, ceremonial ruler. He had paid little heed to the politics and divides within his nation even throughout the turbulent 'intifada' uprisings of the 1990s. The government had been effectively maintained by Bahrain's first and only Prime Minister, Emir Isa's younger brother, Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman Al-Khalifa. The late Emir was succeeded by his son, Sheikh Hamad bin Isa Al-Khalifa. Emir Hamad, whose title was changed to King in 2002, clearly intended to be a much more active ruler than his father. So began a process of liberalisation, with economic goals underlying the change in direction. [2] Bahrain was running out of oil, and it was turning to financial services and Gulf tourism. [3] It occurred to King Hamad that a traditionalist policy, based in a reliance on a single export, was not going to be successful in the future. It is important to note that tied very closely to Bahrain's political landscape and levels of corruption in this period is the sectarian divide within the country. The majority of Bahrain, 70%, is Shiite, the Khalifa family is Sunni. Poverty levels are highest amongst the Shiite population. [4] I have been selective in terms of the time period for my research. It spans from the death of Emir Isa to immediately before the sudden surge of unrest and instability of the Arab Spring. My reasons for excluding the Arab Spring period from my data input is based on the fact that the interactions between the government and the populace after late 2010 were quite different and more extreme than in the ten years prior, so may have provided unrepresentative or erratic results. In 2001, the National Action Charter was passed through referendum initiating a bicameral legislature. [5] Before this, the unelected Shura Council had maintained full legislative power. The new structure kept the appointed Shura Council as the upper house and introduced an elected Council of Representatives as the lower house. The Council of Representatives was initially expressed as being the sole source of law in Bahrain, with the Shura Council simply acting as an executive branch and setting the legislative agenda. However, in 2002, behind closed doors, the government amended the Charter giving the Shura Council equal law-making power and the power of veto over the Council of Representatives. The opposition was not consulted. Voter turnout in the first election for the Council of Representatives was reported as 53.4%. [6] As of 2010, approximately half of the cabinet ministers were members of the Al-Khalifa family. The most important ministries especially were allotted to the Khalifas. [7] Opposition parties had a very limited platform upon which to operate, mainly due to institutional constraints. They consistently boycotted the elections, stating that the Council of Representatives had no real power, with the executive maintaining absolute control over the passage of laws. [8] This created a vicious cycle, with the boycotts further limiting any potential representation of opposition groups in the Representative Council, especially as the opposition groups are largely separated along sectarian and religious lines. There was simply no means for the opposition to gain a foothold that might lead to substantive power. Even if opposition parties accessed the Council of Representatives its powers were simply not enough to allow for truly representative law-making. Bahrain remained a repressive state even whilst King Hamad tried to instigate such political reforms. With the legislative reform initiated in 2002 there came a heightened level of confidence amongst the opposition movements, even having boycotted the Representative Council elections. In February of 2004 a conference was organised aimed at discussing the structure of a truly democratic, social contract constitution. [9] The hotel that was hosting was heavily pressured to cancel the event and foreign guests were refused entry into the country. Later that year the opposition drafted a petition for the changes to be made to the constitution. Seventeen signature collectors were arrested. The leader of the political NGO the Bahrain Center for Human Rights, Abdulhadi Al-Khawaja, made a speech that same year calling for the resignation of Sheikh Khalifa, the Prime Minister. [10] He was then arrested and the BCHR was dissolved and dubbed a terrorist organisation. In 2005, moderators of the Bahrain Online website were arrested for allegedly defaming the government. [11] Throughout this period internet usage was restricted with the Ministry of Information having full capacity to block any websites of their choosing. [12] Both Freedom House and Reporter Without Borders rate the press within Bahrain as 'not free', with wide reports of government agents applying rules as to what can and cannot be published and checking publications before release for anti-establishment material. In line with many autocratic governments the Bahrain constitution does not coalesce with reality, promising liberties distinctly separate from those in practice. Members of the judiciary are nominated by the Minister of Justice, with the Prime Minister then decreeing their appointment if he so wills it. [13] King Hamad chairs the Supreme Judicial Council who makes appointments for the constitutional court. High-ranking judges are predominantly members of the royal family or have personal or economic ties to the royal family. [14] The power that the royal family holds is furthered by the overlap within the judiciary. There is no separation of powers or realistic potential for judicial checks on the exercise of power. The Court of Cassation, Bahrain's highest appellate court, also wholly consists of judges appointed and removed by royal decree. [15] In 2006, the Al Bandar report was released by the Gulf Centre for Democratic Development, a clear example of corruption at the executive level. [16] It contained allegations that leading members of the government and royal family had organised a scheme to foment the sectarian divide within Bahrain. It claimed that the Minister of Cabinet Affairs financed the operation that organised spying on Shiites, establishing government organised non-governmental organisations, election rigging, and inciting hatred online. The 'Bandargate' report is but one example of the alleged corruption at the highest levels of Bahraini government, especially as relates to the sectarian divide within the country. More recently, it has come to light that one of the Prime Ministers foremost advisors Sheikh Isa bin Ali Al-Khalifa reportedly took bribes of up to $6 million from a British-Canadian businessman between 2003 and 2004. [17] Instances such as this, in addition to damning reports from various international NGOs all point to widespread governmental corruption, even before considering the Transparency International data that will form the basis of the corruption element of this study. [1] Associated Press, 'Bahrain Emir appoints Crown Prince,' March 9, 1999. [2] Katja Niethammer, 'Opposition Groups in Bahrain,' in Political Participation in the Middle East, ed. Ellen Lust-Okar and Saloua Zehoni, (London: Lynne Rienner Publishers, 2008), 145. [3] Bahrain Monetary Agency, 'Annual Report -2004' . [4] Toby Matthiesen, Sectarian Gulf: Bahrain, Saudi Arabia, and the Arab Spring That Wasn't, (Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2013), 3. [5] Elections Today, 'Bahrain -Referendum on Government Structure', Spring 2001, vol. 9, no. 3, 26. [6] The National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, 'Bahrain's October 24 and 31, 2002 Legislative Elections,' 11. [7] Hassan Ali Radhi, Judiciary and Arbitration in Bahrain: Historical and Analytical Study, (Leiden: Brill Academic Publishers, 2003), 130. [8] Niethammer, 153. [9] Ibid, 155. [10] Human Rights Watch, 'Bahrain: Rights Center Closed as Crackdown Expand,' September 30, 2004. [11] Niethammer, 147. [12] Reporters Without Borders, 'The Enemies of Internet Special Edition: Surveillance,' 2013. [13] International Commission of Jurists, 'Attacks on Justice 2002 -Bahrain,' August 22, 2003. [14] Ibid. [15] Radhi, 120. [16] Hassan M. Fattah, 'Report Cites Bid by Sunnis in Bahrain to Rig Elections,' The New York Times, October 2, 2006. [17] Simeon Kerr, 'Bahraini royal accused in $6m bribe case,' Financial Times, October 27, 2011.
