Justification: Q. 1, 2 & 3 Around the administered year of 2006, I have used the years 1998 and 2008 as inclusive boundary points to limit my period of study. These dates coincide with Robert Kocharyan's ascension to the presidency and subsequent mandatory relinquishment 10 years later, after the conclusion of his second five year term in power. The extent of this period affords us the ability to examine the regime in its entirety, as during Kocharyan's decade in power few seismic political or social reformations occured which suggested the Armenian political landscape was anything but consistent. There is no need to further limit the scope of analysis as to accurately classify the regime we must consider it over its full trajectory, rather than an isolated portion. Q. 4 Armenia transistioned to democratic rule in a 1991 election, after regaining independence from the Soviet Union in 1990. However, the state has struggled to instill due academic process and integrity - with the apperently democratic elections acting as one of the main problems. The 1998 and 2003 elections, both of which Kocharyan won, were widely disputed by the opposition and critized internationally. John Brady Kiesling's statistical review of electoral fraud during the 1998 Armenian election drew on data released conditionally by the Armenian Central Election Commission (as obligated to the International Foundation for Electoral Commision, to encourage honest democratisation of elections), finding significant numerical abberations suggesting systematic interference. According to Kiesling's data, the election CEC spreadsheets contained numerous errors, missing data and obvious transpositions - or terminated data where transpositions were unfeasible (Kiesling, undated) . Kiesling elaborates on these inconsistencies, reporting that local leaders 'deliver as close as possible to 100% of the possible votes to the expected winner.' In Armenia, voter turnout this high is implausible, and electoral roles list thousands of emigrants who do not return to vote. This heavily implies active fraud - namely invalidation of opposition ballots and ballot-stuffing - as observed by OSCE election attendees. The OSCE itself concluded that 'there was a lack of sufficient political determination by the authorities to ensure a fair and honest process' (OSCE, 2003) . Similar suspicions were voiced following the 2003 election, in which defeated opponent Stepan Demirchyan accused Kocharyan of electoral fraud - inciting extensive violent protests as a result. Therefore, whilst there are elections for the executive and legislure, these elections have minimal potential to change the regime as fraud is too prevalent and powerful. Q. 5 As per the CIA World Fact Book, Armenia had universal suffrage over the age of 18 during the studied period (CIA, 2015) . Q. 6 Despite Kocharyan's political dominance over an entire decade, and the subsequent ascendency to the presidency of the candidate he advocated after the conclusion of his two terms in power, there were significant opposition movements during his regime's rule. This is evidenced by the fact that, in the 2003 presidential election, the opposition managed to force a second round of voting as the results of the first round proved inconclusive (Babayan, 2015) . Sufficient evidence exists to suggest that Kocharyan's regime engaged in active electoral fraud (as previously discussed), making the results all the more impressive as, most likely, the opposition support was so strong that it would have been undeniably fraudulent to claim victory after a single round of voting - hence a second round was called in an attempt to grant the proceedings the appearance of validity and plausibility. The resulting protests also indicated extensive, commited opposition support. Despite conditonal aid from the US and EU, and warnings from the OSCE and CoE, legislative process was undermined by illegal actions in an attempt to avoid defeat - granted false veracity from a newly introduced elections law (Babayan 2015) . This suggested that the Kocharyan regime's main priority in governance was re-election, regardless of whether it was democratically licit or not, as they were willing to risk international ire and loss of benefits to achieve their goal. This gave the opposition an extremely low likelihood of being elected. The classification model is unfortunately ill-fitting for this particular circumstance, as none of the options fit correctly. The opposition was significant, however had no real chance for it to gain power. The framework assumes that only oppositions that lack significant support similarly lack the ability to gain power, however in situations where fraud is as inherent a factor in electoral process as it is in Kocharyan's Armenia then even strong opposition cannot feasibly achieve power without support outside domestic politics (international intervention or military backing) . Despite this slight incongruousness, the model is broad enough that the classification can roughly fit. To say that the opposition is miniscule or unheard from would be untrue, however to say that the opposition only has a miniscule chance of gaining power would still technically be accurate, as 'low likelihood' would encompass the complete lack of true likelihood, and thus this classification is most apt of those offered. Q. 7 Active political power and agency is, in reality, mostly restricted to the president and his regime. The guise of democracy and free and fair elections are a smokescreen for presidential manipulation and monopolisation of political power. As previously discussed, Armenian elections during the rule of President Robert Kocharyan were largely fraudulent and had little potential to determine with whom power should lie. Elections are the primary conduit through which the general populace can exert their political power in a meaningful way, however if elections are lack the capability to produce regime change, then the average citizen loses any political power and ability to influence governance. Access to political power under Kocharyan, therefore, is limited only to those either in power (the Kocharyan regime) or those who can help sustain the regime's political omnipotence. The power structure was manipulated in a strictly top-down manner, where power is able to breed power. This is exemplified in, again, the elections - in which the incubent received three times as much media coverage as the opposition candidates combined; which is a clear violation of the electoral code (Babayan, 2015) . Due to this imbalanced power structure, in reality those who are already politically elite have monopolise the majority of the majority of political power and block access to those less powerful. Q. 8 Just as the Armenian media was manipulated to advance Kocharyan's political ambitions by biasing media coverage, the distortion of the media's integity was motivated by the intent to minimalise public criticism of the regime and to reflect the regime's agenda. Primarily, multiple cases of extreme violence against critical journalists were carried out under Kocharyan's rule, engendering a media environment in which self-censorship became normalised due to fears of violent repression media outlets spoke out against the regime (Grigoryan, 2009) . The diminishing of Armenia's media as a free and fair institution was exacerbated by lawful decrees. Libel was only decriminalised in 2010 (OSCE, 2013), two years after Kocharyan ceded his power. In 2006, legislation was approved to limit the coverage of terrorism, with Kocharyan citing the fear of attacks as justification. The legislation itself was vague and could easily be manipulated to extend restrictions beyond its original intent (Freedom House, 2006) . Therefore, not only was media repression implicit it was also institutional. The intimidating power of the regime, backed with its legislative authority, ensured that the Armenian media was neither free or able to act as a check and balance on power. Q. 9 A NATO review of Armenia's constitution and separation of powers concluded that power in Armenia is extremely centralised, and in particular the President has powerful leverages over the judicial branch due to contemporary legislation (NATO, 1998) . As discussed in response to question 11, this power is exemplified by the president's ability to appoint and dismiss judges (Eastern Partnership Civil Society Forum, 2008) . This implies the judiciary is not independant. Having stripped the voting public of their political power via electoral fraud, and ensuring the judiciary is not independent, the executive has no effective political obligation to uphold the rule of the law. This is evidenced in the fraudulent elections, where Kocharyan breached electoral legislation despite warnings from transnational union organisations. Power is not necessarily wielded arbitrarily however, as the regime at least attempted to justify their moves in legislative terms and avoided absolute tyranny. And yet, the executive clearly was not subject to the rule of the law. Q. 10 Human rights in Armenia under Kocharyan were frequently restricted both institutionally and through social coercion. Abuses towards rights of assembly were perhaps the most egregious, reflecting the regimes priority of retaining power. As per political academic Neil Babayan, legislative restrictions on the right to hold peaceful demonstrations were imposed in 2000/01 (Babayan, 2015) . In 2008, public transport was suspended in the capital Yerevan, in a thinly-veiled effort to minimise attendance at a planned opposition rally (Shoghikian, 2008) . These examples demonstrate how the Kocharyan regime utilised various methods of restriction - both legislative and systematic - to effectively restrict the civil rights of the populace. His rule also cultivated a landscape in which speaking out against domestic violence was considered taboo, and many womens rights activists received death threats (Human Rights Watch, 2010) . Therefore, whilst the regime did not actively suppress women's rights, it did sustain a society in which such injustices were prevalent and cannot be absolved of accountability. Furthermore, the attacks on critical journalists further indicated a lack of institutional respect for basic human rights - violating rights to freedom of speech by attempting to control the media and suppress criticism Therefore, while human rights were available, they were regularly abused when the exercising of these rights were detrimental to the consolidation of regime power. The regime also did little to correct previous injustices. Q. 11 As previously discussed, there is little separation between the executive and the judiciary. Indepence is therefore implausible, as it is extremely unlikely the judiciary would make rulings at the detriment of the executive as the leverage they hold is likely too great. For example, with regards to the power of the Coucil of Justice, the President has the power to appoint as judges 'candidates acceptable to him.' Also, a judge who ruled against the tax authority was removed. With inseparable executive power within the judiciary, independent process is impossible. The Armenian judiciary also faces significant obstacles to becoming fair, as the ombudsman reveals that bribes are commonplace. Karen Andreasyan, the lawyer who headed the ombudsman investigation, contends that bribes range from roughly $500 to $50,000 USD - or 10% of the cost of lawsuits (Cassin, 2013) . As the judiciary, and relating legislation, existed during Kocharyan's rule - combined with the country's pervasive corruption - an independent and fair judiciary was a largely unachievable ideal. Q. 12 Few effective institutions existed to check and balance Kocharyan's power. An ombudsman existed (known as the Human Rights Defender), one which was purported to 'have free access to any state institution or organisation' according to parliament legislation (Kocharyan, 2003) . However, as the referenced legislation is one enacted by Kocharian himself, it is unsurprising that in effect the ombudsman lacked that power and authority. According to political analyst Simon Payaslian, the Human Rights Defender had no real legally-binding power to truly protect the citizens' human rights, and as an organisation was disorganised and inefficient. Combined with a corrupt and non-independent judiciary, few barriers stood between Kocharyan and true personal rule. Any checks and balances that existed were ineffective, and their bloated existence to appease international institutions and powers blocked the path of any efficient and effective models being instituted. As the classification discerns, such institutions can only be considered as 'checks and balances' if they are actually effective rather than merely existing, and thus in Armenia between 1998 and 2008 there were none. Q. 13 Kocharyan's regime had little cultural agenda. However two minority groups - the Yazidis and Jehovah's Witnesses - were systematically repressed. The Jehovah's Witnesses were seen by the government as a threat to the Armenian Apostilic Church and persecuted them as a result - preventing them from registering as a religious group and incarcerating members for refusing to serve in the military (US Department of State, 2009) . The Yazidis - a race of religious refugees - faced regular military hazing, poor police response rates to crime and high rates of poverty (US DoS, 2009) . Therefore, whilst minorities largely share the same rights as the majority of the populace, their rights are often restricted for various discriminatory reasons despite their equal statutory rights. This conclusion fits the classification mode well. Q. 14 I feel significantly assured in my classifications, as not only have I exacted extensive research from a broad range of reputable sources, I have also minimised the number of assumptions made to ensure my contentions are based fully in historical fact. However, I hesitate from marking myself as being absolutely confident, as I understand that there is always the potential for certain important information to be lost or skewed over time. There is always the potential for error. Q. 15 & 16 As previously discussed, the Armenian judiciary is corrupted - both from above (lack of independence from the executive) and below (bribery) . As well as this, however, there is evidence of severe mis-appropriation of public resources. In a 2008 investigation by journalist Ararat Davtyan, it was uncovered that tracts of land had been expropriated by the government under public domain laws. This land, however, was unjustly granted to an employee under the guise of an 'eminent domain' (Davtyan, 2008) . This revelation implies a further two kinds of corruption in the Armenian government; misuse of public resources by top officials, and special privileges granted to politically-connected people. While there is sufficient evidence to imply corruption at the state and official level, there is a lack sufficient information to discern whether this corruption extends further down the political structure. While the assumption that it does would not be unfounded or unlikely, my philosophy regarding this regime classification is to minimise the amount of assumptions made, and claims which lack significant evidence. Therefore, we may only conlude that these three types of corruption existed under Kocharyan, and that they occured only at certain levels of the regime structure, however concede that further corruption could feasibly have occurred at a number of state and civil levels. References: Babayan, N. (2015) . Democratic Transformation and Obstruction. Cassin, R. (2013) . Armenia Judges Have Price List For Bribes. CIA. (2015) . World Fact Book Davtyan, A. (2008) . Justification: Political Rights 1, I gave Sudan the classification of free voting because while everyone is entitled to vote, it is hard for opposition parties to appear legitimate and compete with the ruling National Congress Party. As it has formed a government with the second largest party in the country, the Sudan People's Liberation Movement, it is virtually unbeatable. However there is no chance another party could win and take power, as there are huge restrictions on the public space opposition can occupy during and leading up to elections (US State Dep.) There are also reported large polling irregularities and the European Union has refused to monitor elections. One could not call these elections fair. Political Rights 2, Universal suffrage exists for all Sudanese nationals over the age of 17 (ACRLI) Political Rights 3, it is legal to form opposition parties following 2000 legislation, with 72 registering for the 72 elections. However political clout lies with the NCP, and ruling elites in the capital city of Khartoum. Military power lies with the SPLM, which allied itself with the NCP (Minority Rights) . Other minor parties have no hope of being elected due to their marginalisation, and if they were then interference with the results would prevent them from taking power (US State Dep.) Political Rights 4, as mentioned above, only those within the Khartoum elite can rise to power, which on itself entails having considerable wealth and political social connections, which is why I chose this answer Political Rights 5, the interim constitution guarantees freedom of speech. However according to Freedom House reporters practice self-censorship and can face harassment for criticism of the government, In 2006 a journalist was found mysteriously dead after being charged with blasphemy. Universities also practice self-censorship in the same manner. Civil Liberties 1, It is clear that the state commits atrocities in such as during the Darfur conflict (BBC) there is also high level corruption throughout the state and police, meaning crimes are committed on a daily basis. It is also classified by US State department reports as a state sponsor of terroism Civil Liberties 2, People legal have these rights but not in practice, most greatly infringed upon is freedom of speech, as the government retains the majority of hard power so organised resistance is not such a concern, however if the government did decide to oppose a group or peoples mobility, then they are fully capable of doing so. This is in part inferred, as they have no independent judiciary. There are also confirmed cases of slavery in Sudan, and the leader and state have been found by the International Criminal Court to be guilty of war crimes. Women also have very little rights and representation in Sudan, and are restricted to where they can go and who with. Civil Liberties 3, legally the judiciary is free, however in practice it is appointed by the ruling elites (ACRLI) Civil Liberties 4, the elites have the power to do as they wish, however the coalition with the SPLM means that there are some checks. However in general corruption is widespread throughout the bureaucracy. Civil Liberties 5, there are laws I could find to protect minorities, as already mentioned, women are discriminated against, and much of the conflict historically in Sudan has come from conflict with minorities, be it race, religion, or culture. It is a very divisive nation. (BBC) (Freedom House) It is clear there is much corruption in Sudan across all levels, businesses find it hard to begin here due to the incredibly high cost of paying your way in to any area. Many investigators in corruption have been exiled from the country, and NGOs working on stopping it are prevented from doing work within the country. It is hard to find academic work on it as it appears it is prevented before it can actually be studied and written. (Perception Survey) (Researchgate) http://www.ecosonline.org/reports/2007/PerceptionSurveyonCorruption.pdf https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2007/sudan#.VVpbAJ2UceE http://www.minorityrights.org/4010/sudan/sudan-overview.html http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/3496731.stm Sudan. (2007) . In Country Reports on Human Rights Practices (Vol. 1-2, p. 526+) . U.S. Department of State. http://www.researchgate.net/publication/228322318_The_Failure_of_Education_in_Combating_Corruption_in_Sudan_The_Impact_on_Sustainable_Development

Justification: Guatemala Justification In 1996 Guatemala's civil war ended after three decade of conflict. The state was responsible for the vast majority of human rights abuses during the war and arguably committed genocide against the Mayan population. Following the war, a return to democracy took place, but the new democratic regime was beset with corruption and violence. 2-3. The years 1998-2006 have been chosen for research because two transitions in government occurred as a result of elections during this period whilst corruption remained widespread. 4. Guatemala received three points because elections in these years were 'meaningful' and 'fraud free' (Jon Moran, Crime and Corruption in New Democracies, UK: Palgrave Macmillan, 2011. p.119) . The 1999 election was 'largely free and fair' according to Freedom House. Changes of government are likely following elections in Guatemala. However, during the 2003 election there was some violence from supporters of a previous dictator General Efrain Rios Montt, but not enough to constitute significant barriers to the opposition gaining power (The Economist Intelligence Unit, Guatemala Politics: Oscar Night, New York: 2004) . 5. Guatemala had universal suffrage at 18 with the exception of members of the military and police who must remain at bunkers during elections, and as such receives two points. (CIA World Fact Book, https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2123.html ) . 6. There was effective opposition in Guatemala who regularly form governments as demonstrated in the transitions of power after the 1999 election where Portillo gained the Presidency and the 2003 election where Berger became president. As will be discussed later, media can be influenced in favour of the government, but this did not prevent opposition achieving victory. I have given them 3 though a 2.5 would have been more suitable option. 7. Guatemala received two points for the level of access its citizens have to political power. Guatemala did not fit the criteria for 1 point as many people do have effective access to power, but 2 points is overly generous, 1.5 would have been more suitable. In Guatemala there were no formal restrictions on access to power, but patriarchy and illiteracy led to serious disadvantages for women and indigenous peoples in utilising political power (Roman Krznarichtt, United Nations Human Development Report, 2005 http://hdr.undp.org/sites/default/files/hdr2005_krznaric_roman_17.pdf also Nineth Montenegro, The Challenge of Women's Political Participation in Guatemala, Sweden:2002, www.idea.int/publications/wip/upload/montenegro-CS-Guatemala.pdf ) . 8. Guatemala received one point because much media is privately owned and independent from the state, but prone to political influence. Journalists looking into human rights issues frequently received death threats and intimidation from the State and parallel power structures (Freedom House 2002, https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2002/guatemala#.VV5Rlvmqqkp ) . 9. Guatemala receives one point because the rule of Law was 'severely undermined' by the Judiciary's lack of independence and chronic corruption (Freedom House 1998, https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/1998/guatemala#.VV6CnPmqqkp ) . The President admitted that the 20,000-strong police were 'infiltrated by organised crime,' and there are 100,000 privately employed security workers who operate without regulation (Moran, p.122. also The Economist Intelligence Unit, Guatemala Politics: Impunity Rules, New York: 2006) . 10. Guatemala has received one point as citizens in this regime have access to fundamental human rights, but there is sometimes suppression and violence is common. People were freely able to form political parties and have constitutional rights, but violence from military, police, private security, gangs and 'death squads' lead to mistreatment of peasants and a climate of fear where rights are frequently breached by the state or other parties (Moran p.127. also The Economist, Guatemala Politics: Impunity Rules ) . 11. Guatemala's judiciary was plagued by corruption and manipulation by the State and criminal groups. If something reflects badly on the State it was not investigated, for example, military and General Rios Mont were not held to account for their actions in the civil war in these years ( Impunity Rules ) . Moran maintains that criminals were rarely brought to justice and that the judiciary is not effectively independent. Guatemala receives 0 points, not just for State interference in the judiciary but also that of criminal parallel power structures. 12. I have given Guatemala two points for this section. The judiciary had no role in holding the governing regime to account. Opposition in congress did not appear to be meaningfully hold the government to account in these years. Guatemala had an ombudsman but their role in these years is not clearly visible in sources ( Inter-American Development Bank, 2005 http://www.iadb.org/en/projects/project-description-title,1303.html?id=GU-T1017 ) . In Guatemala non-government organisations aided in holding the governing regimes to account, such as the office of the UN Commissioner for Human Rights (Human Rights Watch, 2010, http://www.hrw.org/world-report-2010/guatemala ) . 13. Guatemala receives one point. Despite minority groups gaining a statutory right in the indigenous Indian language becoming used in courtrooms, they barely featured in the nations police force recruits (Freedom House 2005) . Indigenous people who frequently come from rural or more impoverished backgrounds were often politically disenfranchised due to location or illiteracy. 14. I am confident in my research as I found much quality material from Freedom House, the Economist and published academics. 15. All sources agree that corruption was pervasive and endemic in Guatemala. The President admitted to corruption in the Police involved in drug crime, Moran draws attention to the corruption of the 'higher slopes of power' such as the judiciary, central government and institutions who protect the military, elites and organised crime. Transparency International's Corruption Perception index 2005 awarded the country a low rating of 2.5/10, indicating widespread perceptions of corruption ( http://www.transparency.org/research/cpi/cpi_2005 ) . 16. The aforementioned sources describe each of the selected forms of corruption being perpetrated by groups and individuals at the high and low levels.

Justification: When conducting my research for Belarus I choose 1990 as my starting year as it was when Belarus declared state sovereignty. This is important as it pinpoints a subconscious move to democratic measures, however it is important to note that Belarus had strong ties with Russia and therefore Russia had some influence in the government workings of the state. The main reference year is 1995 as it was when the first parliamentary elections took place. The actions by those in power particularly influenced my answers to the Political Rights and Civil Liberties questions. The final point of reference was 2000 as I wanted to look at 5 years prior to 1995 and after, but mainly focusing on 1995. When determining the answers for these questions I looked at the Transparency International Corruption Index as well as a US report on Belarus in 1995 (found here: http://dosfan.lib.uic.edu/ERC/democracy/1995_hrp_report/95hrp_report_eur/Belarus.html) POLITICAL RIGHTS: 'Political Rights 1: Are there free and fair elections for this state's executive and legislature?' For this question I looked at the main example of elections in the decade of research and this was the 1995 elections. The 1995 elections can be deemed to have been very limited as the government heavily restricted the ability of other parties to advertise candidates and their ideologies of what they would do if they got into power. The International community did not view the elections as free and fair and ultimately four referendums took place in order to get the parliament to resemble an acceptable structure. However, all voting was influenced as a result I gave the answer of: '1 point: There are elections for the executive and the legislature but there is a very low likelihood of government change via elections.' as there was influence on the general public and very little information offered regarding other parties in the election, the Government also engaged in a lot of propaganda to channel the voting of the public. 'Political Rights 2: Does this country allow universal suffrage?' For this Question I answered: '2 points: The majority of people in this country are able to vote. However, there are minor restrictions because of things such as age or incarceration, etc.' I answered this as generally everyone in the public from the information I looked at was able to vote including women as long as they were over 18 and were not incarcerated. 'Political Rights 3: Is there an effective opposition and is there a possibility for it to be elected to govern?' The opposition parties in this period were so downplayed and had no opportunity to advertise and make themselves, as well as their ideologies known, that the opposition parties were not effective as a whole nor was there a possibility for them to govern. Public awareness was heavily limited and the smear campaigns that were being initiated meant that I answered: 1 point: There is an opposition, however its numbers are minuscule and often never heard from. There is no chance for it to gain power.' This process of elections means that there is no chance of political shift and implies a corrupt state. 'Political Rights 4: Do all people have effective access to political power?' The Government allows anyone to have access to political power, although gender is a restriction as there are fewer opportunities for women to get involved regardless of the fact that they earn equal pay to men. Although the government allows anyone access to political power the amount of political power is debateable purely due to the influence and the tactics initiated in the 1995 elections. Hence why the following answer was involved: '2 points: Many people have access to political power, with some exceptions.' 'Political Rights 5: Is there a free, independent and well-resourced media that is able to act as a check and balance on power?' The government in this time period maintained the idea of a 'free media' however, the government owns all of the publishing and news corporations. This restricts the medias ability to be able to place checks on power as anything that is printed is heavily censored by government involvement, from the research it is also noted that slandering the government was an offense. This is why this question was given the following answer: '1 point: Independent media may exist, but there is heavy censorship, self-censorship or government intervention in editorial processes.' CIVIL LIBERTIES: 'Civil Liberties 1: Does this regime uphold the rule of law?' The regime seems to take the law and adapt it in a way that benefits those in charge more, although they do uphold a majority of the law some of it is manipulated or ignored to a certain extent. This can be seen through my answers for the political rights section and therefore influenced my answer here: '2 points: The rule of law is generally upheld, but notable and significant breaches do occur.' 'Civil Liberties 2: Do all citizens within this regime have access to fundamental human rights, including: Freedom of Assembly and Association; Freedom of Speech and Expression; Freedom of Mobility? ' All of these civil liberties in the time period were heavily restricted as discussed in the US report on Belarus. The report outlined the government's views and how these impacted the individuals in society. 'Civil Liberties 3: Does this country have a free, independent and fair judiciary?' Due to the information provided this question and the one below were educated guesses as all the evidence contemplated pointed at the fact that Belarus did not have a free, independent and fair judiciary. 'Civil Liberties 4: Does this country have effective processes in order to hold the governing regime accountable? These could be measures such as independent Ombudsman, inquiries, parliamentary question time, an upper house of parliament, select committees, etc. These processes must have some real effectiveness, not just exist on paper.' This question was also an educated guess as the actions that occurred in the 1995 elections and the way in which the government restricted behaviours in the general public made it very unlikely that there was anything in place to make the governing regime accountable. 'Civil Liberties 5: Does this country uphold the right to equal treatment and due process for minority groups?' It was established on the Human Rights report conducted on Belarus that the government had laws and fundamental practices put in place to help the minority groups in Belarus in this time period. The main reason I did not give it the full marks for this question was because that although there was equal pay for women, women's opportunities were restricted and it was incredibly hard for them to get into governmental positions. This restricted access to opportunities also meant that being a woman became a minority group. Another issue I had with this was that although there were laws in place for the disabled when the government had not put aside money to be able to alter public buildings to allow for easier access. The government encouraged equal treatment of minority groups however it has some flaws, which meant I gave it, the following answer: '2 Points: There are legal and statutory rights, but there is active social and procedural discrimination and inequality towards groups or minorities, such as over-representation in the criminal justice system and electoral systems which lock minority groups out of power.' CONCLUSION: Belarus has a government that seemed to manipulate the laws in order to benefit the officials and made it incredibly hard to develop any form of opposition rendering the elections that took place in 1995 particularly useless as many voters did not even know that there were any other parties in the election as they couldn't campaign. Belarus establishes itself as a corrupt country due to the government manipulation of laws, political restrictions and restrictions on the fundamental human rights.

Justification: Regime Period: 2001-2006 represent one Chadian Presidential term which I use to demarcate the regime period. It includes key events like an election of the National Assembly, two Presidential elections, a constitutional referendum, and a coup, aiding examination of civil and political rights in action to ascertain Chad's condition in order to classify it. Approach The first step was establishing whether or not each political or civil feature (e.g. elections) was present. If so, next was determining the condition of the feature (i.e. whether it's free, fair, independent etc.) and the degree of the condition (i.e. how effective or limited this feature is, the amount of people included, etc.) . It wasn't enough to establish the presence of governing process since it doesn't guarantee robust or proper practice so I utilized two types of information: the provisional, technical, law/policy-based and the evaluative, critical, report/news based. The former is useful to establish whether the features are present, and the possibility and some extent of their formal presence and practice. The latter is important to understand the reality of the practice of these provisions and whether, in actuality, they work effectively as intended. Both types were weighed and used evenly in the final calculation of each rating. Every section (labeled in this justification) includes supporting background information in justification of each answer. Sources All sources used in this research project are as credible as possible. The information attained from them is generally regime-period specific. Most sources dealt with the technical, formal processes, and were readily enough available. The issue was finding sources that dealt with the evaluative side of actual practice. Freedom House 'places a greater emphasis on whether these rights are implemented in practice' . They were a baseline for further independent research (as far as possible) with the African Elections Database, Electoral Institute for Sustainable Democracy in Africa (E.I.S.A.), European Union, Global Edge (Michigan State University), Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance (I.D.E.A.), Inter-Parliamentary Union, Knoema, Reporters Without Borders, and World Bank. Challenges Three key challenges during this project were source language, information limitation, and system terminology and definition. 1. Source Language: Many reports and Chadian news cites were solely in their official language, French, making it difficult to obtain information in English in order to understand and supplement other reputable sources. This was a barrier to research scope and understanding by limiting the extent of research. 2. Information Limitation: Though Chad has some degree of prominence as an African country it was difficult to find information/reports on the reality of civil liberties and political rights. While some sources like Freedom House and the European Union documented the condition of these regime features, it was hard to find additional supporting information. I suspect there isn't a great deal of literature surrounding Chadian civil liberties and political rights in readily accessible locations and forms, though there was information on technical procedures and policies. Further, it was difficult to find relevant information for the regime period since many sources started documentation from 2006/7 onward. Since Chad is an African country I believe in general there is a lack if literature that analyses African regimes, and those that do lack a breadth in coverage. 3. System Terminology and Definitions: Some terminology in the RCE was undefined; problematic since the quality of the answers depend on a clear understanding of what is being asked or is meant. Specific issues are further addressed under each individual section justification. To resolve this it would have been useful to have a glossary of key terms and their definitions -the main ones being 'free', 'fair' -and the scope of terms like 'universal suffrage' . For continuity, once terminology like 'free' were defined, I employed it consistently for subsequent use. Classification Summary According to this system Chad is semi-democratic, rating ­­15 out of 30. This is due to the presence of formal democratic institutions and process that function minimally but aren't effective and capacble of restraining power. Heavy corruption and misuse also contributes. Freedom House classed Chadian political rights and civil liberties unchangingly between 2001-2006, with Chad consistently rating 6 for political rights, 5 for civil liberties, and a freedom rating of 5.5, (with 7 as the worst for each) . These ratings, as an initial indicator, were fairly aligned with my own research. Technically between 2001-2006 at least, Chad was a republic and seemed to have many political institutions but there is a discrepancy between the Freedom House ranking and apparent formal republican 'democratic'process on paper. Additional research showed that the functions of political institutions that govern rights or check power, like media, judiciary, elections, were dysfunctional. The rule of law was often an excuse to inflict oppression and consolidate power. Chad definitely has oppression, particularly censorship, political terror, and the prevention of free association, undermining civil liberties. There are also many cases in which groups opposed to the state engage in political terror that undermines other freedoms. Definitions 'Free and fair'* is defined as per Levitsky and Way's understanding. 'Free'is when there is virtually no fraud or intimidation of voters (citizens), and 'fair'when opposition parties campaign on relatively even footing. (In relation to media and judiciary -free is the near absence of fraud or intimidation; fair is the nonpartisan nature of operation/action.) ( Source: 'Competitive Authoritarianism: Hybrid Regimes After the Cold War, Steven Levitsky and Luncan A. Way) 'Political power'is defined as 'the ability held by individuals and groups in a society that allows them to create and enforce policies for the community and manage public resources.' ( Source: http://study.com/academy/lesson/political-power-definition-types-sources.html ) POLITICAL RIGHTS Question 1 Chad has a plurality/majority [1] system with two elections, the National Assembly (elected from and proportional representation constituencies) and Presidential ( elected via an absolute majority) [2] . While there are many issues with accuracy of real turn out or coercive influencing factors, voter turnout is useful to begin with because no proper election has 100% turnout, but no functioning democracy has too low a turnout roughly below 40% (if so, legitimacy of the elected governing body is difficult to establish) . Voter turnout in 2001 Presidential elections was roughly 61.12%-61.37%. In 2002 National Assembly elections turnout was 52.04%, and 2006 Presidential elections had 53.08% turnout; indicating some genuine electoral activity [3] . Particularly interesting is that 'power has never changed hands through the ballot box in Chad, and previous elections which returned Deby to power in 1996 and 2001 were denounced as fraudulent by opposition leaders.' [4] There are processes for anti-corruption such as 'verified'demonstration that ballot boxes are empty and sealed; voter identification; voter's finger is marked with indelible ink; polling booths placed to shield the voters from observation during voting; and counting commencement at the polling station immediately after polling, observed by candidates and candidate agents. There is a ban on vote buying and on state resources being used in favour or against a political party or candidate. However, there is no data available regarding the need for reports on political finance in general or election-related finances, nor for such information to be made public, and there is no institution designated to receive reports [5] . There is no law or code of conduct governing election observers however Chad has an electoral code and electoral management body [6] . There are two Electoral Management Bodies, the Commission Electorale Nationale Indépendante (CENI; National Independent Electoral Commission) and the Constitutional Council (CC) . More here. The EU Observational report provided information on, and insight into, issues encountered in the 2001 Presidential elections such as election irregularities; restriction freedom of demonstration; restricting media freedom; political detainment/violence - Amnesty International documents excessive force by security forces including throwing tear gas canisters at the protesters, and six presidential candidates and some of their associates were briefly detained [7] ; and election fraud. The 2006 elections were the first in Chad with no participation by a major opposition candidate. Most political parties in Chad boycotted the elections in response to President Déby's decision to run for a third term. In 2005, a constitutional amendment scrapped the two-term limit, allowing Déby's third-term run. In the two elections past, there were 15 and seven candidates respectively, including some opposition heavyweights [8] . An attempted coup was made on 14 March 2006, but was put down by members of the army loyal to Déby. Critics said 'that with all key opposition leaders refusing to field candidates, the elections have become meaningless' ; 'many people say the polls will not be free and fair [9] . Conclusion: Though there are technical legal provisions for elections and their management, the reality of Chadian governance with election irregularities and violence, the conditions for free and fair transition of power weren't present. Further, that this is historically commonplace in Chad is highly indicative of the dysfunctionality of Chad's elections. Chad is rated 1 accordingly. ISSUE: The RCE didn't provide a definition for 'free' and 'fair' so I used Levitsky and Way's . and broadly employed it for subsequent uses. [1] http://www.idea.int/uid/countryview.cfm?id=213#Electoral%20System%20Design [2] http://www.electionguide.org/countries/id/43/, http://www.content.eisa.org.za/old-page/chad-electoral-system [3] http://www.content.eisa.org.za/old-page/chad-voting-statistics-overview [4] http://www.irinnews.org/report/58943/chad-opposition-denounce-presidential-poll [5] http://www.idea.int/uid/countryview.cfm?id=213 [6] http://www.content.eisa.org.za/old-page/chad-electoral-legislation [7] http://www.refworld.org/docid/3cf4bc0219.html [8] http://www.irinnews.org/report/58566/chad-opposition-denounces-poll-as-masquerade-refuses-to-field-candidate [9] http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/4967594.stm Question 2 Chad allows those over 18 years, with Chadian citizenship, and full possession of civil and political rights, to vote. Disqualifications included insanity, criminal conviction, undischarged bankrupts, contempt of court, prison sentence of at least two months for certain offences. ( Source: http://www.ipu.org/parline/reports/2061_B.htm ) Conclusion: Given that Chad has numerous reasons like incarceration for disqualification from suffrage, but not restrictive on more arbirtrary, unalienable grounds like race, ethnicity, or gender, Chad is rated 2 accordingly. ISSUE: The '3 points'rating 'universal suffrage'is misleading. I don't believe any country exists with universal suffrage in the full extent so it would perhaps skew the data of the project since those points are unattainable. Question 3 Incumbent President Deby and his party Mouvement partriotique de salut (MPS) have been in power since 2001 with 63.17 % of the votes, through to 2006 with 64.67% of the votes. In the 2002 National Assembly elections they won the majority of the seats (113/155 or 72.90%) [1] . Though Chad has an opposition (notably not participating in the 2006 elections), they are severly disadvantaged. They must finance itself independently and privately [2] . And with censorship and bias of media [3] and threats of political violence, they have little avenue for promotion or safe platform to campaign [4] . Conclusion: Given Amnesty reports of political detentions and violence on opposition candidates, the 2006 boycott by opposition parties in protest of the unfair and unfree elections, and the bias and restriction against opposition parties regarding campaign funding that creates an uneven playing field, Chad is rated 2 accordingly. [1] http://www.content.eisa.org.za/old-page/chad-election-archive [2] http://www.content.eisa.org.za/old-page/chad-political-parties-party-membership-and-party-founders [3] http://www.pressreference.com/Be-Co/Chad.html [4] http://www.refworld.org/docid/3cf4bc0219.html Question 4 One form of power is the ability to politically participate or be elected. Chadians can run as candidates as long as they are 25 years+, have Chadian citizenship, resided in Chad for at least one year, and are able to read and write French or Arabic. Persons under guardianship or having acquired Chadian nationality in the last 10 years are ineligible [1] . Further, any citizen is free to join a party of choice, but no one may be forced to join a party, be professionally prejudiced as a result of a party membership or belong to more than one party at a time. Other opportunities include holding public office. Beyond being elected into the National Assembly there was little-to-no information (in English) available about how public officers are elected. Another political power opportunity is a referendum, which can provide checks on executive power. Though Chadians have legal provisions for mandatory and optional referendums at national level, it is ineffective since they have no legal provisions for citizens or agenda initiatives at national level and there is no quorum for a referendum to be valid and no legislation specifying requirements for referendum to be valid [2] . Conclusion: Technically Chad has provisions for political power. But given the issues with arbitrary political detention and violence (for instance see here ), Chad doesn't have proper political power because these features may impede, prohibit, deter, or coerce citizens to avoid authentic electoral expression (via voting etc.) or from pursuing freely, honest political actions, opinions, or decisions. Chad is rated 1 accordingly. ISSUES: No definition was included regarding the meaning and scope of 'political power'. Chadian political power wasn't easily conceived as any of the scale rating and seemed to fall in between 1 and 2. Given the absence of necessary information about the ability for Chadians to hold public office and manage public resource and that most avenues of general power exercise are ineffective, I rated Chad a 1. [1] http://www.ipu.org/parline/reports/2061_B.htm [2] http://www.idea.int/elections/dd/search.cfm# Question 5 T hough the 1996 multiparty Constitution 'officially guarantees freedom of speech and freedom of the press', in practice 'the government severely restricts press freedom' [1] . Freedom House rates Chad 74/100 for press freedom in 2002, only slightly improving in 2006 to 73/100 [2] . The Reporters without Borders annual 2002 report states free press isn't present, echoed in Amnesty International's 2002 annual report. Actions like 'criticizing the president or other government officials, reporting on the northern rebellion, or casting government officials in an unfavorable light are sufficient causes for landing journalists and parliamentarians-and occasionally even private citizens-in jail.' Further, 'considerable censorship exists in Chad -both self-censorship practiced by editors, journalists, and broadcasters, and active censorship by the government, anxious to preserve its position and to not risk losing control again of the country in a coup or riot situation.' [3] More here, here, and here . Conclusion: Despite technical provisions, it's overwhelmingly evident Chadian media is far from free and fair; Chad is rated 1 accordingly. [1] http://www.pressreference.com/Be-Co/Chad.html [2] https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2013/chad#.VVH_Iut63zQ [3] http://www.pressreference.com/Be-Co/Chad.html CIVIL LIBERTIES Question 1 Chad has a constitution with any amendment initiative comes from the President after consultation. No amendment may be made while emergency power is in effect or during the office of an acting President. It was adopted in 1996 and establishes the framework of the Chadian state/government, specifying the rights and freedoms of its citizens. Recent 2005 amendments have eliminated term limits for presidency [1] . Chad also has a legal system, and the judiciary, courts, and police act as extensions for the rule of law though there was little in the way of sources accessible to reveal the extent to which the rule of law is upheld. The World Bank's Governance Indicator did however show Chad ranking poorly in rule of law here [2] . Conclusion: Chad has numerous violations of fundamental human rights however the reasons for violation generally speaking, like defamation laws, meant that technically the rule of law was upheld. In this case the rule of law was a pretense for oppression and control. Chad is rated 2 accordingly. [1] http://globaledge.msu.edu/countries/chad/government [2] http://internationalbudget.org/wp-content/uploads/Chads-Oil-Miracle-or-Mirage.pdf Question 2 Though legalities like the constitution are supposed to be the framework upholding civil liberties and various freedoms, the reality is far removed. Amnesty International cite attacks on freedom of expression, association, and assembly. Their 2002 annual report states freedom of expression continues 'to be threatened and human rights defenders work in a climate of intimidation and danger.' [1] Freedom of expression was undermined as the legislative elections approached; 'Non-state radio stations would not be allowed to broadcast political programs or debates during the electoral campaign.' [2] 'Michaël Didama, acting editor of the newspaper Le Temps, received a six-month suspended sentence after being found guilty of defamation in January. He was also ordered to pay substantial damages. The complaint& was lodged by one of President Déby's nephews after Le Temps alleged that a number of attempted coups had been carried out by relatives of President Déby.' [3] In particular are issues around the Chad-Cameroon oil pipeline. 'Protests against the recruitment policy of a French firm involved in an oil pipeline were arrested in Bam and& detained. They were released without charge or trial after three days.' Human rights defenders working outside the capital, N'Djaména, are particularly vulnerable to arbitrary arrest. More here . Conclusion: Whilst some rights are present (at least on paper), and exercised to a degree, robust rights are actively denied and those exercising them brutally dealt to. Chad is rated 1 accordingly. [1] http://www.pressreference.com/Be-Co/Chad.html [2] http://www.refworld.org/docid/3edb47e018.html [3] http://www.refworld.org/docid/3cf4bc0219.html Question 3 Chad has a judiciary consisting of a Supreme Court of sixteen members, the court of highest ordinary jurisdiction and also hears disputes about local elections, the Courts of Appeal, Tribunals and Magistrates' Courts. It has a Presiding Judge appointed by the President. There are eight President-appointed judges and seven Speaker-appointed judges. Court members are only removed from office if convicted of criminality. It was incredibly difficult to access information but one source detailed its inadequate and weak institutional capacity, is not always independent or impartial in civil matters, and is 'ineffective, underfunded, overburdened, and subject to executive interference' . 'Intimidation and violence against judicial branch members were also problems, and members of the judiciary sometimes received death threats or were demoted or removed from their positions for not acquiescing to pressure from officials.' (More here and here ) . Conclusion: Due to the weak state of the judiciary, corruption of process, and unhealthy executive influence, Chad was rated a 1 accordingly. Question 4 Chad has a few checks and balances in place, including an Ombudsman who is supposed to oversee reports of the Government administration and of public services or establishments. There are also oral and written questions parliamentarians may pose to a minister with reply mandatory within fifteen days. The parliament 'exercises this control by means of committees of inquiry and control, via hearings before the committees, as well as by missions to the relevant government sectors. Besides the questions, interpellations may also be addressed to the Government. However, only members of the Government intervene in the plenary.' ( Source: http://www.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/CtrlParlementaire/2061_F.htm ) Conclusion: While it is evident there are checks and balances, I wouldn't say they are effective and restrain power, evident in the (dys) function of institutions (see judiciary) and imbalance favourably disposed towards the executive. Chad is rated 2 accordingly. Question 5 There is little information on minority protection. The UN Refugee Agency s tates, whilst the government adopted a law in 2006 including the promotion of tolerance and respect for other cultures as one of the objectives of the educational system, discrimination against minorities in Chad continues [1] . Women remain largely discriminated against in Chad despite the constitution providing equal rights for all citizens. In practice there is a big inequality between men and women (who are underrepresented in government and decision-making positions) [2] . Societal discrimination also occurs routinely by members of virtually all ethnic groups, evident in patterns of buying and employment, 'of de facto self-segregation in urban neighborhoods, and in the paucity of interethnic marriages, especially across the north-south divide.' [3 ] Conclusion: Though there are legal provisions, discriminatory practice is evident on the basis of gender, ethnicity, and other minority demographics. Chad is rated 2 accordingly. [1] http://www.refworld.org/docid/4c33311c2.html [2] http://www.makeeverywomancount.org/index.php?option=com_fjrelated&view=fjrelated&id=101&Itemid=100 [3] http://www.ncbuy.com/reference/country/humanrights.html?code=cd&sec=5 Corruption Summary Chad is an incredibly corrupt country with issues of extortion, cronyism, nepotism, misuse of public resources, and illegal trade, perpetuated by weak institutions, greed, and civil and political instability and violence. It's also perpetuated by the 'resource curse'; 'once the money is flowing, the unholy trinity of oil, power and corruption will make corrective action difficult' [1] . Transparency International data only went as far back as 2004, with Chad ranking very low between 2004-2006. In 2004 it tied with Myanmar with a CPI score of 1.7 (0 being the most highly corrupt), tying with Bangladesh in 2005 with the same score. In 2006 it slightly improved to 2.0. This score relates to perceptions of the degree of corruption as seen by business people and country analysts. The '2003/4 Public Institution Index -an influential ranking of the strength and integrity of laws and institutions and the presence of corruption published by the World Economic Forum -placed Chad at the bottom of the list of 21 countries surveyed.' [2] Further investigation revealed that, 'corruption, nepotism and the sheer murkiness of Chad's government have seen much of the cash either frittered away on non-existent projects or fattening public contracts run by the president's inner clan.' For example, 'members of the president's inner circle have formed ad hoc companies and charities to benefit from government contracts. An independent committee set up to monitor oil spending produced a report last year suggesting corruption was alive and well [3] . It also comes from 'civil servants who are not paid' [4] and even goes as far where 'in some cases, tax and customs authorities may facilitate evasion only to return later to pursue the infractions they facilitated.' [5] The 'corruption or abuse of office by the police and military are widespread'. [6] Other examples are arms embargoing [7], illegal animal trade [8] . An apt quote from Nadjikimo Benoudjita, the editor of Notre Temps (one of Chad's few opposition papers) says: 'Corruption isn't just a part of Chad: it is everything.' Justification: I have chosen the periods beginning at 1989 up until 2015 (present) as Omar al-Bahir carried out a coup in 1989 and installed a military government, where in 2003 he made himself president of Sudan. He is currently in power and thus his effective regime stems from 1989 till now. The evidence I considered when answering these questions comes from a variety of different sources and of varying degrees of insightfulness and information. One of the sources consulted (transparency.org, link will be appear below) states 'There is little data and research available on the country's state of governance and on corruption, particularly on its impact' . This is echoed throughout when conducting further research as there multiple sources suggesting very high levels of corruption but had very little specific evidence or in depth analysis for which to work with. However, one claim that is commonly made it that the regime of Sudan is one of most corrupt in the world and at all levels of society, this gives some perspective when making judgements where relevant data is unavailable. As stated before, there is little available data on the specific corruption within Sudan's regime so naturally some of the questions answered were 'educated guesses'. These guesses were made in light of other information that will be listed at the end but I am confident that they fall within the general consensus that Sudan is extremely corrupt, at least from an observer view. Furthermore, because of a lack of available and credible information, finding sources to directly answer some of the questions was difficult. But given the information I have that indicated that corruption is very prevalent in Sudan, most of the questions were not difficult but more independent judgement calls. The research results did not suggest answers that do not fit well the options. Being ranked as one of the most corrupt countries that are monitored, there was little doubt that a lot of the answers given tended to give very low scores and fitted into the more extreme options well. Below is a list of the sources and SOME of the evidence quoted (Some sources contained a great deal of general information whereas other had not so much) . It would be impractical here to give all of the evidence consulted in answering the questions, so extracts of good evidence have been given. Further and wider details about corruption in Sudan that were consulted can be found in the links. Sources: http://www.transparency.org/files/content/corruptionqas/342_Corruption_and_anti-corruption_in_Sudan.pdf 'There is little data and research available on the country's state of governance and on corruption, particularly on its impact.' 'Corruption can be found in all sectors of the economy and at all levels of the state apparatus in Sudan' http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/world/sudan/corruption.htm 'Sudan's public sector is perceived as one of the most corrupt in the world, ranking 173 out of 174 nations in the 2012 Transparency International Corruption Perceptions Index. In a November 2012 address to parliament, Sudan's Auditor General declared 175 million dollars had been stolen from September 2011 -August 2012.' http://www.hrw.org/news/2014/12/10/dispatches-another-declaration-another-sudan-crackdown 'These arrests, tragically, are not surprising in Sudan, where authorities routinely silence dissent. NISS and members of other security organs continue to detain, often without charge, those who express opposition to the policies of the government -whether through political declarations, protests, articles, or simply attending events.' http://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jan/22/we-are-the-victims-of-our-own-corrupt-government-life-as-an-activist-in-sudan 'The Sudanese government routinely silences the peoples'dissent. Human Rights Watch recently reported that Bashir's government frequently detains without charge anyone who opposes it 'whether through political declarations, protests, articles, or simply attending events.' 'In the past six months, the government has tried to wipe out their opposition' http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2015/04/bashir-sweeps-sudan-election-150427111551251.html 'A statement issued on April 20 by the United States, the United Kingdom and Norway criticised 'Sudan's failure to create a free, fair, and conducive elections environment', concluding that 'the outcome of these elections cannot be considered a credible expression of the will of the Sudanese people'. This follows earlier criticism by the European Union.' https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2012/sudan#.VWQ7p0anHgM 'National elections mandated by the CPA were held in 2010. The process was undermined by intimidation, vote-rigging, and restrictions on freedom of expression by the NCP in the North and the SPLM in the South.' 'Sudan is not an electoral democracy. Although the first multiparty elections in 24 years were held in 2010, they were plagued by irregularities and failed to meet international standards, according to monitors from the United States, the European Union, and Sudan itself.'
