Justification: Question 4 : I have said there were no elections held during this time because from when the military took power in 2006 until the recent democratic election in 2014, citizens of Fiji were not able to vote on their government. There were promises by the military of democrtic elections for 2009 but these were postponed until 2014. While it could be said this was just a period between elections (as we have in New Zealand e.g. 2011-2014), it is still considered to have not had elections as this was an 8 year period. For this infomation, I looked at 'Fiji's forst election in eight years: Why so many coups in paradise?', a CNN article, for some general information on the (then) upcoming vote and what Fiji's politics had been like since 2006. Question 5: I again had some technical difficulty answering this question as FIjian's did have the irght to vote, were promised they would still retain the righht to vote in the upcomong elections and did vote in the 2014 elections. However, I concluded they did not have sufferage as this is a democratic feature allowing citizens the right to vote and during the coup their were no elections for Fijian to vote on. Again I used CNN for this background information. Question 6: There was opposition to Bainimarama's regime. Many did not agree with his power believing it was illegal but the regime did not give them the ability to voice their opinions. Many opposers were alledgedly questioned and detained. The coup did allow opposition to run in elections, as there wer eno elections, thus there was little to no opporutnity for opposers to gain power. I looked at a report from the Nautilus Institution, 'Background to 2006 Fiji Military Coup', for this information. Question 7: A military coup, like this one in Fiji, does not allow citizens to participate in the country's politics. Opposers to the regime ofte faced consequences and there were elections thus no opportunity for others to gain political power. Question 8: Initially following the coup, media in FIji boycotted against the regime's attempt at censorship - key news programmes did not air and national nespapers were not published immeidately following the coup but were running agains soon after. While the media in Fiji was allowed and not completely governed by the military, media outlets who criticised the interim government found themselves facing reprecussions. Question 9: Only the military held power - there was no separtion of powers (the military had influence over the judiciary, legislature and executive), no transparency or acocuntability of the militaries actions or due process. This conclusioni s from the New Zealand Law Society's article 'Fiji sentences show continued erosion of rule of law'. Question 10: I had difficulties answering this as from hearing accounts of those livingin Fiji during this time, both locals and foreginers, many were content with their rights under the interim govenrment as their was minimal change to everyday life. However factual information Question 11: While there was suggestions of political influence over the judiciary, Freedom House in their 2009 report stated the judiciary was reletavely free and fair, the main issue being only the lack of resources, common in a developing country. Question 12: The executive had total control with no accountability to the legilsture or others though in the consitution there were checks in balance that were not met in the reality of the coup - this is a common feature of a military coup. Question 13: Relationships betwene Indo-Fijian and ethic Fijians are said to be one of the factors leading to the coup. Follwoing the taking of power by Bainimarama, an ethic Fijian, there were reports Indo-Fijians, often of the Hindu rleigion, were subjected to some discrimination by the majorty population. I look at Freedom House's report for information on this. Question 14: As there are conflicting views within Fiji and the world on the matter, if it difficult decide what ones to give more weight to and hard to not let my own opinions influence my conclusions. I have looked at both factual information and opinions of people living in Fiji during the coup and thin kthis allowed me to get a good understanding of the environment on both a personal and objective level. Question 15/16: Again this was difficult to answer but after looking at Transparency International and Freedom House, I came to the conclusion that there was some corruption within the interim government largely to do with bribery.

Corruption_types: "Special privileges granted to politically-connected people"
Justification: Party opposition did exist, but the political climate suffer ed from oligarchic, personal/ presidential-driven tendencies. Parties were vehicles for the presidential candidate and their names were more for branding purposes than reflective of any ideology. As a prime example, the United Liberal Democrats were lead by Kim Jong-Pil, the reactionary/conservative candidate (Morriss 181) . C orruption in South Korea during this period was not systemic, but some held over from the authoritarian 'fifth republic' . Peter Morriss' article on the South Korean elections of 1996 was especially helpful here. The presidential rather than party/ideological nature of Korean politics here is of note, as is the oligarchic practical restriction of standing for election limited to those who had money or military connections. Morriss points out that, ironically, President Kim's anti-corruption reform platform was undercut by a scandal involving one of his closest aides having their own corrupt practises made public (184) . The inverse of this argument is that the very fact it came to light, rather than obscured by the president exercising executive power and deep pockets, is a sign of increasing transparency for South Korea during this time. Morriss does concede that many of the NKD's reforms were successful in furthering transparent democratic rule (183) . Corruption at this time consisted of cronyism rather than systemic bribe-taking or leaders accruing personal wealth. Freedom House's statistics on press freedom for South Korea are intriguing. Newspapers and news organisations were privately-owned, and there were no major censorship laws like those seen in China. Yet, there was much precedent for the suing of journalists for libel, that is, publishing works with falsehoods about public figures (including government leaders) in them. Journalists were in fact jailed during this time after accusations of libel, according to Freedom House. That the judiciary was (and is) independent meant this was not simply sneaky way for politicians to get rid of pesky news hounds on a whim -actual libellous statements needed to be proved beyond reasonable doubt, as with any other case. While this source is from 2002, there is little to indicate that press freedom was significantly lower or higher mid-way through the period studied. This does mean I relied upon an educated guess, taking into account analysis of earlier elections which did not directly state the level of press freedom at that time, and inferring from those. Many sources noted that press freedom was relatively stable until taking a turn for the more censored around 2008. This is not within my scope of study, but is helpful in ascertaining that press freedom was not far worse before 1997, otherwise there would presumably be much material on the matter, rather than academic silence. In 'South Korea's Miraculous democracy', Hahm Chaibong claims that South Korean politics at this time held on to a deeply-ingrained political culture of authoritarian strains, adding that: '...rampant corruption emerged from a political system and a public long accustomed to political expediency based on personalism and cronyism rather than agreed-upon procedures and the rule of law.' (130) I awarded only two points to the rule of law criterion for this reason, in conjunction with other research on the judiciary. This was the only academic source to produce such a concise and useful quote, but there were many others which supported the assertion. Indeed, it was borne out both in the occasional scandals and general culture of Korean politics at this time (i.e. giving death sentences to previous presidents for their 'corruption', albeit later pardoning them) . Most evidence for the judiciary question came from Freedom House 's report on it, published in 1998. Though n ot directly from the time-frame studied, most o f it speaks for a pre-1998 state of the courts . It elaborates upon the history of Korea's democracy while showing how the judiciary has, despite some minor ups and downs, been relatively free since the transition to Kim Young Sam's presidential office in 1992. Checks on the executive other than those provided by the judiciary were similar then as they are now. Impeachment by the legislature is possible, as was shown in 2004 when President Roh Moo Hyun was impeached, and this right had existed since the constitutional overhaul in 1987 (Chaibong 137) . It is likely that, though it was not used until 2004, this power could indeed have existed as a political reality were it attempted before 1997. More tangible checks have existed for as long as Korea's tentative democracy has, such as the opposition being prone to violence toward an executive they see as trying to curtail democracy. Sometimes this is borne out literally, as in the case of the opposition using sledgehammers to bash down a barricade by the government set up to stop them entering the chamber (see the Telegraph article) . Checks on executive abuse are not always from the creation of independent bodies like an Ombudsman (which are often unique to the Westminster system) ; sometimes they involve the permanent reduction of executive branch power. The wide mandate of intelligence agencies to arrest and interrogate suspected North Korea sympathisers was drastically reduced in 1994 as part of Kim Young Sam's reforms (Freedom House Report 1998) . Inevitably, due to the personal/presidential nature of South Korea's politics, and its unicameral legislature, it is prone to being, in the words of Geoffrey Palmer, an 'executive paradise' . The winner of an election often has essentially unbridled power for the next five years. I checked the '2' box for minority treatment, but this is in fact misleading, due to the poor phrasing of the question. South Korea does not mistreat any and all non-majority groups to the same minimal extent. In reality, the full 1998 Freedom House report details South Korea's unusual standards of only having intolerance for politically extreme views. Given that it is a virtually mono-ethnic society, there are few social issues on the treatment of ethnic minorities. The constitution guarantees freedom of religion, and this works in practise, with minority shamanistic pagan beliefs tolerated alongside the major religions of Christianity, Buddhism and Atheism. Freedom House documents the relative intolerance for individuals seen to be pro-North Korea, even if they do not publicly announce they are, leading to Red Scare-type denouncements that evoke Cold War-era McCarthyism in America. Communism is tied up with the North's tyranny in the minds of the South Korean public, and until Kim Dae Jung took office in 1998, ending the period that is my scope of study, any socialist policies were viewed with distaste. Sympathisers were a legal exception to freedom of political views under the National Security Act; hundreds of people each year were arrested for alleged North Korea sympathies and held as political prisoners during this period (Freedom House 1998) . If this question had instead asked whether any particular minority groups received certain treatment, alongside having all minority groups treated this way as an option, it would be more applicable to the situation here and, presumably, many similar countries. R esearch Sources Suffrage in South Korea . Index Mundi. http://www.indexmundi.com/south_korea/suffrage.html . Web. 21st May 2015. Chaibong, Hahm. 'South Korea's Miraculous Democracy' . Journal of Democracy 19.3 (2008) : 128-142. Print. 'S outh Korean politicians use fire extinguishers against opposition' . Daily Telegraph . http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/southkorea/3832972/South-Korean-politicians-use-fire-extinguishers-against-opposition.html . Web. 20th May 2015. Morriss, Peter. 'The South Korean N ational A ssembly E lections 1996' . Representation 34.3 (2007) : 180-189. London: Routledge. Print. Report on South Korea. Freedom House. 2002. ( https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2002/south-korea#.VV5SXk-eDGc ) . Web. 21st May 2015. F ull R eport on South Korea. Freedom House. 1998. ( https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/1998/south-korea ) . Web. 20th May 2015.

Corruption_types: "Bribe-taking by public officials","Misuse of public resources by top officials"
Justification: Political Rights: There is a very low likelihood of government change in Kazakhstan due to the consolidated authoritarian rule that governs the country and the sheer size/dominance of the party. The number of political parties dropped from 19 to 8 in 2002, due to law changes that require a minimum of 50,000 signatures for political parties to reregister (Freedom House) . In 2006, the political parties, Asar, Civic and Agarian merged with the ruling party Otan to create the political party Nur Otan which gave them 90% of seats in Parliament. Constitution exemptions have allowed for the President Nursultan Nazarbayev to stay in power, with the usual maximum of two 5-year terms revoked in favour of the president to secure a 7-year term in 1999. One-point was awarded as Kazakhstan does hold regular, free elections but they are marred by the limited political party variation. This has be International agencies monitoring internation election processes, such as the OSCE which refused to monitor the 1999 election because it failed to meet basic standards. The leader of the Asar party is also the president's daughter, which indicates the likelihood that the Nur Otan rule will continue to endure into the future. Universal suffrage exists so 3-points were given. (Index Mundi) The only major contending political party in the 1999 elction was the Communist Party, but the size and dominance of the ruling Nur Otan party make it extremely unlikely for the opposition to gain power. Leaders of the opposition are often barred from election participation by government allegations and convictions of corruption such as Akezhan Kazegeldin in the 1999 election. Since 2001, the rise of the Republican People's Party of Kazakhstan (RNPK) has become the only serious source of opposition. However with a membership of 14,000, it is difficult to compete with 300,000 membership of the Nur Otan party. This is further undermined by the law requiring political parties to reregister with 50,000 signatures for the 2004 election. It is also a requirement that a politcal party have 300 representatives in all cities and regions. This quesiton was difficult to evaluate because constituionally all people have access to political power but in reality, the heavy weilding influence of Nazarbayev limits those in political power to his close associates and family. This is evident through the influence his daughter has as former leader of the Asar party which formed a (convinent) coalition with the presidents party, and her role as head of the state run news-agency Khabar. The political elite are also made up of heads of major businesses (Freedom House) which cites the role of wealthy in politcal power in Kazakhstan. Any media publication crictical and independent of the regime is quickly squashed by the government which is why Kazakhstan rated 0 for this part of the classification system. Most media outlets are controlled by Dariga Nazarbayev, the president's daughter and her husband, through privistation of media companies and all broadcast transmission facilities are government owned (Freedom House) . Law changes instigated by the regime ruler Presdient Nazarbayev, mean that publications that insult the honor of the president or disclose information regarding the president's investments/economic interests face criminal conviction. This has rendered independent media void and unable to provide an open, fair platform for political discussion and critique. Civil Liberties Abitary power is with the state, with the President having over-ruling power in all political matters. His over-ruling decision power extends from constitutional reform to local level politcals making dissenting political change virtually impossible. This question was a bit of an educated guess but constitutionally, Kazakhstan citizens have access to basic human rights. Citizens have freedom of religion. We can assume the citizens have little access to Freeedom of Speech as publication of dissenting opinion of the President faces criminal conviction, which by extension means there is no room for critique of the regime. The judicary system is heavily influenced by the regime. The President has the over-ruling power on the judicary system and regular amendments to the constitution to suit the political agenda of the regime have undermined the judicary system. The President decides whom will become judges most levels of the judicary system from the Supreme court to the locacl-level judges. Judges frequently engage in bribery. There are no independent enquiries Minority groups have equal legal and statutory rights but ethnic representation is very limited 3-points were given. The Assembly of Peoples of Kazakhstan does not give fair and equal representation as the President is the chairman and encourages members of the assembly to not engage in political matters. National cultural centres are also required to be registered with the Ministry of Justice, further restricting minority group's influence in politics. Corruption 'Corruption is pervasive from the head of government to low-level government workers'. - Corruption is heavily concentrated at the head of the government with the President heavily mis-using his position of power to remain in power, through constant legislation change. Misuse of public resources by top officials is the biggest form of corruption, which is clear in the case of the Kazakhgate scandal in 2003 which investigated allegations that U.S official James Giffen was sending 60 million to overshore accounts believed to belong to Nazarbayev. As aforementioned, constitutional amendements instigated and implement by the President himself provide special exemptions for the President (e.g to continue his Presidential term indefinitely) and also restricted dissenting opinion and the rise of any major political opposition. Frequent bribe taking by judges from government officials is conducted. Summary: Overall it was relatively straighty forward to classify Kazakhstan's governing regime (1999-2007) against this classification system as typical of a long-standing authoritarian regime, there were high instances of corruption and legislation/constituitional changes implemented to severly limit the likelihood of a change of government. Most of my research was taken from Freedom House due to the extensive information available and Carnegie Endowment for International Peace also provided background information on the regime. Also referenced: http://www.minorityrights.org/2359/kazakhstan/kazakhstan-overview.html

Justification: I chose to focus on the years of 1991 to 2014 for a number of reasons. First of all it seemed a good range of years which encompassed the year I was assigned (2012) - significant changes in the political atmosphere of Lesotho occured during this period with serious ramifications for the nation's political identity. Democratic elections in Lesotho occur every 5 years with three major political parties occupying the majority of the nations votes. the nation itself is a constituional monarchy, however the King's power is largely ceremonial as he possesses no executive authority and is proscribed from participating in political initiatives. Universal suffrage is in place in Lesotho with anyone over the age of 18 permitted to vote and women gaining the ability to vote in 1965. Access to political power is largely accesible by all, however in terms of the monarchy, which as previously mentioned is almost entirely ceremonial: there is a hereditary neccesity in order to become king/queen. In terms of conventional political power, this answer was an educated guess. There are numerous examples of evidence that suggest access to political power eg. the ability to run for election or petition the government is seriously combatted by government legislation including the Sedition Proclamation and the Internal Security (General) Act of 1984. However there is a general consensus amongst political commentators that Lesotho's restriction towards public-government interaction is loosening, with numerous attempts being made in recent years to insist that systems are in place to support democratic action eg. the demonstrations staged in 2011 by unions and political groups to protest a number of governance and economic issues. Lesotho's contemporary govt administration has been responsible for the nation's adoption of several human rights law. Freedoms of speech, press, religion, assembly and association are largely respected with a few cases in each category exemplified as detrimental to the nation's human rights growth. Press is largely independent in Lesotho withe criticism of the government routine, however state owned media does exist and generally reflects the opinions of the ruling party. Protests have occasionally been dispersed violently with several claims that Police shot at crowds during the 2011 demonstrations. The judicial system in Lesotho is nominally independent, although higher courts are susceptible to external interference. Prisons are in a state of decay and are seriously overcrowded. There is an ombudsman's office in place in an attempt to defend personal civil liberties, however the ability for this office to defend individuals is seriously impeached by it's inability to enforce effectively. The legislative branch of Lesotho's government is made up of two groups: the National Assembly made up with 120 members and the Senate with 33 nominated members. The two systems theoretically work to balance each other's legislative action. The homogeneity of Lesotho's national identity is illustrated in the fact that a massive majority of the nation's population identify as 'Basotho' making rights for minority cultures obsolete. To this end there are no ethnic minorities represented in either chamber of Lesotho's government. Religion also proves to be of negligible importance in terms of disparity as an overwhelming majority of Lesotho's population attribute themselves as Roman Catholic (Christianity) . Corruption is a big issue in Lesotho: rife in all sectors of government and public services with cronyism prevalent in a state bidding procedures. Their has been an aggressive witchhunt against corruption by Lesotho's government yet according to the African Peer Review Mechanism, corruption remains the biggest issue that the country faces, behind AIDS.

Justification: Since I know very little about Croatian political history I did a general Google search about Croatia, its History, the war of independence and the Racan Government to give myself a general idea of what happened around the year 2002.Based off of the research I decided so select 2000 as the Year to which to start my investigation on Croatia following the Croatian war of independence. It was a War over the independence of Croatia which divided the public causing over 20,000 casualties (BBC news, 2003) . It also saw an investigation by the ICTY into various war related crimes by top tier officials within Yugoslavia, convicting 8 elites (BBC news 2006) . Franjo Tudman, suspected of playing large roles in sketchy privatisation of Croatia movements was also under investigation but died from cancer in 1999. I also selected the year 2000 because it was the rebound year from a tough Croatian rescission in 1999. From 2000-2003 the government saw a huge restructuring under a new Racan government (under the leadership of Ivica Ra an) . This saw the dispersion of power and decision making spread among various institutions in a restructured parliamentary system (3) . It was generally considered a crucial turning point in a country that was in need of a serious rebuild. Previous leaders had make poor economical and selfish political decisions that had led the country on a downward spiral. In combination with this the people of Croatia were in conflict with each other, providing and environment of little stability. It was a three year bracket which developed the country of Croatia dramatically under the leadership of President Stjepan Mesi and Prime Minister Ivica Ra an. After 2003, the European commission issued a report on Croatia with it finding that described Croatia as being transformed from previous years into a country with a modern democratic government leading to a diverse and competent economy and with the ability to progress providing the reform stayed strong. I thought it would be interesting to focus on how the reform came about and how the Croatian government transformed its country in this three year gap. For question four. I scored it a maximum of three points, not because I felt that elections are fully transparent, but because the criteria of answer 3 was for filled by the Croatian government. The elections of both 2000 and 2003 appear to be free. On both occasions the elected party was not previously in government, so they appear to not have faced significant barriers to overcome the previous government. Also, the European Commission (2005) report following the 2003 elections described Croatia's election as democratic after taking on board recommended tactics suggested by the EU (4) . Currently Croats all Croats can vote at the age of 18, however if employed can vote at the age of 16 (5) . If the individual is seen as contributing to society he/she can vote earlier. Gender or ethnicity do not play a role but you need to be a citizen of Croatia. In 2005, the EU described Croatia's 2003 election as being held under Universal Suffrage (4) . EU immigrants to Croatia, under law, are expected to be treated the same when it comes to work, employment and creation law. MP are elected by everyone living in Croatia, although the votes and MP's elected are selected by Croats based on their ethnicity, with the Czech and Slovak Croats selecting Different Leaders. Using some educated guessing, based on Croatia's Corruption rating from Transparency international with a score of 38/100% in 2002 and a score 0f 48/100 now, the 59% corruption control rating would be at approximately 74%. This takes into account the ability for public to influence the private sector in a corrupt manor (6) . Along with this Croat elites must (not officially) have a certain level of wealth, and not anyone can be elected from each ethnicity. Croats have access to free Speech, and there are state owned and private media outlets. The two major private media outlets are owned by foreign investors. This is not to say that they are not corrupt, but more so that if corruption is involved, it has one more barrier to pass. All media is regulated by the government, which is a cause for concern as they can select propaganda which benefits them in elections and polls (7) . The Croatian Judicial system currently has three tiers. The Legislative branch is the highest authority that is directly elected by the citizens. They look at general and essential laws (laws around human rights and equality) with a majority rules system. Essential laws -seen as crucial and important -often need 2/3's of the elected participants votes in order to pass. Croatia holds no binding referendums, which leaves the public detached from political affairs. In the executive branch, President has the ability to appoint the prime minister of his choice, which usually goes the way of the party with the leading votes however the prime minister does have the right to the final say. Obviously it wouldn't be seen as a smart tactic by the public, but the president still has the potential and ability to act (8) . Settling disputes has been a long and demanding task throughout Croatian history and disputes often take money and time to settle (9) . Bibliography BBC News. Justification: Eritrea defeated Ethiopian army in 1991, and got independence in 1993.Ever since then Eritrea have been ruled by one single party known as PFDJ (people's front for democracy and justice) it is the only legal party in Eritrea. Eritrea has no multi-party system, president Isaias Afwerki has been on power since Independence Day (Wikipedia) . According to human rights organisations such as amnesty international Eritrea never hold any executive or legislative election. Eritrean government made promises for election many times, for example Isaias Afwerki and his cronies set 2001 to for elections to take place, however they changed their stand, claiming that Ethiopia was still controlling the disputed area on the border. So the national election is officially postponed indefinitely (freedom house, 2005) . Eritrean government set up constitution commission in mid-1990s, after three years of extensive work which participated Eritreans throughout the country, the constitution was ratified in 1997. According to Wikipedia the ratified constitution called for 'conditional'political pluralism, it also restricted the president's terms in the office, it also opened the door for multi-party system politics, however the constitution never implemented up to date. However according to senior government officials and some the regime affiliated websites the local elections have continued, Yamane Gebremeskel the president's chief of stuff, said the electoral commission responsibility to set the day the local elections, he also stated that the national assembly mandated the electoral commission to set dates for local elections. As Eritrean citizen who keep close eye to what is happening in Eritrea, with the there is no such a thing called electoral commission, as Eritrea has no a national assembly today (Madot.com) . In 2001 senior government ministers and party officials wrote an open letter to the president accusing him of authoritarianism and called him to introduce reformation, as they have called for PFDJ to hand power to the people. The presidents responded accusing them for treason and run widespread defamation campaign against them. The president had army and security officials on his side, and arrested all the fifteen members of the group locally known as G15, as well some private journalists. In September 18 2001, is a day Eritrea's dream to become democratic country with proper functioning government institutions was buried, the newly born private press was banned for ever. Since that day Eritrea is a country with no elections, no free press, no independent judiciary, and only one party one man ruling by decree (freedom house, 2010) Political corruption and human rights abuse is a common phenomenon, with no constitution with no accountability to the rule of law, Eritrea today is known as North Korea of Africa. Some religious minorities such as Pentecostal, and Jehovah witness are prosecuted and they are officially banned, those who have been caught praying arbitrary arrested and languishing in notorious underground prisons. Amnesty International reported more than ten thousand prisoners of conscious are thought to be imprisoned throughout the country. Many detainees thought to have died including government officials and journalists (Amnesty international, 2011) . Finally I would like to post a video of President Isaias Afwerkis interview with CNN openly ruling out any possibility of holding election for many decades to come. http://www.madote.com/ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UAXKsZ8OsWo Freedom house, (2005) . https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2006/eritrea Freedom house Eritrea (2011 https://freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/FOTP%202013%20Booklet%20Final%20Complete%20-%20Web.pdf Human rights watch, (2011) . http://www.amnestyusa.org/research/reports/annual-report-eritrea-2011

The media under Suharto was controlled by the Ministry of Information and television licenses were only given out to Suharto family members, friends and wealthy conglomerates. News programs were all state-run although there were alternatives who produced their own news programs but stayed relatively tame. Questions 9, 10, 12 and 13 I looked at the Human Rights Watch World Reports for 1990, 1992 and 1993 which all show evidence that the rights of Indonesian citizens were being violated including freedoms of expression, association and assembly, right to life, not to be subjected to torture etc. (Human Rights Watch, 1990), (Human Rights Watch, 1992), (Human Rights Watch, 1993) For question 11 about the judiciary, I could not find any source about whether it was free and independent, so from the control Suharto had over everything else such as the media, other parties, ministries I think it is safe to assume he had control over the judiciary too. Justification: The resources I used as my reference were; Transparency International's country profile on Guinea-Bissau that can be found at http://www.transparency.org/country#GNB, The BBC's country profile at http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-13443186 and the US' Central Intelligence Agency's profile on the country at https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/pu.html. Guinea-Bissau is a relatively small country in Western Africa, as such it is situated in an area rich in natural resources and large enough population to provide for a good economy. However it is also characterised by unstable regimes, frequent government turnovers (post 1984) and multiple conflicts, armed or otherwise. The country's richness in natural resources has not been able to provide the country with an income with which to provide for the needs of it people. The potential that the country's resources has is taken away by bad governance (government official's abuse their power, taking away the profits for themselves), lack of investment, weak economic policies and a very low literacy rate with more than half the women in the country not being able to read and write.The country's financial stability is supplemented in large by foreign aid. As Transparency International's report places the country in 161st place out of 175 countries, corruption is widespread in Guinea-Bissau, abuse of power is common it suggests the country's political system is abused by those in power to benefit themselves. Political Stability has been one of the greater challenges of Guinea-Bissau, post-independence from Portugal in 1974 the country has been headed by a 'de facto' dictator that usurped power from an 'elected' leader and as such the country has not experienced a democratic transition of power in its history. Election results have been questioned by domestic and international bodies in more than one occasion. Coups that replace existing 'elected' governments are mostly overthrown by members of the military, with the military citing a multitude of reasons over the years including economic problems, abuse of political power among others as reason to overthrow the existing regime. The last elected president of Guinea-Bissau preceding the current president was assassinated, João Bernardo Vieira was a former military general that overthrew the democratically elected president Kumba Ialá having only served three years in office. Vieria was then himself taken out of the office by a group of renegade soldiers that carried out his assassination. This example of turbulence and pervasive political instability within the country has greatly affected Guinea-Bissau's problem with corruption and bad governance. In more recent times the country has been headed by either a presiding military council or a more internationally recognised elected president with the current president José Mário Vaz assuming office in June 2014 having won the most recent elections in the aftermath of the most recent military coup in 2012. In a recent estimate the World Bank estimated that more than half the people in Guinea-Bissau or a staggering 69% of the population is in poverty. (http://data.worldbank.org/country/guinea-bissau) . Poor and uneducated, the country's population has little in terms of political and social rights that they enjoy in practice.The country's other political institutions in the the legislative and the judiciary are undermined by the authority of the executive. Non-governmental institutions are also subject to state interference and are mostly prevented from discrediting the ruling party. Overall the profile provided by the institutions mentioned above paints a picture of an undemocratic regime within Guinea-Bissau.

Justification: These are some of the evidence that I found quite interesting when researching on East Timor: On the 20th of May 2002 East Timor gained Independence from Indonesia. Getting to that position was very difficult for East Timor as there was so much opposition from the Indonesian militia who wanted nothing else but to keep tabs of them. Now that they have gotten past this obstacle, the new government is now trying to build up democratic institutions in a land plagued by neglecy and brutality. Although under new leadership East Timor has a long way to go in trying to eradicate corruption. One problem being faced by the country is the discrimination of minority groups. Ethnic Malay Muslims and ethnic Chinese face occasional harassment; while non Portuguese speakers claim to be at a disadvantage in competign for political and civil service posts as reported by Freedom House. Moreover women face problems such as domestic violence daily. The Judiciary doesnt help this situation as they keep a relatively poor record of these criminal practises. Their judiciary system also says alot about the corruption that goes on within it as civil law judiciary is weak and inexperienced. Courts are short on trained lawyers, prosecuters and translators. I found it difficult to answer question 12 as there is a limited amount of institutions out there that can hold the government accountable for whatever reason as most institutions are weak and unstable at times. All in all, the research I carried out suggests that East Timor is finding it difficult to move forward into a more transparent democracy as their past suggests otherwise.

Justification: Q4 - There are evidences show that legislature voting is not really fair in Singapore: In the Singapore's first presidential election in 1993, Lee Kuan Yew successor - Ong Teng Cheong - won against oppsition cadidates. The point was the the Presidential Elections Committee (PEC) rejected two potential opponents. Meanwhile, the defeated Workers' Party candidates were even faced a defamation suit from PAP. Additionally, in 1999 presidential election, opposition cadidates from Singapore Domocratic Party (SDP) was jailed for making speeches without permission.Generally, opposition candidates had to face alots lawsuits and bankrupting. Q5 - The Elections Department of Singapore has clearly noted the following suffrage for a voter are: being the Singapore Citizen and holding the Pink Identity Card; be at least 21 years-old; being a resident with residential constituency Address (Singapore's Elections Department website: http://www.eld.gov.sg/voters.html ) Q6- There is evidence that voting in Singapore is not completly fair and clean. Base on freedomhouse.org, the People's Action Party dominates the political process. In the electing process, it was reported that the opposition campaigns have been repressed by mass media banning, otherwise there were strict regulations (Retrieved from: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2013/singapore#.VV2iW_nvO01 ) . Moreover, Singapore's Constitution provided that a person that has been convicted of an offence is not eligible to stand for parliment for a considerably long time, which can be applied to poitical opponents and eliminate them from electing process (Retrieved from ' International Bar Association': http://www.ibanet.org/Article/Detail.aspx?ArticleUid=77f9bba5-38bd-4a2a-8972-8680d7821d5b ) Q7- Not every person has access to the political power in Singapore, due to the pre-dominated PAP and its successors have always leading the process and even controed the civil society.Furthermore, Singapore is considered to have weak pluralist politics. ( Politics in Pacific Asia: An Introduction. Huang, Shiaoming. 2009. pg. 87) Q8 - In Singapore, Radio and television are both managed by government corperation. The press is also being regulated in various ways: through the government's licensing power or informal advice ( Milne, R., & Mauzy, D. K. (1990) . Singapore: The Legacy of Lee Kuan Yew. San Francisco : Westview Press) . (Retrieved from freedomhouse.org, and international.org ) Q11 - The judiciary was under the effection of PAP leaders, and to some extent was not judicial independent. Examples are the lawsuits and bankrupting mentioned above. (This part retrieved from freedomhouse.org: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/1999/singapore#.VV2l0PnvO00 ) . The same report in 2008 also confirm that the judiciary is not independent ( https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2008/singapore#.VV6jNPnvO00) q12 - once again, the power check and balance depends on the role of judiciary. But as mentioned, judiciary in Singapore is highly regulated by the ruling party. q13 - there are three major ethnics in Singapore: Chinese, Malaysian and Indian. Justification: Saudi Arabia was a very easy country to find information from - it has been an important Middle Eastern ally of Europe and the United States for decades, so there is a wealth of reliable material to study in order to find answers to these questions. I am very confident in the answers I have given to these questions, as information regarding them is freely available online, including studies by Human Rights Watch and Freedom House, amongst others. Two questions that I had some difficulty with were Question 5 about universal suffrage and Question 15 about corruption. In terms of Question 5, I was unsure whether to go for option 0 or option 1; voting in Saudi Arabia is restricted to males over the age of 21, though there have been extremely conservative reforms to let women vote in some minor matters. I was unsure whether males over the age of 21 constituted a majority in Saudi Arabia, so I opted to go with option 1, as women are all banned from voting because of their gender In terms of Question 15, the data about corruption in Saudi Arabia seems to suggest that the corruption is largely limited to the elites of the government, i.e. the royal family. This was defended by Prince Bandar bin Sultan, who was at the centre of the most notable corruption scandal in Saudi Arabia in 2007, when it was revealed that he had been paid $2 billion in bribes by the British defence contractor BAE Systems relating to the huge Al-Yamamah arms deal between Saudi Arabia and the UK. Thus, it seems that while the royal family are massively corrupt, the corruption ends there for the most part. Otherwise, Saudi Arabia was an easy country to find reliable information on in regards to the questions, and I am very confident in my answers to these questions.

Justification: Is Russia a ''managed democracy'' (Kratsev and Holmes), a ''pseudo-democracy'' (Graeme Robertson), or just a kind of authoritarian regime among others ? Even if the common assumption shared by occidental countries nowadays is that Russia is definitely not a democracy, it is still difficult to range the country within the traditional classification of political regimes. That is why looking at specific features such as the importance of political rights, civil liberties and corruption is relevant in order to understand a bit more the current russian political system. The time period picked is 2008-2012, in order to analyze a moment of political change in Russia : four years when Putin was not supposed to hold power. In 2012, Putin became president for a new term, showing that russian constitution was actually weak in front of him. Indeed, as being president more than twice in a row was not legally possible, he had to find a trick to come back. The constitution is supposed to rule the functionning of the state, and the fact that Putin managed to get around it that easily says a lot about russian political system. It shows that what is supposed to be applied in theory is not always applied in practise. In fact, it is interesting to notice that the russian constiution is very similar to the french one, whereas it is obvious that both regimes are very different... Some questions above were difficult to answer because of that matter. In terms of political rights : In theory, elections are supposed to be free in Russia. Every adults can vote from 18 years old, for the candidate of his/her choice. This is what the constitution states, but in reality, corruption or pressure on voters can applied. Moreover, elections are not fair, they are ''rigged''. In term of political opposition, Putin has a control on it. An opposition is supposed to exist but Putin through the party ''United Russia'' has actually a grip on russian politics. Still theoretically, people can have an access to political power, but the road ahead would be long and full of obstacles. As an example, to be candidate in the presidential elections, 2millions of signatures are required, signatures that members of United Russia don't need to get. Putin is also the one who picks candidates of his party at every levels of the country (Putin's ''Power Vertical''), and he is the one who picked Medvedev to replace him as a president, while he was actually still ruling the state behind the scenes. That is why nothing has actually changed during that time, and that is why russian politics is usually defined as the ''Putin's system''. Finally, in terms of media, a censorship is applied by the government, but the internet is still a way to express freely in Russia. It is a very important point to notice, as generally, regimes considered to be non-democratic, control the internet. However, the questions on the database do not allowed to underline that specificity. In terms of Civil Liberties : The existence and the freedom of associations are part of civil liberties. In Russia, civil liberties tend to be repressed. If we take the example of a new legislation introduced in 2012, changing the legal status of NGO, it is obvious. Within the framework of that legislation, if an NGO gets its funds from another county, it has to be registered as a ''foreign agent'', which supposed that it is an ennemy of the power and that it has to be watched. However, partial rights exist in Russia. For instance, it would be wrong to say that freedom of speech is totally impossible. The protests of winter 2011-2011 happened and allowed people to express their opposition to Putin, even if this opposition did not manage to be a political force afterwards. It is also important to notice that the Krelim has a control on the judiciary, which is not free, not fair and not independent. Judges appeared to be often corrupted making verdicts unfair, and penalties are often disproportionated and sometimes do not even respect human rights. The case of the ''Pussy Riots'' is really relevant in order to understand the nature of justice in Russia. It is also interesting to focus on the existence of the russian ''prokuratura'', an institution dependent on the executive power, which controls the actions of the administration members and of the courts. It makes the political power able to participate and have an impact on the judicial procedure. Talking about the treatment of minority groups, russian consitution is supposed to protect them. However, russian society is quite xenopobic and in reality, the idea of ''equal treatment'' is not respected. As a matter of fact, between the time period covered, many caucasians have been persecuted by russian extremists, but the legal process did not reflect the facts. Corruption : This is a real problem in Russia. Corruption exists at every levels of the society. Between 2008 and 2012, Russia has gone from the 147 th country out of 180 to the 133, in t erm of corruption. This little improvement shown that the government tries to work on it, but it is a phenomenon deeply anchored in russian society. At a state level, the corruption is also noticeable if we look at the close relationship between the power and other groups of interests, or if we look at the way elections are engineered in Russia by ''Putin and his clique'' (Kratsev and Holmes) .

Justification: Votes - Mozambique broke into a brutal 16 year civil war directly following its independance from Portugal. This was completely military fueled and no elections were held. Suffrage - In the absence of elections, suffrage was irrelevant. Opposition - NOT THROUGH ELECTION, two forces fighting against each other. RENAMO and FRELIMO fought hard against one another to hold power over different regions throughout the entire 16 year civil war. Both had power over the other, and their confilct was fueled by a belief that the other group was evil. Access to political power - Only military leaders had access to power. The tactics of this war were brutal and resulted in huge bloodshed for civilians. Media - The government was essentially two feuling military groups, and was not concerned with media. Freedom of media was not a concept as there was no working constitution. Rule of Law - No constitution, in 1989 a draft constitution by FRELIMO was the product of peace talks between sides, but was not enacted until 1990 but the brutal war was not over until 1992 Fundemental Human Rights - Mozambique was a place of massive bloodshed and fighting. There were child soliders. Global human rights activists were aware of the situation. RENAMO was known for its war crimes and crimes against humanity. All civil liberties - No working constitution! Only outside groups existed to help out groups. The post Portugal government was incredibly frail and divided and was not effective at governing so much as fighting. Types of corruption - Hard to tell! Because the two groups of the civil war were fundemental to the identity of the newly independent nation, there is little history to base this on, and the government was primarily inside dealings. Overall - sometimes hard to gather data because of the nature of the corrupt government. Most information was about the fued, not about the people who were subject to a corrupt government. I did the best with the information available, and really enjoyed learning about Mozambique, especially the peace talks which weren't covered here too much, a very cool history. I hope that the stability found in 1992 can be continued, even if some corruption continues to emerge.

Justification: The first country that I'm doing my research on is Belarus since 1994 until the present day. Since the 20 th June 1994 Alexander Lukashenko rules the country. His style of governing is described by many scholars such as Steven M. Eke, Taras Kuzio or Vitali Silitski and NGOs like Amnesty International as authoritarian. The Bertelsmann Transformation Index 2003 ranked it as an Autocracy (Index, 2003) . Even the very first presidential elections were 'relatively free and fair' (Silitski, 2005) Lukashenko created his own political apparatus to keep power to himself rather than establishing more democratic institutions. Since then, like Vitali Silitski notes, Lukashenko's Belarus changed some major things within the state apparatus, which extend the personal power of the president and created a long-lasting non-democracy in East-Europe. He made Russian the official language, extended his first term of being a president up to seven years 'and replaced the unicameral Supreme Council with a much weaker bicameral legislature consisting of a 64-seat Council of the Republic and a 110-seat House of Representatives' (Silitski, 2005) . According to the Freedom House reports from 1998 until 2015 Lukashenko's regime is nothing but a restricting and brutal political system with a unchallengeable leader. They ranked Belarus as a not free state though out their reports (Freedom House Rating: 6.0 1998->2005 ; 6.5 2006->2015 (House, 2015) [-with 7 being the worst] ) . But just like Steven M. Eke and Taras Kuzio noted in their analysis of the Sultanism in Belarus -as what they call Lukashenkonism -we have to consider 'that the majority of the population either did not take this threat seriously or did not see anything necessarily bad in an authoritarian dictatorship' (Eke & Kuzio, 2000) and that there was support for Lukashenko's power extension since then. And although the constitution guarantees universal suffrage the elections processes are manipulated and rigged by the regime in favour to keep Lukashenko in the presidents seat or to change (with a referendum) certain aspects of the political apparatus to extend his personal power -like the Freedom House report says. The rule of law is not protected and the personal rule of Lukashenko and his regime established 'a growing personality cult in Belarus' (Eke & Kuzio, 2000) . There is no real independence of the judiciary (which is guaranteed through the constitution) . Not only that the regime gained control over the hole state administration and judiciary, they also managed to first of all weaken the opposition and then systematically get rid of it. Like Silistki wrote, opposition politicians simply died or got lost: 'First to go missing was Lukashenka's former minister of interior Yury Zacharanka' (Silitski, 2005) . Other sources like a BBC's article in 2012 show that the opposition basically has no chance and that politicians who are willing to challenge Lukashenko (direct or indirect) are jailed (BBC, 2012) . Other sources like a Radio Free Europe / Radio Liberty article draw the same picture: there is no democratic institutionalization in Belarus and the opposition is taken out (and into jail) (Bigg & Hruzdzilovich) . Lukashenko's Populism is broadcasted through almost every media channel in Belarus. The regime is in control of the media and rules with an iron fist to end every kind of rising protest, organized threat or journalistic critique. Furthermore certain civil liberties such as Freedom of Assembly, Speech or Mobility are not guaranteed. The people of Belarus are not allowed to form informal Organisations and travelling is restricted. And even though the constitution ensures equal rights to everybody the reality in Belarus shows something different. According to the Minority Rights Group International and their report 2015 (Lattimer & Verbakel, 2015) Poles in Belarus have to fear some sort of Xenophobia. And GlobalGays.com notes that 'Homosexual sex was legalised in Belarus in 1994, however Gay rights in Belarus are still severely limited' (GlobalGayz.com, 2010) . All in all that shows a picture of an authoritarian regime or dictatorship with great power and force. It seems that Alexander Lukashenko does not have to be hold accountable for his action within the country, but he and his regime gets a lot of international negative criticism. Finally corruption within the Lukashenko regime is a big problem - although corruption is legally criminalized. Like the Freedom House reports show and the Business Anti-Corruption Portal notes: it is 'at all government levels in Belarus; industry, education, healthcare and construction are particularly vulnerable sectors' (Portal, 2014) . List of references BBC. (2012, September 24) . BBC News . Retrieved from http://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-19690249 Bigg, C., & Hruzdzilovich, A. (n.d.) . Radio Free Europe / Radio Liberty . Retrieved from http://www.rferl.org/archive/belarus_crackdown/latest/3510/3510.html Eke, S. M., & Kuzio, T. (2000, May) . Sultanism in Eastern Europe: The Socio-Political Roots of Authoritarian Populism in Belarus. Europe-Asia Studies, Vol. 52, No. 3, pp. 523 - 547. GlobalGayz.com. (2010) . GlobalGayz.com . Preempting Democracy: The Case of Belarus. Journal of Democracy, Vol. 16, No. 4 .

Justification: Comoros gained independence from France in 1975 and in that 20 year span has endured 20 coups. The constant change and shifts of power have made it difficult for any stability within the country. In 1995, following on the corrupt and oppressive regime by President Mohamed Said Djohar, Mohamed Taki Abdoulkarim was elected in what is considered by international observers to have been free and fair. During Takis presidency he worked to root out corruption within the government, however he also removed all the women working for the government. Women were allowed to vote due to universal suffrage but they were mostly told how to vote by their husbands. Constant turmoil over independence and re-establishment with France between the three islands of Comoros led to inter island political conflict. In 1998 Taki died under suspicious circumstances and his replacement Tadjidine Ben Said Massounde, the interim President, postponed elections indefinitely. Not long after Col. Azali Assoumami led a successful military coup to overthrow Tadjidine. Following this Azali worked with the other islands of Comoros to initiate a power dynamic that would rotate leadership every 5 years between islands. In 2001 the draft agreement was signed and the following year a Presidential election was held. The election is reported to be marred by violence, with allegations of voter fraud as well as the boycott by two of the three candidates. It was later announced that Col. Azali Assourmani was the new president of unified Comoros. Individuals or coups that have risen to power have been come throughout Comoros independence. These coups often have powerful benefactors behind them such as Bob Denard, a mercenary, ruled with and behind Ahmed Abdullah who held power in the 70's and 80's. After a final coup that ended Abdullahs rule in 1979 he continued to lead coups followed by his sons later on. In Freedom Houses report Comoros stayed constant with civil liberties and political freedom in 1 -7 scale coming in at 3.5- 4 from 1995-2003. For political rights Comoros went from a 4 in 1995 to a 6 in 2002. In a Freedom House report on press it reported starting at a 35 in 1995 rising to a 45 in 2003 showing a decrease in freedom of speech, as the scale increases in a higher censored and monitored press. Transparency International reported Comoros as being in the lower half of most corrupt countries citing rule of law, press freedom voice and accountability and corruption being very prominent undressed issues.

Justification: 2. 2003 is one year before trade normalization between Laos and the United States. The United States has since become one of Laos's most important trading partners. The influx of easy wealth into the country with no doubt has had a great impact on Laotian politics. 3. 2014 is almost now. 4. Elections are held in the country, but only for representatives in the National Assembly. But they are meaningless as candidates are fielded from local Party loyalists - active local members of Party and its Patriotic Front - and approved by local Party secretaries. Important positions such as President, Prime Minister, Central Committee and Politburo members are officially elected by National Assembly but de facto appointed by top personages upon consensus. 5. Laos does not grant voting right to those under 18, mentally ill, or incarcerated. And it prefers to keep the population away from mass mobilization and political participation. Interestingly, the court is given power to revoke one's right to vote and be elected by Article 36 of the Laotian Constitution. Since the court is not independent of the Communist Party, it can be used to disable political rivals. 6. Laos does not have an effective political opposition, if any at all. Some intellectuals provide gentle criticism of government policies but their number is tiny, their profiles are obscured, and their organization is non-existent. Furthermore, Laotian (political) culture is characterized by mildness and passiveness. 7. Most Laotians do not have access to political power. Those wielding it inherit from their predecessors or buy it with personal connections and wealth. Laos's ethnic makeup to a large degree is heterogeneous. Loyalty to the Party is of utmost importance and has helped many from ethnic minorities ascend the ladder of power. However, the Hmongs and Montagnards are implicitly barred from politics. These tribes are converted Christians and fought for imperial masters, and have been actively persecuted since nationalist / communist independence. 8. The rapid penetration of information technology and the lawless frontier characteristic of cyber space have been tipping the scale minorly in opposition's favor. However, computers have not been as effective as television in reaching rural areas beyond the cities, where most of Laos population live in material, and informational, poverty. Here, state media under firm government control and state propaganda dominate. 9. This regime is not constrained under the law. Legally and technically. Legally, it is the paramount leader of the country. Technically, the Party controls the National Assembly, charged with legislation, so laws are written as they suit the interests of the Party. Its leaders, both national and local, are officially subject to the rule of law. Hovvever, a regime built upon corrupt co-optation has not other choice but to give their supporters some leevvay in terrorizing ordinary citizens. 10. Laotian citizens and residents are accorded with all fundamental human rights by Laotian Constitution. However, the more important of these rights are subject to regulation by lower laws: freedoms of movement and settlement, of demonstration, association, and assembly. Article 42 of Laotian Constitution also allows for the 'violation' of a person's body, honor, and home without leave from the prosecutorial authority or the court. Article 41 requires complaints and petitions to be lodged to Party's organs according to Party's guidelines in order to be considered not illegal. In conclusion, freedoms are enshrined in constitution, but provisions are customized to be empty on their own. Instead of using amendment as done in the United States, constitutional conditions are stripped away and hidden in complicated legal decrees frequently changed without public consultation, aimed at increasing regime's flexibility to rule, disorientating the common folks and dissidents, discouraging their constitutional invocation, denying them shelter under the law. 11. Laotian People's Supreme Court is the highest judicial organ in the country, however, not the highest judicial authority. By proletarian dictatorship, the National Assembly is repository of all power in the state, including judicial power. It delegates this power to the Supreme Court by appointing judges from within the Party's rank. 12. In practice, Laotian government is answerable to the Party long before they are called to be held accountable to the public if grave circumstances arise. The Party by virtue of law and power answers to its own. There is no separation of power, no independent checks and balances. Power flows from the Party and is coordinated by the Party. Corruption investigation authority is available, but is staffed but the Central Committee of the Party, and answers to Party alone. After all, Party power comes from being the head of Human Resources, and knowledge impacting seat allotment is very much a Human Resources business. Parliamentary proceedings are open to public scrutiny. But meetings that truly matter, the Party Congresses in every five years, when all pillars of the country gather under one roof and decide the fate of the realm, are conducted behind closed doors. As are all other Party conferences. 13. Equal treatment to all ethnicities is recognized under the Constitution. But beyond that, there is no measure to protect or promote the welfare of any particular minority. And as mentioned, the government oppresses oppositional minorities such as the Hmongs and Montagnards. 14. I am very confident. Descriptions of Laos are not scarce in Vietnam given Vietnamese extensive commercial presence and ethnic contribution to Laos's population. I have also studied and lived alongside Laotian privileged kids. 15. & 16. It's just really bad. I don't want to spoil all surprised before we get to the Vietnam section.

Justification: Ethiopia in 1999 According to Steve (2010 ),In 1999, Ethiopia was really engaged in war with Eritrea and despite minor political problems, generally political parties and even people of Ethiopia had been sympathetic government. The war gave an opportunity for the prime minister ( Meles Zenawi ) to have consolidated power ( Ibd ) Political rights Political right in 1999 according to Human Rights Watch World Report 1999 Ethiopian People's Revolutionary Democratic Front (EPRDF) led Ethiopian government mad efforts to introduce political and economic reforms with the help of donor countries. Generally speaking, the constitution that drafted in 1994 allowed those ethnically based federal districts to have executive, legislative and judicial power. However, the EPRDF led federal government put obstacles over the judicial process by means of affiliated political parties who have greater influence in the regional admirations (Human Rights Watch World Report 1999 The government did not respect the basic human right of political dissents especially those who strongly criticized the government, many political figures were detained for many months without trail and exposed severe harassment ( Human Rights Watch World Report 1999 ) . For example All Amhara People Organization (AAPO) and the Council of Alternative Forces for Peace and Democracy in Ethiopia (CAFPD), are excluded and many people have been arrested without trail in the country side by militias who are loyal to the EPRDF affiliated parties. Judicial system According to Ethiopian constitution drafted in 1994 judiciary system is independent but in practice, judicial system of the country was under the influence of government. For example the practice of extrajudicial killings were commonly seen especially for those who sympathized with Oromo Liberation Front (OLF ) had been the subject of this systematic extrajudicial killings ( Amnesty International (1999 ) . According to US state Department, In February 1999, Soro district police committed atrocities over the two farmers who had been accused of cooperating with the opposition and for refusing paying taxes for the government and also one young man who attended funeral for the renowned and founder of All Amhara people Organization Dr. Asrat Woldeyes, became victim of extrajudicial killings. The report went to say that the Ethiopian government committed arrested twenty six Nuer who were the members of Gambela people's democratic Congress ( GPDC ) though twelve of them were set free soon. The cause of arrest for some activities directly associated with the student demonstration took place and Oromo people who were suspected of cooperating with OLF. In November 1999 a week long demonstration was held by the students of Sodo when two teachers had been arrested because they showed their resistance against the use of new language. In those demonstration ten people were killed and about hundred demonstrators got injured or wounded and also thousand faced arbitrary arrest (U.S department State 1999 ) Media In 1999, the government passed law that needed to review the 'application of private radio and TV licenses in order to prohibit/ restrict opposition parties'medias consumption US State Department 1999) . Even though Freedom of speech was relatively allowed but arrest for journalists were reported by US state department. For example, In June 1999 Dr Woldesemayat was the president of Ethiopian Teacher Association ( ETA) put behind bar for allegedly conducting terrorist activity and sentenced to fifteen years ( US State Department 1999 ) . The well renowned Samson Seyoum Kebede ex editor of GOH was arrested for allegation of inciting war and helping spread Islamic fundamentalism ( ibid ) In December 1999, Aberra Wegi, the deputy editor in chief Maebel has taken to prison because he was accused of demonising Tigray People's Liberation Front ( TPLF ) who mercilessly killed to the those captured soldiers of the ex-communist leader Mengustu Halimariam. And also Tesehalene Mengesha, deputy editor-in-chief of Zegabi, was accused of breaking press law arrested for six months and fined 2000 birr equivalent to US 250. In addition to in June Tewodros Kassa, editor-in-chief of Ethiopia, was arrested (Reporters without Borders) The international community condemned the violation of human rights against Eritreans who had been live for many years. A year later, after the war between Eritrea and Ethiopian, the Ethiopian government arrested and deported Eritreans. According to US State Department about one thousand and two hundred were rounded up from where they had lived and taken to prisons ( Dedesa, ) by the security. The ICRC reported that hundreds of Eritreans were held in the police stations. In June 1999 the Ethiopian government granted for the first time to the ICRC to visit where Eritreans were held. As US State Department report showed that Eritrean were allowed to go to any countries (except their country) if they got visa. However the government gain violated the right of those of who retuned back from Malawi ( US State Department 1999 ) . However, 6, 000 members of Jehovah Witness who had lived, did not face deportation as the Ethiopian government believed that they would face persecution if they went to Eritrea (US State Department. Freedom of movement Though Freedom of Movement Within the Country is enshrined in the country's constitution which is any citizen has the right to travel and emigrate but the government did not apply the constitution and All Amhara people organization who had been accused of treason in the 1998, had been denied the right of travel . and in similar way, the government denied the Norwegian human rights group who sought to supervise the election which was going to be held in 2000. In the early of April 1999, the Ethiopia government formulated policy that allowing Eritreans who had been in prisons ( Bilate and Dedesa ) to get visas from any country except Eritrea. About 90 prisoners had got chances of getting visas, most of whom got from (US State Department) Election In fact, there was no election held in 1999 but a year after ( 2000 ) parliamentary election was held. In that election relatively was generally described as fair election though there had been electoral fraud in the southern region (US State Department 2000) The Ethiopian Peoples'Revolutionary Front (EPRDF) had got high turnouts, opposition parties participated in the election but they did not do enough job due to lack of fund, were only competed for twenty percent of the federal seats while the EPRDF and its affiliated political parties won 518 seats out of 547 Meles was re-elected as in the parliamentary election 25 million people cast their votes and 35 opposition parties contested in the election ( US state department office ) . According to European Union observers, the election which was held in 2000 was free from violence though prime Meles zenawi accusing opposing groups for preaching 'ethnic hatred' in a similar way of what happened in Rwanda (1994 ( BBC 2000 ) Freedom of association (religion) The constitution respects the freedom of religion, the government, generally commendable on the freedom religion despite some local authorities did minor infringement on the right of religion (US state Department 1999) . Corruption According to Plummer ( 2012 ) corruption in Ethiopia is common especially in the government institutions and organizations for example corruption in telecommunication sector is pervasive. In 1999 though number of mobile phones was very limited but corruption was relatively high. I can not justify all my answers are right but I can justify all are reasonable. Pershanps in the 1999 Ethiuopia wa under new leadership which was the guerrilla fighters who overthrew the Dergi Regime. In fact It was at war with Eritrea and depoted and arrested thousands of Eritrea. I know both Tigray Liberation Front (TLF ) which domnated the ruling party EPRDF and Eritrean Liberation Front ( EPLF ) followed alomst the sytem though ideologically differeed. Therefore, EPRDF led government of ethiopia do not seem good at handling or treating minorities and and also seem intorelent when journalists come to critize. and the ruling party does not seem to leave power via eletions becasue even the 2000 eletion did not seem fair though some reports said it iwas fair. Generally Ethiopia in the 1999 seemed be better than now because the 2005 election was the sheer violation of human rights.

Justification: The Ivory Coast was once one of West Africa's most prosperous states, however the regime of President Henri Konan Bédié from 1993-1999 sowed the seeds of an ethnic and religious conflict that was to tear the country apart. [1] From 1993-1995 Bédié was not an elected president, he served as an interim president following the death of the nation's founder in 1993. Politcal rights under Bédié were fairly straightforward to classify according to our metric: The elections held in 1995 were not considered to be either free or fair due to the ban on opposition supporters and general harassment, [2] however universal suffrage was present. [3] Opposition parties did exist under Bédié, and they were large, but there was little opportunity for them to gain power. Indeed one of the major reasons for the down fall of the regime was Bédié attempt to make the main opposition leader ineligible to oppose him due to ethnicity. [4] As a result not many people had access to political power. Journalists were ill trained and underpaid, making them particularly susceptible to corruption. [5] The only media outlet capable of reaching the majority of the population were state-owned. [6] The civil liberties that people enjoyed under the regime were somewhat harder to classify. Bédié appeared to have the ability to change the constitution at will: he lengthened presidential terms to 7 years (supposed to come into force after the 2000 elections that were prevent by the 1999 coup), although it was a struggle to identify if this had been achieved through his own voice as president or his power over the legislature. [7] It was also difficult to access the level of human rights people had access to under Bédié, although it is evident women's rights were consistently violated. [8] The judiciary was neither free nor fair, judges were political appointees and were not limited in their terms. [9] No measure existed that could investigate misuses of power, all organs of state were controlled by the president. [10] Minority groups in the Ivory Coast were previously treated well, however Bédié's regime promoted Ivory nationalism (which ultimately lead to the regimes downfall) . Throughout the regime there was evidence of widespread corruption and misuse of state resources. [11] Under Bédié the Ivory Coast scored poorly across almost all of our metric.
