Justification: I found it difficult to find specific information for many of the questions for Comoros. Some information also seemed contradictory, for example the extremely low freedom house ratings and the apparent existence of free and fair elections. Some questions were also difficult to answer due to the concurrent application of the French legal code and Sharia (Islamic) law, as this made it difficult to determine which is more commonly applied. Question 21 - Free and fair elections: Comoros scores poorly according to both Freedom House and Transparency International for electoral, and general political, freedoms. However, according to Freedom House Comorans have voted freely in several parliamentary and presidential elections since 1996. Political parties operate freely at both the federal and local level. Comoros also suffers from high levels of corruption and has a history of coups. As such I answered, 'Voting is free but opposition parties face some significant barriers to gaining power via elections' Question 22 - Universal suffrage: I answered, 'The majority of people in this country are able to vote. However, there are minor restrictions because of things such as age or incarceration, etc.' According to the CIA World Factbook, everyone over the age of 18 has the right to vote in Comoros. I was unable to find any other specific information on voting ability or restrictions. Question 23 - Opposition: I answered, 'There is a significant and effective opposition with a high likelihood of it being able to gain power through election' as there are several opposition parties and the government has changed more than once in the last ten to fifteen years. The presidency rotating between the three islands also ensures there is governmental change, at least in theory. I also selected this answer as I couldn't find anything to suggest otherwise. Question 24 -Access to political power: I didn't feel that any of the available options were entirely accurate for Comoros as, from the information I found, while not everyone has equal access to political power, wealth or family connections is not the deciding factor. Restrictions on access to political power in Comoros include gender; due to the presence of Sharia law women are underrepresented at the political level and only one parliamentary member is female, and religion; non-Sunni Muslims are also reportedly subject to restrictions and detentions. This combined with universal suffrage for those over the age of 18 led me to select that 'many people have access to political power, with some exceptions' as my answer. Question 25 -Media: Self-censorship is reportedly widespread and though the constitution and laws provide for freedoms of speech and the press these are not always implemented; Freedom House lists several cases of journalists, in varying fields of work, being arrested over reporting related to the issue of corruption. Transparency International's Press Freedom Index, which measures the violations of press freedom in the world, ranks Comors 45 th out of 179 countries. Comoros also scores very poorly on Transparency International's measure of 'Voice & Accountability' which captures perceptions of the extent to which a country's citizens are able to participate in selecting their government, as well as freedom of expression, freedom of association, and a free media. As such, I answered 'Independent media may exist, but there is heavy censorship, self-censorship or government intervention in editorial processes.' Question 26 -Rule of law: I answered, 'The leaders of the state are not subject to the rule of law.' In answering this question I considered both Transparency International and Freedom House. On a scale of -2.5 to 2.5, with higher values corresponding to better governance in terms of the rule of law, Transparency International gives Comoros a -1.06, placing it in the 14 th percentile. According to Freedom House the judicial system, which is based on both Sharia law and the French legal code, is subject to the influence of various elites, including the executive branch. Pre-trial detainments tend to be lengthy, and prison conditions are harsh with severe overcrowding and inadequate sanitation, medical care, and nutrition. Question 27 -Human rights: I answered, 'Partial rights exist, but there is still heavy suppression and monitoring.' Considerations in answering this question included the following information from Freedom House: Freedoms of assembly and association are typically upheld, though same-sex sexual activity is punishable by imprisonment and fines; with prison conditions including severe overcrowding and inadequate sanitation, medical care, and nutrition: the law also prohibits discrimination based on gender but this is not always practised due to the concurrent application of Sharia law, which limits gender equality: forced labour of Comoran children is not uncommon, despite a labour code criminalising the trafficking of children: and non-Sunni Muslims in Comoros are reportedly subject to restrictions, detentions and harassment, while conversion from Islam and non-Muslim preaching is illegal. As previously mentioned, Comoros also scores very poorly on Transparency International's measure of 'Voice & Accountability' which captures perceptions of the extent to which a country's citizens are able to participate in selecting their government, as well as freedom of expression, freedom of association, and a free media. Question 28 -Judiciary: As I mentioned in my justification of my answer to question 26, Comoros'judicial system is subject to the influence of various elites, including the executive branch. As such I answered, 'The judiciary is clearly not independent or free.' Transparency International does not have anything on judicial freedom in Comoros. Question 29 -Measures for regime accountability: According to Freedom House Comoros has a constitutional court that provides a check on electoral corruption, as well as other constitutional violations by the government. However, I'm not sure as to the effectiveness of the court as corruption is high in Comoros, and the fact that the constitutional court upheld the election of President Dhoinine in 2010 despite irregularities being reported on one of the islands. However, President Ikililou Dhoinine introduced the National Commission for the Prevention and Fight Against Corruption, which has had a positive effect on Comoros'ranking on Transparency Internationals Corruption Perceptions Index. There is also and Anti-Corruption Commission and a Supervisory Body for the Approval of Government Procurement (information found on Global Voices online) . This led to me answering 'Somewhere in between...' as there are some checks on power put in place by the current governemnt, and they appear to be becoming more effective. Questions 30 -Minority Groups: I answered 'There are only minimal rights for minority groups, and these may be often violated by the government.' According to Freedom House 98 percent of the populations are Sunni Muslim and non-Sunni Muslims are subject to restrictions, detentions, and harassment. Same-sex sexual activity is also punishable by imprisonment and fines. Question 31 -Confidence in answers: I selected a three in regards to my confidence in my answers to the above questions as the countries ratings on Freedom House and Transparency International are very poor, but the written information I accessed did not always correlate with this, as such I was unsure of how to answer some of the questions. Question 32 -Corruption: Comoros has a Corruption Perception Index score of 2.8 out of 10, which is 24% worse than the average. The World Bank's Control of Corruption Indicator ranks Comoros in the 25.6 th percentile. While it is currently ranked 127 th out of 177 countries, Comoros has gained six places compared to its 2012 ranking. According to 'Global Voices Online'this may be due to the installation of the National Commission for the Prevention and Fight Against Corruption by President Ikililou Dhoinine, which has laid the foundation for the fight against corruption in Comoros. Dhoinine has also signed an application decree establishing the Regulatory Authority for Public Procurement, committing to growing transparency in public affairs. These measures alongside checks such as the Anti-Corruption Commission should continue to see a decrease in corruption in Comoros. As corruption is being actively combatted I answered 'Corruption is common, but concentrated in only some levels of the state.' Question 33 -Forms of corruption: I didn't feel that any of the available options were quite right for describing corruption in Comoros as corruption is pervasive throughout the government, judiciary, and civil service, as well as among the police and security forces. However, I answered 'Misuse of public resources by top officials' as, according to Freedom House, in 2011, the opposition party -the CRC or Convention for the Renewal of the Comoros -led by former president Azali Assoumani, filed a complaint in a Moroni court against former president Ahmed Abdallah Sambi for alleged misuse of public funds while in office. A major cabinet reshuffle in July 2013 was also widely seen as a purge of politicians loyal to Sambi.

Justification: I chose to focus around the period 1997 to 2002, because I wanted to include the election of Nawaz Sharif as Prime Minister of Pakistan, his subsequent overthrowing, and the military rule of Pervez Musharraf. My justifications for my ratings are as follows: 21. Elections in 1997 appear to be free and fair, Sharif defeated Benazir Bhutto due to a failing economy, and corruption within the government. The election was observed by international observers. http://www.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/arc/2241_97.htm . In 2002, Musharraf relinquished power as Chief Executive (Prime Minister), but stayed on as President (until 2008) . Held elections, and closely followed them. Despite his assurances the elections were free and fair, many political parties alleged that the elections were rigged. However, none took further action. There were international observers present. I would not consider these elections transparent though. http://storyofpakistan.com/general-elections-2002/ . 22. 2002, minority communities were allowed to vote and contest seats for the first time. The age of voting was also lowered from 21 to 18. Before this, there were considerable restrictions to voting and participating in elections. Because these restrictions were in-place for the majority of the period I considered it to be only partial suffrage. http://storyofpakistan.com/general-elections-2002/ . 23. There is an effective opposition during democratic elections. Sharif's government was elected after being the opposition to Benazir Bhutto's pervious government. The 2002 election was close and resulted in a hung parliament. http://storyofpakistan.com/general-elections-2002/ . 24. Convicted people were barred from taking part in elections under the Representation of the People's Act. Several other politicians were unable to contest the elections, as they did not have a Bachelor's Degree, which was a mandatory qualification in the elections. Bachelor's Degree can reduce the chance for anyone to access political power. http://storyofpakistan.com/general-elections-2002/ . 25. Freedom House considers Pakistan's media in 2002 to be 'Partly Free', giving them a score of 57 out of 100 for 'Press Freedom'. Police shutdown newspaper offices under anti-blasphemy laws, which journalists claim were politically motivated charges. After the beginning of the War in Afghanistan, official expelled several European correspondents. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2002/pakistan#.VV3bBfmqqko . 26. Nawaz Sharif was allowed some lee-way when it came to manipulating the law, the military, and the governmental branches. With a strong majority in Parliament, Sharif was able to pass legislation with ease. He amended the constitution to take power away from the role of the president. He also attempted to interfere with the Pakistani Supreme Court. http://www.pakistanherald.com/newprofile.aspx?hofid=7 . However, with falling public opinion, and the attempt to manipulate the loyalty of the army, Chief of the Army Staff General Pervez Musharraf responded with a coup d'état. Sharif was removed from power and exiled, with Pervez taking power for himself. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/1999/pakistan#.VV3cI_mqqko . While Sharif was able to do as he pleased with a majority parliament. There was a point where the army felt like it had to act to ensure things did not get out of hand. Pakistani courts however did not indict Sharif for any of the charges brought against him, and he was allowed to leave the country. So I feel as if not everyone is subject to the rule of law. 27. Freedom House rates Pakistani civil liberties a solid five between 1997 and 2002. Meaning there are heavy restrictions on personal rights. As mentioned before, minorities only received the right to vote in 2002. https://freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/Individual%20Country%20Ratings%20and%20Status%2C%201973-2015%20%28FINAL%29.xls . 28. In 1997, Nawaz Sharif caused problems for the judiciary. Sharif was able to openly criticise the Chief Justice Ali Shah without any immediate punishment. Sharif then removed two judges close to the Chief Justice Ali Shah. The Prime Minister's supporters then entered the Supreme Court disrupting a hearing against Sharif. The Court system was under the influence of the Prime Minister. http://www.pakistanherald.com/newprofile.aspx?hofid=7 . 29. Because Sharif's party dominated the 1997 election, and won a complete majority in the house there was no real power in the legislative branch to hold him accountable. Because he interfered with the court system early on in his reign, they had little power against him. It was not until the Coup d'état in 1999, that Sharif was finally held accountable. 30. There was unequal treatment of minority ethnic groups within Pakistan during the period. Pakistan's anti-blasphemy laws (against the Prophet Mohammad) were/are used to intimidate religious minorities. http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2013/apr/30/pakistan-tops-worst-list-for-religious-freedom/ . 31. Some of the sources I have used may not be supported by academic findings (Pakistan Herald, Story of Pakistan) . 32. Benazir Bhutto had been removed from office due to widespread corruption in and around her office. Sharif was also sentenced to 14 years imprisonment for corruption. It was reported that investigators were looking into 18 separate allegations of corruption by former Prime Minister Sharif. These however, may or may not have been false allegations, with a sham trial orchestrated by Musharraf. I will however consider corruption to be pervasive throughout the Sharif Government. So it is difficult to answer. http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/845490.stm . 33. The case against Sharif centred around a civilian helicopter he had supposedly owned during the mid-1990s, and had not paid taxes on. In my opinion, this is classified as special privileges, and misuse of public resources? http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/845490.stm.

Justification: During the early part of the timeframe analysed in this exercise Nepal was still in a state of Civil war. Maoist rebels fought with the monarchy for great political control and the establishment of a People's Republic of Nepal. The conflict lasted 10 years and meant that democratic principles came under threat with the King seizing full control over Nepal in 2005. Corruption was also rife as the monarchy sought to stay in power by any means necessary. Peace accords in 2006 ended the civil war and saw in a paradigm shift to democracy in Nepal. Firstly, Nepal's elections were confined to the legislature with the executive being the King and royal family. These elections did mean that local representatives were elected and competition was rife and political parties did gain some control, but ultimate power always lay with the Monarch. From 2004 the Maoist insurgency had fallen into a stalemate with the large population centres held be government forces with the Maoist rebels holding much of the countryside. This prevented elections from taking place and forced the King to take absolute control in 2005. Nepal's monarchy was in complete control of the central government for the year of 2005 and was willing to reach a compromise in 2006 in order to ensure peace for the country. 2006 also saw the shift towards a more democratic and inclusive nation with the Maoists standing for political office. Secondly, during the insurgency journalists and wealthy individuals were targeted by the rebel groups, which decreased economic and press activity greatly. Freedom of the press could not be guaranteed by the state as journalists faced the very real prospect of assassination by Maoists. The monarchy also vetted press releases to further its own agenda. (Freedom House, 2005) . Press freedoms were greatly reduced over this period and this flowed onto individual freedom as travel became restricted and security checks on citizens became rampant. The security situation in Nepal during this period meant that civil liberties were greatly reduced to combat the severe insurgency throughout the country (Global Security, 2011) . Thirdly, access to political power was almost impossible for the average Nepalese Citizen. Connections to the royal family or owning large plots of land were the primary ways politicians held power over this period. The monarch relied heavily on a network of family members who advised him who could be trustworthy. Maoist regions saw persecution of those who supported the status quo and enforced tough restrictions on personal freedoms in areas under their control. The monarchy also purged citizens who it believed were Maoist sympathizers and used the police to prevent public gatherings of more than 10 people. Human Rights Watch has noted many abuses on both sides during the conflict, with a spike in human rights abuses by the monarchy in 2005 (Human Rights Watch, 2005) Finally, corruption during this period was at an all time high. Former members of the dissolved parliament sought to remain in positions of power through accepting bribes and using their personal influence to gain favour among the royal family. Nepal was ranked 90 out of 146 countries surveyed in Transparency International's 2004 Corruption Perceptions Index, which highlights the severity of the corruption. Police were known to accept cash bribes at low levels and even senior public bureaucrats were known to accept assistance from organised crime gangs as the civil war deepened. During these years the Monarchy lost legitimacy with its people as it failed to uphold anti-corruption policies put in place prior to the dissolving of parliament. Still today Nepal is plagued by corruption issues and the democratically elected government remains almost as closed as the monarchy that preceded it (Transparency International, 2014) . Justification: The turn into the second decade of the 21st century was one of pivotal importance for Iraq. The United States, which had played an occupying role since its invation to overthrow the regime of Saddam Hussein in 2003, were leaving, and the fledgling democracy it had created would be left to fend on its own. But, despite successful elections, the Iraqi government seems to be struggling with the tenets of democracy, and corruption remains pervasive. Although they were held two months late, Parliamentary elections in March 2010 were deemed relatively free and fair, despite violence on election day (Freedom House, 2012) . They were governed by a 2009 election law that introduced an open-list, proportional representation voting system, with multimember districts and seats reserved for women, Christians and other religious minorities (Freedom House 2012) . The Electoral Commission conducted a partial recount after opposition complaints, but no evidence was found of significant fraud. However, the elections brought months of political deadlock because none of the rival blocs, political parties representing various factions of Iraq, could combine to form a majority. It took until December for Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki to be reappointed after he agreed to form a unity government that encompassed all of Iraq's major factions (Freedom House 2012) . During this deadlock, violence in Iraq skyrocketed to levels not seen since the early days of US occupation, with insurgents targeting national institutions and other factions. In 2011, the United States began withdrawing its troops, and within days, tension again rose between Sunni and Shiite groups -and also political parties. Freedom House said this saw acts take place like Sunni parties boycotting parliament and Prime Minister Maliki seeking an arrest warrant for his own Vice President. It is for these sectarian and security reasons that Freedom House does not deem Iraq an electoral democracy. Although the country conducts meaningful elections, political participation and decision-making remains seriously impaired by sectarian and insurgent violence. The Parliament is also incomplete, with the upper house still unformed and executive functions remaining vacant (Freedom House 2012) . Regarding fundamental rights, Freedom House says political parties representing a wide range of viewpoints operate without legal restrictions -except for Saddam Hussein's Baath Party, which is officially banned. Freedom of expression is enshrined in the constitution, however it is impeded by sectarian tension and fear of violent reprisals. The media is allowed to function without significant interference, although party ownership, security fears and threats of violence towards journalists create an environment of minor self-censorship (Freedom House 2012) . Freedom of religion and assembly is also guaranteed, however sectarian violence has threatened both of these. Arbitrary arrest and detention, torture, and inhumane treatment are all banned under the constitution, but there are few effective safeguards to prevent them from happening, and reports of it are commonplace (Freedom House 2012) . Transparency International rates Iraq as one of the most corrupt countries in the world, with corruption being endemic at every level and in every facet of the government. It says corruption risks have been exacerbated by the historical legacy of the Hussein regime, a lack of experience in the public sector, a weak capacity to absorb aid money, sectarian issues and a lack of political will for anti-corruption efforts (Pring 2015, p1) . Iraq's main anti-corruption body, the Commission of Integrity, has estimated that US$330 billion of public money is missing or unaccounted for (Pring 2015, p8) . While a number of anti-corruption initiatives have been introduced in the country, the legal framework is insufficient to tackle corruption, according to Transparency International. The Commission of Integrity is subject to interference from the government, and the Ombudsman's office is weak and under-funded (Pring 2015, p8) . The judiciary, like other institutions, while constitutionally independent, suffered from nepotism and clientelism (Pring 2015, p9) . In his article Iraq: The Masked Democracy? Aaron Edwards writes that despite strong election turnouts, Iraq is far from stable and that widespread sectarian violence, human rights abuses and endemic corruption leaves a question mark hanging over the country's political future (Edwards, 2013: p 12) . ===== Justifications: Q21,22,23,24: These answers are based off the 2010 election. Q21: Banning the Baathists is still a restriction, hence why it was marked down. Also, the security situation may have played a role in preventing people from voting. Q23: A significant and effective opposition exists to the point of political stagnation. Q26: Endemic corruption. Iraq was difficult to answer as none of the questions really took into account the effect a weak security situation and sectarian divides played in the country's instability and corruption. While there may be free and fair elections and rights enshrined in the constitution, in many cases these were over-ridden. Bibliography: Freedom House (2012) . Iraq: Freedom in the World 2012. Justification: Political Rights: Nicaragua between 1999 and 2006 was a country that generally protected political rights although certain restrictions did apply. Freedom House rated the country 'partial free'in 1999 and between 2002 and 2006 ( https://freedomhouse.org/reports#.VV5ycPmqqkp ) noting that 'Nicaraguans can change their government democratically' with the country having a voting age of 16, universal suffrage and a number of choices of parties. Although they do note that '[c] hanges in the political system in 1999 made it increasingly difficult for smaller parties to achieve electoral representation' . As a result I scored Nicaragua a 2 for question 21. In terms of access to political power, I had to make an educated guess. It seems like leaders of the largest parties generally retain their position for long periods so I would guess that, although people have access to and can run for local office fair easily, access to power at the highest level is maintained in a fairly oligarchical way, with a few families/clichés dominating national politics. Hence I scored the country a 2 for question 24. Another topic that informed my answer for question 24 (as well as 25) was press freedom. Although Nicaragua has a free press it is highly politicized with newspapers siding with particular parties. This led journalists to cite 'the lack of access to public information and the culture of secrecy that pervades the government' ( https://cpj.org/2003/03/attacks-on-the-press-2002-nicaragua.php ) as problems in 2002. They also voiced concerns that 'the government gives a disproportionate share of advertising to large media outlets that support its agenda at the expense of smaller organizations without government ties' ( https://cpj.org/2005/03/attacks-on-the-press-2004-nicaragua.php ) in 2004. For these reasons I scored Nicaragua a 2 for question 25. Civil Liberties: To answer these questions I mainly used Freedom House's 2004 and 2006 'Countries at the Crossroads'reports ( https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2004/nicaragua#.VV5yt_mqqko and https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2006/nicaragua#.VV6EYPmqqkp ) . These reports showed that while Nicaragua has all the trappings of a liberal democracy (constitution proclaiming rule of law, separation of powers, freedom of speech etc) in reality such institutions are generally quite flawed (although not completely for show) . I had difficultly answering question 26 as there was no option for people with means (not just those in power influencing the outcome of criminal and civil matters. The 2006 report states that although rule of law is guaranteed by the constitution, 'the belief that people without means bear the full brunt of the law while the well-to-do buy their way out of trouble is pervasive' . In the end I decided to rank Nicaragua a 1 as the pervasive nature of such breaches made me uncomfortable saying that 'The rule of law is generally upheld, but notable and significant breaches do occur.' Freedom of assembly and association are respected with the 2004 report stating: 'The constitution protects the rights of public assembly, demonstration, and mobilization. Organizers of public activities must obtain a permit, but this is regularly granted. In general the government has not used excessive force to maintain order during public events, including protests and strikes. Political parties are free to organize.' However it goes on to concluded woman's rights, which are upheld in theory, are not in practice. The report goes on: ' Deeply rooted cultural practices of male dominance (machismo) and the exclusion of women from significant public roles (marianismo) are rampant. Episodic efforts to redress generalized injustice, for example in pay, have met with limited success. Similarly, though, there are measures on the books that protect women from domestic violence and rape, these have been under-funded and not pursued with great vigor.' This made answering question 27 difficult. In the end I scored the country 2 although I would not describe the conditions above as a country where '[r] ights are generally upheld, but there is still minor suppression' I cannot see heavy state suppression, monitoring or surveillance so it seemed like the best fit. The reports are heavily critical of the judiciary and checks on power. They cite the ability for large parties to colonize the judiciary at all levels as key issues asserting in 2004 that 'pervasive culture of corruption [within the judiciary] has yet to be fully addressed' . In 2006 is stated that: 'The branches of state do not check one another as liberal-democratic governance requires. Since 2000, the dominant Sandinista and Liberal parties have used their control over the National Assembly to colonize and subordinate other branches and agencies of government, with the current exception of the executive. In 2005, these parties continued to control the elections council, judiciary, comptroller's office, attorney general's office, and ombudsman's office, politicizing each and vitiating the independence of and separation among the powers of government, thereby fostering corruption.' However the 2004 reports explained that former president Aleman had been convicted for fraud and embezzlement. Therefore I scored the country a 1 for question 29 as 'the regime sometimes investigates alleged breaches.' Both reports raise concerns surrounding rights and representation of ethnic minorities however they are not openly repressed hence I scored Nicaragua a 2 for question 30. Corruption: Both reports cite corruption as a major problem for Nicaragua between 1999 and 2006. The 2004 report states that 'state is still opaque to most Nicaraguans' and that although the 'media have shed light on some state corruption, but the public does not have genuine access to government information' . The 2006 report gives Nicaragua a slightly better score but adds that 'corruption allegations are never properly investigated and courts issue few convictions' . Instead it assert that authorities have pursued cases that took place under the former president Aleman. All the evidence points to corruption being endemic within the government and civil service and that dealing with corruption is an inherent part of doing business in Nicaragua with public officials taking bribes and the judiciary susceptible to economic persuasion.

Justification: Political rights the main source I used to answer these questions was the EUs Mozambique Election Follow-Up Mission Summary 2013. Here the EU delegates outlined that improvements had been made in how elections were carried out in the country, however there were still areas that needed attention. An example was the worry that preventing people with criminal convictions running for president could be unconstitutional. An issue that this raises is that the incumbent government could strive to convict opposition leaders in order to exclude them from the political arena. This is a worry in Mozambique as the opposition party RENAMO carries out extensive protests against election processes. It would be possible for the government to arrest protestors, convict them, and then exclude them from running. Civil liberties For this section I used sources such as the World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples (WDMIP), The Open Societies'report on Mozambique's judicial system, and Freedom House's review of free media. Here I found that some extensive defamation laws protecting the President and other political elites degraded the freedom of press, as journalists are exposed to possible prison sentences. Further to this WDMIP's analysis of the treatment of minorities in the country highlighted the divide between south and north as a significant block to equality. The south represents the political elite who have consolidated power, where the north represents the opposition party RENAMO. As recently as 2005 there have been violent protests between the two groups. However the judicial system in Mozambique appears to be effective in ensuring the rule of law and holding government to account when it rules that there have been breaches in the constitution. For this reason I scored Mozambique threes on the judicial questions. Corruption Based on transparency international report on corruption in Mozambique the country scores a 2.7 out of 10, with zero equaling completely corrupt. Corruption in the country for businesses takes the form of extensive bureaucratic involvement in small to medium enterprises, drawing resources away from performance increasing activities and towards compliance. An initiative to reduce this is the simplification of regulations, a step that the government hopes will reduce the possibility of corruption and return firms human capital towards growth, rather than navigating complex regulation. Further to this the report found that there is significant regulation surrounding financing of political campaigns, but that in practice little of it is ever implemented.

Justification: Swaziland is at the whim of an absolute monarch who commands supreme power over generally all forms of political life. The government of Swaziland cannot be changed democratically and all political parties are banned. The King has strict control over the media, especially when it refers to the royal family, and there is no system of checks and balances that protects judicial independance from the King. With this in mind, the King does take the views of his legislature and advisoray council, and makes an effort to include certain people from minority groups that may have been left out of the political equation to have a voice. The Prime Minister is selected from the legislature by the King, himself.

The previous president was ousted amongst corruption rumours and succeeded by Arroyo who had appeared to have been very popular at first, but she did have to resist a few coups from supporters of the previous president. Corruption_types: "Other"
Justification: Corruption as merriam-webster states is definied as 'dishonest or illegal behavior especially by powerful people (such as government officials or police officers) '. In regard to the question above, as well as the definition of corruption given, I believe Brazil to be a relatively un-corrupted country in the time period of 1997-2006. I have come to this conclusion after researching the government processes as well as looking at instances of controversy in Brazil during the time period. I found it interesting as well as optimistic to see that the government election's in Brazil are relatively free and equal. By this I mean that opposition parties have a good chance of getting into parliament. This can be seen in the two terms Fernando Henrique Cardoso served (Brazilian Social Democracy Party) from 1994 till 2002, when he was replaced by opposition leader Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva (Workers Party) . This is very important for two reasons, firstly it illustrates a functioning democracy, secondly Lula (as he is known) was a political prisoner himself, which shows that regardless of wealth or position any citizen (with the right mind) can win an election. It is interesting to note however, that Lula's government and subsequent legislature is considered the most corrupt in the country's history. However all is not sunshine and rainbows in Brazil. Groups such as the 'landless', people from poor backgrounds with no legitimate home have undergone significant violence from the police force. The police murder rate in Brazil is monumentally high. For example 'figures released by the state secretariat of public security showed that the police killed 317 civilians in the first seven months of 1999'. This lead on to 1997 having one of the highest rates of police homicide rate. This is important in regard to how the judiciary deal with these murders and whether the police officers involved are treated the same in the eyes of the law. 'From 1971 until July 1999, only twenty-eight officers had been expelled or sanctioned with a loss of rank in São Paulo.' This is the same state where 317 civilians were killed in the first seven months of 1999. On this basis one can see that only two police at the very most are punished for their treatment of civilians, while the rest (which number in the hundreds) are let free with no repurcussions for their actions. It is believed this is due to the Police force being exclusively dealt with by the military police rather than the government itself. The prison and rehabilitation system in Brazil is also heavily defunct and seems to be heavily corrupt in the sense that they are managing the system dishonestly. I believe this due to the statistics on how many prisoners the Brazilian jail system can hold, and how many they actually hold in the system. Census results in 1999 showed that while Brazilian prisons had capacity for just over 74,000 inmates, they held more than 170,000. More than double their capacity. To deal with this influx of prisoners, the system crams prisoners into cells in police stations (unfit for longterm prisoners) and over-filled prisons which cannot be managed and inturn drive crime forward rather than backwards through proper rehabilitation. Inside the prisons themselves mass violence has been shown to exist, for example 'On June 2, after a disturbance at the Americana City Jail in São Paulo state, the special police made more than one hundred detainees strip and then run a gauntlet. Police in two parallel lines beat the semi-naked prisoners with whips, bats, iron bars, bottles, and other objects; afterwards, they poured vinegar and saltwater over the prisoners' open wounds. A week later, at the Fiftieth Police District, twelve police officers entered thelockup, forced detainees to strip to their underwear, and engaged in an abuse session that included severe beatings with bats and metal bars, and electric shocks. Police repeatedly beat detainee Nilson Saldanha on the head, injuring him so severely that he died ten days later.' Such beatings and torture are rampant in the media, however not much has been done to solve the problem of over-crowding of jails as well as abuse of the prisoners themselves. In conclusion i belive that while Brazil has a great track record for free and fair elections as well as relatively good human rights, they fall short (and hard) in regard to police violence and mismanagement of the rehabilitation system which predominantly involves the poorest of Brazils civilians (the Landless) . This is a big short-coming as without a police force the civilians of Brazil feel safe with, the security of personal human rights is severly pesimistic and leaves the civlians exposed.

Justification: Syria is an Arab Muslim country located in the West of Asia. Syria is the home to diverse ethnic and religious groups such as Greeks, Truks, Kurds, Armenians, Assyrians, and religious group that include, Muslim Sunni, Alawite, Christians, Druz religion, Mandeanism and Yezidi and the Sunni Arabs make the largest group of people in Syria. These differences overshadowed most of the political cases of Syria. The research meant to examine Syria in the year of 2000 as a case study. The year of 2000, was the point of change for the Syrian politics. In that year former president of Syria Hafiz Al Assad, current president Bashar' father has died and therefore, Bashar Al Assad has taken the position of his father and was elected as the new president for Syria. Fair and free election for Syria? considering the results of the elections it is hard to say that Syria enjoy a fair election. Yet could be free but not fair election. In 2000, president Bashar was elected as the president of Syria when he gain 99.7% of the total vote and being the only and one candidate on that election which is lack of legitimacy. While there are no other candidates to compete with Bashar and form options for people to choose the candidate that represents them. Universal suffrage? Suffrage is the right to vote in elections, and the universal suffrage is considered being the most important in suffrage, when all those who are counted as adults in a country will have the right to vote without any sex, race, religious distinctions. In Syria, partial suffrage is alowed, adults who are over 18 and are able to vote are those who use to vote. Voting is not compulsory. Effective opposition?! In Syria there is no effective opposition. Absolute power lies in the hands of the ruling party. However, there are small parties that does not make any changes or noticeable influence to the decision of the government. In the year of 2000, there was no opposition to government. The election in the year of 2000 was more likely to be a referendum that has followed Bashar's nomination for presidency to confirm the Parliament choice bringing Bashar as president to Syria. Opposition to government was not allowed. Based on The Europa World Year Book 2002, Bashar's uncle, Rifaat Al-Assad 'claimed that the assumed succession by Bashar was unconstitutional, and declared that he would challenge his nephew for the presidency. But the Syrian authorities reportdly issued a warrent for Rifaat's arrest should he attempt to enter the country from exile.' Therefore, this approve that there is no existence for opposition in Syria, and that it is strongly prohibited. Do people have effective access to political power? Not all Syrians have access to political power, when there are still many Syrians are far from being able to participate in politics. The meaning here is that there are many people who still live in borders which is not being politically reached or those who live in the rural. On the other hand, people may have access but it is not considered being an effective access due to the policies that does not give the people the rights for effective access to political power or even the restrictions that it poses over them. Media act as check and balance on power? In Syria and most of the Arab countries' governments exercise its power to impose censorship in all different type of the media, visual or printed ones and certainly if a state denies to give its people the basic right to access to political power it will not let the media to act as a check and balance of power and off course if there is no opposition for the government it is hard to find an effective media that check and balance the power. Does this regime uphold the rule of law? the regime of Bashar failed to uphold the rule of law. The way that Bashar used to treat his people by and not being accounted for, show that the rule of law is far from being upheld by Bashar's regime. The fact that there are many people were suffering from being excluded from politics and the minorities that were excluded and not being treated well question whether the rule of law was carried out or not. Access to fundamental human rights?! Partialy. Some of the fundamental human rights which criticise the government and its politics is not acceptable. For instance, the case of Bashar's uncle, when he criticised the legitimacy of Bashar's government and that Bashar should not be the president since there was no complete legitimate election and that he would compete Bashar to gain the power. The reaction of the Syrian authorities was pretty tough when an arrest warrent issued against him, this show how the Syrian government is considering such speeches and that it afraid of all what criticise the government. Free, independent and fair judiciary? The judiciary in Syria is not fully fair and independent, when it is also influenced by some of the political factors. Especially in a country such like Syria the country that are imposed to many issues that threat the Syrian survival. There are no effective process to keep the regime accountable for all its actions despite all the attempts that are carried out. This illustrated clearly, when we see all kinds of injustice going on but no any changes are to be made in regards to all the issues. Minorities in Syria still facing discrimination. Regarding this, Syria is a country with the diverse ethnic and religious group. Therefore, the apartheid easily to be found and difficult to be addressed. Some of the answers was predicted from other information due to the difficulty to find the exact information that answer them correctly. As well as that there were some question which were difficult to answer either not covered enough or were not specific.

Justification: The time period that has been chosen for the study of the political regime in Taiwan is 1990 to 2014, in which the political regime was democratic. During this period, Taiwan had undergone democratic reform between 1980 and 1990, after the decline of threat from mainland China and popular democratic protests. Taiwan ended it martial law in 1987 and gradually restored democracy. In the period of 1990 to 2000, it was a period of transformation from authoritarianism to democracy, thus during this time there were still some characteristics of authoritarianism. Since 1990, Taiwan has had a semi- presidential system in which the president is the head of state and the commander in chief of the armed forces. Both the president and members of parliament are directly elected. However, the period from 1990 and 2014 was largely democratic and political situation during this period was stable; there was no interruption by extra-constitutional forces. There have been peaceful transfers of power from one government to the next. In the democratic regime, Taiwan has a separation of power. Taiwan has a separation of power, there are five branches of government; legislative, executive, judiciary, control, and examination. The legislative branch is directly elected through the mix member proportional system. The parliament has the proactive and reactive power which means that they can create bills and pass legislation as well as reviewing and cutting the budget when it is deemed necessary. The executive branch consists of the president, vice president, and cabinet members. In Taiwan, the executive branch holds most power in the government. The president can request the legislature to reconsider problematic or controversial bill and if the bill cannot be passed within 15 days then it would be invalid. The control branch of government is in charge of the public service and the investigation of corruption cases. The examination branch of government is in charge of the civil service and examination of civil servants. The multiple branches of government demonstrate the great degree of separation of power within the government. More importantly, the branches of government operate independently of the executive branch. This is important especially for the judiciary and the control because they are important in combating injustice and corruption. Taiwan has an effective separation of power under this regime. Elections between 1990 and 2014 have been free and fair, and voters have had political freedom and rights. According to Freedom House, throughout his period Taiwan was considered as 'free'. There is universal suffrage, all adults (20 years old and above) have the right to vote. Before 1990, there was a monopoly of power under the Kuomintang (KMT), who established the nationalist government in Taiwan in 1949. Since then, the party controlled the state assets, media, and companies. Prior to democratization, there were authoritative elections in which KMT used party assets for vote buying and created patronage and clientelism with companies and local political factions. After 1990, the ban on opposition parties was lifted and the political playing field became evener. The first legislative popular election occurred in 1991 after the removal of the old legislature that was elected in 1947. The first direct presidential popular election occurred in 1996 which brought Lee Teng-hui from the KMT to power. Despite democratization, the KMT remains the dominant party in Taiwan politics and when Taiwan, the KMT had a significant advantage as the incumbent government. However, there was the liberalization of the media which allowed for freedom of press, speech and expression. For example, some newspapers no longer support KMT, such as China Times and United Daily News. Political parties used the media for their political campaigns against the KMT party during election time, which led to the decline of KMT's popularity. However, KMT dominance did not end until 2000 when the first non-KMT president was elected, Chen Shui-bian from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was elected the president. The democratic regime in Taiwan between 1990 and 2014 has been effective as it was possible for a new opposition party to be elected into office. As Taiwan became more democratic, the problem of corruption has declined. The contestation of power between political parties has led to the decline in corruption. It is common for opposition parties to target corruption issues of the incumbent government. A tactic in which opposition parties use against the incumbent is the exposition of corruption consequently, the popularity of the incumbent declined. The reduction of corruption became important in winning elections. The form of corruption common in Taiwan is public officials taking bribes from the private sector, the government has been subjected to the influence of big businesses. The liberalization of media played an important role in exposing the citizens to the wrong doings of the government and its officials. It is an important mechanism which has helped prevent public officials from engaging in corruption. References: Chang, Pao-Min. 'Taiwan: The 1994 Elections.' Asian Affairs 22, no. 4 (1996) : 224-38. Justification: Suriname Suriname is relatively small state in South America, with a population of only around 500,000. The country while small, is a thriving democratic state, though this was not always the case. The country was ruled by Jules Wijdenbosch until 1999 when midyear his rule began to crumble and the likely favourite to take over the country was ex-dictator Desi Bourterse. Bourterse though had a checked past. The Dutch courts had tried and convicted the ex-dictator of drug trafficking just a few years prior. It seemed the country was not ready to forgive Bourterse as instead elected former president Ronald Venetiaan (Freedom House, 2001) . Venetiaan stated that he would focus on improving corruption and economic development in the state, as Wijdenbosch had left state with a 20 percent unemployment rate and a troubled legacy due to Bourterse. Venetiaan held power for ten years in the state (Freedom House, 2001) . For this reason I will focus on the stable presidency of Venetiaan, that is, from 2000-2010. The Surinamese state houses an electoral democracy, that is, the president and vice-president are elected indirectly. Elections are held every five years in Suriname where the National Assembly of Suriname is elected into parliament. It is this group who then decides on the presidency. Fifty-one members of the National Assembly had been elected on May 25, 2000 (Caribbean Elections, 2015) . The elections seem to be free and fair as all members of the National Assembly are able to vote on who they believe to be fit for president. The population of Suriname is also able to vote by using their polling cards (separate to a national identity card) . Both forms of election were observed by the Organisation of American States (OAS) . The 2000 elections were only the fourth time OAS had observed Suriname. The OAS stated the elections were conducted in a 'peaceful [manner] and demonstrated a spirit of tolerance.' (Organization of American States, 2001) . Therefore there are competitive and transparent free and fair elections with a high chance of the governing arrangements changing as a result of them. Though it was noted by (Organization of American States, 2001) that polling cards had not reached all pollers in remote areas. The Constitution of Suriname has universal suffrage, where all Surinamese national adult (above the age of 18) are able to vote. All voters must register as it is compulsory in the state to vote, though this is not policed (Organization of American States, 2001) . As stated above, the country holds elections every five years. Though the political system appears weak due to the lack of change in political leadership as the elites of the 1970s are in fact still in power (Netherlands Institute for Multiparty Democracy, 2009) . However, it still can be said that there was effective opposition in the 2000 election as Bourterse, was expected to win the election, but Venetiaan promised the country a better economy. Venetiaan eventually won out. There have been other presidents in the state (Wijdenbosch), and a record 23 parties competed in the 2000 elections (Organization of American States, 2001) . It is clear the state holds elections with a significant and effective opposition and a high likelihood of being able to gain power through election. While the country is democratic it could be said that not all individuals of the state have access to political power. It is said that woman have had little power in the state. The National Assembly is made up of 51 members but only six of these members were woman before 2000. There is also less representation of indigenous peoples (the Maroons and Amerindians) where there was only 12 indigenous members out of 51. It is thought that indigenous people are less likely to participate in the political process as these people often live in the remote areas of the state. That is many people have access to political, with some exceptions, i.e. sometimes woman and indigenous people. (United States Department of State, 2011) . It is thought that news outlets in the state were linked and influenced by many political parties. Senior government officials also used intimidation techniques on news outlets which posted negative stories on the government. (United States Department of State, 2011) Freedom House (2001) though, asserts that state media generally offers pluralistic viewpoints and that state and commercial radio stations compete with one another. I would say that while there was some government influence on what is being reported on, this was not always the case as Reporters without Borders found Surinamese media to be in a 'good situation' from 2008, where before that it was not recorded (Kholsa, 2014) . Therefore, no state censorship, but a degree of self-censorship may exist, or there is substantial government influence on what is reported . Civil Liberties in the state in 1999 were not too great with the state scoring a 3.0 out of 7.0 in the index but when Venetiaan became the president the state moved up to a 2.0 and has held this position ever since (Knoema, 2015) . While the state provides Freedom of Assembly and Association the country has a weak civil society as it does not have enough capacity to pressure the government, so the government is not pushed to uphold the citizen's needs (Netherlands Institute for Multiparty Democracy, 2009) . Though it should be said that rights are generally upheld, but there is still minor suppression . It could be said that because many of the ex-political rulers are still in power it is hard for rule of law to be established. These ex-leaders still have a say over the country even after having passed their time as president (Netherlands Institute for Multiparty Democracy, 2009) . Therefore while the rule of law is generally upheld, there are notable and significant breaches . The country hosts an extremely weak judiciary which often experiences political influence on cases. As Freedom House (2002) states, it is also ineffective as there is a massive number of cases to be dealt with and not enough staff. While prisons suffer from overcrowding and institutions such as the police abuse their rights and mistreat prisoners regularly (Freedom House, 2002) . Corruption was found as well throughout both the previous and current government (United States Department of State, 2011 ) . Therefore while the judiciary sometimes operated independently, it susceptible to undue influence and corruption . Suriname does not have an independent Ombudsman though from as early as 2000 there had been calls for one to be established. It wasn't until 2011 (after Venetiaans presidency) that the government accepted the calls to establish one. Also, the government had a noticeable absence of appropriate checks and balances (Cardenas, 2014) . As a result it could be said that there are no checks and balances on power, but the regime may sometimes investigates alleged breaches . The country houses two groups of indigenous people, the Maroons and Amerindians. These groups are said to be discriminated against even at the state level. While Surinamese law prohibits discrimination on the basis of race, Freedom House reports that indigenous individual's rights to lands are not upheld nor is their cultural integrity (Freedom House, 2001) . Their land is given away by the government to the mining industry without consultation. Due to these minority groups often living in remote areas they do not receive the same access to education and health as other Surinamese do (United States Department of State, 2011) . There are legal and statutory rights, but there is active social and procedural discrimination and inequality towards groups or minorities, such as over-representation in the criminal justice system and electoral systems which lock minority groups out of power. Transparency International (2015) ranks Suriname a 4.3 out of ten in 2004 in terms of corruption. While the country successfully overcame the military rule of Bourterse and the economic deprivation by Wijdenbosch, corruption was still found throughout the state. The criminal economy thrived through drug trafficking and gold smuggling while social inequalities divided the state (Encyclopædia Britannica, 2015) . The countries ex- president Bourterse was on trial for drug trafficking during the time of the 2000 election, showing that corruption was found at the very top of the state. Although in terms of answering the question I would say that corruption is common, but concentrated in only some levels of the state as it seemed that it was mostly the old government who was corrupt and Venetiaan's goal when becoming president was for the state to become less corrupt, which he had succeeded in. The Global Competitiveness Report shows that the amount of bribes or irregular payments made were drastically decreasing (Knoema, 2013), from which one can assume that bribe-taking by public officials (or others) was previously being condoned, Condoning illegal business dealings can be seen in the state due to the large amounts of drug trafficking found, and Misuse of public resources by top officials can also be seen when the government takes advantage of the indigenous people over land. Special privileges granted to politically-connected people can also be seen in Suriname as Freedom House (2006) states favouritism was common among the elites of the state. The above answers provide reasonable evidence for each on the questions on the Regime Classification exercise. Therefore I would rate my confidence in my answers at 4.3 as I thoroughly researched the Surinamese state not just focusing on using one website and didn't make educated guesses, instead I went looking for the answers. Though I would not rate my confidence as high as I did for the classification of Mexico as when researching Suriname it was a lot harder to find authoritative material or a wide a variety of sources. Justification: As the relevant years are between1992-2006, states that use to belong to Yugoslavia and have since become independent will not be included. Regarding the political rights of Yugoslavia in this period, free and fair elections were present in the 2000 elections as NGOs were present to observe the process. Other elections have been corrupted by Milosevic up until then. Restrictions are present in the electoral process but during the 2000 elections, 70% of the population participated electing Milosevic's political opponent as the new President. Unsure of other election prior to 2000 elections. Yugoslavia allowed people of or ethnicities to form political parties allowing people access to political power but of course they still need to be elected into parliament. There were movement censorship in the years Milosevic was in power and there is still a small presents of censorship but a rise in opposition and independent media outlets have increased since 1992. Therefore the Yugoslavia political rights score is moderate showing partial freedom (score:10/15) Rule of law is not always followed. There allowance of fundamental human rights to an extent with some restrictions as there is a presents of harassment and tension between different communities such as the different religious communities. The judiciary was not independent and opponents of Milosevic were removed from office. Holding the regime accountable would not happen until much later (ie towards the end of Milosevic rules and international intervention) . Many crimes committed by Milosevic indirectly were never solved and ties with organized crime were very present. Treatment of minorities by Milosevic regime was very harsh and many activists were imprisoned only being released when Milosevic lost power. Civil liberties score: 8/15 indicating another partial free score. Corruption in the state was very apparent during Milosevic's rule and the transitions after his rule began the rise of anti-corruption taskforces that target those loyal to Milosevic and that gained many benefits from being his 'cronies.' Theft of from the public sector, corruption in the arm forces and local police, economic crimes and assassinations to name a few were all allowed under Milosevic's regime and that is why the international community saw Yugoslavia under Milosevic as one of the most corrupt states in the world (at the time) . Justification: Question twenty one The 1994 elections saw the Social Christian Reformist party aligned with the Christian Democratic political movement, the leader being Balaguer, against the Dominican Revolutionary Party aligned with the Socialist International, whose leader was Gomez, against the Dominican Liberation Party, whose leader was Bosch. In this election it was observed internationally that there were irregularities in the voter lists and the Dominican Revolutionary Party charged the Central Electoral Board and the Social Christian Reformist party with fraud. These charges were not accepted and determined that 200,000 citizens had been excluded. Balaguer was sworn in despite popular demand for new elections. However, two years later in the 1996 elections, the Dominican Revolutionary Party won in its first round and was defeated in its second round by Fernandez'Dominican Liberation Party after gaining support from the Christian Reformist Party. These elections were deemed free and fair, domestically and internationally. Question twenty two This country has universal suffrage, people over the age of eighteen can vote, married people of any age can vote. There are exclusions of members of armed forces or national police, who can not vote. Additionally discriminated minority groups, can not vote, such as the Dominican Haitians. Question twenty three There is an effective opposition, there are several oppositional parties as outlined in question 21, it is possible for these countries to be elected to govern and gain power through election. Question twenty four The Dominican Republic is a small country where family connections and friendships play a part in politics. This results in wealthy elite and people with connections, by blood, marriage or friendship, being in power. Question twenty five The majority of media in the Dominican Republic is mostly private. In the early 2000s Freedom House suggested that despite newspapers being independent, they could be subject to governmental pressure through the denial of advertising revenues and taxes. In Transparency International's press freedom index, the Dominican Republic currently ranks 95/179. Question twenty six The Dominican Republic currently ranks at 25% in regards to how the rule of law is followed; data for the years in question can be found on World Bank and suggests that there was a ranking of 34% in 1994 through to 2000 http://info.worldbank.org/governance/wgi/pdf/c64.pdf Question twenty seven Freedom House claims that the government generally respects freedom of speech and freedom of assembly and association as human rights. According to the Human Rights Commission, prisons are often overcrowded, unsanitary and inmates are often the subject of extreme violence. Police brutality and police corruption has been a big issue in the Dominican Republic for some time, often clouded with allegations to do with bribes around illegal drug trafficking. Question twenty eight The Dominican Republic's judiciary is and was corrupt. The judicial branch is known to be another branch of the governing party's power, rather than a separate institution. According to Freedom House, the courts do not offer services or recourse to those without wealth or power. Additionally, in most prisons nine out of ten inmates have not been convicted. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/1998/dominican-republic#.VV7TZkJ0ba4 Question twenty nine When it comes to checks and balances on power, it is claimed that the Executive controls over half of the government budget. Additional claims state that checks and balances only exist on paper and that the judicial branch, as discussed before, is not independent. This article by political scientist Edward Gonzalez-Acosta comments that because of this non-separation of powers, it fuels competition between parties even more to gain control over all branches and resources. http://www.alterinfos.org/spip.php?article2032 Question thirty The Dominican Republic does not uphold the right to equal treatment and due process when it comes to minority groups. Haitians who live in the Republic do not have this equal treatment, Dominican authorities have been changing policies on nationality to exclude Haitians from certain rights. One ruling meant that the Electoral Commission was ordered to remove Haitians who were Dominican citizens from the electoral roll. Dominicans of Haitian decent can not travel, marry, work, register children or to vote, not to mention general discrimination. This minority group does not enjoy the same civil liberties as the rest of the public. Question thirty three When it comes to question 33, bribe taking by public officials and condoning illegal business deals both can describe the Dominican Republic's condoning of illegal drug trafficking for bribes. Many of these questions were hard to answer given the scarcity of data relevant to the country and general time period.

Justification: North Korea is a textbook example of a highly oppressive totalitarian regime. Investigating the DPRK did not unearth any information that was not expected. The provided questions were all relevant in classifying the North Korean regime as it is a less complex situation as it is obvious that the oppression, corruption and societal problems are either officially sanctioned by the government, a result of government activity or an essential part to the ongoing function of the regime. Unlike the failed government in Afghanistan the North Korean regime is strong and power is highly centralised around a cult of personality leader. North Korea functions as a single-party state under a totalitarian family dictatorship. The Korean Workers Party (KWP), which was founded in 1926 and led by Kim Il-sung, is the only legally permitted party. Kim Jong-un currently serves as the 'first secretary' of the KWP. The North Korean parliament is elected to 5-year terms. All candidates are selected by the KWP and they run unopposed. There are no political rights available and citizens or state officials that attempt to exercise any political belief other than that which is officially sanctioned by the KWP will be incarcerated in Nazi style prison camps or executed. All domestic media outlets are run by the state. Televisions and radios are permanently fixed to state channels, and all publications are subject to strict supervision and censorship. Access to information is strictly controlled and it is widely understood that the general population in the DPRK have no knowledge on the realities of the outside world and their situation. This is a key instrument of control employed by the regime. North Korea does not have an independent judiciary. The UN General Assembly has recognized and condemned severe DPRK human rights violations, including torture, public executions, extrajudicial and arbitrary detention, and forced labor; the absence of due process and the rule of law; and death sentences for political offenses. Updated South Korean reports estimate that there are 80,000-120,000 political prisoners held in detention camps in the country. Corruption in North Korea is an integral part of the regime. The misuse of public resources is so endemic that it has developed into an independent economy in its own right. The use of public funds in the purchasing of luxuries for the purposes of rewarding service to the regime has become a key instrument in the maintenance of loyalty and the development of admiration towards the regime. There is no Universal Suffrage as there are no meaningful elections but there would be little point to elections as the Kim Dynasty is idolised like gods and I would suspect that due to the ignorance of the population if free elections were to occur nothing would realistically change. There is no access to fundamental human rights in the DPRK as the state systems actively oppress individuality and focus on wellbeing as a state. There is no freedom of movement, and forced internal resettlement is routine. Access to Pyongyang is tightly restricted; the availability of food, housing, and health care is somewhat better in the capital than in the rest of the country. Recently, this disparity has increased, with the capital featuring more luxuries for a growing middle class. North Korea is among the worst countries, if not the worst in the world in terms of the regimes oppression towards its citizens. I'm confident that all answer provided are correct and a true and fair representation of the North Korean regime. Sources for research are Vice News, Freedom House, Transparency International and RAND.
