Justification: I will go through and justify my answers to each question starting from question four in a bullet point format: 21 and 23) The 1997 election of Charles Taylor was declared free and transparent theoretically, but practically there were serious difficulties for the opposition in terms of gaining any power. The Liberian Civil War had just ended, and Taylor had emerged from the conflict with near war lord status outside of the city of Monrovia. The countryside was the main site of atrocities and war crimes committed by militias and Taylor's rebels during the war - rape and violent murder being the main weapon of choice against civilians. Taylor won 75% of the vote in the Presidential election, and a campaign slogan of 'he killed my ma, he killed my pa, but I will still vote for him.' Practically, the thousands of people that voted for Taylor were terrified that he would start the war again if he lost the election. Therefore, the elections were conducted under an atmosphere of fear and intimidation. 25) The Press in Liberia were mostly free with enshrined rights under the constitution and international treaties. Libel cases continue to be a significant problem in Liberia, despite efforts by the government to restrict criminal libel cases against journalists. Often the freedom of information laws are available to the public but are not widely known. Freedom House lists the Press Freedom of Liberia as 'Partly Free' 26) During the rule of Charles Taylor between 1997 and 2003 there was no rule of law upon the President. He was able to wield complete violence against citizens or rebels to his regime. He tolerated official opposition, but ethnic groups and rebel groups continued to be oppressed and Taylor acted as a war lord in his role as President. He also shamelessly funded, supported, and planned war crimes with the RUF, the main militia in the neighbouring Sierra Leone civil war, to generate personal wealth from stolen blood diamonds. In 2012 Taylor was convicted for these crimes. The President commissioned his own paramilitary units, especially the ATU, and used these gangs to systematically carry out extra judicial killing and rape of opposition figures. Rape in particular was used as it was a demoralising and devastating method of control. 27) Under Taylor there was a ban on political rallies and public gatherings for fear that the unrest in the unfolding Second Civil War would spill into the captial. In 2002 Taylor restricted further civil liberties such as the right of peaceful assembly to combat real or pretended threats1 to the government and his power. 28) as a whole, there is an appropriate separation of powers in Liberia according to the constitution. During the Civil War there would have been fear and chaos in terms of implementing the the rule of law - however, judges and the supreme court can uphold constitutionality and strike down laws which they see as being against the constitution of liberia. However, despite the apparently effective judiciary, there is still a prevelence of corruption through bribery, as well as severe lack of efficiency. Details of trial by ordeal and mob killing are still recorded widely in Liberia, especially in the countryside. 29) the regime of Charles Taylor was organised chaos - there was absolutely no way of holding the President or high ranking government officials to account. Under Taylor, the Armed Froces of Liberia actively recruited child soliders to oppress and fight opposition, and campaigns of terror were carried out in the countryside including burning of civilians, rape and murder. Taylor also actively engaged in highly corrupt and calculated negotiations with RUF rebels in Sierra Leone, offering them assylum and arms in return for political control of diamond mines in the neighbouring state. 30) Ethnic Krahn and Mandingo minorities were targets of abuse by government forces, and as many as 18,000 people fled to neighbouring Cote d'Ivoire as refugees. 31) I am fairly confident in my information and assesment. However, the information is difficult as the regime of 1997-2003 was essentially one run through anarchy. The entire time Charles was President, there country was engaged in a brutal civil war that affected all areas of civilian and state life. It is difficult to be able to make assertions between government abuses of power and opposition abuses of power - where both sides were equally guilty of atrocities and corruption throughout the conflict.

Corruption_types: "Bribe-taking by public officials","Special privileges granted to politically-connected people"
Justification: Nepal Start date : I've opted to study the Nepalese state from 2002 as it was in this year that its newly installed monarch King Gyanendra dismissed its fledgling democratic government, according to infoplease.com. In this way an unelected leader did away with (Nepalese society's) elected representatives, and so the first step toward authoritarianism was taken. In this same year Gyanendra then proceeded to attack the Maoist rebels fighting against the monarchy. Freedom House confirms these findings, and reports that its freedom ratings declined from there on, peaking in 2006. End date : since 2008 there has been an upturn as far as Nepalese democracy goes; then, according to Freedom House and the BBC, elections were held, and the monarchy was abolished. Moreover the fact, according to Freedom House, that subsequent years didn't see a sudden reversal of this development, supports my choice of 2008 as the end of a monarchic and dictatorial period: according to Freedom House, a coalition was formed in 2008 -this lends further credibility to the practice of Nepalese democracy insofar as it implies a representative governing bloc; 2009 saw a Prime Ministerial dismissal of the army chief overridden (this implies a healthy democratic diffusion of power among Nepal's leaders) ; 2013, despite seeing violence, nevertheless saw new elections which Freedom House described as 'generally free and fair.' Free and fair elections for executive and legislature : I have given zero points for this question, as dictatorial monarchism characterised Nepal throughout my chosen period of study; monarchism which saw no elections, and a form of government only insofar as King Gyanendra arbitrarily appointed and dismissed it; In 2003, a year after Gyanendra ascended to the throne, he refused to call new elections, and instead appointed a handpicked 'interim administration.'Freedom House further reports that this situation continued through a failed attempt in 2004 to reconstitute government. In 2005, 'free and fair elections'were still off the agenda, as, according to Freedom House, Gyanendra further worsened Nepal's undemocratic situation by dismissing his unelected government and personally taking executive control. Nepalese democracy only began to recover near the end of my chosen period; in 2006 the Maoists joined with the rejected politicians to protest and resist; thus forcing the King to restore parliament. The prospect of 'free and fair'elections returned, and, in spite of subsequent violence such elections took place in 2008, according to Freedom House. As to verification, bbc.co.uk's reportings on Nepal are consistent with Freedom House's chronology. Universal suffrage : according to cia.gov, suffrage is universal -though naturally this didn't apply during Nepal's democratic drought, as referenced above. Effective opposition and possibility to be elected to govern : I have chosen one point for this question because, as per information cited above, when Gyanendra ascended to the throne he divested existing politicians of their power, assuming it himself. Political opposition existed during the King's rule, most conspicuously in the case of the Maoists; however they had no chance to obtain power during the King's reign -the King devoted efforts to combatting them (Freedom House) . Furthermore, as alluded to above, the King did appoint an interim prime minister, but the choice was partisan, according to Freedom House -it was taken in spite of a 'consensus candidate' decided by the Nepal's disempowered parties. And thus, political opposition during the King's tenure had scant chance to exercise any authority. Attempted negotiations with the Maoist opposition in 2004 came to nothing, according to Freedom House. Are all people able to access political power : I give zero points in response to this question, as the monarchic reign throughout the bulk of the noughties in Nepal implies that power was concentrated in the hands of an elite few; not even the Maoists, nor former Nepalese representatives, had access to political power during the King's reign. Is there a free and effective media to hold power to account : I have chosen one point for this question as, according to Freedom House Nepal experienced a restricted media environment during 2002-8. This included harassment and arrestment of reporters critical of the (King's) government and/or supportive of the Maoist opposition. Self-censorship also occurred, as a natural consequence of such persecution. More specifically, an 'ordinance'gave the King and his government the power to keep unwelcome media in check. In this way it is clear that this environment left no room for media that might otherwise have 'held power to account'during this period. Does it uphold rule of law : according to Freedom House, the maintenance of Nepal's rule of law significantly improved from 2006 onwards; however, the rule of law saw a peak in its 'deterioration' in the previous year. More specifically, Freedom House reports that Gyanendra's administration paid little heed to Nepal's Supreme Court's orders. Thus, it is implied in this information that the rule of law throughout the period I've studied was less than binding; thus, I give this question with one point. Do its citizens have human rights, including freedom of Assembly, Speech and Mobility : I have chosen one point for this question, as, according to Freedom House, free assembly suffered 'occasional restriction;' demonstrations in 2005 were combatted by Nepalese police; many protestors were arrested. As may be inferred from my answer to the earlier question on media freedom, free expression was limited: more specifically, according to Freedom House, both its constitution and a 'Press and publications Act' prohibited expression which was unsavoury to the monarchy. Furthermore, in the period before 2006, Nepal failed to honour basic human rights, especially insofar as its police committed all manner of abuses, including 'extrajudicial killings, disappearances, arbitrary arrests and detentions, rapes, and torture (of suspected Maoists.) ' Free, independent, fair judiciary : Freedom House reports that despite a perception of independence regarding Nepal's Supreme Court, Gyanendra's administration came to disregard its orders. According to the same source, lower courts were more susceptible to 'pressure' and corruption. As a result of this general ineffectiveness and unfairness I answer this question with one point. Institutions to hold executive to account : I answer this question with one point. As mentioned above, the executive enjoyed virtual impunity insofar as the media and judiciary were about powerless to constrain Gyanendra. More specifically, the corruption among officialdom noted by Freedom House during Gynaendra's reign wasn't usually met with prosecution; however pretences at propriety were made via the creation of 'anticorruption regulations.' Again, with the abovementioned improvement in 2006 of Nepal's rule of law, so too did the implementation of such regulations improve. Equal treatment for minorities : according to Freedom House, various minorities alleged discrimination during the King's rule (as per the 'US State Department's Report on International Religious Freedom' ) ; furthermore, prior to 2007, at least, Freedom House reports that Christians faced discrimination before Nepalese law. However I answer with two points for this question, given official 'constitutional provisions that ban caste-based discrimination.' Confidence in answers : I have used various credible sources, especially the BBC and Freedom House. How corrupt was Nepal throughout this period : as mentioned above, 'anticorruption regulations' were introduced during the King's rule, however a lack of prosecution of top officials, as reported by Freedom House, undermines their credibility. But, again as reported above, prosecutions increased as Gyanendra's rule wore on. Freedom House reports that Transparency International ranked Nepal 121 of 163 nations in a 2006 index; this ranking supports the case for Nepal's corruptness. In consequence I answer this question with a one, rather than a zero, given the lack of explicit accounts I found regarding corruption in Nepal's top tiers -as mentioned earlier, Freedom House noted corruption among lower courts. Types of corruption : I answer this question by ticking 'bribe-taking'and 'special privileges granted to politically-connected people;'the first tick is based on an inference regarding evidence cited above that refers simply to 'corruption'in lower Nepalese courts; the second tick I based on King Gyanendra's appointment of a royalist-supporting administration during his reign, as according to Freedom House data. Justification: Question 21 There have yet to be elections in the newly formed country of South Sudan, and elections that were scheduled for 2015 have been pushed back until 2018. Source: http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-27381509. Q. 22, 24 Despite the fact that South Sudan is yet to have elections, its constitutions state that every adult, over the age of 18 can vote in elections, however this is yet to be proved. This same constitution states that for an individual to hold office, they must be literate. This limits 75% of the population who are not able to read. Source: http://aceproject.org/ero-en/regions/africa/SS/south-sudan-the-national-elections-act-no.-39-of Q. 23 As of yet there are 170 seats in the South Sudanese legislature. However 160 of these are made up by the Sudan People's Liberation Movement, therefore giving the opposition little to no say whatsoever. Source: http://africanelections.tripod.com/ssd.html Q. 25 According to Freedom House, South Sudan does not have restrictions on the media, however due to the state's failure to provide protection to journalists, many have been killed. Furthermore many press workers have been detained and mistreated by state officials, resulting in Freedom House declaring the media in South Sudan to not be free. Q. 26, 28 The President of South Sudan, Salva Kiir Mayardit, has been exempt from much of the transitional constitutions conditions, and has sacked his entire cabinet in what seems to be a consolidation of power. He also has considerable power over the judiciary, as do many other politicians and officers in the armed forces. Finally, the state legislature moved the upcoming election from 2015, to 2018, therefore making the country without an election in its history, and without one as a territory since 2010. Sources: http://www.refworld.org/pdfid/530cb3604.pdf and http://www.aljazeera.com/news/africa/2013/07/201372318388499663.html Q. 27, 29 Both the incumbent government and opposition officials are likely to have committed widespread atrocities against the South Sudan population, restricting human rights, and by creating grievances against them. This is due to a lack of accountability through not having proper checks and balances against those in power. The Human rights commission is unable to follow through in its role as it is understaffed, with a lack of resources, and is therefore unable to conduct investigations into human rights breaches. Sources: http://www.refworld.org/pdfid/530cb3604.pdf and http://www.americanbar.org/content/dam/aba/directories/roli/sudan/aba_roli_sudan_assessment_final_report_0614.authcheckdam.pdf Q. 30 Freedom House has stated that due to mass killings of people along ethnical lines, South Sudan cannot be considered a protector of minority freedoms. Furthermore the President has continually voiced opposition to sexual rights (http://www.sudantribune.com/spip.php?article35815) . Finally, in 2015, the NGO Minority Rights Group International lists South Sudanese minority groups as the 9th most threatened people in the world. In regards to question 32 and 33, due to South Sudan's developing stage, and infancy in terms of national history, it is likely that corruption is widespread. South Sudanese officials have been said to have stolen much of the states financial assests, and laundered money into offshore, foreign bank accounts. Whether or not President Kiir is involved in this is unknown. However he has condemned these actions, and pleaded that the money be given back to the people of South Sudan in order for the country to further develop. Source: http://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/04/us-southsudan-corruption-idUSBRE8530QI20120604 South Sudan is also seen as one of the world's most corrupt nations, which may eventually change as the country grows older and creates additional institutions to safeguard the interests of the state economy and resources. Source: http://www.voanews.com/content/south-sudan-corruption-transparency-international-annual-index/2544599.html

Justification: Political Rights 1: We can see that there are low chances of government change in Namibia as President Sam Nujoma was elected three times and adopted an authoritarian governing style. Political rights 2: people are required to be of 18 years of age when voting the only limitations on voting are that you need to be a citizenship of Namibia (by birth) or child of at least one parent born in Namibia or residence in the country for at least 4 years prior to the date of registration as elector. Political rights 3: There are opposition parties but the South West African People Organization has won with more than 50% of votes for consecutive years. And opposition parties numbers dwindling. Political rights 5: there is good media coverage shown for parties as can be seen in Namibia as it scores a 20/179 from the press freedom index. Also there media coverage is among the best according to minoritygroups.org and are the freest among the continent with no reports of discrimination against minority groups. Civil liberties 1: on the freedom house index Namibia scored an 3 out of 7 which is directly in the middle which would indicate that Namibia does consider their civil liberties. Civil Liberties 2: As Namibia was ruled as an authoritarian regime even though it is a proportional system. It would be assumed that human rights are often violated but freedom house reports that Namibia has some of the best although there are reports of forces beating citizens and Angolan refugees. Civil Liberties 3: Namibia scores a 49/100 which is half way of being clean or being or very corrupt. This would indicate that there are some forms of corruption and political influence in judiciary. Civil Liberties 4: Ombudsman was entrenched when the Constitution of the Republic of Namibia came into operation on 21 March 1990. From this we can gather that there is some check in place for the government and keeps it accountable for its actions. Civil Liberties 5: as stated in 'political rights 5'minority groups have not been discriminated against by the media.

Justification: I chose to study in between 1990 and 2001 because the Movement for Democracy party was established in 1990 and in power from 1991-2001. Freedom House only dates back to 1998 so it did not provide me with any information before then but it claims that since the transition to multiparty elections in 1991, there was free and fair elections with universal suffrage. [1] The fact that Movement for Democracy lost power in 2001 to opposition PAICV with a 12-vote margin [2] indicates that there is a good chance that opposition can get into power. This win did not cause any violent backlash, and was accepted peacefully. It is stated 'having two parties of fairly equal strength, as opposed to the ruling party dominance so common in Africa, has ensured lively debate in the National Assembly and meant that no government has been able to be complacent.' [3] While all people were able to form a party and run for government, Cape Verde is marked with significant poverty and the majority of people did not have the resources to offer material incentives for supporting constitutional rule. [4] This means that while people are free to gain power in theory, significant poverty does not permit such freedoms. In the test there was no option that represented this poverty factor. Given the ratings of Freedom House, I would have expected that the media was free. However, the main media outlets are owned by the state, which brings a degree of self-censorship. Other media is allowed, although in 1998 the government shut down a radio station that was partially owned by an opposition politician [5] . This was not a common occurrence. The government generally upheld basic human rights but there was significant societal discrimination especially domestic violence towards women and mistreatment of children. Poverty exacerbated these violent acts and while there was government legislation to ameliorate these problems, they failed to properly implement and enforce these policies. [6] Again, significant poverty disabled the government from enforcing any minimum wage or workplace policies. Many people opposed to the government assembled in peaceful protests and the government did not inhibit these. Freedom of religion was generally upheld and the government did not enforce any religious beliefs. There were also two private human rights groups in Cape Verde that hold the government accountable for human right breaches. [7] However, in the year of 1995, there were no investigations carried out. The judiciary operated independently and was not significantly coerced by the government. This is illustrated in a judge refusing an influential minister's allegations about an independent journalist. Also journalists were successful in gaining compensation after unfair dismissal from a government owed media company. [8] Police were also subject to the same laws as civilians. [9] I could not find much more information to answer this question. However, the judiciary was overburdened with cases and from 1998 there has been a move to make it more efficient- between 2000-2005 there was a 15 percent increase in number of judges. [10] The government have to declare their interests and income, making for a more transparent government [11] Through Google search engine, Google scholar and Victoria library database, I could not find much more information on corruption during this time other than it was the least corrupt in Africa, which most likely indicates that corruption was not significant in Cape Verde. However, I find this difficult to believe given significant poverty in country. Justification: Political Rights: Question 1: It is commonly known that the election in Russia are not fair, however its often found that actual voter ballets are not manipulates (usually) and the outcome of the election generally represent the will of the people. However, the fairness and international standards are not meet by agreement of most of the international community including NGO's such as the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) who agreed that the 2004 election of Putin did not meet international standards of elections, particularly due to media bias. In 2012 the term before an election was lengthened to 6 years from for and in 2011 executive elections from 4 to 5 years under Putin's order. Question 2: There is Universal Suffrage in Russia as of age 18. Question 3: The political system in Russia is a multi-party system, however the pro-president party (United Russia) control more than two thirds of the Duma and put majority support in for president priorities. The Russian Constitution provides citizens the opportunity to change their government peacefully. However, it is commonly known that this is easier said than done. Most elections are unfairly weighted in favour of a the party that is already in power at this time United Russia, although the president is not directly accountable to the party, there is mutual uses for one another. The party strongly backs the president. As mentioned the leading has an unfair advantage in terms of publically, there does not leave much room for political change. Question 4: The executive levels of government in Russia are held most commonly by rich white older men that are loyal to Putin. The system of appointment of positions at governmental level is more or less controlled by the president (Putin) . The president nominates that Prime Minister, who appoints the federal assembly, and confirms the constitutional assembly and members of the Duma (Who are all nominated by the president) . This makes it increasingly difficult to enter the government at this level, unless you are a loyal friend or former Security forces co-worker of Putin, he relies on these personal relationships in order to maintain power, as Gorbachev and Yeltsin before him. Question 5: Transparency International has ranked Russia low in terms of Freedom of Press (142/179) . Although print press remains majorly pluralistic, radio and television media freedom is very limited. There have been many cases of infringement by the government on the freedom of the press right. Mainly in terms of election coverage skewering the opponents'ability to campaign and positively portraying their own. HHR, 2010 notes that independent media networks are, 'faced with continuing financial difficulties, as well as pressure from the government and large privately companies with links to the government, many media organizations saw their autonomy further weakened' (HHR, 2010) . Civil Liberties: Question 1: Although many of the principles of democracy are outline to be protected in the Russian Constitution the political system, corruption and lack of accountability means that the principles are generally not upheld. Question 2: Government institutions used to maintain human rights in Russia were relatively weak, including freedom of speech and media as mentioned earlier. The Russian government has to some extent maintained the human rights of citizens in some regions in of the country. However, human rights are weakly maintained in other less economically prosperous areas, and have even worsened in some in the years. Overall, human rights standards in the country are poor. Protection of human rights remains relatively high in the public sphere. Question 3: The constitution has an independent judiciary. Unfortunately the judiciary is usually driven by the decision of the executive. The judiciary does not work as a fair of effective counter balances or monitor for the other branches of the government, as mentioned before the members are made up of people approved by the president. Judges are subject to influence constantly by executives, military and Special Forces. It lacks the resources to be effective and is riddled with corruption, threats and intimidation. Question 4: As mentioned earlier the lay out of the political system in Russia makes it difficult to have any kind of transparency or form of accountability in the country. Along with all the corruption the executive has a huge grasp on power. HRR states 'Changes in the parliamentary election laws and move from election to nomination by the president of regional governors further strengthened the power of the executive branch and, together with media restrictions, a compliant state Duma, short comings in recent national elections, law enforcement corruption, and political pressure on the judiciary, raised concerns about the erosion in accountability of government leaders to the people' (HRR, 2010) Question 5: The constitution prohibits discrimination based on nationality. However, Roma persons and dark skinned persons commonly face discrimination in both the public sphere and by the government, Muslims and Jewish also face prejudice and social discrimination in the country. The HHR notes that a informally study of Africans (mostly students and refugees) in Russia in 2002 found, 'indicated that nearly two thirds reported having been physically attacked in Moscow because of their race. Fifty four percent were verbally insulted by the police because of their race. The 180 students questioned reported 204 attacks, 160 of them reported to the police, resulting in 2 convictions.' Sources: U.S. Department of State -Human Rights Report: Russia (2010) Economist Intelligence Unit -Country Report: Russia (2015) Transparency International -Russia Central Intelligance Agency - The World Factbook Also a fair bit of educated guessing Graeme, Gill - A new turn to Authoritarian rule in Russia? (2006) Gill, Graeme. 2

Justification: For this case, I have elected to evaluate Iran based upon a timeframe of between 1989 and 2015. These dates correspond to the (contemporary) rule of Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei, the second Supreme Leader of Iran. Ali Khamenei was elected as Supreme Leader by a committee of Islamic theologians (the Assembly of Experts) appointed by his predecessor, Ruhollah Khomeini, who was responsible for the overthrow of the previous ruling imperial dynasty in 1979 and established a uniquely theocratic-democratic republic in its place. This time frame was chosen predominantly because of the consolidatory and transitional nature of the regime under Ruhollah Khomeini, during which time the Iranian government faced much internal and external conflict (see the Iran-Iraq War, 1980-1988), and in which time the civil and political policies of the Iranian state cannot be considered as having yet become stabilized enough as to constitute an institutionalized regime. Hence, we have elected to base our evaluation upon a timeframe which corresponds to the rule of Ali Khamenei, which offers a framework in which the policies of the Iranian state have remained both effective and stable. In our classification of the Iranian regime, many of the answers given are based upon evidence sourced from various international reports (see links below), including those conducted by Transparency International, Freedom House, the Wall Street Journal, and the Human Rights Watch, as well as from the United States Department of State and the Central Intelligence Agency. Each of these reports generally indicate that the Iranian regime constitutes high levels of corruption, censorship, and the denial or suppression of civil and political rights. Consequentially, many answers were given a scoring of 0 out of a possible 3, particularly those which concern the independence of the media, of the judiciary, and the rights of minorities. According to international reports, no election held during our timeframe can be considered either free or fair. In one report, Freedom House notes how Iranâ<U+0080><U+0099>s Guardian Council â<U+0080><U+0093> a constitutionally mandated committee charged with overseeing obedience to the constitution â<U+0080><U+0093> has on occasion used its powers to arbitrarily disqualify opposition candidates; in one case, in 2012, for instance, the Guardian Council is stated to have disqualified one-third of candidates on the basis of dubious accusations of drug-smuggling, espionage, and heresy. Other reports also indicate that opposition politicians are often subject to harassment or harsh restrictions, and that certain political parties have been forcibly dissolved on the basis of their reformist beliefs. Religious and cultural minorities are also generally forbidden from attaining high-ranking positions in government. Furthermore, despite universal suffrage being afforded under the Iranian constitution, reports such as those conducted by Freedom House and the United States Department of State indicate that in practice universal suffrage is often violated by the government. In one instance, Freedom House reports that women were arbitrarily disqualified from participating in the 2006 elections. However, because there is some evidence of political pluralism in the Iranian Parliament, with opposition groups such as the Reformists generally holding a significant portion of Parliament, and because specific restrictions upon universal suffrage are arbitrarily and irregularly imposed (and thus difficult to consistently account for), many questions concerning political rights were scored as either 1 or 2. According to the Iranian constitution, the Supreme Leader directly appoints the heads of the judiciary, as well as the heads of state-run media institutions and security forces. Consequentially, the judiciary and media are demonstrably not independent of the government. Further, reports indicate that the media â<U+0080><U+0093> both state-run and independent â<U+0080><U+0093> is subject to considerable censorship (both self-censorship and government censorship), with reports indicating the harassment and the restriction of the mobility of journalists, and of laws which prohibit the criticizing of Islamic doctrine and of past and present leaders of the state. Hence, questions relating to the independence of the media and the judiciary, and of their use as an effective check on power, were scored 0. However, in spite of this, questions relating to the rule of law and on the existence of effective checks on power were scored 2. This is, in spite of reports which suggest that the rule of law is weak in Iran, based upon the existence of tutelary institutions such as the Guardian Council which serve as an arbitrator of Sharia law, upon which the Iranian legal code and constitution is based, which act as a legal check on both the power of the Supreme Leader and on the power of the Iranian Parliament. Although Iranian laws may be contrary to laws standardized in the international community (and they may be generally considered Draconian), they are nonetheless upheld by such independent bodies as the Guardian Council, and hence the rule of law is generally upheld. However, because this perspective is limited to the application of Sharia law, and thus room for the breaching of secular laws exists (and is reported in some cases in which the government pressures lawyers to drop cases, and in cases where the constitutional rights of minorities are wilfully violated), the regime was afforded a score of 2 instead of 3, noting the possibility for significant breaches. Human rights in Iran are also reportedly severely limited. Although freedoms to assembly and movement are guaranteed under the constitution, these are often limited in practice, with reports indicating that assembling in opposition of Islamic doctrine is prohibited (labelled as â<U+0080><U+0098>counter-revolutionaryâ<U+0080><U+0099>) and on occasion responded to with violence. Other freedoms are not guaranteed, however, such as the freedom of association, expression, and religion, and homosexuality and apostasy are both punishable by death. Reportedly, discrimination against non-Islamic minorities (particularly non-Judeo-Christian and non-Zoroastrian minorities) is routine, and many such minorities are forbidden from practicing their faith. For these reasons (as well as the prohibition against non-Muslims from attaining senior political posts), questions relating to the protection of human rights and of empowering minorities were scored 0. Finally, reports corroborate that corruption is widespread within the Iranian regime. According to these reports, cases of widespread embezzlement and fraud have been uncovered (including a significant case in 2013 involving a group called the Fatemi Circle, which was responsible for embezzling the state treasury), and high-ranking members of the Iranian government have sought to abolish anti-corruption agencies so as to reduce the transparency of government (this was the case under the Ahmadinejad administration, which, according to Freedom house, abolished several independent anti-corruption â<U+0080><U+009C>watchdogsâ<U+0080>). Furthermore, high-ranking members of the government have been indicated in acts of fraud, such as in 2011 in a pervasive case of fraud involving the fraudulent purchasing of state-owned businesses. Hence, the question regarding the prevalence of corruption in the Iranian regime was scored 0. Sources: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constitution_of_the_Islamic_Republic_of_Iran https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2014/iran#.VVvIokZp0vQ http://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704575304575296652104011166 http://www.transparency.org/country/#IRN http://www.hrw.org/middle-eastn-africa/iran http://2001-2009.state.gov/g/drl/rls/83185.htm

Justification: For the regime classification exercise I was assigned two countries, one of which was Chad, 1994. I chose the period of time between 1991, when general General Idriss Déby Itno became the President of Chad after approval of a national charter by the Patriotic Salvation Movement (MPS) ; up to 1997, the time of the countries first multi-party presidential election. During this time period, political parties were legalized, . Following his rise to power in December 1990, Debybegan to gradually restore the basic functions of government and entered into agreements with the world bank and International Monetry Fund (IMF), showing intent from Deby to uphold a government focused in the wider goals of the nation. Suffrage in Chad is granted to all individuals over the age of 18. However, as 1996 was the first multi-party election held in Chad, and there remains speculation as to its level of transparency, I took as educated guess when answering the questions on the existance of an effective opposition, and universal suffrage. With regards to the question on access to political power, I rated Chad a 1 out of 3, this is because the president has the power to appoint the prime minister, and cabinet. He may also exercise considerable influence over the appointment of judges, generals, officials and heads of firms. When beginning research for this exercise regarding Chad, I struggled to find sources, and therefore I am not confident in many on answers provided. In particular I struggled to answer the final two questions on Corruption, and made an educated guess using the little information I gathered regarding the President Derby, and Chad's polity. Justification: Azerbaijan is an intresting country to classify, as the period of study in this case represents the entirety of the time the country has exisitsted in its current form, having declared independece from the Soviet Union in 1991. This is both a positive, as it means all releveant data is mostly available through the internet, but also a negative, as the country has not had time to politically mature, and the sample size for elections is limited. Regardless, it is clear from all sources that Azerbaijan is by no means a free and fair society or electoral system. For the first section, to establish the methods and rules around the electoral system, publically available information lsited by the Central Intelligence Agency was used and cross checked against a human rights NGO. Both returned the same results, and thus I am satisfied that my findings on the systematic makeup of the system are sound. Questions on corruption, political and civil rights form the majority of this dataset, and are easily answearble. Pratically all sources consulted, including two seperate NGO reports, agree that there is strong systematic corruption and bias within Azerbaijan. The governing house is made up of single constituencys, and has no real power or speration from the executive branch, and a recent referendum removed term limits from both these seats and the presidency. The first elections after the millitary coup in 1993 resulted in the incumbent winning a suspicious 99% of the vote. In the most recent elections, the incumbent President, the son of the coup leader in 1993 allegedly won 84% of the vote, with the closest opposition party winning just 5%. The same election suffered widespread rigging allegations after results naming 2013 candidates were pushed to a mobile app run by the goverment BEFORE voting had begun. The goverment claimed the data was from a previous election (Technically an Investigation, meriting the Question 29 Answer), but the data pushed included 2013 candidates. Corruption and political pressure is widespread in the Judicury and public service, as well as the media. All of these are considered subserviant to the executive branch, and while the consitution does allow for indepentent media and judiciary, in practise they are heavily censored or pressured. Defamation remains a criminal offence, despite the goverment promising to decrimanalise it in 2012. Freedom house is scathing in their report, noting that random arrest and detention without charge is common, especially for political oppositon figures. Additionally, the right to freedom of assembly and freedom of regligion are heavily supressed, with 'non-traditional' religions requiring registrations, and assembly heavily supressed especially for opposition parties. I am very confident in the answers given for Azerbaijan. For this investigation I read reports by both Freedom House and Human Rights watch, investagatory articles by several intenational news agencys, and consulted data available from several govermental organisations such as the Central Intelligence Agency. None of these sources offered any information to contrast the widely accepted understanding of the state of the country both politically and socially, meaning I am confident to say my answers reflect reality. Although several other sources were consulted in various ways, the primary evidence for these answers can be found: Reports by NGOs: Freedom House: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2013/azerbaijan#.VV7lD0-eDRY HRW: http://www.hrw.org/europecentral-asia/azerbaijan Govermental: Central Intelligence Agency https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/aj.html News: Washington Post: http://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2013/10/09/oops-azerbaijan-released-election-results-before-voting-had-even-started/ Aljazzera Reporting: http://www.aljazeera.com/topics/country/azerbaijan.html

Justification: This period was chosen because although it was a repressive period in history, it was extremely stable. After his rise to power in 1987, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali promised competitive elections, democracy and a better Tunisia than was seen under his predecessor, Bourguiba. Under his 23 year rule, the authoritarianism because more pronounced, and repression stronger than Tunisia had seen. Originally supported by foreign leaders for educational reform and economic growth, Ben Ali fled the country after mass protests in 2010. Given how recent the overthrow of Ben Ali was, there is a significant amount of information about the end of his regime, and still a large amount about the regime itself. A particularly useful source on Ben Ali-s Regime is a thesis by Logan, who went to Tunisia to interview those who had lived under the regime. This gave great insight into life under Ben Ali and provided the basis for many of my answers, supported by other sources. Question 21 Although there were consistent elections during the regime of Ben Ali, there was no chance of any opposition receiving any real power. In the 1989 and 1994 elections, Ben Ali had no opponents. (Department of State) .Even once the multiparty era began, there was no possibility of gaining a majority. It was a way to avoid criticism and appear inclusive - a façade of democracy and a tool to appease those who wanted to see opposition. (Logan) . Results during these elections were inconceivable in free and fair elections. The 'majority list'system meant that whichever party got the highest number of votes would receive all the seats in that district (the RCP) . This was a way of blocking out minority parties. Elections were there to reinforce the regimes hold over the state, they were not a way of distributing power amongst the people. In 1999 rallies were banned outside polling booths to further the appearance of democracy and candidates were selected (by Ben Ali) to run against him in the Presidential elections. Question 22 Despite the repressive regime, universal suffrage existed under Ben Ali. In fact, Tunisia since it's independence has been consistently pro gender equality, especially when considering it's geographical location in the Arab world. (Department of State) The only restriction on suffrage prevented those serving in the military or internal security forces from voting. Universal suffrage may have been Ben Ali's way of improving his façade of democracy. Question 23 As Logan calls it, Ben Ali only had 'décor opposition'. The opposition had no hope of gaining power, despite Ben Ali's National Pact promising democracy and competitiveness. Many opposition parties were created by the regime to improve appearances. Real opposition parties suffered from lack of funds, infiltration, and the threat of punishment. They were also persecuted to reduce the support among civil society. Media published by the opposition was hard to find. The Islamist 'Ennhada'was refused permission to run and exist. Sadiki mentioned that the change to multi-party rule was a change 'from single party rule to multi party hegemony'-essentially, other parties existed but they had no hope of overtaking the RCD. Question 24 Anyone hoping to have access to political power had to be close to Ben Ali, and support the regime. This meant that they did not truly have power because they would simply be supporting Ben Ali's policies. Close supporters and family of the President had access to political power. His wife Leila Trabelsi's family in particular were powerful, with rumours that she would take over the Presidency due to abdication or death. (Logan) . Information on this question was less obvious. Given the nature of the regime it is assumed that political power was extremely unevenly spread. Question 25 Ben Ali was more open about media at the very beginning of his reign than at the end -perhaps reflecting how progressively worse his regime became for the people of Tunisia. After two years in power, he began to attack journalists. The regime may not have owned all the media outlets (especially after technological advancements such as the internet), but the regime had full control of news vendors, meaning only pro-regime media could be sold, and anyone hoping to purchase otherwise would be reported to the regime. Journalists had two choices -working for the regime media, or risking your wellbeing and working undercover. Websites were blocked (although people got around this by proxy), and much foreign information was inaccessible. Media was strictly monitored. Ben Ali even created a propaganda machine, announcing achievements and skewing figures in favour of the regime (Logan) . In 2009 Reporters Without Borders ranked Tunisia 154/173 in their World Press Freedom list. Question 26 It was difficult to find appropriate information in order to answer this question. Worldwide Governance Indicators show that in 2003, Tunisia was in the 50 th percentile for rule of law, and in 2008 when it was next measured, it was in the 58 th percentile -showing some improvement. However there are also indicators that the large security force was not to destroying homes to instill fear in the population. Surveillance was common and supporters of the opposition were frequently harassed. Question 27 Human rights in Ben Ali's Tunisia were severely suppressed by the regime. In 2010 FreedomHouse ranked Tunisia as Not Free, with a Freedom Rating of 6/7 (seven being the worst) and political rights a 7/7. Despite a Code of Personal Status promising an improvement in human rights and Freedom of Assembly and Association and Freedom of Expression from the Bourguiba regime, Ben Ali did not follow through. During Islamist protests in 1990-1992, 8000 Muslims were arrested. Raids and torture were not uncommon against Muslims. Declaring oneself as 'neutral'towards politics was considered dissent -citizens had to actively support the regime. Unlike similar regimes in China and Syria, where the government could be criticized, this was not possible in Tunisia, as to criticize the government was to criticize Ben Ali himself ( Logan) . Human rights activists in Tunisia are suppressed. Prisoners can be detained without reason and torture is prevalent. The government preventing certain groups from existing, and bugging known locations of groups hinders Freedom of Assembly and Association. Freedom of Expression is clearly violated, as any dissenting remark was dangerous. As Logan found while interviewing Tunisians after Ben Ali fled, they were still hesitant to criticize the regime. Question 28 According to the US Department of State in 2010, the judiciary was 'nominally independent'. Essentially, the judiciary was made to appear independent from the executive, but it was clear that Ben Ali had significant influence over the judiciary, as he also did over the legislature. The Minister of Justice and Human Rights appointed all judges. Bribe-taking was rife in the 'Reshwa State' (Logan), so those who had money also had power within the judiciary. Question 29 Any processes to hold the regime accountable only existed on paper. The legislative body may have been bicameral, but given the lack of opposition, there was no accountability. It was rare for any changes to be made to prospective bills (US State Department) . Any inquiries would have been seen as criticisms of Ben Ali. Question 30 The most persecuted group in Tunisia were Islamists. Originally, the regime was not hostile to Islamists who had previously been discriminated against. Given it's reputation as a secular state, religious based political parties were banned. However the regime still allowed to Islamist Party Ennahda or An-Hahdha operate until 1991. At this point is was deemed a terrorist organisation, and thousands were arrested (State Department) . Some marginalised groups forfeit rights for food. Although there may have been other minorities facing unequal treatment under the regime, it was not significant enough to appear in journal articles and sources upon which this is based. Question 32 Corruption was huge under the Ben Ali regime. A small group surrounding Ben Ali, depended on the regime for their extreme wealth. State resources were funneled into the hands of those in power. False figures were given to international institutions such as the World Bank and the IMF (Logan) . Welfare was given to the wealthy. The poor got poorer through coercion, and the government demanding large percentages of any profits. The most obvious example is Muhammed Bouzazi, whose suicide is often named as the spark of the Arab Spring. Bouzazi was not allowed to get his scales back from the government, and could not run his small fruit stand. The state was known as a 'Rashwa' or Bribing state. Embezzling was huge among elites. Infrastructure deteriorated as allocated funds were misused. After the revolution in 2011, figures began to emerge, with Logan stating that the ruling family embezzled one third of the state budget -with his wife's family the main culprits. Society could barely eat. WikiLeaks in 2010 put the number in the tens of billions. Question 33 Bribes were the most common form of corruption, hence the name Rashwa State. Ben Ali himself co-opted several industries and the ruling family liquidated to avoid taxes -fraud at the highest level. The ruling family monopolized the economy and assets were seized from the working class without explanation. It is unclear whether there was fraud by private citizens against the government. It can be assumed that this would be a huge risk given the importance of capital to the government. Anonymous, Tunisia, Department of State Publication: Background Notes Series, (2010) . Justification: Freedom House reports were also used to inform the answers on Thailand's case. The confidence in which these answers were given varies, as I often found that the range of possible answers were limited and were not exactly suitable to the case. This will be further explained: Political Rights Question One was answered with: ' There are elections for the executive and the legislature but there is a very low likelihood of government change via elections' Although these answers did not fit the case well, this answer was given due to the Freedom House (2003) report which highlighted that although Thais can change their governments through elections, that they are marred by fraud, irregularities, and some political killings. In previous elections - such as the January 2001 balloting - candidates gave money to voters in order to buy votes. Question Two: was straight-forward, since the 1933 elections there had been universal suffrage in Thailand. Although there are now restrictions including, being over the age of 18, being a citizen and being registered to vote. Question Three: as shown in Question One, although Thais can change their government democratically -Freedom House (2005) used the August 2004 election of an opposition Democratic candidate as the governor of Bangkok, as an example - there are major obstacles such as widespread official corruption that undermines the ability for opposition to have a fair standing in elections. Question Four: was answered with 'Many people have access to political power, with some exceptions' According to Freedom House (2002) report, roughly half of the 700,000 to 880,000 members of hill tribes reportedly lack citizenship, which in turn, leaves them ineligible to vote, or even own land and be covered under labour laws. Although, the government in 2000 eased the rules for hill tribe members to be eligible for and obtain citizenship, it is still unclear as to how many of these hill tribe peoples have benefited from the changes. Majority of citizens did have access to political power, with non-governmental organizations representing farmers, labourers, women, students and human rights more broadly. Question Five: Although the 2002 Freedom House report stated that during Thaksin's reign, Thai newspapers freely criticized government policies and reported allegations of official corruption and human rights abuses, the opposition Democratic Party alleged that some papers might have toned down their criticisms because of the advertisements they received from state companies and Thaskin's Shin Corporation and its subsidiaries. Freedom House highlighted that these journalists may have exercised some self-censorship regarding national security issues etc. Furthermore, the 2005 Freedom House report highlighted that print press had come under attack, not through formal censorship, but through political intimidation, libel suits, and the threat of lost corporate and government advertising revenues, which resulted in media companies carrying large debts. Civil Liberties Question One: The leaders of the state are not subject to the rule of law, this was more of an educated guess based on the information Freedom House reports (2005) provided, such as the pervasive and widespread official corruption, involving both bureaucrats demanding bribes in exchange for routine services and law enforcement officials being paid off to ignore trafficking and other illegal activities. Criminal charges were often laid against political oppositions as well, which undermines the legitimacy of state officials. Question Two: Was answered with 'Partial rights exist, but there is still heavy suppression and monitoring'. Freedom House (2005) reports highlighted that Thailand's Constitution provided for freedom of assembly and association, and that the government generally respected these rights in practice, according to the US State Department human rights report for 2004. In addition to this, the constitution also allowed for the government to restrict free expression on national security, public order, and other grounds (Freedom House, 2002) . Domestic Violence and trafficking of thousands of Thai women and children were (and still remain) a serious and pervasive problem of Thailand, although according to the Freedom House (2002) and U.S. State Department reports, the police did not vigorously enforce laws to bring perpetrators to justice, thus the law enforcement agencies were widely perceived as incapable. Although this is not an example of states suppression of human rights, it still provides an example of state incompetency and how this indirectly perpetuates the suppression of (certain groups of) people's rights. Question Three: 'The judiciary sometimes operated independently, but it is susceptible to undue influence and corruption', Freedom House (2005) reports state that the judiciary is generally regarded as independent, but is sometimes subject to corruption. The 2002 report also stated that The judiciary also lacks a sufficient number of qualified judges and has huge case backlogs. Defendants generally receive adequate due process rights. Question Four: Does this country have effective processes in order to hold governing regime accountable? This was difficult to find information on whether processes put in place were enacted effectively. Thus, from the information gathered on the corruption that was rife within state officials in the regime, I assumed there were no effective processes that held them or the governing regime accountable. Although, I thought it was important to note that the opposition party (Democratic Party) in 2005 often brought to light the issues within their current ruling party, keeping the party check. Question Five: Does this country uphold the right to equal treatment and due process for minority groups? Although the constitution includes basic rights which the government generally uphold, as explained in other answers, many groups are often neglected by the government. Maybe not directly, but the incompetence of the government allows for the unequal treatment of certain (including minority) groups. Thai women and children are often neglected by the state, and many police, soldiers, local officials and immigration officers reportedly either are involved in trafficking or take bribes to ignore it. As well as this, Muslims in the South have long complained of discrimination in jobs, education, and business opportunities (Freedom House, 2005) . REFERENCES Freedom House 2002: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2002/thailand#.VV8EO_mqqko Freedom House 2003: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2003/thailand#.VV8ETvmqqko Freedom House 2005: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2005/thailand#.VV6fi_mqqko

Justification: The time analysis in which the Solomon Islands has been ranked accordingly, is the mid-1990 to early 2000. In this particular period, the Solomon Islands was doomed to become a failed state, after tensions between the Malaita's and Guadalcanal populations intensified. Increasing violence saw the failure of the state to protect victims of violence, or implement law and order. (Yoldi, n.d) So, although the government remained legitimate, their incompetency meant that citizens were unrestricted to become violent, oppressive, liberated etc. to fuel an escalating failed state. For these reasons, it becomes difficult to assess the political rights and civil liberties of its citizens, when the government cannot exercise power to enforce these mechanisms. During this period, elections remained. However, it became inaccessible for people to vote as a result of the violence that occurred. People had also lost a sense of political efficacy towards the government, as a result of a deteriorating economy, public institutions, state capacity and the enforcement of law and order. (Kere, 2015) Furthermore, elections were held for the sake of it without making much difference in the political status. While the freedom of media exists, it is highly concentrated in the urban capital of Honiara. (Kabutaulaka, n.d) Eighty-five percent of its population are located in rural areas of the country, without access to avenues of political information and discussion. Generally, people would vote based on candidates that could help them and their families. Voting was also driven by areas where candidates possessed power to punish those who didn't vote for him, as well as a constraint by the authority of local constituencies. 'Nearly ninety-nine percent of People's Survey Respondents answered that they were 'told to vote for them', suggesting they had little choice.' (Steeves, 1996, p. 130) However, in general terms all citizens have the freedom to vote. In saying that, the countries'government system and party liability tends to be....'highly unstable, continually in flux, and open in persistent challenge through the mechanism of votes of no-confidence, which feature throughout the term of an elected government.' (Steeves, 1996, p. 120) The Isatabu Freedom Movement and Malaita Eagle Force during ethnic violence opposed the government at the time. However, they were too weak and lacked sustainable resources to transition into power. In the case of civil liberties, citizens have access to fundamental human rights. However, this contradicts with the reality of poverty, unemployment, the lack of access to basic amenities, education, health etc. This lack of provisions of basic human rights have been drivers of ethnic violence and desperation for solutions to socio-economic grievances. (Reid, 2008) This is why I ranked it a one. The judiciary system during this period was weak, incompetent and on the verge of collapse. They had lost authority to perform its rightful duties and posed no threat to its citizens. However, this caused an upsurge of tension from civil societies, business groups and the international community led to the Townsville Peace Agreement in 2000, between the Isatabu Freedom Movement, Malaita Eagle Force and the government to create a framework for consolidating peace. (Yoldi, n.d) While the government had no mechanisms in place to hold them accountable, their lack of accountability propelled a pressure from below. This lack of accountability was also conveyed in the discrimination between minorities and the continued suppression of the Malaita's by the Guadalcanal people without any government prosecution. (Yoldi, n.d) Ultimately, the regime classification system was analysed in accordance with the political environment of the Solomon Islands in the mid-1990 to early 2000, particularly during the period of racial tensions and civil unrest, lawlessness and threat of a failed state. Where peace talks began in 2000, violence remained but conditions were improving. In 2003, the Freedom House analysis of civil liberties and political rights in the Solomon Islands resulted as partly free (3/7) . 'The Townsville Peace Agreement has lessened the violence but today the Solomon's is a bankrupt nation where the politics are fragile and the people are trying to adopt some semblance of normal life again' . (Reid, 2008 p.1) In reality, the livelihoods of their people must be improved in order to suggest that peace is consolidate. Ultimately, people are still vulnerable to violence because of corruption and the lack of investments in its citizens living conditions. Reference: Kabutaulaka, T. T. (n.d) . Justification: Question 21 - The electoral sytem in North Korea, at this time period (and also now), is basically a farce. Since the instillation of the Kim Dynasty - and the 'line of succesion' system, it has allready been decided who would lead the country. Parties are in place, and the fact that during their electoral process that only one cadidate is avaliable, makes it that much more difficult for opposition to happen. Question 22 - Using the information gathered in the previous question, the fact that only a singular candidate is avaliable shows how restrictive the electoral system is. Factors and ideals to consider is that all North Koreans citizens are indoctrinated in their daily lives by the Kim Dynasty/goverment officals - it speaks for itelf that people would just go with the flow - pr depending on political persusaion - that they would want to stay with the current system for reasons of comfort . (the idea of comfort/staying with what is easy rather than being practical) Question 23 - Parties and a 'pseudo' oppostion are in place - but it is ultimately a facade. Considering previous statements, it is near to impossible for any form of opposition or challengers to take plac ein North Korea, at this given period, or in the near future. Question 24 - Power is highly concentrated amongst a select few, often hand-picked by the leader himself. Note, it is also common to see those who are selected, are those who dedicate their entire life/being to the regime as well. It si neccesary also to consider how isolated North Korea is from the outside world as well as it is at a national level. The population were, and still are, isolated fom political levels, as to avoid potential competiton and so on for power. Question 25 - Media is owned by the state and tightly regualted by the state. The detah of Kim-Jong-Il, and the succesion of his son Kim-Jong-Un, were highly publicised events (basically on repeat, almost like a conditioning and indoctrination process) . With media being state owned, it was near to impossible to be independent. At this time, the media also, whilst endorsing the Kim regime, also used the media as a form for defemation against defectors from the state and the United States. Any form (which was unlikely) of defemation against the state, would result in persecution and arbitary punishment. Question 26 - The rule of law was virtually non-exsistent,a dn did not apply to the elite in power. It was applied more, and rather forcefully on citizens, whereas the misuse of power by the head of state, was completely ignored, and if challanged, oppostion were shut down, and faced harsh punishments and even faced corporal punishment. Question 27 - In theory, they did at this given time. The reality is that, being in the self-imposed isolated state it was in, and still continues to be in, access to civil rights were barred off from the citizens completely. The 'line of succesion' system also violates human and civil rights. Citizens had no participation or say in who was to be their new leader,, and as a result were left for the worse. (It is to beleived that since being in power, Kim-Jong Un has brought the DPRK into a fast state of decline) Question 28 - Judicary and whatever follows suit, was brought underneath an 'umbrella' created by the state. The Supreme People's Assembly 'hand-pick' candidates (Something which needs to be considered - the Supreme People's Assembly consists of those 'chosen' in a elective process of sorts. Question 29 - Relating to the statement of the judicary, the fact that despite having a pseudo- judciary, citizens had little to no access to the judical system. The concepts of bribery and loyalty are brought to mind. Those loyal to the state are rewarded, whislt defectors and rebels are abandoned and persecuted. Question 30 - The state of decline and isolation the D.P.R.K was in, (as imposed by the regime) - the results affected all. Favours and preference were rampant. In order to gain favour & support, the regime rewarded those who dedicated themselves wholy to the regime (showing that those who did not were left powerless to change their situation - also they were domianted by a large majority of those who supported and to an extent endorse the regime) Question 31 - Due to the fact that i have a little more knowledge on this regime, unlike the previous country, this has been easier to answer. Question 32 - Corruption was completely ramapant and dominated North Korean society. The economy and popualtion suffered as a result of misuse of resources, and still does to this day. Those in postions of power in the regime were the main culprits of this ( accepting bribes and promises from those in high positions of power in return for loyalty etc. ) Question 33 - After watching this documentary (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jEJqEuM5V68) - on the North Korean economy - this encompasses how corruption is rampant - and how the regime has had a negative influence on the popualtion in the best. The main feature her is mis-use of state/civilan resources showing how corruptive this regime is.

Justification: Timeline chosen to as 1999 was when King Abdullah II was crowned and to this day there are pushes for Jordan to become democratic. Q21 - Jordan is not an electoral democracy. While there are elections whereby citizens vote in 120 members of the National Assembly, it cannot enact laws without the assent of the upper house - who are appointed by the King. Jordan is a constitutional monarchy and hence the King holds broad executive and judicial powers. The King must approve appointment of judges, but technically according to the constitution the legislature has independance. ('Middle East: Jordan,' accessed 22/05/2015, https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/jo.html) Q22 - Jordan technically has universal suffrage as women were given the vote in 1974, hoewver 'noncitizen residents' (Jordan's approximately 600,000 permanent refugees which are overwhelmingly Palestinian) cannot vote. ('Freedom in the World: Jordan,' accesesd 22/05/2015, https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2012/jordan#.VV5A3bmqpBc) Q23 - being a constitutional monarchy there is obviously no multiparty competition - the ruling family passes leadership down through generations. However, the King (will consistent encouragement from the US) allegedly has intentions of helping Jordan evolve from an autocratic state to a democracy with political pluralism. A political party law was passed in 1992 with amendments made in 2012, and as of 2013 there were 30 registered parties, but as long as the monarchy still stands there is no possibility of them gaining any tangible power. ('European Forum for Democracy and Solidarity: Jordan,' accessed 22/05/2015, http://www.europeanforum.net/country/jordan) Q24 - while the Chamber of Deputies is voted for by citizens of Jordan, they have effectively no power without consent from the upper house (Senate) who are elected by the King. The King and his family hold all the power in Jordan, and without connections to the royal family regular citizens have no access to tangible political power. ('Legislative Power - The National Assembly,' accessed 22/05/2015, http://www.kinghussein.gov.jo/constitution_jo.html) Q25 - most broadcast outlets are state-controlled, but satellite dishes do make foreign media available to citizens. Private newspapers and magazines exist, though government has extensive powers to close them at will. Authorities have informers in printing presses who alert them to potentially offensive material and in turn the presses are censored. Journalists are threatened with prosecution, fines and dention to encourage self-censorship. In 2008 the King issued a statement prohibiting the imprisonment of journalists for crimes of publishing; in 2013 over 200 online media outlets were blocked. Censorship of the media in Jordan is still extreme. ('Freedom of the Press: Jordan,' accessed 22/05/2015, https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2013/jordan#.VV5J87mqpBc) Q26&28 - as far as I can tell - an educated guess is being made here - the law is applicable to most everyone in Jordan. The judiciary is independant from the executive, though it is my guess that crimes committed within the royal family are often overlooked or brushed under the carpet. The King approves the appointment of judges and it is likely to be a family affair, as it often is with Middle Easten monarchies. Q27 - Jordan has limited freedoms of speech, association and assembly. Governmental organisations have the power to reject registration requests for NGO's, and any NGO's with political purposes are prohibited. There is limited freedom of expression, with those who violate unwritten rules with regards to reporting on the royal family or violate societal taboos face arrest. ('World Report 2013: Jordan,' accessed 22/05/2015, http://www.hrw.org/world-report/2013/country-chapters/jordan) Q29 - the constitution does not give the parliament a whole lot of power to weild with regards to checking the power of the royal family. During the suspension of parliament between 2001 and 2003, King Abdullah passed 110 temporary laws, some of which that dealth with election law were seen to actually reduce the power parliament had to question the monarchy. ('The Parliament of Jordan,' accessed 22/05/2015, http://parliamentfiles.com/parliamentary-information/the-parliament-of-jordan/) Q30 - I wouldn't quite give jordan a 2 but I also wouldn't give them a 1 - somewhere in between. While only Islam and Christianity are recognised religions in Jordan, other minorities are guaranteed the right to free worship also. 12 seats are reserved in parliament for women, Christians are reserved 9 seats and Circassian minorities are guaranteed three. I wouldn't say that these are fair representations as the lower house remains heavily imbalanced with regard to minority representation. Also honour killings and femicide are a regular occurance and are not appropriately addressed by the government alot of the time. ('The Parliament of Jordan,' accessed 22/05/2015, http://parliamentfiles.com/parliamentary-information/the-parliament-of-jordan/) Q32 - corruption is only detectable as far as I could tell within the upper levels of government, that is, within the royal family and it's connections. Q33 - as far as I can tell, the largest form of corruption in Jordan currently is that of nepotism and bribery - there have been cases of corruptopn involving high-level business and political officials with connections to the royal family.
