Justification: Sudan is another country rich with a history of dictatorship and civil unrest; Sudan finds itself in a position in 2010 where there were elections in the Sudan and South Sudan. Again a large majority of the questions were answered with information gathered from the Freedom house page from 2010, where it was ranked as being not free https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2010/sudan#.VVwZs_mqqko . The International Criminal Court's arrest warrant for the current president of Sudan for crimes against humanity, already predict the low scoring for political and civil rights within the country. In terms of the Political rights the elections have been dominated in Sudan by the current president Omar Al-Bashir, with little room for opposition parties to gain a viable foothold, making free and fair elections rather questionable. Despite people having the ability to access political power it is severely repressed. There are little or no checks on balance of power by the media as reflected in its extremely low ranking of 172/178 in the 2010 Press Freedom Index https://en.rsf.org/press-freedom-index-2010,1034.html . The Civil Liberties aspects for Sudan are just as problematic with many fundamental human rights being severely suppressed, for example the freedom of assembly is restricted and enforced by Sudan's National Intelligence Security Services. There continues to be ethnic and religious conflict between the Muslim North and the Christian South and as a result there is continued repression the minorities in either portion of Sudan. The effect of corruption on Sudan, limits the ability for the regime to be effectively held accountable with little academic freedom, a deterioration of the ability of NGO's to operate as reflected in Transparency Internationals Corruption Perception Index ranking of 172/178 countries http://www.transparency.org/cpi2010/results#CountryResults . In terms of the Civil Liberties question regarding fundamental rights, the influence of religion impacted the degree of accuracy as prior to the end of the civil war in 2004, Sharia law dictated and still has a huge influence on the extent to which these human rights are viewed as important or not. Despite agreements on peace between the North and the South, ethnic conflict continues to persist through the abuse of power and corruption as Gamal Gassim notes in his Study of Sudan's 2010 presidential elections. http://www.sciencedirect.com.helicon.vuw.ac.nz/science/article/pii/S0261379411000266 . Currently Sudan have dropped to 173/175 in Transparency Internationals 2014 rankings, depicting the lack of meaningful progress or change.

Corruption_types: "Misuse of public resources by top officials"
Justification: Muammar Qaddafi came to power in Libya in 1969, and described as the leader of a bloodless military coup. Within 42 years in power, he invented his own system and government. His rule was characterized by patronage and the tight control of a police state. Libya's population is only six million and its oil revenues of US ($32bn) annually in 2010, but still Libyans do not feel the wealth and living in very poor conditions and it considered as one of the far poorer countries. Under Qaddafi, there was huge unemployment that estimated to be approximately 30%. Socialism did not provide free education, healthcare, subsidized housing or even transport. Also Wages were far low and the wealth from any foreign investments only benefits the elites (Kafala, 2011) . In this section I will try to focus on the corruption under Muammar Qaddafi between the periods of 1969 to 2011 and will illustrate the status of human rights and civil liberties under his authoritarian regime. Political rights and civil liberties: Political parties, universal suffrage and elections under Muammar Gaddafi: During Qaddafi 42-year rule, although the universal suffrage was existed, Muammar Gaddafi banned direct elections, calling the process of democracy 'bourgeois' and in essence anti-democratic. He is the best known as the de facto leader of Libya, ruling from 1969 till he met his death in 2011. Elections to the new General National Congress were only held in Libya on July 2012. These elections are the first elections of any kind held in Libya since 1965, Additionally, political parties in Libya were banned from 1972 until his removal in 2011. This means that Libya has not had political parties to speak since the monarchy banned it, and this shows that the situation in Libya is different from Egypt or Tunisia that both had political parties prior to their revolutions in 2011. Qaddafi introduced his own political philosophy in a book called the 'Green Book' . In this book, Qaddafi spurned political parties as form of dictatorship and he considered those who claim the right to assembly to be a betrayal of his green book. However, after his fall, a total of 130 political parties were established and started to provide people with different ideologies and political thoughts for the July 7 constituent elections. Access to political power: Libya under Gaddafi was a direct democracy in which the masses held the power. In reality, of course, all power laid in the hands of the ruler Gaddafi and his relatives of including sons, family, and thugs. No one can have access to participate in politics under his authoritarian regime. Additionally, Qaddafi warned people who want to organize politically and said that anyone who opposes his system would face repression. For example, in 1976 Gaddafi authorized the execution of 22 officers who had participated in an attempted coup the previous year, beside the execution of several civilians and rights activist. No independent Media: Under Muammar al-Gaddafi, the Libyan media system was among the most restricted in the world. He considered that mass media is a tool for revolutionary mobilization and national development. Even in the latest event and the revolution that held n 2011, the revolution was first organized using the Internet with around 500 protestors from all Libya towns. As a response, Gaddafi cut of the Internet, and blamed some channels for its coverage such as Al-Jazeera and different websites. Even more, he tried to have more control over what his people and the international world, therefore he attacked international journalist by the military, and beaten the BBC news crew by his soldiers. Media censorship was not a recent problem under Gaddafi's regime. In 1972; he also stopped all existing newspapers and linked all media stuff to all newly formed committee by people. In the 'Green Book', he illustrated that 'the press is a means of expression of society and is not a means of expression of a natural or a corporate person. Logically and democratically, the press cannot be owned by either of them. I believe that although what Gaddafi have done to largely restrict the media and have control over what is going to appear to the masses, there is a large sector of people that were willing to circumvent these boundaries (Richter) . This clearly appeared in the step that has taken by the Libyans in 2011 when they succeed to get over the limits and media censorship to end the existed authoritarian regime. Finally, after the revolution, Nouri Abu Sahmain, the General National Congress president, has confirmed that no censorship will be imposed on the media again. Corruption and the misuse of public resources (Oil) : Libya's economy mainly depends on the revenues from the petroleum sector. People can obviously see that revolts in Libya in 2011 were partly because of the corruption and the misuse of oil money by some officials. Libya produces 1.6 million barrels of oil per day and is the 17th largest producer in the world. Despite such great wealth, citizens in Libya have not seen benefits from their countries'national resources. According to Ibrahim Jadhran (2014), former commander of the Petroleum Defense Guard, the government was accused for corruption in oil illegal sale deals. People were extremely surprised to see that the Libyans living standards were very low, no clean running water, bad sewage system and they are struggling to find their basic needs. The United Nations declared that 40 per cent of Libya's populations that reached 6.4 million are living under the poverty line. This explains that no advantages from the oil reserves in Libya that are considered one of the largest country for exporting oil in Africa. Rising poverty and other problem was due to the wealth and specifically oil revenues that always channeled to the ruler Qaddafi, his family and supporters. People in Libya especially in the east were aiming not just political freedom but economic ones and need the wealth to be distributed fairly among the nation (the national world, 2011) . Rule of Law and the judiciary system: Without a doubt, the justice system in Libya under Qaddafi was completely corrupted, and there is a need to establish new fair system that pursue the course of justice and uphold the rule of law as well. The justice system was dysfunctional under Qaddafi and the detentions of approximately 8000 people that were hold by the Militias in relation to the demonstration in 2011 was an example of such corruption. Minority rights: Under Qaddafi's regime the minority groups were always marginalized and were not given the same rights as the rest of the citizens. For example, in Libya the majority of its populations are Arabs, but there are a large minority groups such as the Tuareg, Amazigh and Tebu. These groups were not treated or enjoyed the same rights as the Libyans. The Amazigh were considered to be one of the strongest opponents to the Libyan dictator 'Al-Qaddafi', and he also considered them a major threat to his own vision towards the united Arab nations (Mcbain, 2011) . On the other hand, the new government is now working on making new commitments in order to ensure that all citizens in Libya are treated equally, and the new constitutions protect the rights for all minorities. Therefore, Muammar al-Qaddafi's downfall in 2011 was a result of aggressive suppression and brutality. Under Qaddafi's regime, crimes against humanity were held and Libyans were suffering to live and achieve their basic rights and liberties for four whole decades. References: Armitage, J. (2013) . This could be due to the 1994 amendment which looked to make a positive change within Argentina. With a population of potential voters of 20.5 million in 89, there was a registered voter database of 20.02 million, a stat that only increased by the next election. Although just because they are in law doesn't make them fully engrained into society. The religious majority enjoy their freedoms while the minorities like the Jewish community are subject to much abuse, but not government sanctioned abuse. At a social level instead. This is still a form of abuse and reduction of civil liberties within a community. One aspect that plagued the Menem government was the constant forms of corruption that appeared while at the same time trying to reduce corruption at a state and government level. Things like bribery to allow drug trafficking across borders, people being granted political and judicial immunity due to bribery and connections. This corruption was commented on by freedom house by claiming how Menem's control over the judiciary resulted in much outrage as it failed to fully enforce a separation of powers in the state. Another issue during the Menem government was the freedom of press. They were allowed within the law to act independently and freely but were often subject to intimidation and threats while trying to do their job. This included over 1000 beatings, kidnappings and torturing during Menem's presidential reign for apparently free press members. Justification: Ukraine, up until 2012, had had a near flawless democratic system. Unfortunately, 2012 heralded an unseen turn of events: 'Ukraine's October 2012 parliamentary elections were deeply flawed, ending a string of national elections that had been considered free and fair. Former prime minister Yuliya Tymoshenko, who represented the most outspoken opposition to President Viktor Yanukovych's Party of Regions, remained in jail and was not allowed to compete. The new electoral law, revised at the end of 2011, delivered more seats to the ruling party than it would have won under the previous system. Monitors cited numerous abuses in the elections, which strengthened the position of antidemocratic factions in the parliament. ' This shows that is extremely difficult for opposition parties to even contend in elections, let alone for a change of government to happen. ( https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2013/ukraine#.VV7Wq_mqqko ) Ukraine practices universal suffrage to any citizen of 18 years of age or older. ( http://www.indexmundi.com/ukraine/suffrage.html ) As previously stated, in 2012, the leader of the opposition was imprisoned and not allowed to contend in the election. This shows that there is virtually no chance for a change of government to happen. Although political parties are allowed to be formed by citizens, there are many restrictions in place. Also, by reading the aforementioned statements in the previous questions, I can make an educated guess that there would be many significant barriers to creating one. 'Article 5. Restrictions on the Formation and Operation of Political Parties The formation and operation of political parties shall be prohibited if their programme objectives or activities are aimed at: (1) liquidating Ukrainian independence; (2) forcefully changing the constitutional order; (3) violating Ukraine's sovereignty and territorial integrity; (4) undermining national security; (5) unlawfully seizing power; (6) propagandising war and violence, inciting interethnic, racial or religious animosity; (7) encroaching on human rights and freedoms; (8) encroaching on public health. Political parties shall not have paramilitary formations.' ( http://www.legislationline.org/documents/action/popup/id/7110 ) . Although the Ukrainian constitution enshrines freedom of speech, journalists have reported that they have been the subject of intimidation and many media outlets self-censor their work on topics that may be sensitive to the government. Freedom House evaluates Ukrainian media as 'Not Free' . : Fourteen journalists from the Ukrainian edition of Forbes magazine resigned simultaneously in November to protest censorship.' There are many issues within the Ukrainian media regarding censorship. The Ukrainian government has no recognition or respect for the Rule of Law. 'The Ukrainian government did not espouse the Rule of Law, but instead denied the public fair access to the justice system; infringed upon the integrity of the judicial branch; passed unreasonable legislation; unfairly administered laws; and removed government officials from the purview of the law.' ( https://www.bhba.org/index.php/component/content/article/250 ) . This seriously undermines the restriction, checks and balances that would otherwise characterise a democracy. Ukraine has had many issues in terms of upholding human rights. This includes the freedom of assembly and the freedom of expression. 'The government's unexpected decision to suspend signing the agreement sparked large and mostly peaceful protests in Kiev and other major cities. The protests grew after the authorities used excessive force to disperse protesters, injuring dozens, and arrested several activists for allegedly 'rioting.' The Ukrainian Government also tried to pass homophobic legislation. 'Parliament considered homophobic bills aimed at criminalizing the 'promotion' of homosexuality among children and failed to revise the labor code to include lesbian, gay, bisexual, and transgender (LGBT) people as a protected category.' ( http://www.hrw.org/world-report/2014/country-chapters/ukraine ) . The Ukrainian judiciary has long been subject to scepticism from international and domestic parties. 'Global Corruption Barometer 2013 reveals that citizens perceived the judiciary to be the most corrupt public institution in Ukraine. According to Nations in Transit 2013, there has been little progress with regard to ensuring the independence of the Ukrainian judiciary& Companies generally do not trust the Ukrainian judiciary to be an effective and fair broker in business matters, according to the Investment Climate Statement 2013 .' This proves that the judiciary is inherently corrupt and that this has pernicious repercussions not only on the reputation of Ukraine's reputation but also the private citizens of Ukraine. It was hard to research this question as there was no clear evidence pointing either towards a clear checks or balances system or not. There is a judiciary, executive and legislative branch which shows that there are different organs of government. However, whether or not they are separate is another question and because of this, I can make an educated guess that there are no real checks or balances in the Ukrainian Governmental structure. (http://www.ukrainianjournal.com/index.php?w=comment&id=68) Many minority groups, such as ethnic groups, experience discrimination and do not have any legal protection 'UNPO treasurer Mr. Jeroen Zandberg also focused his speech on the situation of the Crimean Tatars, highlighting numerous human rights violations committed against them since the outbreak of the current crisis. Unjustified passport controls, the marking of doors, cases of land expropriation for 'social purposes', harassment of reporters, as well as mysterious disappearances are among the examples illustrating the unfear treatment of the Crimean Tatars. ' The LGBT situation also shows that there are no legal protections for them either.

Justification: Paraguay is a country described as democratic republic, and from 2001 had an upward trend towards a more democratic society. Politics of Paraguay takes the framework of a presidential representative democratic republic, and the President is both the head of state and head of government and a has a mutli-party system. There are three branches of the National Consitiution which mandates a separation of powers. Executive power is done solely by the President. Legislative power is in two chambers of the National Congress. The Judiciary power is vested on Tribunals and Courts of Civil Law and the 9 member supreme court of Justice - all working independent of the legislature and legislature. According to Freedom House, Paraguay's 2001 status was 'partly free'. Out of 'freedom rating', Paraguay was rated a 3.5, in civil liberaties was rated 3, and political rights was 4 (the rating was 1=best 7=worst) . Everyone over the age of 18, was allowed to vote for their choice in political party. There was other political parties allowed to run for power, and in 2008, the candiates were close - the winner had 42.3% and second was 30.6%. The media had free and open rights, without fear of consequence. The Judiciary, used to be heavily influenced by the ruling party and military during the 90's. The system was very susceptible to corruption, spreading through all public and governmental institutions. Corruption was rife throughout Paraguay, but during 2000, things were changed up, and the leaders responsible for the corruption were arrested and government was changed. Paraguay is an relatively open and free country. Competing political parties were allowed, those over the age of 18 are allowed to vote, and minorities are not segregated from universal suffrage.

Justification: I chose to examine the period of time from 1969 to 2011 as this was the length of time the Qaddafi regime was in power in Libya. This is evidenced by 'Libya country profile -Overview'by BBC. Concerning free and fair elections, the question was difficult to answer. There were elections under this regime, but they were for 'People's Committees', a myriad of local elected representatives. Representatives of these groups made up the Municipal People's committees, representatives of these made up the Governate People's committees. However, these committees held little power compared to that exercised by Qaddafi through 'revolutionary committees'. Therefore, there were elections but they have no chance of causing a shift in power. This information came from 'Libya country profile -Overview'and 'The Cultural Revolution and People's Committees'from 'Libya: A Country Study'by Helen Chapin Metz. Any adult over 19 years old can vote in these elections. This information is from 'The Cultural Revolution and People's Committees'. In Libya there is no effective opposition -opposition parties need official approval, and as there are no elections or other mechanisms by which Qaddafi could be dethroned, there is no effective opposition at all in Libya. This information is from Freedom House 1998. Similarly to the question of free and fair elections, the ability of citizens to access political power is a difficult one, as any citizen can run for a place in the people's committees. However, there is no opportunity to run for Head of State, or any positions of real power. I questioned whether to score this a 3 or 0, and decided 0 as the political competition is not for positions of real power. This information came from 'The Cultural Revolution and People's Committees'. On the question of free media, none exists in Libya. What little exists is state controlled. This institution therefore checks the power of the regime in no way whatsoever. This information was from Freedom House 1998. Rule of Law does not exist in Libya. Qaddafi rules by decree, and his power is arbitrary. However, I could not ascertain whether other members of the government would be held accountable. The level of judicial corruption however, led me to believe that this is not the case. This information came from the 2002 Libya report by Freedom House. The judiciary in Libya was not independent for the majority of this regime's rule. The first decade, up to 1979 had a relatively independent judiciary that deteriorated after this point. Political trials are held in secret, arbitrary arrest and torture are commonplace, and security forces can hand out sentences without a trial. Courts do not make decisions contrary to the opinion of Qaddafi. This information came from Freedom House reports from 1998-2007 and 'LAW AND THE JUDICIARY'in Libya: A Country Study. In terms of checks on power, there are none to speak of in Libya. Qaddafi rules arbitrarily and without consequence. There are no official bodies to check his power. This information was found in Libya: A Country Study, as well as several Freedom House articles. Concerning the rights of minorities, Libya is dominated by Sunni Muslims of largely Arab-Berber descent. The Berber people in the South of the country are the focus of serious discrimination, with no rights to decent housing, access to higher education, no ability to open a bank account and no formal citizenship. The Tebu live in similar conditions, as do refugees in the country. This information was found in 'LIBYA OVERVIEW'by World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples. I am confident in my answers for the questions, but the issues around elections and access to power lead me to question these specific answers. Corruption is extremely pervasive in Libya, from the arbitrary power of Qaddafi at the top, down to bribery and defrauding the government at lower levels. Many different types of corruption occur on a widespread scale. This information comes from Transparency International as well as from 'Corruption undermines Libya's oil-rich economy'by Al Arabiya News. Concerning the types of corruption present in Libya, most relate to the arbitrary power of Qaddafi, and the disappearance of most of the money earned by oil exports. Even Qaddafi himself did not know where the money went, and attempted to set up anti-corruption institutions to ascertain who was stealing what. Bribes were commonplace among mid-level government officials, politically connected people were given positions of power or economic opportunities, and mass disappearance of oil revenue points to private citizens defrauding the government, if not Qaddafi taking the money himself. This information was found through 'Corruption undermines Libya's oil-rich economy'by Al Arabiya News, Transparency International and papers from The 9th International Anti-Corruption Conference by the IACC. Corruption_types: "Special privileges granted to politically-connected people"
Justification: Regime Period My reference year for Congo Kinshasa is 2001, therefore I have chosen to research the period from 1998 - 2002, which represents a period of minimal significant change. May 1997 marked the overthrow of President Mobutu's Dictatorship, which had been in existence from 1965. From 1990, Mobutu began opening his regime to democracy; in 1991 Mobutu's Popular Revolutionary Movement joined with the Sacred Union of the Radical Opposition and Allied Civil Society to establish a High Council of the Republic to oversee a democratic transition. Laurent Kabila, who headed the Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo-Zaire (AFDL) appointed himself head of state after he overthrew Mobutu. This was seen by some to mark the 'derailing of the democratic process' - a phrase used by Francois Ngolet in his book 'Crisis in the Congo' . Consequently, the year following this (1998) marks the beginning of my period of study. Laurent was assassinated in 2001, and his son Joseph emerged as President. Another outbreak of civil war in 1998 (which ended in 2003) made it difficult to consolidate power due to the strong presence of rebel groups in the country. In June 2003, a national power-sharing government was inaugurated; there was to be one president and four vice presidents; one representative from the Rally for Congolese Democracy, one from the Movement for the Liberation of the Congo, and one from government and civil society. No significant change occurred to the political system until this point, therefore 2002 marks the end of this regime; my period of study. Political Rights Upon appointing himself head of state, Laurent Kabila promised presidential and legislative election in 1999 however this was never upheld; political parties were banned in 1997 under a law giving power to the ministry of interior to suspend parties 'in the event of violation of the law and emergency or the risk of serious public disorder' . From 1998-2002, civilians could not choose or change their government through any form of electoral process. While he did develop a transitional parliament, Kabila filled his 26-member cabinet with loyalists from his political party. By decree, the AFDL was the only political party that could engage in political activities. Despite this providing for an independent judiciary, Kabila held all executive and legislative power through the AFDL, giving him the power to appoint and dismiss members of the judiciary. The courts were highly ineffective in regard to protecting constitutional rights, which were subject to corruption and manipulation. This parliament was by no means representative, and caused no considerable political change; it just further enforced his rule. A court of military order, created in 1997 to restore military discipline increasingly delivered harsh sentences to civilians with questionable political convictions -in the first 2 years of existence, 250 people were executed through this court. A 2010 UN report on International Human rights focusing on the period between 1993 and 2005 detailed the 'lack of capacity, resources, expertise and independence of the Congolese judiciary' . Civil Liberties Freedom of speech and expression were heavily repressed. While there were approximately 30 newspapers classed as 'independent', these were not distributed beyond the country's bigger cities. In these cases, heavy self-censorship took place as Journalists were constantly harassed and arrested for producing content not to the states liking. An example of this took place in September 2002 as identified by the Freedom House Report, when two reporters were imprisoned and convicted for falsification of a public document after an article appeared that claimed the minister of public order and security had been poisoned. The newspaper printed a correction the next day and the two reporters were sentenced to 12 months in jail, clearly indicating freedom of speech was not widely respected during this time. Further to this, a report from Amnesty International in May 2001 reported the unlawful killing of thousands of unarmed civilians and torture, rape and other forms of degrading treatment conducted by government authority. Freedom of Assembly was non-existent due to an illegalisation of public demonstrations. There were no specific restrictions on the Freedom of Movement however due to the divided conflict in Congo, armed groups in the Eastern regions restricted this movement. The 2010 United Nations Mapping Report documented 600 detailed pages of the most serious violations of international human rights and humanitarian law committed in Congo between 1993 and 2003. There was definitely not equal treatment in regard to the 250 minority groups present during this time. Following the 1994 genocide in Rwanda, many Hutu refugees fled to eastern Zaire where widespread ethnic killings occurred as identified in a U.N Report in June 1998. 'A Congolese Citizen' was one who has at least 1 parent that was a member of one of the tribes of Congo at time of independence. This victimized the refugees through political marginalization as they were denied full Congolese citizenship. Also, women were routinely discriminated against; they experienced fewer employment and education opportunities, even having to ask husbands permission to enter into a financial transaction. Corruption In most sources I researched, corruption was widespread, and in all forms from low level officials to elites. Although it was difficult to find examples of specific cases, an article I found in the Encyclopedia of the Nations identified corruption through taxes to be particularly widespread. The Government collected arbitrary taxes primarily from businesses. The article stated widespread claims of harassment from authorities surrounding this issue. Taxes served to enrich corrupt government officials. Research Evaluation I found deciding on a period of research for Congo Kinshasa to be very difficult. The country had been plagued by civil conflict under Mobutus dictatorship since 1965, however I thought beginning my period of study in 1965 would be simply too difficult to gather relevant data. As it happened, some changes did begin to occur, therefore I chose between 1998 and 2003 as it appears to encompass the least changes; between an oppressive dictatorship and the first democratic elections. In regard to consistency of information, I found my most of my sources to report and identify the same issues; I used a range of web pages and academic journals to ensure this. I found the Freedom House website to be very useful as a starting point for my research as it provided a broad overview concerning most issues relevant to my research, broken down year by year. The only issue I encountered with this was their research didn't extend earlier than 1998. I could not find specific information relating to question 26 and 29, however the information I had gathered on the judiciary system allowed me to make an educated guess (there was no independent check on government and the rule of law was not upheld) of which, I am very confident about. In my own words, the 'shambolic' nature of regime over my research period meant that my research fit very well with the options given; it was mostly a matter of political rights and democratic processes being non-existent. Here is my full list of references used to formulate the above summaries on political rights and civil liberties in Congo Kinshasa from1990-2004. http://www.notablebiographies.com/supp/Supplement-Fl-Ka/Kabila-Joseph.html - Biography of Joesph Kabila 'The Emperor Mobutu' by Michela Wrong. Transition, 2000 (Reading List) Freedom House Report https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/1998/congo-democratic-republic-kinshasa#.VVw4KGSeDGc - http://reliefweb.int/report/democratic-republic-congo/end-mobutus-dictatorship http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/132363/Democratic-Republic-of-the-Congo-DRC/242734/The-Democratic-Republic-of-the-Congo 'Reconstructing the Authoritarian State in Africa' By George Klay Kieh, Jr.,Pita Ogaba https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=wQMiAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA90&lpg=PA90&dq=transitional+constitution+congo&source=bl&ots=VOAK-BRwAu&sig=QiL7jB4lPxlsfJWl7UvALLWs0GQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Hi1cVeD_DaTsmAWpn4D4Ag&ved=0CC8Q6AEwAzgK#v=onepage&q=transitional%20constitution%20congo&f=false http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-13283212 'The Politics of Democratic Transition in Congo' By Osita Afoaku, 1999 http://journals.hil.unb.ca/index.php/jcs/article/view/4357/5013 The Great African War: Congo and Regional Geopolitics, 1996-2006 By Filip Reyntjens https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=KPVxJX6ycG8C&pg=PA128&lpg=PA128&dq=difference+between+mobutu+and+kabila&source=bl&ots=kCrmGKumW1&sig=X1hE3-KKkoTOwU5JajubO1gW8JM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=RXldVcqXNJLg8AXu6oHgAw&ved=0CDgQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=difference%20between%20mobutu%20and%20kabila&f=false Crisis in the Congo: The Rise and Fall of Laurent Kabila by Francois Ngolet https://books.google.co.nz/books?hl=en&lr=&id=tXHFAAAAQBAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PP1&dq=laurent+kabila&ots=FA_jzZDR62&sig=wmRRjWr58e4BdcM5ydAlVlpYtLI#v=onepage&q&f=false Article on Government Tax Corruption http://www.nationsencyclopedia.com/economies/Africa/Congo-Democratic-Republic-of-The-POLITICS-GOVERNMENT-AND-TAXATION.html - Minority Rights http://www.minorityrights.org/5082/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/democratic-republic-of-the-congo-overview.html - Human Rights http://www.hrw.org/africa/democratic-republic-congo

Justification: 21. According to the 1993 Human Rights Report, Romania does have competitive and transparent free and fair elections. It states that: 'Most international observer groups considered that the 1992 parliamentary and presidential elections met international standards of freedom and fairness.' 22. By the 1992 election, suffrage was universal in Romania. 23. According to the 1993 Human rights Report 'opposition groups currently (1993) have 47 percent of the seats in parliament.' 25. Balkan Media ( www.kas.de/wf/en/71.13619/ ) states that: 'the relationship between the media and politics had its ups and downs: 'honey moon'feelings, harassment, economic and political pressures, 'co-habitation', aggressions and abuses on both sides.' 27. The 1993 Report mentions that 'The constitution provides for freedom of Assembly. In addition, the law on public assembly provides for the right of Romanians to assemble peacefully while unarmed and states that meetings must not interfere with other social or economic activities.' 28. The 1993 Human Rights Report notes that 'the minister of Justice relieved the president of the Bucharest municipal court, Corneliu Turianu, of his duties, allegedly politicizing the judiciary.' This is an example of how Romania attempted to keep its judiciary independent in the time period. The Report also states : 'under the terms of the 1992 law, the courts are independent of the executive branch.' 30. The 1993 Human Rights Report on Romania states that in 1993: 'In a significant move to deal with minority issues and problems, the Government established a consultative Council for National Minorities to serve as a forum for the discussion of minority issues and problems and to make recommendations to the government.' The 1992 elections were the first democratic elections in Romania following the end of the Soviet empire and the removal of the authoritarian leader Nicolae Ceausescu. Therefore by 1993 corruption in the higher echelons of Romanian politics was not prevalent since the system had only been in place four years. Source: 1993 Human Rights Report. dosfan.lib.uic.edu/ERC/democracy/1993_hrp_report/93hrp_report_eur/Romania.html

Corruption_types: "Bribe-taking by public officials","Misuse of public resources by top officials"
Justification: Most of the information was gathered from a 2006 'Country Report on Human Rights Practices' by the US Department of State. USAID and Freedom House provided extra information when unclear. Question 21: Mali's period of democracy from its first democratic multi-party election in 1992 to a military coup in 2012 saw it become one of the most stable democracies in Africa. During this time Mali elected its first democratic leader Alpha Oumar Konaré. Mali suffered from low voter turnout for its first elections and the 1997 election was voided by constitutional court, however, outsiders downplayed this as incompetence rather than voter fraud on the part of the government. In 2002 Konaré reached the end of his presidency and was succeeded by Amadou Toumani Touré. This election was highly contested with 24 political parties in total participating. According to a report by the Carter Center the election was relatively well-run and transparent despite some irregulaties. Mali's reputation for being one of the most democratic nations in Africa continued up until 2012 when a coup d'état overthrew the democratically-elected government. A 2003 report by Freedom House stated that Mali's elections were regularly free and fair and consequently the country was given a 2.5 score (1=best, 7=worst) indicating 'free'. Question 22: Mali's constitution guaranteed its citizens universal suffrage for every man and woman over the age of eighteen years and during the specified period there was no evidence to suggest that this was not followed. Question 23: According to the US Department of State political parties in Mali generally operated free from restriction and since Mali's move to a democracy political debate is common and extensive. Freedom House stated that there were at least 75 political parties. Research from election results shows that there were regularly high levels of competition between these political parties, with no single party dominating. Question 24: In Mali all citizens had fair access to political power. In 2006 its National Assembly had fourteen members who came from historically marginalised ethnic minorities and fourteen women. Five women were members of the cabinet and a further five were on the Supreme Court. The only requirement for running as a candidate in an election was a $7000 deposit that was returned if the candidate made it over the 5% threshold. There is no evidence to suggest that there are significant legal barriers to certain citizens accessing political power. Question 25: A 1999 Freedom House report stated that Mali's media was 'among Africa's most open'. The state-run television, radio and newspapers presented a large variety of views and there were numerous independent media outlets including 40 newspapers and 60 radio and television stations that regularly criticised the government. These independent sources of media were generally free from government suppression. However there were still some concerns about overly harsh libel laws that may have cause journalists to self-censor. Question 26: The constitution of Mali upheld the rule of law and forbade the arbitrary arrest of citizens, meaning that any arrest required a judicial warrant. Further research from the US Department of State website shows that the rule of law was mostly respected in Mali and arbitrary arrests and detention were uncommon. There were no significant instances of breaches of the law by government officials and while the judiciary was not fully independent, there had been instances of anti-executive decisions and this show of autonomy was respected by the President. Question 27: Despite somewhat strict laws surrounding libel, the freedom of speech was enshrined in law and the constitution and was generally respected. However, self-censorship was common among some media who feared Islamic backlash to certain opinions or material and in 2007 two independent journalists were arrested for libel for defaming a government minister. Freedom of Assembly and Movement were generally respected, however there were instances of police using violence to quell protestors and also instances of bribe-taking during police stops of vehicles. Instances where civil liberties were not fully respected were too common for me to award the highest grade. Question 28: Mali's constitution guaranteed a judicial branch free and independent from the executive. However in practice this was not always been the case. An analysis of the Global Competitiveness Report shows that up until around 2009 Mali did not score highly in judicial independence, but I have not been able to find specific instances of regular political interference and am instead basing my judgement primarily on the aforementioned report as well as statements by Freedom House. In addition rural areas laws were enforced by local chiefs and there were often substantial waiting times before defendants could see trial. Question 29: The Supreme Court of Mali acted as the primary check on power and while there were cases where the court had gone after the administration, there were also instances of constitutional oversight as well as public corruption by government officials who were not held accountable. 'Question 30: Discrimination in Mali based on ethnicity, sex and race was prohibited under law and the constitution. However, according to the 2007 US Department of State Report domestic violence against women was common and tolerated by both the police and greater society. Spousal rape was legal and the majority of rapes went unreported to the authorities. Like many places in central Africa, female genital mutilation remained common and the country was a source of the human trafficking of women and children. An estimated 200,000 people in Mali were held in coerced servitude to a master. There is also prevalent social discrimination against members of the Taureg servile caste, the Tameshek community and other ethnic minorities. I would have marked Mali a two in this category because there is not a large amount of official government discrimination, however societal discrimination is very pervasive and minorities face many disadvantages in Mali. Question 31: I am confident in my answers for my second country. I was able to find a very useful resource in the US Department of State Report and I believe I have been able to answer each question quite comprehensively. Question 32: According to the US Department of State Report the law in Mali provided legal consequences for political corruption. Despite this, there had been numerous frequent occasions of corruption that went unpunished. This was evident in a 2007 auditor general's report where it was stated that during 2006 approximately $218 million of public funds had been lost due to a combination of economic mismanagement, corruption and fraud. Combined with this was large-scale tax evasion from fuel importation companies and also instances of fraud and financial mishandling from the departments of energy, education and health. However, top to bottom corruption was not as pervasive as in many other African nations and the judiciary had occasionally shown the willingness to prosecute cases. Question 33: The primary instances of corruption stemmed from misuse and mismanagement of public resources by government officials and occurrences of bribe-taking by police and other authorities. However, in recent years Mali began to take many steps to curb such incidences of corruption.

Justification: For the following responses, I will be outlining the work that enabled me to come to the conclusions I did in regards to regime and corruption classification in Zimbabwe around 2005. I will separate the explanations to each question by an indentation in the paragraph and the number of the question that it is referring to and the subsequent point that was allocated to the country for the question. I will follow this with the resource/s used to answer each of the questions. I chose the date range of 2003-2007 for the focus of my study because it encompassed the 2005 Zimbabwean Election and allowed for studies about the reinstated governance of President Mugabe to be formed. There is a vast range of reports on corruption and other things that relate to the above questions in Zimbabwe so I felt that I had to choose one or two that I believed would be most accurate and full with information in order to form my answers. This is why I chose Transparency International as a core resource because it has no political affiliation to Zimbabwe nor any other country and carries out extensive reports yearly on the issues being discussed throughout. 4) 1 point: The ability of Zimbabwean elections to change governments is highly contested but appears to me as quite simple. Most African states such as South Africa and Namibia argue that the 2005 Zimbabwean election was both free and fair but the Commonwealth, the EU, and the United States state that they were not. Elections are not fraudulent enough to completely eliminate competition but the widespread allegations of ballot tampering and intimidation alongside the fact that President Robert Mugabe has been in power since 1987 seems to infer that the likelihood of the government changing via election is very low. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2004/zimbabwe#.VV0n0fmqqko ) 5) 2 points: From information gathered from the CIA, Zimbabwe is said to allow universal suffrage to those over the age of 18. I think that it is unlikely for this information to be untrue but whether or not the ability to have universal suffrage matters if elections are neither free nor fair is debateable. (Reference: https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/zi.html ) 6) 2 points: The two main political parties in Zimbabwe are Zanu-PF and the MDC. Zanu-PF is headed by Robert Mugabe and has been in power since independence but the MDC still contests its power. The contestation is relatively useless as Zanu-PF makes it a top priority to negate the ability of the MDC to form a strong following. The leader of the MDC has been charged twice with treason and members of the MDC are frequently the targets of political violence. I think that the size of the MDC following makes it a legitimate opponent to Zanu-PF but there is little potential for it to gain power through an election process. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2004/zimbabwe#.VV0n0fmqqko ) 7) 2 points: The participation of women in Zimbabwean politics (through fixed quotas) and the representation of major ethnic groups points towards the ability of people to have access to political power. The core exception to this is that if the person does not follow Zanu-PF and Mugabe then they will not have the ability to stand for government as tests on loyalty to the party and leader are frequently undertaken in civil service sectors of Zimbabwe. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2004/zimbabwe#.VV0n0fmqqko ) 8) 1 point: The Zimbabwean government controls most of the print and broadcast media. Although independent media may exist, the restrictions on it are immense and legislation is structured to criminalize the false reporting and statements that 'incite or promote public disorder or public violence.' This type of reporting is decided on by the government and books and films are heavily censored by the government. Journalists are frequently the targets of violence and prosecution often goes unheard as it is often unclear if perpetrators are governmentally affiliated or not. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2004/zimbabwe#.VV0n0fmqqko ) 9) 1 point: I found it quite hard to answer this question and decide between if arbitrary power is wielded by a few people, the state, or both or if the leaders of the state are not subject to the rule of law. Based on the information I gathered, I think that it is more likely that the leaders of the state are not subject to the rule of law. This is through the pardoning by Mugabe of injustices that took place during the 2005 election, the failure to support property rights through the confiscation or restriction of property, and the rare investigation of torture and allegations of such which are directed towards the government. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2004/zimbabwe#.VV0n0fmqqko ) 10) 1 point: Independent civil society organizations, labour unions and the freedom of assembly and association are technically allowed in Zimbabwean legislature but many restrictions surround them. Civil society organizations and labour unions are closely supervised and must be registered with the relevant governmental ministries to which they belong. Public gatherings of two or more people must be declared to the police and can still face aggressive action but police. This is exemplified by police response to student protests which include harassing, arresting and torturing student leaders. This clearly points towards a heavy suppression and monitoring of citizens and restricts their human rights. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2004/zimbabwe#.VV0n0fmqqko ) 11) 0 points: The Zimbabwean constitution states that there exists an independent judiciary, where senior judges must have legal training, be experienced with Roman-Dutch law, and must be fluent in English. Under this judiciary, it is stated that every person charged with a criminal offence must be innocent until proven guilty and may receive a fair and public hearing. Although stated in the constitution, this is not followed. Government officials have publicly stated that the government has the ability to ignore court decisions that are not 'objective,' or do not go in their favour. In 2003, High Court Judge Benjamin Paradza was arrested after ruling against the government on a number of cases and it is observed that Zimbabwean's can face long-term detention without legal trial. This is clearly not an example of a free, independent or fair judiciary and regardless of constitutional agreements, these are fundamentally not upheld. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2004/zimbabwe#.VV0n0fmqqko ) 12) 0 points: Although stated in the constitution that an auditor general will conduct audits on government operations, these are ineffective at demonstrating what actually occurs in the Zimbabwean government. The auditors who exist are appointed by Mugabe and as there is no independent parliamentary audit body then the legitimacy of the audits that exist is put into question. Public officials and ruling party leaders often evade prosecution for wrongdoing and most, if not all, government officials are not accountable to the electorate. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2004/zimbabwe#.VV0n0fmqqko ) 13) 1 point: Regardless of the constitutional agreements and presence of women and major ethnic groups in politics, the Zimbabwean government and society does not uphold the right to equal treatment and due process for minority groups. Land seizure is a key example for the lack of this. Justifications for land seizures are made on explicitly racist grounds, on the basis that because white Zimbabweans gained the land illegally in the first place, they should be subject to the removal of it from the government. Although this is justified by the government to themselves, they are still not upholding the right to equal treatment and due process for minority groups. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2004/zimbabwe#.VV0n0fmqqko ) 15) 0 points: With corruption defined as the private misuse of public resources, it is quite clear that corruption is widespread from the head of government to low-level government workers. High Zanu-PF officials receive seized land as gifts whilst the government is viewed to use food to buy votes during election times, not to mention undertaking many other practices to gain support. I was not able to but would like to find information regarding the direct misuse of public resources for private gain but many of such information goes unrecognized. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2004/zimbabwe#.VV0n0fmqqko ) 16) Special privileges granted to politically-connected people: Freedom House information shows that members of police and security forces are often fast-tracked through to official positions by Mugabe upon his approval. From this 'loyalty,'it seen that these people gain benefits such as land and properties, although it is unclear if these were obtained in lawful or unlawful manners. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2004/zimbabwe#.VV0n0fmqqko ) Condoning illegal business dealings: As was just mentioned, the illegal seizure of land and redistribution of such to high-up governmental officials or to those who can afford to buy it is an illegal business deal that is taken part in predominantly by the government itself. (Reference: https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2004/zimbabwe#.VV0n0fmqqko ) In addition to the points checked under this question, I think that if I were able to find relevant data proving it then 'bribe-taking by public officials'would also take place within the Zimbabwean government. The level of corruption is at a point already that condones illegal business dealings and provides certain benefits for those in power so I think that bribe-taking is something that could easily go alongside these things.

Justification: Q19. & Q20. I have chosen the time period between the years of 1988-2011, as these are the years that Zine El Abidine Ben Ali held presidency in the Republic of Tunisia. Q21. Free and fair elections were non-existent during the period of Ben Ali's rule. According to Freedom House (2004), Tunisian citizens could not change their government in a democratic manner. During the presidential elections, the ruling government did not trouble themselves with constructing the illusion of competition: the people knew there was little chance for change. Although parliamentary elections were manufactured to allow for the appearance of a multiparty legislature, Ben Ali's party held 148 of the 182 seats. Any opposing parties played a symbolic, superficial role if anything. -Tunisia -Freedom House, 2004. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2004/tunisia#.VVx4w_mqqko Q22. Universal suffrage was granted to the citizens of Tunisia in 1957. The 1959 constitution (relevant to the time of rule as no major amendments alter the laws following) states under Article 20 that any citizen is eligible to vote, provided they meet the condition of being twenty years of age, a Tunisian nation of at least five years, and fulfil conditions stipulated in the Electoral Code. The CIA World Factbook states however that various parties were inhibited from the opportunity of voting, including those of current government security force positions (police, military) ; those with mental disabilities; people who have been imprisoned for more than three months (criminal conviction only) ; and those who have attained a suspended sentence of more than six months. With these conditions oppressing the rights of what amounts to thousands of citizens, by settings which would be undemocratic in many countries subject to the modernised world, the universality and equality of suffrage rights in Tunisia is questionable. -Republic of Tunisia, Constitution of 1959. http://confinder.richmond.edu/admin/docs/Tunisiaconstitution.pdf -CIA World Factbook -Tunisia. https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ts.html Q23. Difficult to answer -in Ben Ali's first eleven years of leadership there was a 30 signature requirement (to be gained from members of parliament) for any citizen wanting to establish a political party or represent government; this law led to little or no political opposition. The rule meant that was there an unrealistic possibility to run against the current president, due to the mass number of seats filled by Ben Ali's own party members (holding 144 out of the available 163 seats in 1994), which therefore disabled the ability to gain signatures. After 1999 however, with the mitigating of the 30 signature law, political opposition was able to form. This was the first 'democratic' competition Ben Ali (or any Tunisian president) had faced during his reign. Regardless of this law change however, the former president retained his position of power, implausibly (and likely undemocratically) gaining 99.4% of the popular vote. -The World Today Series: Africa 2012 . Tyler J. Dickovick, 2012. Lanham, Maryland: Stryker-Post Publications -Zine El Abidine Ben Ali -Wikipedia Q24. (See political conditions in Q23) There are several barriers listed in the Tunisian Constitution which would have disabled many potential candidates from running for presidency. Article 40 states that a candidate must be exclusively of Tunisian nationality (and no other) ; must be a self-declared Muslim; and their father, mother, paternal and maternal grandparents must all be also of Tunisian nationality without discontinuity. The candidate also had to have been at least 40 years of age, and at most 75 years of age. These strict guidelines for possible government representatives restricted a great number of the multi-cultural population from having the option of standing for president. I classified this question as receiving 1 point, but as opposed to a dynastic family or a quantity of wealth, the factor of an established religion and exclusive nationality could also create an unequal/underrepresented dynamic. -Republic of Tunisia, Constitution of 1959. http://confinder.richmond.edu/admin/docs/Tunisiaconstitution.pdf Q25. The mainstream and news media in Tunisia during Ben Ali's rule was mainly government controlled; the state owning all the major TV and radio networks. In the early years of Ben Ali's rule, self-censorship was expected by the media and press, but as the regime progressed, the extent of this censorship only increased to a more official degree. In the 2009 election process, the government of Ben Ali attempted to fix the results through restrictions on media coverage, repressive action taken against journalists and bloggers, and the bribery of official media to discredit critical coverage. Ben Ali's party monopolized prime-time advertising and campaigning, and independent journalists and commentators were arrested or assaulted, and their publications, broadcasts, blogs and websites were blocked. Although varying degrees of freedom in the media existed over times during Ben Ali's presidency, it was repressed heavily for important/majorities of the time. -CIA World Factbook -Tunisia. https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ts.html -Freedom House -Tunisia, 2011. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2011/tunisia#.VVx4q_mqqko Q26. As defined by the World Justice Project, for a government to abide by the rule of law (among the four universal principles), the government and representatives of the state must be held accountable under the law. With this guideline for what was expected of the Tunisian president, it was difficult to find instances which were made public during Ben Ali's five term rule. An expert at avoiding any notions of a fair, democratic system, it is more than likely that Ben Ali could have conducted violations of his own laws, and let these happenings go unannounced to the public (namely through the suppression of the media) . Therefore I have answered this question by means of an educated assumption. -'What is the Rule of Law?' World Justice Project. http://worldjusticeproject.org/what-rule-law Q27. According to Article 8 of the Tunisian constitution, freedoms of opinion, expression, the press, publication, assembly, and association are guaranteed for citizens, in context of terms defined by the law . This left room for suppression of the government in many of these instances; an example of this is was the prohibition of independent organisations conveying desire for political objectivity, and the registration of independent human rights groups. The fighters for human rights of the Tunisian people were considered criminals by word of Ben Ali's government, and many were harassed, slandered, and abused. -Republic of Tunisia, Constitution of 1959. http://confinder.richmond.edu/admin/docs/Tunisiaconstitution.pdf -Freedom House -Tunisia, 2011. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2011/tunisia#.VVx4q_mqqko Q28. According to the Freedom House report of 2011, the judicial system of Tunisia was (/is) dictated by the executive branch, which controlled the allocation of judges. The courts did not ensure due process in politically motivated cases, and often served those accused with harsh sentences (sometimes including internal exile after release from prison) . Trials of suspected human rights activists, and journalists were typically condemned as exceedingly unfair, and more often than not, politically biased by domestic and international observers. These indiscretions of political justice by Ben Ali's government signalled an undoubtedly corrupt/unfair judicial system. -Freedom House -Tunisia, 2011. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2011/tunisia#.VVx4q_mqqko Q29. I could find no evidence of an empirically effective ombudsman or other organisation/representative who served as a check and balance system for the Tunisian government during the authoritarian rule of Ben Ali. Given the history of corruption and unjustified policy making during the regime however, it is fair to assume that even if these institutions did exist, they would not make a significant impact on the behaviour of those in charge, or influence the amendment of unfair treatment to citizens via the government. Q30. (Religion as an example of minority group) . Due to the established religion of Islam in Tunisia, (technically speaking) those who belonged to any other religion existing in the country would instantly become minority group members. The constitution claims that the regime permits the respect for the establishment of equality among citizens, in terms of rights and duties, but this promise was not always fulfilled to the people of Tunisia. The government under Ben Ali's reign regarded the Baha'i Faith as 'a heretical sect of Islam,' and allowed its followers to practice their faith solely in the private confines of the home; strong surveillance was maintained over Islamists; on more than one occasion, the issue of passports were refused to Islamists; and efforts of Christian missionaries in converting Muslim citizens were considered a disturbance the public order, and thus were ruled illegal. There was an instance in 2006 where a report was filed over a Christian citizen was told by a security official that it was illegal to be of Christian persuasion, and were subsequently threatened with imprisonment. -Republic of Tunisia, Constitution of 1959. http://confinder.richmond.edu/admin/docs/Tunisiaconstitution.pdf -International Religious Freedom Report: Tunisia, 2007. US Department of State. http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/irf/2007/90222.htm Q31. I am relatively confident of my answers due to a large catalogue of reliable information (i.e. Freedom House, international government databases), but I do signal doubt in the lasting effects of some of the points discussed, as the information over a 23 year period can vary across sources; it was also hard to summarise the reforms and judgements of regime the length of Zine El Abidine Ben Ali's. Q32. & Q33. I answered this question more by the misuse of public trust and abuse of power in order recognising corrupt behaviour, but the changing of laws to rule the economy, and exploiting tax payer money (misuse of a public resource) was a standard reality for the Tunisian president between the years of 1988-2011. An example of special privileges granted to those associated with Ben Ali, was the changing of regulations to education providers, directly targeted at the competition school to his wife, Leila Ben Ali's, international education establishment in the later period of his reign. The claim that Ben Ali permitted illegal business deals was made relevant by the drug and weapon trafficking, and theft charge that he and his wife were convicted for at the end of his time in presidency, to which they were sentenced to 35 years of jail for. -'Ben Ali Family's Corrupt Grasp on Tunisian Economy Detailed in New Report.' Tunisia Live, 2014. http://www.tunisia-live.net/2014/03/27/ben-ali-familys-corrupt-grasp-on-tunisian-economy-detailed-in-new-report/ -'Revealing Tunisia's Corruption Under Ben Ali.' Justification: Q1: Are there free and fair elections for this state's executive and legislature? (3 possible points) There are free and fair elections in Estonia (BTI, 2014) . There is also a high likelihood of governance change thorough successful election of the opposition. Furthermore due to the nature of the political system executives are often empowered by coalitions which frequently change, making changes to the executive during elected terms extremely common. This is clearly shown as 13 cabinets that have held power since 1992 (Current constitution approved & first elections held), lasting an average of 1.5 years each (BTI, 2014) . There are also a large number of political parties, with the majority of the vote divided between 6 primary parties, making elections highly competitive. Therefore the requirements of 3 are easily satisfied. Q2: Does this country allow universal suffrage? (3 possible points) There is universal suffrage among citizens over the age of 18 in Estonia. However Estonia has an extremely selective citizenship policy due to its historic relationship with the USSR, excluding many remaining residents of Russian origin. In 1992 this reduced the voting population to 60% of its potential total. Increased nationalization has improved this figure to 86.5% (BTI, 2014) . Because this exclusion is based on a qualitative feature of the population, ethnicity, rather than a quantitative feature such as age this raises serious doubts as to the universal quality of suffrage in the country. However ethnic Russians are still able to vote in local elections and are therefore not excluded entirely from the political system. There are also a number of ethnic Russian politicians although an ethnic Russian party has not been represented in parliament since 2003 (BTI, 2014) . Therefore although ethnicity could be considered more than cause of a minor restriction there is sufficient suffrage for Estonia to qualify for 2 points as it is far from the widespread restrictions associated with 1 point. Q3: Is there an effective opposition and is there a possibility for it to be elected to govern? (3 possible points) Currently there are six parties represented in the Estonian government, the largest vote portion is held by the Estonian Reform Party (27.7%) with the next two parties holding 24.8% & 15.2% respectively, showing extremely effective opposition between the parties running for government. Because of the small margins between these parties it is very likely that the opposition could gain power through election. Also because of the often fluid nature of coalitions it is possible for the opposition to gain power before the next election occurs. Therefore opposition is both effective and significant with a significant chance of gaining power through non-violent elections gaining it 3 points. Q4: Do all people have full electoral rights and opportunities to participate in the electoral process? (3 possible points) As mentioned regarding question 2 members of the ethnic Russian population are often excluded form national electoral activities and rights due to a lack of citizenship. However they are able to participate in local elections due to residential status. As nationalization of this population occurs the affected population will significantly decrease, a reduction of stateless residents of Estonia by 40% has already occurred since 2002 (BTI, 2014) . Ethnic Russians are also represented to some extent by nationalized politicians who have been elected. This qualifies Estonia for a further 2 points due to a majority holding political rights. Q5: Is there are free, independent and well-resourced media that is able to act as a check and balance on power? (3 possible points) Freedom of expression is guaranteed both constitutionally and legislatively. There are 5 national TV channels, three of which are privately owned, and two of which are owned by offshore companies (Norwegian & Swedish) (BTI, 2014) . There are also multiple print and radio publications, again both publicly and privately owned (BTI, 2014) . Social media is free of constraints with Estonia having well establish technological development (the first country to introduce e-voting) . There have however been instances of passive censorship in early 2010 legislation was introduced which would allow the state to access the details of journalistic sources in limited circumstances including criminal investigations and national security. Because this increases the risk to information providers it can be viewed as a form of censorship. However the media was able to publicly protest the legislation without any form of interference (BTI, 2014) and was even involved heavily in a consultation process, although the legislation was passed regardless of their objections. Because some popular news outlets are owned by the state preferential access to information has occasionally occurred, enable the state to play a role in defining the initial angle from which an issue is viewed. These restrictions prevent Estonia from gaining the full 3 points, and could also prevent is from receiver 2, however given the distance from the requirements for a single point, 2 points appears to be the closest available result. 12.4/15 possible points for Political Rights Civil Liberties for citizens Q1: Does this regime uphold the rule of law and democratic principles? (3 possible points) In Estonia rule of law is applied across the board and there are extremely low levels of corruption recorded (BTI, 2014) . There have also been high profile cases of prosecution of both parliamentary and judiciary officials, showing that no individual is above the law. Furthermore public sector organizations have been established to act as an effective watchdog with no high level interference or pressure. Gaining it the full three points as all citizens and organizations including the governments are subject to the rule of law. Q2: Do all citizens within this regime have access to fundamental human rights, including: Freedom of Assembly and Association; Freedom of Speech and Expression; Freedom of Mobility? All citizens in the country have access to fundamental human rights which are assured in the constitution and upheld in governmental practice (BTI, 2014) . Given the countries exclusive citizenship policy there is however a significant percentage of the population which are denied the right to vote in national elections. This lack of suppression gains Estonia a further 3 points. Q3: Does this country have a free, independent and fair judiciary? The Estonian judiciary is for the most part free from political pressure and with three tiers allowing for appeals combined with a strong constitution and legislative process is regarded as fair. All people in the country are responsible to it, including non citizens. However appointments are made by the executive, and although they are for life the ability of the executive to remove the Chief justice under pretense and replace him has been publicly considered although no legislative change was passed. There have also been corruption changes made again Judges from the north-east regions where judicial practice has often come under scrutiny. However the successful prosecution of these judges illustrates a highly compliant system and thorough application of rule of law. The judiciary is in practice operated independently, although there are constitutional loopholes which have been publicly addressed, furthermore there is universal responsibility justifying a further 3 points. Q4: Does this country have effective processes in order to hold the governing regime accountable? These could be measures such as independent Ombudsman, inquiries, parliamentary question time, an upper house of parliament, select committees, etc. There are effective checks on power within the Estonian system. These include a lack of veto, even the objections of the president can be overruled by a majority vote from parliament, a constitutional review chamber of the supreme court, a legal chancellor who acts as a national ombudsman and effective publication of all legislative motions (BTI, 2014) . Neither the executive, legislative to the judiciary have over-riding power, however each is able to act as a check against actions of the other enabling a sustainable democratic system. This effective separation of powers and processes for both inquiry and investigation, meets the criteria for 3 points. Q5: Discrimination? (the right to equal treatment and due process for minority groups) The constitution expressly prevents discrimination and is fully backed by strong legislature and social safeguards. Although there is discrimination against non-nationalities ethnic Russians among citizens there are extremely high levels of equity and equality. In order to address gender equality there is even a commissioner with the power to investigate suspected cases and effectively facilitate court based resolutions of gender discrimination. There is effective representation for all minority groups and social expectation of equality which has been linked to residual communist roots (BTI, 2014) . The presence of active social and procedural discrimination prevents Estonia from getting the full 3 points, leaving it with 2. Main resources: Bennich-Björkman, L. (n.d.) . Estonian Elections. Stability And Consensus . Baltic Worlds . Bertelsmann Stiftung. (2014) . BTI, 2014 2014 | Estonia Country Report. Bertelsmann Stiftung. Bertelsmann Stiftung.
