Justification: Mexico 2000 Q19) I selected 1994 because it was the first year that a relatively free election took place in Mexico since the PRI party had taken power. Q20) I selected 2001 because it was the year after PRI lost power for the first time in 71 years. Q21) In this period, it was possible for opposing parties to gain power, which became the case in 2000, but PRI still had a substantial influence on the elections due to its widespread influence. Q22) Mexico has had universal suffrage since 1953 Q23) After PRI's consistent success in the polls, the midterm elections of 1997 saw the lowest vote for a PRI candidate for the first time in the party's history, and the PRI lost power in 2000 which demonstrated an effective system that could allow opposition into power Q24) Political power is accessible to everybody Q25) The Mexican media was notoriously influenced toward PRI during their time in power, especially the Televisa channel Q26) I was unable to find information on the rule of law in Mexico during this time. Q27) Corruption in the police force resulted in arbitrary arrests, illegal searches and illegal detention. There was also widespread but not severe discrimination against women and immigrants. These factors infringed on basic human rights. Q28) The Mexican judiciary struggled with bribery and corruption - primarily political Q29) The checks and balances in Mexico had very little effect on checking the power of the PRI until reforms were put in place after they lost power in 2000. The judiciary, for example, suffered from a lack of independence from the influence of the PRI as they did not want to clash with the party on issues, even if it was at the expense of civil and political rights. Q30) Minorities, especially immigrants, suffered from discrimination socially and were not well protected from this in the legal system Q31) I am fairly confident of my answers but have doubts about some aspects of some, especially as there was a lot of political change once the PRI began to lose its grip on power. Q32) Corruption was a long term and pervasive problem among lower level government officials, with the police and security forces being two notable examples. Q33) Bribery of public officials was common during PRI's power. The government ratified an anti-bribery convention in 1997 to attempt to rectify this problem, with mixed success. I researched all of the questions and found journal articles, reports and news articles to answer the questions. I found it difficult to find information on minority rights and the rule of law. All of the answers fit well with the options given.

Corruption_types: "Bribe-taking by public officials","Misuse of public resources by top officials"
Justification: Q. 19, 20: I chose this timespan because during this time, arguably two of the Philippines least corrupt Presidents held office. President Corazon Aquino was in office from February 25 th 1986 until June 30 th 1992. President Fidel V Ramos, who held office from June 31st 1992 until June 30th 1998, succeeded her. My time period of 1987 to 1997 most importantly contains the 1992 Philippine general election, which allowed me to convincingly answer many of the political rights and civil liberty questions. This time period could also be said to be a period of relatively 'peace' politically within the Philippines, as President Aquino's predecessor was Ferdinand Marco, a dictator who ruled under martial law until ousted by Aquino in 1986. Further, after Ramos's time in office, Joseph Estrada became the 13 th President of the Philippines in 1998, however he was expelled in 2001 through a revolt following allegations of corruption. My timespan represents a time within the Philippines where tackling corruption was one of the primary goals of both Aquino and Ramos, who both aimed to lower the levels of corruption within their country (Freedom House, 2003) . Both Aquino and Ramos introduced democratic reforms to the Philippines, such as the Presidential Commission of Good Government by Aquino, and the liberalisation of the economy from Ramos (Freedom House, 2003) . Although it is easy to establish that the goals of these governments has been to introduce democracy and stamp out the corruption which previous regimes has left, the difficult thing to answer is 'even though it is the goal of these regimes was to stamp out corruption, how much corruption was still occurring?' Q. 21: International observers called the 1987 legislative elections and the 1992 Philippine General election 'free and fair' (Moratalla, 2000) . Under Corazon, the constitution was reformed, not only emphasising more civil liberties and political rights for citizens, but also barred presidents for seeking election for more than one term. This was amended in the hopes of dismantling any barriers that stopped opposition parties gaining power (US Department of State, 2010) . However, during the 1992 election, a woman named Miriam Santiago was the front runner for most of the campaign, however, following a power outage during the counting of the votes, Fidel Ramos was named President (winning with 23% of the votes, while Santiago has 19%) . Santiago filled a protest to the Supreme Court, but it was dismissed, despite many Filipino's arguing this result. Many call this to be evidence of fraudulent elections, rigged by corrupt government employees that supported Ramos. Although this was perhaps the freest election in the country's history, even the fact that there was protesting from the public suggests that many believe the elections weren't 100% fair (Hedman) . I found this question a little tough to answer because although many state the 1992 election wasn't fair, there isn't a lot of evidence to back up these allegations. However, I made somewhat of an educated guess that since there were still levels of corruption occurring in the Philippines at this time (the transparency index score was 2.77, indicating high levels of corruption (Transparancy International, 1995) ) . The 1992 election may not have been completely fair and free, as some opposition members such as Santiago potentially faced barriers to gaining power. Q. 22: Suffrage is universal, but not compulsory, at age 18 (US Department of State, 2010) . The constitution states that 'Suffrage may be exercised by all citizens of the Philippines not otherwise disqualified by law, who are at least eighteen years of age, and who shall have resided in the Philippines for at least one year, and in the place wherein they propose to vote, for at least six months immediately preceding the election. No literacy, property, or other substantive requirement shall be imposed on the exercise of suffrage.' (The Philippines Government, 1987) . I could find no evidence to suggest any repression on voting, in particular around the 1992 election. Q. 23: Similar to question 21, in theory anyone who meets the eligibility criteria for presidency (see answer in Q. 24 below) has the ability to be elected to govern. 'The 1987 constitution mandated the attainment of full democracy for the Philippines, encompassing all the people. It also broadened people's participation in governance with a party-list system and increased the role of nongovernmental organizations. It also mandated the establishment of a multiparty political system and banned political dynasties' (Citizen Reform Agenda, 2010) . In the 1992 P residential election, there were a total of seven candidates, who all in theory had equal opportunity to gain power (US Department of State, 2010) . Although the eventual election of Fidel Ramos as President was marred with allegations of election fraud from the populist Miriam Santiago (referred to in question 21), the elections still included 'an effective opposition and a possibility for it to be elected to govern' (Hedman) . I found this question difficult to answer, as it is very similar to question 21. Although this 1992 election may have involved fraudulent behaviour, the 2 point answer of 'There is an opposition, however the system is constructed so that there is little potential for it to gain power' does not fit the events occurring within the Philippines. I would instead make a slight alternation to the 3 point question (in which I chose for the Philippines) of 'There is a significant and effective opposition with a mild likelihood of it being able to gain power through election.' Q. 24: The 1987 constitution has the following conditions that need to be met in order to be eligible to become president: 'No person may be elected President unless he is a natural-born citizen of the Philippines, a registered voter, able to read and write, at least forty years of age on the day of the election, and a resident of the Philippines for at least ten years immediately preceding such election' (The Philippines Government, 1987) . Everyone meeting these criteria has access to political power, although there is no guarantee they will be elected. Q. 25: Again, the 1987 constitutional amendments issued by Aquino included the right to an independent and free media (The Philippines Government, 1987) . However a 2005 'Reporters without Borders' report stated that 'at least 52 journalists have been killed because of their work since the instalment of democracy in the Philippines in 1986' (Brossel & Julliard, 2005) . 34 of these deaths occurred within my time frame (Mabuhey News) . Journalists such as Danilo Vergara, 'known for writing columns on graft and corruption was shot at close range by three unidentified assailants as he left a printing plant on Quezon Avenue in Iligan City' (Committee to Protect Journalists, 2011) . It is therefore safe to assume that even though the constitution provides a free and independent media, the press is often harassed, and sometimes killed while reporting on high profile features such as corruption. Although there is no option in the classification that actually fits this research, I chose the answer of 'No state censorship, but a degree of self-censorship may exist, or there is substantial government influence on what is reported' as it fits the events that occurred in the Philippines to a certain degree. The state didn't censor the media, but occasional events (such as suspicious deaths of corruption journalists) have led to a certain level of media repression. Q. 26: Notable and significant breaches for the rule of law under both Aquino and Ramos have occurred, although both generally attempted to uphold this law and rectify past breaches. The most significant breaches that have occurred under both leaders have been extrajudicial killings and disappearances. 'Police, soldiers, and local civilian militias are accused of committing several extrajudicial killings and disappearances and are implicated in the torture and arbitrary arrest and detention of suspects. Security forces are also accused of involvement in extortion schemes, the drug trade, illicit logging, and other illegal private activities' (Freedom House, 2003) . This is an example of certain members of Philippines society not upholding the rule of law, and were going unpunished under the regimes in power. I found this question difficult to answer, as although it was obvious that some citizens/government officials were not following the rule of law, finding example of both Aquino and Ramos directly disobeying the rule of law was hard. However, it can be surmised that since these police and local militia were not being prosecuted, therefore were not being held accountable, not only was fundamental rights being breached, the regime's were not holding government officials accountable under the rule of law. Q. 27: The 1987 constitution states the following 'No law shall be passed abridging the freedom of speech, of expression, or of the press, or the right of the people peaceably to assemble and petition the government for redress of grievances' (The Philippines Government, 1987) . However, similar to question 25, there have been reported instances of repression/harassment of media, signifying minor suppression. The Revised Penal Code of the Philippines also 'criminalises libel and slander by act or by deed' (The Philippines Government, 1930) . This could be seen as a breach to the freedom of speech, as 'the The United Nations Commission on Human Rights ruled that the criminalisation of libel violates freedom of expression and violates Article 19 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (a treaty amongst the UN which the Philippines is a part of) ' (Morphis, 2014) . A problem I found answering this question is that I couldn't find out when this part of the Penal Code was revised. Therefore, it could be possible that it was revised after my timespan. However, other breaches of human rights, such as minor suppressions of the media, can still justify my answer. Q. 28: The judiciary in the Philippines was stated to be independent. However, in some instances, due to understaffing and backlogging, the courts were rife with corruption (Transparancy International, 1995) . Events such as not allowing select citizens (particularly those in the poorer demographic) the right to an attorney was common practise, which frequently occurred as poorer people had little resources under the law (Freedom House, 2003) . This is also a breach of the rule of law. 'The public verdict on the judiciary is mixed. In 1985, a Bishop-Businessmen's Conference poll revealed that 30% agreed and 29% disagreed with the statement that most judges could not be bribed. In 1993, a similar split in half can be discerned. While 50% said none or few judges could be bribed or bought, 49% thought many or most could. However, one out of two Filipinos considered the degree of corruption in the judiciary serious (Moratalla, 2000) . Although this is not statistical evidence, the fact that one out of two people believed that corruption occurred in the judiciary is a sign that some level of corruption must have been happening. Q. 29: Established by Corazon in under the 1987 constitution reformations, special independent bodies were established to promote honesty, integrity and accountability amongst the governing body of the Philippines. These 'Constitutional Anti-Corruption Bodies' include; 'the Office of the Ombudsman as the people's protector and watchdog; the Civil Service Commission as the central personnel agency; the Commission on Audit as the supreme body responsible for auditing the government's expenditures and performance; and the Sandiganbayan as a special court that hears cases of graft and corruption' (Moratalla, 2000) . Both Aquino and Ramos appointed various presidential anti-corruption bodies, Aquino created the 'President's Committee on Public Ethics and Accountability' (PCPEA), and Ramos the 'Presidential Commission against Graft and Corruption' (PCAGC), both tasked to investigate corruption allegations within the President's employees (Moratalla, 2000) . The 1987 constitution adopted by Corazon herself acted as a successful check on presidential power when it limited President Ramos from running for a second term in office. Although he tried to amend the constitution in time for the election, widespread protesting on the streets from the Filipino people who opposed this measure forced him to retract these amendments, convincingly showing there are effective processes of inquiry (US Department of State, 2010) . Q. 30: As more than 90% of the Filipino population were Christians, citizens who practised other religions such as Filipino Muslims were not generally respected, and had previously lacked rights to land and lack of economic opportunities. The Christian majority has historically discriminated against minority groups like these, even though freedom of religion is constitutionally respected. However, Corazon Aquino did partake in talks with Muslim secessionists in an attempt to repair previous discrimination towards this minority group, and created an autonomous region for Muslim Mindanao's (Transparancy International, 1995) . Unfortunately, the lack of fiscal autonomy and indecisive land borders instead created more dissent amongst these minority groups and has led to insurgencies against the regimes. Both Aquino and Ramos used conciliatory and aggressive military tactics to address these insurgencies (Transparancy International, 1995) . Although it was not always the regimes themselves showing unequal treatment towards minority groups such as Muslim's, social and procedural discrimination was occurring nonetheless from the general public. Q. 31: I found the Philippines much harder to answer than Djibouti, and am therefore less confident of my answers. The reason for my uncertain is most likely because my time period starts in the 1980's, so it was hard to find credible sources for this far back in time. For example, regarding the questions 21 and 23, although there are a few newspaper articles stating corruption in the election, I had to make educated guesses on whether this was credible, or just an opponent angry because she lost. It was also hard to assert the levels of corruption occurring internally during both Aquino's and Ramos's time in office. Although it was evident that corruption still occurred, investigating whether or not the two Presidents themselves were corrupt was especially difficult. Q. 32, 33: The earliest the Philippines's corruption index score was measured by Transparency International was 1995. Luckily this falls within my time span. In 1995, the Philippines corruption score was 2.77, indicating a high level of corruption. Although both Aquino and Ramos administrations took steps to reduce opportunities for corruption since 1986, these have not been sufficient to control corruption, largely because elected officials have not shown sufficient political will to enforce anticorruption laws (Transparancy International, 1995) . Ramos's attempt to decentralise the government in the 90's perhaps led to an increase in corruption amongst lower level government officials, where legislation in 1991 transferred power to localities and regions to provide more services and increase revenue. This had adverse effects as it increased corruption, a 2001 study stating 'contractors admit to paying mayors of the towns where they have projects, because, they say, the officials can delay the work by withholding necessary permits or harassing the workers. Municipal mayors get 7% while the barangay (village) captain is given 3%. The heads of implementing agencies -usually the district, municipal or city engineer -get about 10%' (Shah, 2006) . During Aquino's time in office, a survey was taken regarding public opinion on corruption. 'As much as 58% of respondents agreed that given current conditions, corrupt government officials are a greater threat to the country than the NPA (New People's Army, communist guerrillas who lost ground after Aquino's assumption to office) ' (Moratalla, 2000) . Essentially, both Aquino and Ramos tried to rectify the corruption left in the government from Marcos's regime, but neither fully succeeded. 'The Office of the Ombudsman reported that about P9 billion was lost to government due to malversation, estafa (swindling) and violation of the provision of the Anti-Graft and Corrupt Practices Act for a period of eight and a half years (1990 to June 1998) . In the Ombudsman's report, 63 agencies and departments contributed to the losses. However, the top ten of these agencies alone accounted for almost P8.5 billion' (Moratalla, 2000) . Therefore, the type of corruption occurring during the time that both Corazon Aquino and Fidel Ramos were in office was the private misuse of public resources by government officials and public workers. Although Aquino and Ramos themselves perhaps weren't corrupt and vowed to fight corruption, it was beyond their power to harness the corruption occurring around them amongst the lower levels of government. Justification: Peter Lamour argues that the defintion of corruption is subjective and therefore there can be different in different cultures, in this instance it is a western standard of democracy and corruption being measured against a non-western country. In Thai politics during Banharn Silpa-Archa regime, Thailand was a constitutional monarchy, meaning that the Prime Minister (in this case Banharn) is the head of government while the monarch is the head of state (although the King of Thailand has little political power, and is largely just a symbolic position) . This also meant that the judiciary was independent. In Thailand the role of prime minister is usually held by a military person. The high turnover of parties in power shows that there is a strong chance of an opposition party being elected, and the fact that there were three different parties in succession around Banharn's period also is a good indicator of this. Banharn Silpa-Archa, of the Chart Thai party was in power from 1995 to 1996. A middle class revolt in 1992 resulted in the next two elections being democratic (including Banharn's election) . Silpa-Archa's time in power was rife with corruption, to the extent that it led to his resignation less than two years after he took office. Things like ombudsmen and enshrined political rights were not written into a constitution until 1997, after this particular regime. As it was not until 1997 that checks and balances were put in place, it is safe to assume that Bansharn's regime was lacking in these. As well as this, Thai police have a reputation today as being extremely corrupt, therefore it is safe to assume that they also were in the mid nineties, meaning that the reliability and effectiveness of the rule of law is extremely questionable. Because of these facts, it seems that the leader of the country is not subject to the rule of law, as Banharn evidently subverted the law on many occasions. Thailand has widespread suffrage and it is compulsory to vote, however, there are restrictions based on age (you can't vote if you're under 18), and also for things like mental illness, people detained for legal reasons, etc. however reliability of its electoral commission is questionable as they aren't accountable to anyone, and have large amounts of power, as they can cancel elections at any time. This didn't seem to fit in with any of the multiple choice questions, however I think it is worth noting in relation to the states corruption levels. Vote buying is also an issue in Thailand, as the election in which Silpa-Archa gained power had many reports of vote buying as the main reason that he was able to gain power (Bloomberg) . The information I gathered also doesn't quite fit in with the answers available, as while there is a high chance of a change in regime, the way in which it was voted for is somewhat unreliable. Banharn has also been accused of appointing his friends to important positions, rather than people who are actually qualified to do the job, as well as stacking his employees in his favour. As well as this, he was accused by someone within his own government of accepting millions of dollars in bribes. According to transparency international's 2014 data, Thailand has a corruption perception index score of 38/100, a good indication of the persistent corruption throughout the country. The press freedom index in 2011-2012 gives Thailand a rank of 137/179, which pretty clearly shows restrictions on the media that would likely be entrenched in society. However, he had been nicknamed 'Mr ATM' by the press due to suspicions that he had brought support of political associates. This also implies that Thailand had relatively free press, as they were able to provide semi critical commentary of their leader. These ideas conflict however, so while it is difficult to judge exactly how free Thailand press was under Banharn, an answer in the middle is a safe bet. Many minorities in Thailand lack citizenship even if they were born there, essentially making them stateless. This shows that rights for minorities aren't upheld and equal treatment is not enshrined. In the 2010's the number of stateless people in Thailand is estimated to be between half a million to a million, making it one of the countries with the highest number of these people (Katja Dombrowski) . Human rights provisions were written until the constitution was written in 1997. I found that there was a lack of accessible information on Thai politics at this time, probably due to the fact that news sites would not have 1990's Thai political articles listed, and books relating to Thai poltics were predominantly from the 1980's. Because of this, some answers ended up being educated guesses that really relied on filling in the blanks from the data that I was able to gather. I also often found that the options given for answers didn't quite line up with the information that I had, making it a bit more of a challenge to give accurate answers. Justification: I chose the period between 1999 and 2009, as these were the last ten years of non-democratic Presidential rule in Tunisia. In 2011, after a year of protests, Tunisia transitioned toward democracy with a revolution and instituted its first election -which was declared free and fair by international observers. Locating sources on which to base my answers on was not easy, possibly due to the heavily controlled nature of Tunisian press during this period, so it should be stressed that most answers required a healthy dose of educated guess alongside fact. During the period 1999-2009, corruption was widespread in Tunisian politics. The President, Zine El Abidine Ben Ali, controlled the ruling party, the Democratic Constitutional Rally. Transparency International in the 2006 Corruption Perceptions Index awarded Tunisia a score of around 4/10 -not the worst, but indicating strong levels of corruption. The party won multiple elections with improbably high vote counts, indicating vote rigging, and the pretense of opposition parties was maintained, but never allowed to grow into any kind of genuine threat to Ben Ali (for this reason, Tunisia gets a '2'on Political Rights question 4 -political involvement was accessible, but power was not) . Freedom House gave Tunisia a score of 83/100 in 2006 on their Freedom of the Press scale -the press was 'not free'. One example of this is the 'harassment'and state legal action against journalist Taoufik Ben Brik, who criticized Ben Ali, which Human Rights Watch reported on in 2000. Certainly in the years between 1999-2009 journalists were restrained from openly airing their views, and for this reason there was little in the way of a free media to act as a check and balance on power. Finding information regarding the rule of law during this period proves difficult, and this lack of information helps draw its own conclusion. Rule of law was upheld in Tunisia between 1999 and 2009 -as best as it suited the ruling party (as can be seen in the aforementioned case of Taoufik Ben Brik) . I can take an educated guess and assume, from this and general corruption index scores cited earlier, that judicial independence was not guaranteed. Universal suffrage was in place during this period of Tunisian history, and respect of international human rights was improving gradually. According to womensuffrage.org, women in Tunisia have had the right to vote and stand for election since 1959. However, the first official female governor was only appointed -according to Freedom House -in 2004 (by Ben Ali) . The CIA Factbook file for Tunisia places it at 99% Muslim, and so the country has throughout its history had to deal with the restrictions that Islam imposes on women's rights. For this reason, along with the muzzling of press freedom, the question Civil Liberties 2 is answered with '2': a 2008 US Department of State report provides insight into events concerning Tunisian human rights. The implication is, as with Transparency International's 2006 rank, that Tunisia is not the worst, but was certainly not particularly flash. Sources : Transparency International http://www.transparency.org/ Freedom House https://freedomhouse.org/ & https://freedomhouse.org/sites/default/files/inline_images/Tunisia.pdf www.womensuffrage.org CIA World Factbook: Tunisia https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ts.html Human Rights Watch http://www.hrw.org/en/news/2000/04/04/two-international-organizations-protest-ongoing-harassment-tunisian-journalist

Justification: Niger as a country has experienced many political problems and other issues over the past decade. There has been a series of changes in regime and governance which have led to a series of instability issues. However research specifically relating to Niger and it's issues in isolation I found hard to locate. Many of my searches seem to redirect to it's close neighbor Nigeria and therefore I found it difficult to formulate concrete answers for the questions above. Bearing this in mind as I justify my answers most of these will be subject to educated guesses resulting from some wider research into the surrounding political situation. The implementation of a constitution in 1993 meant that Niger now had what was described as a semi-presidential system. A President and Prime Minister were to be elected every 5 years in elections and a Unicameral legislature was also elected for 5 years. However in 1996 a presidential election was organized by Col. Ibrahim Baré Maïnassara during which he ran against 4 other candidates but just he dissolved the voting early and concluded himself as winner. This obviously does not constitute as free and fair. However Col. Ibrahim Baré Maïnassara was assassinated in 1999 by a military led coup and the following two presidential elections of 1999 and 2004 have been wholly concluded to be free and fair. In this way it doesn't really fit into the categories suggested by the survey for question 21, as in the first election there were opposition who had suffcient chance to run but this was taken away from them mid election. The following two elections being free and fair therefore led me to place this answer at number 2 as it cannot be said that they were completely free and fair elections but the criteria of number 2 doesn't really go as far as to cover what really happened. Question 22, it is stated on this website http://www.factrover.com/government/Niger_government.html that the 1992 constitution provided universal suffrage for all citizens over the age of 18. Question 23, The political history of Niger at this time was complicated as there was much regime change. However when the first presidential election was held although it was not concluded democratically there was opposition in the form of other candidates however they were not able to have a fair chance at obtaining power after Bare dissolved the election. Therefore this supports the proposition that there is opposition however at this time the system was constructed with little opportunity for them to gain power. Question 24 asks about access to political power. I found this exceptionally hard to find any clear cut information on for this time period, so therefore I had to make an educated guess in this instance. As the constitution was implemented in 1993 I can only assume that it contained within procedural requirements to do with gaining political office. One can only assume that seeing as suffrage was granted to be universal that the access to political power would be a similarly open pathway however this is only an assumption. For the remainder of the questions I will rely heavily on the information gained from Freedom House as this is a reputable source for documenting civil liberties and political situations. This is also one of the few sources that I was able to locate with any such information about Niger. Question 25 asks if there is a free and independent media present. The Freedom House discussion for the year 2001 (which is the primary year I was allocated) states that The National Communications Oversight Group was created in 1999 to provide independence for media and ethics. However there is a government newspaper and a number of private publications but these have loose political affiliations. They have been cases such as in 2000 when a journalist was jailed for publishing an article detailing a dispute between Niger and Benin. He was charged with 'disturbing the public order' and 'spreading false information.' This therefore supports my answer to the question as there seem to be safe guards in place to promote a free media but this is not always the case. Question 27 ponders whether citizens have freedom of speech, expression and other civil liberties. According to Freedom House in the early 1990's Niger was considered not free but moving into the 2000's it's status had increased to partly free however there is still great oppression of the citizens. Question 28, once again relying on Freedom House it states that the judiciary should be independent, however due to limited training and resources this is not always the case and they are often subjected to executive interference. This therefore supports such a low score in this area. Question 29 again is a somewhat educated guess based on the information gathered from Freedom House. For the year 2001 Freedom House states that the president is held to be 'politically unprosecutable' but should only exercise such powers in a crisis, however the fact that the President has such extreme powers hardly seems to holding the regime accountable. This also applies to my answer to Question 26 as option 1 states that the leaders are not subject to the rule of law. Question 30 asks about the treatment of minority groups in this society. Freedoms House states for the 2001 year that there is great discrimination of minority groups despite constitutional protections. People from certain groups continue to have less access to government services. It also notes a very high level of discrimination towards women. Women are given inferior rights in property, divorce and inheritance rights. Therefore it seems safe to conclude based on this evidence that discrimination of minority groups is of the highest degree. Questions 22, and 23 deal with the level of corruption in the country based on Transperancy International's Corruption Perceptions Index. Unfortunately Niger only appears on the index in the 2004 year which ranked Niger at 122 with a score of 2.2/10 which is horrifically low for a corruption perception. However this was the only year in my time period of study in which Niger appeared on the index. Therefore in the absence of this and again the distinct lack of research regarding this topic, I have been forced to make some assumptions based on what information I was able to obtain. An article from the Global Observatory states that for corruption there are no places worse than the Sahel. It states that Niger is one of the poorest countries in the world. It discusses generally that there is widespread corruption in these countries from not only the top government officials but also within minor officials and police officers. From this analysis it would be fair to conclude that the issue of corruption would have been rife at this time. Sources: Fact Rover, 'Niger Government,' 2002, http://www.factrover.com/government/Niger_government.html (Accessed 20 May 2015) Freedom House, 'Niger,' 2004, https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2001/niger#.VVxqfv1J36Y (Accessed 19 May 2015) The Heritage Foundation, '2015 Index of Economic Freedom: Niger,' 2015, http://www.heritage.org/index/country/niger (Accessed 20 May 2015) Thurston, Alex, 'For corruption, Few places worse than the Sahel,' 2012, http://theglobalobservatory.org/2012/09/for-corruption-few-places-worse-than-the-sahel/ (Accessed 20 May 2015)

Justification: Justification for Answers I selected 2008 -2014 as the period in Bangladeshi politics to investigate, as it represents one full term of the Awami League's governance. The 2008 election was held after nearly two years of 'caretaker'governance, which in the Bangladeshi constitution was the interim government that controlled the administration between the ending of one government's term and the beginning of the next. The caretaker government was in place for so long (normally it would only be three months) due to complaints and a boycott of elections by the Awami League, against the Bangladesh National Party, which had been the government from 2001-2006. The 2008 elections represented a much called for return to electoral democracy after the caretaker government's two year tenure. Political Rights Q1: I allocate 3 points here based on the 2008 election only, and not the 2014 election (which was widely criticised) . After a two year period of prolonged caretaker governance, the caretaker government decided to schedule elections for the end of 2008, in accordance with the recommendations of international observers and the wishes of the Bangladeshi people. The general elections held on the 29 th December 2008 were widely praised, with Freedom House (2009) judging the elections to be 'relatively free and fair', a significant improvement on previous elections in the country's history, and a delegation from the National Democratic Institute describing them as 'well-administered and peaceful'(2009) . An accurate voter list, genuinely secret ballots, largely cordial relations between the major political parties and an exceptional voter turnout of 87% contributed to the good quality of the election. The Awami League came into power in the most fair and peaceful election in Bangladesh's history. Q2: Bangladesh has universal suffrage for all adults age 18 and over (CIA World Factbook) . Therefore, I award 3 points. Q3: Bangladesh has a strong two party system, with regular turnover of governance between the Bangladesh National Party and Awami League, though this turnover is almost invariably contested or temporarily boycotted at the time (BBC) . A lot of the drama associated with turnover of leadership seems to be associated with the personal vendetta between the begums of each major party, Sheikh Hasina of the Awami League and Khaleda Zia of the BNP (The Economist, 2015), which is supposedly traced back to one woman's father being allegedly assassinated by the other woman's father back in the 1970s (Seattlepi, 2006) . With the exception of the 2006-2008 political crisis however, opposition boycotts or strikes have not led to any long term problems with turnover of administration. The 2008 elections were no exception, and the fact that the Awami League won a two thirds majority also suggests the party had a good chance of defeating the BNP from the start. On the basis of the above, I award 3 points. Q4: It is difficult to evaluate exactly who had realistic access to political power in Bangladesh in the 2008-2014 period. It is the sort of assessment that has to be inferred from other facts. Freedom House (2015) notes that 'religious minorities (i.e. non-Muslims) remain underrepresented in politics and state employment, though the secularist Awami League government has appointed several members of such groups to leadership positions.'Certainly the political status of minorities compared with the dominant Muslim group seems questionable. It is also interesting to note that both the major party leaders have occupied their roles continuously since the democratisation of Bangladesh in 1991, and both were closely associated with previous leaders of the country; Khaleda Zia was the wife of Ziaur Rahman, the military dictator who ruled Bangladesh between 1977 and 1981, and Sheikh Hasina is the oldest child of Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, the original founder of the Awami League. Thus, there is an association of the most powerful role in Bangladeshi politics with old political connections. In sum, I cautiously allocate 2 points here, however it is a difficult question. Q5: The Awami League's 2009-2014 government became increasingly repressive of opposition in the media, as articulated in sources such as Human Rights Watch's World Report 2014, and Freedom House's report from that year. Internet media were targeted especially aggressively, with numerous bloggers being arrested in 2013 and 2014 for criticising or questioning the government. In 2014, Reporters Without Borders ranked Bangladesh 146 out of 180 countries in its Press Freedom Index. It is with some confidence that I award only 1 point on the topic of media freedom. Civil Liberties Q6: Rule of law was poor, with a politicised and corruption prone judiciary and court system, access to which was, for the poor, quite limited (Freedom House, 2014) . Police officers regularly detained suspects arbitrarily, and many prisoners were tortured or otherwise intimidated by police. The government also cracked down on protesters at various times, outside the bounds of the law (Human Rights Watch, 2014) . The overall situation, I judge, warrants a 1 on a 3 point spectrum. Q7: As has already been made fairly clear from the above, citizens of Bangladesh had few rights guaranteed to them in the 2009-2014 period, particularly towards the end. Freedom of speech was increasingly limited as government tolerance of opposition decreased. The right to due process was almost non-existent as police undertook arbitrary detention of suspects. Homosexual activity was and is discriminated against within society, and was tacitly accepted by the government (Freedom House, 2014) . Some rights, such as the right to movement and the right to academic freedom, are relatively well upheld, however even in academia, some topics are discouraged from being researched or discussed, such as aspects of religion and politics (Freedom House, 2014) . Citizens had access to a few rights, but many were encroached upon, and so it seems appropriate to allocate 1 point here. Q8: The judiciary was far from free, fair or independent. In Bangladesh, the incumbent government makes Supreme Court appointments, the result of which is that judges have been seen to treat members of the ruling party more lightly, and a 1926 piece of legislation called the Contempt of Courts Act uses vague conceptions of 'contempt'to make much criticism of the court prosecutable (Youth Media, 2010) . The entire court system is also known to be prone to corruption (Freedom House, 2014) . I award zero points here. Q9: As the government's term drew on, it increasingly weakened mechanisms designed to act as a check on its power. The Anticorruption Commission for instance, designed to investigate corruption at all levels of the government, became increasingly ineffective due to restrictions imposed on it by the government itself (Freedom House, 2014) . An example of such a restriction came in a 2013 amendment of the law, which dictated that bringing cases against officials now required permission from the government. Naturally this removed the independence of the Commission, and made it beholden to the desires of the executive. The regime is only deserving of 1 point on the 3 point scale. Q10: Finding specific information on the topic of minority treatment in Bangladesh is difficult. It seems minorities were generally respected constitutionally, however religious minorities continued to be underrepresented in areas of governance and the state. Most active discrimination endured by religious minorities was the responsibility of Islamic groups outside of the government (Freedom House, 2014) . I tentatively award 2 points here. Corruption Q11: Bangladesh continued to be rife with corruption under the 2009-2014 Awami League government. One statistic from the Transparency International Global Corruption Barometer 2013 is especially illuminating on this front. 39% of Bangladeshi citizens interviewed reported having paid a bribe to at least one of eight services they were asked about, a very significant number. Corruption was and is found in practically all areas of the public sector, from customs, to taxation, to utilities (World Bank, 2013) . That Transparency International ranked Bangladesh 145 out of 175 countries in 2014, with a very poor corruption score of 25/100, is telling. I find it appropriate to award 1 point here. Q12: Corruption manifested itself in various ways in the Awami League administration of 2009-2014. As discussed above, bribe taking was very common among various arms of the government. Also, special privileges were granted to politically connected people in terms of how political incumbents were treated by the courts versus how non-incumbents and civilians were treated. And in terms of illegal business dealings, Business Anti-Corruption Portal (2014) wrote that 'Political leaders, who themselves are often actively involved in businesses, collude with bureaucrats in public contracting to beneficiate particular bidders at the expense of other investors, thereby creating an uneven playing field.'Basic observations like these paint a clear picture of Bangladesh's long-rampant corruption. Summary of Results: Political rights: 12/15 (democratic) Civil liberties: 5/15 (non-democratic) Total: 17/30 (semi-democratic) Corruption: 1 point (corrupt) Bibliography BBC News: http://www.bbc.com/news/world-south-asia-12651483 Business Anti-Corruption Portal: http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/south-asia/bangladesh/snapshot.aspx CIA World Factbook: https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2123.html Economist, The: http://www.economist.com/blogs/economist-explains/2015/02/economist-explains-0 Freedom House (2009) : https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2009/bangladesh#.VVgKbPmqqko Freedom House (2014) : https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2014/bangladesh#.VVgn6fmqqko Freedom House (2015) : https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2015/bangladesh#.VVgqpfmqqko Human Rights Watch: http://www.hrw.org/world-report/2014/country-chapters/bangladesh National Democratic Institute: https://www.ndi.org/node/15185 Reporters Without Borders: http://rsf.org/index2014/en-asia.php Seattlepi: http://www.seattlepi.com/national/article/A-whole-country-suffers-rivalry-between-2-women-1223291.php Transparency International: http://www.transparency.org/whatwedo/publication/global_corruption_barometer_2013 World Bank: http://web.worldbank.org/WBSITE/EXTERNAL/TOPICS/EXTLAWJUSTICE/0,,contentMDK:20060563~menuPK:445675~pagePK:64020865~piPK:149114~theSitePK:445634,00.html Youth Media: http://www.youthmedia.eu/media/116429-bangladesh-where-the-judiciary-can-be-an-obstacle-to-justice

Justification: I choose the date of 1996 as a starting point because it was considered the year of the first 'genuine election' since the new constitution. 1998 was a goof indish date because it was prior to a lot of instituional change. Question 21 - There is an effective electoral committee that is perceived neutral and holds credible elections - however it is not completely autonomous from the government (funding etc) . There are a few elements that undermine the fairness of elections. For example: In the 1996 election there was extensive use of state media for the campaign of the reigning party however these elections were classed as 'genuine' on the world-stage. Question 22 - The 1992 constitution declares universal suffrage - 21years old and registered to. In 1998 voting turn out dropped from 78.2% in 1996 general election to 39.5% in 1998. Question 23 - There is multiparty democratic structure - with 8 parties during this period of time. 33% of the seats are opposition parties and in 1996 the President won with a 57.4% popular vote - not a landslide victory and therefore showing significant competition. However, there is significant barriers especially through use of state media. Question 24 - Under law this is correct but in practice, social discriminations would could this from happening - e.g. Opportunities for women in rural areas. Question 25 - There is an independent media and a robust private print media. However this is limited by government pressure and heavy fines against journalists. A 1964 law finds liability for anyone 'likely to injure the reputation of Ghana or its government and which he knows or has reason to believe is false' . Although this law is significantly less severe as the time it was made in the 1996-1998 period, traces of it were active. There are a lot of independent media outlets which are legal and properly licensed however there is government influence to ensure there is controlled and minimal appraisal of opposition. Question 26 - The judiciary is not independent form the head of state hence there can be no fair rule of law. (See question 28) Question 27 - Legally rights and freedoms are upheld through the 1992 constitution but how it is in practice is substantially different. Freedom of expression was tested in 1998 when journalists were jailed resulting in public protest criticising the courts for becoming 'an institution to subvert press freedom' . There is religious freedom in Ghana, with a population consisting of Christian beliefs, indigenous beliefs and many forms of Islam. Although there is tension, there are no significant restrictions by the government to strip citizens of their religious rights. There is an active Trade Union organization but they show little autonomy from the government. Question 28 - As opposed to time prior to 1992, the courts had significantly more autonomy from the government. However the judiciary is forced to enforce the rules of the government and therefore can be used as an instrument to control opposition - especially in media cases, laws have been interpreted to intimidate the media and government opposition Question 29 - Non-government organisations exist that act on behalf of the people to investigate the workings of government - e.g. human rights committees. There is said to be no political prisoners in Ghana however Amnesty finds there to be about a dozen 'prisoners of conscience' - this shows that organisations like Amnesty attempt to check the government but its effectiveness is questionable. The National Human Rights Committee are campaigning against the system which allows and forces young girls into the servitude of religious priests. These are however outside organisations - inside institutions lack autonomy with the reigning party having significant influence over all three branches of government making it impossible for checks and balances - this is seen in the legislators restrictions on the media opposing the executive, and the judiciary's (sometimes harsh) enforcement of such restrictions. Question 30 - Under the 1992 constitution, all citizens can claim statutory rights. There is a social stigma against women (especially in rural areas) and often tension between religious groups that can create unequal treatment in society. For example: One significant minority is the Konkomba who live in the north parts of the country and in the 1990s were restricted with a lack of paramount chiefs. This meant that they had trouble retaining land ownership.

Corruption_types: "Special privileges granted to politically-connected people"
Justification: Togo has three levels of government. The president is an elected official who is in power for 5 years, the prime minister position is appointed by the president, and a National Assembly of 91 seats is elected every 5 years by the people. Togo was due to hold elections in October 2012 but these elections were delayed until July 2013 due to opposition boycotts of electoral reforms. The opposition believed the refoms were put in place to limit their chances of being elected for the National Assembly. Faure G nassingbé is the current Togolese president and head of the Union for the Republic (previously Rally of the Togolese People) . He and his father have collecitvely ruled togo for nearly half a century. This brings into question the countries ability for political change. Are elections held in Togo truly fair? Are there barriers being put in place to ensure incumbent victory? Even after boycotting the 2012 elections the opposition parties were still unable to gain victory in the following years national election. All opposition parties blamed this on election fraud being undertaken by the incumbent party though international observers have credited Togo's most recent election as being free and fair. As ws observed with Burundi, Togo's major electoral issues during this period do not seem to include a lack of sufferage or political involvement from civilians but more a unique occurence (in this case the boycotting of elections, later deemed to be fair, by opposition parties) . Yes there are policies in place that shift some electorates in favour of the ruling party, but Togo demonstartes universal sufforage and engages in fair elections so the people are truly in charge of who is to rule them at the end of the day. Freedom of press is claimed to be guaratneed by law, though some level of self-regulation is undertaken by media outlets. Attempts were made to push through a bill that would allow the National Assembly to shut down any media outlet at will, but the judiciary opposed the bill due to it's restriction of free press. This supports the idea that the judiciary within Togo is also mostly free from executive, and legislative intervention. It is the Constitutional Court that shows the most rejection of Presidential influence in Togo while other levels of the judiciary have shown signs of giving in to presidential demands and policies. Wide-spread ethinc tensions have caused a divide between the north and south of the country. The north and south have distictively different politcal views, share seperate religions, and are home to differing ethnic groups. This causes problems when political outcomes and policies favour one side over the other. The most recentpolicy supporting human rights that has been passed in Togo is one that guarantees equal representation for women in the political environment. This policy willensure that every party must have an equal number of men and women on their electoral lists. Togo currently has it's highest number of women in parliament, with 16 of the 91 seats in the National Assembly filled by women. Togo has even seen female presidential candidates running in the 2010 presidential election.

Justification: I chose 1990 -2002 as my timeframe because of the political unrest which occurred throughout the 1990s and only began to settle in 2002. Are there free and fair elections Throughout this time period, the Awami League attempted to force elections through use of violence and general strikes because they felt that the governing party had been elected due to electoral fraud and corruption. This undermined the ability for elections to occur because of the civil unrest it created. However, observers noted that the 1996 election was one of the fairest elections in the country's history having had a high voter turnout despite the violence and unrest. This was mainly due to a constitutional amendment meaning that elections are overseen by an independent body. The options to answer the question didn't quite suit the situation in Bangladesh because of the complex nature of the system. Universal Suffrage / Does everyone have equal access to political power? All adults of the age of 18 are able to vote. It would appear that all voters have access to political power and this is demonstrated by the fact that elections do tend to result in new governments as opposed to having one party in power for prolonged periods of time. Is there an effective opposition? Yes there is an effective opposition however it is inaccurate to say that they gained power through election. Rather they used their power and encouraged violence in order to force an election. The opposition was nonetheless brought to power in the election which they forced showing that the elections were meaningful. Moreover, the following election in 2001 the BNP were elected, showing changes in government are common. It is worth noting that due to unrest throughout the period being studied, caretaker governments were required to take over during the interim between elections which contributed to the political instability. Freedom of the Press Despite there being forms of media which may criticise the government, there is a concerning trend of violence against journalists. It is commonplace for journalists to be attacked by politically aligned attackers, or even by police. It is also common for journalists to receive death threats or have to restrict the stories they cover because they cannot travel to some areas for fear of being harmed or killed. These are among the reasons as to why Freedom House scored Bangladesh's press as 'Not Free' in 2002. Is the rule of law upheld? Women are severely let down by the justice system -they are simply not seen as equal to men under the law. For example, the procedures around reporting rapes are so strict that they actually mean that women in most cases cannot get help from the authorities. Other laws in relation to protecting women are also frequently flouted or replaced with customary Hindu or Islamic laws which are disproportionately severe upon women. It is also noted that that the poor have limited access to justice. Are fundamental rights upheld? Groups with whom citizens may associate with are heavily regulated by the government; there are virtually non-existent trade unions. Freedom of religion is not upheld, with most minority religions facing discrimination. Is the Judiciary free, fair and independent? While the judiciary is free from state pressure, it suffers severely from lower level corruption and has a huge backlog of cases meaning the accused is detained pre-trial for unfair lengths of time. Checks and Balances I struggled to find a lot of data to answer this question adequately. From what I gather, there must be independent bodies such as those which stand in as caretaker governments when unrest gets too bad and which also oversees elections (from 1996 onwards) . However the effectiveness of these measures are hard to gauge. Corruption Bangladesh was rated by Transparency International as the most corrupt country in the world in 2001. The police are seen to be the most corrupt institution in Bangladesh.

Justification: Whilst Lech Walesa's rule was by no means perfect, and was constantly marred by scandal, corruption and public discontent, it did mark a substantial improvement from that of Poland's preceeding communist rulers. Media was allowed for the first time to flourish under his rule, and free and fair elections were held for the first time in decades. Whilst Poland's media suffered from substantial self-censorship and government interference (particuarly in regards to matters of foreign policy), it was largely free to critisize Walesa's power. Furthermore, Walesa's power was substantially limited by an independent legislature and judiciary. Whilst minority rights were for the most part respected, it must be noted that Poland did for the most part, lack for any significant minority groups, and as rings true accross virtually all Europe, Romani rights were for the most part ignored. Walesa's latter years were marked by increasing numbers of corruption scandals, falling numbers of allies, and failed attempts to consolidate his power. Viewed by many as having surrounded himself with figures lacking both comptetence and integrity, Walesa quickly lost the support of the public. However, it must be remembered in his defence, that when he lost re-election in 1995, this represented the first peaceful change of power in Poland since the Polish-Lithuanian commenwealth was dissolved in 1795. Therefore, Walesa, despite having a questionable record in regards to all things democratic, should be viewed as a precursor to much greater democratic rule as time went by. It is very rare that one see's a state go from outright dictatorship to outright democracy without a substantial period of transition, which Walesa's rule represented. One should now note that Poland now ranks highly in most measures of democracy, demonstrating that his rule was a success.

Corruption_types: "Special privileges granted to politically-connected people","Other"
Justification: I choose the time period of 1990-2004 because this is when Lee Kuan Yew stood down and Gok Chok Tong took over as Prime Minister and 2004 was when Lee Hsien Loong, eldest son of former Prime Minster Lee Kuan Yew was sworn in as Prime Minister. There are elections but there is very low likelihood of government change via elections. The People's Action Party (PAP) has been in power since it was created in 1954. Constitutionally Singapore can change their government through elections and voting is compulsory. There are minor restrictions because to be eligible to vote, you have to be a citizen of Singapore, be at least 21 years old and be ordinarily resident or deemed to be ordinarily resident in Singapore at an address that is in that constituency. However, in practice the PAP maintains tight limits through its use of civil and security laws against political opponents, control over the press, and use of partronage. Opposition parties say that the playing field is uneven because of the governments influence over the press and its use of an array of laws to limit oppsition ideas. There is an opposition, however its numbers are muniscule and often never heard from. There is no chance for it to gain power mainly because the government requires candidates for all seats to pay a deposit of S$13,000 (US$7,123) that is forfeited if the candidate does not win a certain percentage of the vote. Parties and candidates also face restrictions on the types of materials that they can distribute during election campaigns and cannot use political films or videos. Opposition politicans are also constrained by the PAP's record of winning civil defamation suits against political foes. Only people with things such as considerable wealth have access to political power. In this case Singapore operates under nepotism. There are no checks and balances on power, but the regime sometimes investigates alleged breaches. This is because the President appoints Supreme Court judges on the recommendation of the Prime Minister with the advice of the chief justice and appoints lower court judges on the recommendation of the chief justice. Judges, especially supreme court judges, have close ties to PAP leaders. Independent media may exist but there is heavy censorship, self-censorship or government intervention in editorial processes. This is due to the Newspaper and Printing Presses Act which allows authorities to restrict the circulation of any foreign publication that allegedly interferes in domestic politics. By law, the government must approve the owners of key 'management shares' in the Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) . This has close ties to the PAP and owns all general circulation newspapers. Journalists practice self-censorship regarding numerous political, social, and economic issues and editorials and domestic news coverage strongly favour the PAP. The government-affiliated Singapore International Media PTE, Ltd., operates all four free television stations and at least ten of Singapore's nearly 20 radio stations. Foreign broadcasts are available. Journalists often avoid reporting on sensitive topics, including alleged government corruption or nepotism or on the supposed compliance of the judiciary. Although editorials and news coverage generally reflect government policies, newspapers increasingly are carrying letters, columns, and editorials critical of government policies. The judiciary sometimes operates independently but is susceptible to undue influence and corruption. This is apparent because the judiciary has consistently ruled in favour of the government or PAP leaders in a series of defamation suits and other cases that have nearly bankrupted some opposition figures. It is not clear whether the government pressures judges or simply appoints judges who share its values. Many judges have ties to the PAP and its leaders. However, the judiciary is efficient in criminal cases as defendants enjoy a presumption of innocence and the right to confront witnesses and other due process rights. The rule of law is generally upheld, but notable and significant breaches do occur. This is apparent as police reportedly mistreat detainees at times, although the government has jailed several officers convicted of such abuses. The government also has the power to detain suspects without trial under the Internal Security Act. This allows authorities to detain suspects without charge or trial for an unlimited number of two-year periods. There is partial rights but there is still heavy suppression and monitoring in terms of freedom of assembly and association, freedom of speech and expression and freedom of mobility. For example, the Societies Act requires most organisations of more than ten people to be registered and restricts political activity to political parties. Authorities in 2001 reclassified two groups that had been critical of the government: the Think Centre and the Open Singapore Centre as political associations, which barred them from receiving foreign funding, among other restrictions. Authorties must approve speakers at public functions, and they occassionally deny approval to opposition politicans. The police must approve and public asssembly of more than five people. Chee Soon Juan of the opposition Social Democratic Party has served a number of jail terms in recent years for making speeches without the necessary license or on sensitive issues and refusing to pay the resulting fines. Chee was fined S$3,000 (US$1,700) for a speech in 2002. Under the constitution, Singaporeans who are fined more than S$2,000 (US$1,100) cannot contest a parliamentary election for five years. The only place where Singaporeans can make public speeches without a license is Speakers' Corner, which is located in a downtown park. There are consitutional safeguards which protect minority groups from prejudice and a fair representaion of these groups within the executive or other elected bodies. This is the case because the government has taken measures to promote racial harmony and equity with minorities well represented in government after the race riots between Malays and the majority Chinese in the 1960s which killed a lot of people. However, Malays reportedly face unofficial discrimination in employment opportunities but there are several government programs that aim to boost educational achievement among Malay students. Corruption is common, but concentrated in only some levels of the state if corruption is defined as the misuse of public resources. Corruption can take the form of special privileges granted to politically-connected people. The PAP runs an efficient, competent, and largely corruption-free government and appears to enjoy genuine popular support but as highlighted above there are certain aspects that Singapore has corruption within it's system. References: Barr, Michael. The Ruling Elite of Singapore: Networks of Power and Influence. England: I.B. Tauris, 2014. Rodan, Garry. The International Library of Social Change in Asia Pacific: Singapore. Trowbridge, Wiltshire: Ashgate Publishing Limited, 2001. Rodan, Garry. Elections without Representation: The Singapore Experience Under the PAP. In Politics of Elections in South East Asia. America: Woodrow Wilson Center Press, 1996. Ooi Giok Ling, Tan Ern Ser & Gillian Koh (1999) Political participation in Singapore: Findings from a national survey, Asian Journal of Political Science, 7:2, 126-141, DOI: 10.1080/02185379908434151 'Singapore Profile: Timeline' BBC http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-15971013 'Parliamentary Elections' . Elections Department Singapore. http://www.eld.gov.sg/elections_parliamentary.html 'Singapore' Freedom House. https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2004/singapore#.VV0dQZOqqko

Justification: Hungary became democratic in 1989 and although remained this way through my time period selected, Hungary has a troubled past and has had many setbacks, both economic and political. However, With in the time period selected, there were 3 elections held, 2002, 2006 and 2010. Every election since the downfall of communism within Hungary, including all three elections from 2002-2010, was free and fair where every adult was allowed to vote. ( 'Hungary Timeline ', BBC NEWS, 2012, http://news.bbc.co.uk ) In terms of effective opposition, I didn't find any information opposing the statement for 3 points: There is a significant and effective opposition with a high likelihood of it being able to gain power through election. In 2002, the Socialist Party voted into power and remained that way until the 2010 elections, this was the first time a government had been re-elected since the end of communism in 1989. Parties are free to campaign how they wish and there were no restrictions put in place for opposition parties during these elections. ('Elections to the Hungarian National Assembly ', Election Resources on the Internet, Last updated 2015, http://www.electionresources.org/ ) For question 24, on public access to political power, I gave Hungary 3 points as from research gathered I found that all adult citizens have fair access to political power. Viktor Orbán, who was voted into Prime Minister in 2010 had a fairly normal upbringing and had the desire to make a change within Hungary. ('Viktor Orbán, Prime Minister of Hungary ', Encyclopaedia Britannica, 2014, http://www.britannica.com ) . Within Hungary, the constitution guarantees freedom of expression and of the press. However I gave Hungary 2 points as there were cases throughout 2002 to 2010, where there were consequences for reporters who spoke badly about the government. In 2005, a journalist was sentence to jail for slandering a Liberal Democratic parliamentarian, and later that year another journalist was given a suspended 8-month prison sentence for what he had written about the current government. ('Hungary 2005 Scores', Freedom of the Press -Freedom House, https://freedomhouse.org ) . During this time Hungary had many different printing outlets that often would criticised the government, however with these actions taken by the government towards people who publically disapproved the regime, made give Hungary 2 points rather than 3. I also gave Hungary 3 points for a free, independent and fair judiciary, as within Hungary from 2002-2010, the judiciary was free of any political influence and autonomous. Question 27 was an easy 3 points for Hungary as there is freedom of expression and speech, and the government respects citizens'rights to form associations, strike, and petition public authorities. ('Hungary -Freedom in the World ', Freedom House, 2004, https://freedomhouse.org ) . I found evidence for the allowance of parliamentary question time and select committees, and as well as this there was an independent ombudsman during this time, therefore I gave Hungary 3 points for having effective processes of inquiry and investigation within the regime. As well as this, the Hungarian Constitution, which was present from 2002-2010, provides for freedom of assembly and the government respects these rights in practice. The government also, as mentioned earlier, respects citizens'rights to form associations, strike, and petition public authorities. ('Hungary -Freedom in the World ', Freedom House, 2004, https://freedomhouse.org ) . To me, this makes me think that the civil liberties within Hungary during this time were fairly liberal, another reason for giving this state 3 points for this question. For question 30, I struggled to decide whether to give Hungary 2 or 3 points. It was hard to find the exact details on the specifics for each statement, however I decided to give Hungary 3 points because the constitution present during this time, guaranteed national and ethnic minorities the right to form-self governing bodies. The constitution also guarantees religious freedom for all religions and provides for the separation of the church and the state. This means that all religions are free to worship and preach in their own manner. ('Hungary -Freedom in the World ', Freedom House, 2004, https://freedomhouse.org ) . Corruption occurred frequently from 2002-2010 in many different forms. In 2006, there was widespread anger at tax rises and new fees for university tuition and health care. This resulted in street protests after Gyurcsany (Prime Minister from 2004-2009), admitted that his government had repeatedly lied about the state of the economy in order to be re-elected in 2006. As well as this bribery was extremely common, amongst politicians. According to 'A Diagnosis of Corruption in Hungary', written by Mihaly Fazekas in 2010, it is an open secret that parties exceed the funding limits for electoral campaigns and that this money comes from privately owned businesses that await special favours after the election. Because of this I gave Hungary 1 point because corruption occurred, however only in some levels within the state.

Justification: Kyrgyzstan regime from 2005-2010 Kyrgyzstan prior to President Kurmanbek Bakiyev rule from 2005-2010, was an authoritarian government led by President Akayev. President Akayev was eventually overthrown due to public uprisings due to the countries dissatisfaction with his corrupt and repressive regime. That July the opposition Bakiyev captured 89 percent of the Nationâ<U+0080><U+0099>s vote; election passed international standards and marked progress toward a more democratic regime. President Bakiyev made many promises that would be achieved during his term; most notably he was going to repeal the countryâ<U+0080><U+0099>s constitution where more authority would be given to the prime minister. Although President Bakiyevâ<U+0080><U+0099>s term seemed promising to his citizens and the international community, in that he was to reform Kyrgyzstanâ<U+0080><U+0099>s political system for the better, this belief was short-circuited. It became apparent as his term progressed that many of these promises were not going to be upheld as he increasingly adopted authoritarian methods. President Bakiyevâ<U+0080><U+0099>s non-democratic actions included getting rid of the main opposition leader Kulov through bribing him with a high paid occupation, as head of an energy development programme. This sort of corruption is regularly evident in society, where people of high positions obtain this through connections with the government. Furthermore, there is no independent judiciary as it is dominated by the executive. Judges are largely subject to interference from the state, mainly through bribery and this reflected through the convictions. Clearly the political system is corrupt and controlled by the dominant state. The restrictions on civil liberties have increased over time. This is firstly evident through President Bakiyevâ<U+0080><U+0099>s suppression of the media through pressure, violence and arbitrary arrests. This has been facilitated through legislation being passed to make independent journalism pretty much impossible. However, for the journalists who have reported on information unfavourable to the government, many have been suspiciously killed or threatened out of the country. And secondly, this is seen through the passing of legislation to supress minority religious groups from practicing their religion publically. In 2009 the president passed a law prohibiting religious literature in public places, moreover, the same year legislation was passed prohibiting girls from wearing headscarfâ<U+0080><U+0099>s at school. In Kyrgyzstan during the period from 2005-2001 the once widely supported president Bakiyevâ<U+0080><U+0099>s who advocated for political reform and the embracement of democratic values began to take a more hard lined authoritarian form of governance, similar to his successor. This ultimately ended in widespread public upheaval and the consequent resignation of Bakiyev as president. When examining this period, I found answering some of the questions above difficult. This is mainly due to a drastic change in regime strategy and therefore the answers differed depending on what year of Bakiyevâ<U+0080><U+0099>s precedency I was focusing on. Apart from this, the questions above did address the main concerns and issues in the Bakiyev regime. They also were cohesive with the information I found in my research and thus I was able to communicate my point effectively when assessing my selected time period. Justification: I chose the time period of 2010-2015 because 2010 was the first time there were free and fair elections since Guinea's independence in 1958, and 2015 is present time. I used websites such as freedomhouse again plus news articles. News articles helped a lot in my research as finding information about Guinea was some what difficult. They gave also gave more in depth information on how things are like in Guinea, rather than just basic facts about how the country runs. Guinea had their first 'free and fair' elections in 2010, the first since their independence from France in 1958. There have been elections in the past but they were deemed unfair as there was evidence of electoral fraud. Anyone over the age of 18 can vote in Guinea and there are no restrictions to anyone. Anyone can also run for power, but because voters mostly vote for candidates or parties of the same ethnic background, power goes to the ethnic majority. There was censorship imposed on the media in guinea but a new law has since lifted it. Some journalists though practise self-censorship as there are reports that they are harassed and some even arrested if they are critical of the government. I gave an educated guess that the rule of law is generally upheld but there are some significant breaches occasionally. I did not find enough information on this but because Guinea is a recent democracy transitioned from a military government, there is a high chance that some individuals of power get away with things. A vast majority of the population have rights but there is some discrimination to minorites, such as people who identify as LGBT. There is also some religious suppression with muslims not being able to convert and non-muslims are reported to have less chance getting government jobs. An educated guess was again done suggesting that the judicial system was some what independent with some influence from politics. This is because the government is relatively young and before it was a military rule. Corruption is still a big problem in Guinea. If affects the country greatly and many government officials are reportedly corrupt, but there is action being taken to combat this problem, one of them being more press freedom.
