Justification: Are there free and fair elections for this state's executive and legislature? There are free elections through which citizens may vote, however there are significant issues around the legitimacy of these elections, as is reflected in the significant boycotting movement witnessed in recent electoral campaigns, whereby only 52% of the voting populace turned out. http://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/dec/02/kuwait-election-turnout-opposition-boycott Does this country allow universal suffrage? Until 2005 women in Kuwait were not awarded suffrage. However, this right was re-established, and now the existing voting population is only restricted by age in that citizens under 21 are not deemed eligible to vote. http://nvdatabase.swarthmore.edu/content/kuwaiti-women-struggle-suffrage-blue-revolution-2002-2005 Is there an effective opposition and is there a possibility for it to be elected to govern? There is sufficient opposition to the existing government, however institutional restraints greatly reduce other parties propensity to be elected into governance. Kuwait technically holds a ban on political parties, however its political system is generally acknowledged as the most democratic in the Gulf region thanks to its elected parliament which has legislative powers. Many members of opposition parties have been arrested or detained for their political perspectives and it is ultimately unlikely that a contesting party will be elected into governance. http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/kuwait/political-parties-are-banned-in-kuwait-1.1121896 http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/04/13/us-kuwait-politics-idUSBREA3C0HR20140413 Do all people have effective access to political power? There is some bias in which citizens may attain political power, for example; candidates from the ruling, non-Bedouin hadari class hold more political power than the Bedouin tribal population. In addition to this, migrants are seldom given political powers, given many arrive from South-East Asia to work lower income jobs and thus are prone to political discrimination. These and other similar discriminant factors have created significant populist protest in recent times with the aim i=of creating reform. A nation of bureaucrats: political participation and economic diversification in Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates . International Journal of Middle East Studies 41.03 (2009) : 375-395. - Michael Herb Print Media Liberalization and Electoral Coverage Bias in Kuwait - Kjetil Selvik, Jon Nordenson, Tewodros Aragie Kebede The Middle East Journal Volume 69, Number 2, Spring 2015 pp. 255-276 Is there a free, independent and well-resourced media that is able to act as a check and balance on power? Kuwait's media is restrained by self-censorship, intimidation, and government pressure. Freedoms of speech and the press are protected by the constitution, but only 'in accordance with the conditions and in the circumstances defined by law.' It forbids criticism of the emir, the disclosure of secret or private information, and calling for the overthrow of the regime, which in turn has significant impacts on the media's ability to either check or balance the power of the ruling regime. Political assassinations and removals of high-profile media targets who advocate against the regime have been relatively common, which negatively influences the supposedly free media. http://www.theguardian.com/media/greenslade/2014/aug/11/press-freedom-kuwait https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2012/kuwait#.VV6yXfmqqko Does this regime uphold the rule of law? To some extent there is an existing rule of law in Kuwait. However this is often bent or shaped so as to favour the ruling powers, and the legal system is often utilised as a method of restraining any form of opposition to the government. In addition to this, the Emir, though selected by legislature, holds significant power which can be exerted over the other branches of governance. http://www.middleeasteye.net/news/amnesty-condemns-jail-sentence-upheld-kuwait-opposition-mp-1588181674 Do all citizens within this regime have access to fundamental human rights, including: Freedom of Assembly and Association; Freedom of Speech and Expression; Freedom of Mobility? Kuwait continues to exclude thousands of stateless people from full citizenship, despite their longstanding roots in Kuwaiti territory. The government has aggressively cracked down on free speech, often resorting to a law forbidding any offense to the ruler. A new effort to dramatically reduce the number of migrant workers in Kuwait has led to the implementation of regulations to allow for swift and unlawful deportation. According to local activists and lawyers, government forces responded with excessive violence to multiple demonstrations by Bidun and Kuwaiti citizens. The year 2013 saw increased violations of free speech in Kuwait. https://www.hrw.org/world-report/2014/country-chapters/kuwait?page=2https://www.hrw.org/middle-eastn-africa/kuwait Does this country have a free, independent and fair judiciary? Despite the formal independence of the judiciary, sources report that the judiciary is not independent in practice. For instance, the Bertelsmann Foundation states that the judiciary often makes decisions in accordance with the official political view. Correspondingly, Freedom House 2013 reports that the Emir of Kuwait is responsible for the appointment of judges and the executive branch monitors the promotion of judges. Furthermore, the Heritage Foundation 2013 also reports both that the judiciary lacks independence and that the judicial branches are widely perceived to be affected by corruption and political interference. http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/middle-east-north-africa/kuwait/corruption-levels/judicial-system.aspx Does this country have effective processes in order to hold the governing regime accountable? Few formal methods of accountability exist in the Kuwaiti governing bodies, though the legislature does possess the ability to dismiss an Emir if they become unfit to rule, this seldom happens. Likewise the Emir then has the ability to select and dismiss members of the judiciary and executive, meaning the separate branches are severely interlinked. Does this country uphold the right to equal treatment and due process for minority groups? There are some rights guaranteed to minorities, however, many, such as the displaced stateless citizens the 'Bidun' or migrant workers are often subject to significant rights abuses on behalf of the government. As such, it is evident that the Kuwaiti government's treatment of minorities is to be held at a relatively low standard. How corrupt was this state during the period of study? Extensive corruption among Kuwait's high-level government officials is a problem resulting in political tensions between the government and the public. Kuwait has one of the largest oil reserves in the world, and its economy is mainly based on export revenues of petroleum, which comprises 80% of the government's income. Kuwait has demonstrated an increasing openness to foreign investment and has passed several reforms to attract international companies. However, the extensive corruption among Kuwait's high-level government officials affects the political landscape of the country and results in political tensions between the government and the public. Kuwait's bureaucracy is often inefficient and non-transparent, and it can be biased in favour of domestic companies. Nevertheless, Kuwait still faces challenges in curbing corruption. Challenges include the following: Kuwait's bureaucracy is often inefficient and non-transparent, and it can be biased in favour of domestic companies. While Kuwait's public procurement process is cumbersome and susceptible to corruption - and many investigations and trials involving government officials accused of wrongdoing in the procurement process are ongoing - no one has been convicted for bribery since the end of the Gulf War. http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/middle-east-north-africa/kuwait/snapshot.aspx

Justification: 'Robert Mugabe, Zimbabwe's president since independence from Britain in 1980, has abandoned the rule of law and resorted to outright dictatorship. His government faces mounting opposition from all layers of society due to rapidly deteriorating economic and social conditions, the failure to distribute land and the war in the Congo.' This was stated in an article in February 1999 a year before the elections in Zimbabwe, this article helped me come to my conclusion on a lot of the questions stated above. I also read a lot about the state having a large influence on the media within Zimbabwe especially around the period of elections and continuing on for a couple of years after. When the opposition returned to the polls in 2000, they won 57 seats, only five fewer than ZANU . Zimbabwe currently has for a long period of time abused human rights and freedom of speech making it easy to answer quite a lot of the questions regarding state freedom etc, ever since Robert Mugabe began ruling Zimbabwe the rule of law was completely abandoned therefore making the country's political system fairly corrupt. It was difficult to also answer the ethnic groups and cultural groups question because Zimbabwe's society and culture is very corrupt, especially towards white people and the farmers. Over all though my answers to the questions are as accurate as they can be, even though some questions can be difficult to work out culturally. Justification: In Central Asia in the wake of the fall of the Soviet Union liberalisation has been slow, and nowhere has it been slower than in Turkmenistan. It remains one of the poorest, most isolated, and most static of the former-Soviet republics. For 21 years, one man ruled Turkmenistan with an iron fist, Saparmurat Niyazov. He erected a personality cult, maintaining a police state that led to a stability through fear. Societal limitations and an isolationist policy meant that the nation remains one of the most extreme examples of an authoritarian state, the old political habits of the USSRstill firmly in place. Niyazov was quick to declare, upon Turkmenistan's independence, that 'we don't need formal democracy.' [1] The election of Gurbanguly Berdimuhamedov in 2007 raised questions as to whether Turkmenistan would be raised out of the political doldrums enforced by Niyazov. [2] A symbol of the Soviet Era, a Turkmenistan without Niyazov was difficult to picture. Berdimuhamedov promised major reforms, but in most regards Turkmenistan has remained as repressive and insular as it has ever been. The changes have been largely cosmetic. Berdimuhamedov continues to maintain one of the most repressive dictatorships on Earth. The time period I have selected is significant in that it begins with the adoption of Turkmenistan's new constitution which promised major political overhaul. These reforms, as with many of the so-called reforms introduced by Berdimuhamedov, are easily overstated. Once again, they exist predominantly for the purposes of rhetoric and international appearances. That said, they do impact the data insofar as one can no longer say that Turkmenistan is strictly a one-party state. In 1991 the independence of Turkmenistan changed very little. The Communist Party of Turkmenistan's name was changed to the Democratic Party of Turkmenistan, but the people stayed the same. [3] In 2008, elections were held with more than one candidate for the first time. That said, all of the candidates were selected from within the ruling Democratic Party, and Berdimuhamedov had already been appointed acting-President on the death of Niyazov. In addition, very little information was given regarding the different candidates. [4] In elections held in February of 2012 Berdimuhamedov was re-elected after receiving 97% of the vote. [5] Protests, rallies, demonstrations, and political meetings all but fully prohibited in Turkmenistan. [6] Whilst the new constitution in 2008 allowed the restricted existence of parties other than the Democratic Party, Berdimuhamedov made it clear that no other party would ever rule Turkmenistan. [7] Most opposition groups are in exile. There are many reports of government agents bribing and pressuring citizens to head to the ballot boxes. [8] It seems apparent to most that the elections are a sham. Even so, official figures show vast turnouts, in line with the Soviet tradition of displaying electoral unanimity. The executive, legislature, and judiciary have no clear separation. The constitution makes the proclamation of the existence of a separation of powers, yet there is none, largely due to the absolute dominance of the Democratic Party and the active role of the President within each branch. [9] Judges are appointed on five-year terms by the President. There is no judicial review of executive action. [10] In his second inaugural speech Berdimuhamedov swore to be 'the guarantor of the rights of all the citizens of the Turkmen state.' [11] The Turkmenistan Constitution promises such fundamental freedoms as freedom of expression and freedom of movement. [12] No such freedoms exist unfettered in Turkmenistan. All citizens are legally bound to carry domestic passports on their person at all times, and must show them if requested by an official to do so. Human Rights Watch has described Turkmenistan as 'one of the most repressive and authoritarian states in the world.' [13] This notion is echoed by most NGOs. Freedom House gives Turkmenistan the worst score of seven for both infringements of political rights and civil liberties as of 2014. [14] Reporters without Borders'World Press Freedom Index 2014 places Turkmenistan as third worst in the world for its treatment of journalists and media organisations. [15] Some progress has been made since the death of Niyazov, most obviously the establishment of public internet access and a broader education system. [16] However, even with these changes the Committee to Protect Journalists still dubbed Turkmenistan as one of the top ten worst countries to be a blogger. [17] Women too face extensive discrimination, largely based in socio-religious norms. [18] Just a cursory examination of the Turkmen political scene illustrates widespread and institutional corruption. Berdimuhamedov has continued Niyazov's tradition of consistently creating pretext for rotating government officials to avoid the risk of any rivals to his power establishing themselves. [19] Furthermore, entire ministries have proven to be engaged in extremely corrupt behaviours. The Interior Minister Orazgeldy Amanmuradov was dismissed after it was discovered that he had been accepting bribes to garner to release of particular prisoners. [20] It was also discovered that many Ministry of Interior staff were involved in drug-dealing and bribery. Amanmuradov was transferred to the head of a new police academy. Beyond this corruption at high levels of governance, it is also pervasive amongst authorities and officials of a more day-to-day status. Tom Mayne of GlobalWitness states that to do anything in Turkmenistan 'one needs to grease a palm', to the point where bribes are normal parts of everyday life. [21] Furthermore, in much the same way that the Democratic Party simply spawned from the Communist Party, the KGB were renamed the Committee on National Security, accountable solely to Berdimuhamedov. [22] They remain a looming presence within Turkmen society, stamping out opposition on the rare occasion that it arises. Justification: Q. 18, 19 & 20 Around the administered year of 1990, I have used the years 1985 and 1993 as inclusive boundary points to limit my period of analysis. These dates coincide with General Ibrahim Babangida's ascension to the presidency through means of a coup d'etat, and his eventual relinquishment of power. This extended era of study affords a proper examination of the totality of the Nigerian regime apparent in 1990. Q. 21 Babangida presided over a regime established through a bloodless coup in 1985, and existed as part of a series of intermittent military juntas spanning three decades; from 1966 to 1998. The latter years of Babangida's rule were characterised by a restricted - and largely ineffective - attempt to establish democratic practice. Presidential and National Assembly elections were absent during the examined period until 1992/93, when what appeared to be free and fair elections were enacted (African Elections Database, 2011) . However, as a US Department of State human rights practice review addresses, the processes involved leading up to the 1993 presidential election were suspect - Babangida's regime manipulated the proceedings extensively, actively excluding various prospective candidates and significantly damaging the election's credibility as a result. Also, before the National Electoral Commission was able to formally announce the results, a restraining order was issued by the high court - impeding this process (US Department of State, 1994) . Following this, General Babangida annuled the election entirely, tenuously citing election fraud. Therefore, the elections were clearly arbitrary and had little to no chance of truly changing the regime. However, they existed nonetheless and thus aligns with the 'There are elections for the legislature and executive but there is very little likelihood of government change via elections' condition aptly. Q. 22 Suffrage was relatively straightforward during the study period - universal over the age of eighteen (CIA, 2015) . Universality was achieved in the 1977 Electoral Decree, which amended the 1962 Electoral Act, granting women in northern Nigeria suffrage (Azinge, 1994) . Q. 23 The question of effective opposition and respective electoral potential proved a complex issue to rate in this circumstance, as the electoral situation was rather unusual. Due to the fact that the first six years of General Babangida's rule lacked any formal electoral challenge, the only realistic potential for regime change came in the form of attempted coups - of which one very nearly succeeded in 1990. The Nigerian constitution affords citizens rights of political organisation (including party formation), however only two political parties were officially sanctioned for the 1993 election - of which both were created by the Babangida regime (US Department of State, 1994) . By annuling the results of the election and reneging on his promise to step down following the election of president as the result of democratic process, Babangida exemplified the fact that the political power in Nigeria rested solely with the incumbent regime, the public vote and constitution being essentially powerless. Despite it being their constitutional right, the regime's ensuing tyranny evidenced the fact that the parties were only able to form because Babangida allowed them. Thus, they were merely nominal opposition. The extent of their political power was at the mercy of the incumbent president, rather than the opinion of the people. In this circumstance, the provided rating scale is somewhat incongruous as whilst the opposition was significant (theoretically, 100% of the voting public as Babangida did not run himself) it realistically had no chance of changing the regime as power was too centralised. The fact that both parties were Babangida creations, yet he annuled the results anyway, suggests he never intended for a winner to be announced. However, we cannot be entirely certain there was absolutely no chance the regime could have been changed democratically by the opposition, and thus the most fitting condition is 'There is an opposition, however the system is constructed so that there is little potential for it to gain power.' Q. 24 As previously discussed, despite their constitutional rights, the votes of Nigerian citizens carried little political power. Elections act as the primary conduit for the public to exact their share of the political power - hence if such an institution is a veritable farce then little ability to influence political machinations remains with the majority of the populace. The oil economy is a source of great conflict between the citizenry and leaders in Nigeria. The availability of the resource itself is limited to to areas in which the local ethnic groups have minimal control of or access to political power (Ikporukpo, 1996) . In an exploitative regime such as this, then, it would be economically counter-intuitive to decentralise power and allow significant public access to political determination - as otherwise they risk the decentralisation of their assets also. Therefore, it is predictable that access to political power resides almost exclusively within the military regime itself - with the majority belonging to Babangida himself. 'The majority of people do not have any access to political power; power is concentrated within an elite few.' Q. 25 The ability of media to act with freedom and agency under Genera Babangida's regime reflected a simple power dynamic to that suffered by the general Nigerian populace. Critical editors were rarely tolerated, and thus self-censorship was rife as a result. One such editor was Dele Giwa, the editor-in-chief of 'Newswatch' - a weekly news magazine. In 1996 - whilst investigating drug connections to the Babangida's wife - he was apprehended, interrogated, and eventually murdered with a letter bomb (Oputa Panel, 2005) . In a Nigerian Human Rights Violations Investigation Commision (HRVIC) report, it was concluded that significant incriminting evidence implies the involvement of President Babangida his military delegates in the murder (HRVIC, 2002) . Therefore, in the earlier years of Babangida's regime it was institutional repression that proved the greatest barrier to press freedom, however in later years moves were made by the regime in attempt to officialise legal state censorship. Most notably, media houses deemed critical towards Babangida's actions regarding the annuled 1993 Presidential Election were closed, and a series of press freedom-restricting decrees were enacted (US Department of State, 1994) . Therefore, we can conclued that while 'Independent media exist [s], there is heavy censorship, self-censorship or government intervention in editorial processes.' Q. 26 Political academic Claude Ake notes that ' Nigeria democratizes with no separation of power, with all powers having been rested on an imperial Presidency. There is hardly any rule of law, and no plausible system of justice or transparency.' The President is therefore unchallengable in his political power, and thus has no obligation to uphold the rule of law other than to appease the constitution. The Oputa Panel also cites a lack of governmental accountability, in that 'The Chairman of the Commission intervened and referred to section 5 of the Tribunal of Enquiry Act and reminded Counsel that the Commission had the power to summon anybody in Nigeria to attend its sittings and give evidence. However, counsel for General Ibrahim Babangida noted that the section referred to by the Chairman was 'subject to just exemptions' . Therefore, by manipulating the law, and amassing unchallengable power, Babangida is able to act in a tyrannical fashion. Rather than being a subject of the law, the law is a subject of Babangida. The Dele Giwa murder is an expemlification of this fact. 'Arbitrary power is wielded by few people, the state, or both.' Q. 27 The discussion of Dele Giwa's murder also pertains to another important aspect of regime classification; the preservation of fundamental human rights amongst citizens. The treatment of Dele Giwa in no way reflected proper judicial process, and prompted governmental officials to evade human rights panel investigations - heavily suggesting guilt and improper process in the matter. This would represent a major exemplification of human rights abuses in Nigeria, as not only would Giwa - and by extension, the entire Nigerian citizenry - have been denied rights to freedom of speech (by silencing a critic) but also rights to a fair trial if he were deemed criminal. Elsewhere, the US Department of State observed further extra-judicial killings; police brutality; and various infringements on freedom of speech, travel, organisation and affiliation (US Department of State, 1994) . Babangida's Minister of Justice, Bola Ajibola, attempted to justify the repression - stating; 'If we accept that a military rule is an abberation, then we should be prepared to logically assume that it cannot satisfy the condition of regular government in terms of human rights.' Ajibola's statement reveals the systematic, institutional nature of the human rights abuses at the time, as the leadership argued it was not their priority nor a concern. The abuse was active, however. Constitutional rights promised citizens to organise themselves in special interest interest groups without government approval, however the regime denied this right in 1993 when public demonstrations were banned for fear of pro-democratic violent protest. Also, the 1979 and 1989 constitutions promised freedom of mobility, yet Ken Saro-Wiwa's passport was seized as he attempted to travel to Vienna to attend a human rights convention. This act damned the regime's human rights record twofold - firstly by denying constitutional rights, and secondly by attempting to avoid bringing attention to their inadequacies by absenteeing themselves of representation in Vienna - a clear concession of guilt. Therefore, it is clear that while 'partial rights exist, there is still heavy suppression and monitoring.' Unfortunately, there was no option specified that while rights may be promised constitutionally, the regime completely controlled whether these rights were available to individual citizens. Constitutionally, most human rights exist yet few are truly avaiable to citizens. Q. 28 As discussed in question 26, the state clearly has significant power of influence over the judiciary - significantly damaging its integrity. As exemplified by the Giwa case, government tyranny lacks culpability in Babangida's Nigeria. The constitution designates separation of powers and independence of the three arms of government, however as we have seen the regime has little regard for abiding the constitution. In practice, the separation was mostly theoretical. As Yahaya Abdulkarim posits in their examination of Judicial Corruption in Nigeria, the absence of effective power separation between the executive and judiciary 'often results in the former exerting undue influence over the latter.' This is supported by the Oputa Panel's revelation that a witness in the Dele Giwa case had their sentence commuted from fifteen years down to five years, by General Babangida (HRVIC 2002) . The fact that the president was also able to demand a high court restraint of the announcement of the results of a licit election also contributes to the conclusion that the Babangida administration had undue power over the Nigerian judiciary, diminishing its integrity and voiding its process of the ability to be free and fair. Therefore, the lowest rating on the scale is applicable. Q. 29 During the regime, organisations to which the freedom of Babangida's power was obligated were few and far between. An typical ombudsman existed - known as the Public Complaints Commission - however, as political academic Dr. Victor Ayeni (2006) contends, it developed into an 'inefficient bureaucracy'. He argues that the close relationship the commission tended with the civil service nullified its independence and eliminated its defining features as an ombudsman institution. Furthermore, its poor accessability and promotion - the majority of the population were not communicated its existence (Hossain, 2000) - further exacerbated its inability to exact its crucial functions of checking and balancing regime power. Within the government itself, there were no effective mechanisms of power mediation. Therefore, we can conclude that there institutions which intend to check and balance power, yet they are ineffective. This finding aligns with the 'somewhere in between' condition. Q. 30 There is no constitutional repression of minority groups in Nigeria, however certain groups experienced active political discrimination during the Babangida regime. According to the previously referenced US Department of State report, several political organisations were banned by the regime - its justification being that the organisations in question were established under tribal, ethnic and religious ideology for sole purpose of supporting certain political candidates. Also, it was noted that women were the subject of discrimination due to the government condoning various damaging customary and religious practices. Therefore, whilst constitutionally protected, minorites still experienced effective methods of discrimination and repression, in which the regime was implicated. This aligns aptly with the 'There are legal and statutory rights, but there is active social and procedural discrimination towards groups and minorities.' Q. 31 I feel significantly assured in my classifications, as not only have I exacted extensive research from a broad range of reputable sources, I have also minimised the number of assumptions made to ensure my contentions are based fully in historical fact. However, I hesitate from marking myself as being absolutely confident, as I understand that there is always the potential for certain important information to be lost or skewed over time. There is always the potential for error. Q. 32 & 33 Nigeria is regularly referred to as one of the most corrupted countries in world. During Babangida's regime, this corruption was manifested in 3 main areas: bribery, political privileges and misuse of public resources. I did not find significant evidence to comment on the condoning of illegal busines dealings - it very likely did happen, however one cannot be sure or make such bold assumptions. The most egregious example of governmental misuse of public assets is in the oil economy. Much of Nigeria's oil is produced in a region inhabited by the indigenous Ogoni minority, and as the US Department of State report finds, 'the government seizes Ogoni property without fair compensation, ignores the environmental impact of oil production on Ogoni land, and fails to provide adequate social services, such as water and electricity.' This injustice is then supported in Agbiboa and Maiangwa's study of corruption in the Niger Delta, who find that '80% of Nigeria's oil and natural gas revenues accrue to one percent of the population.' The regime clearly prioritises the centralisation of resource profits above the development of a fair state economy. The citizenry has no access to agency over their public resources. In terms of judicial bribery, a UNODC study in 2007 recorded that 79% of respondent business owners paid bribes to the court system - constituting the largest bribes paid to any sector, at an average $87 USD per transaction (Abdulkarim, 2012) . Police bribes were also frequently cited, with a 58% report. Corruption is therefore pervasive at many governmental levels, from lower level civil servants to high ranking officials. Also, as seen in the Dele Giwa case, those with high authority are granted extra-legal powers of privelige, such as Babangida's overriding of high court sentencing to reduce a convicted's prison term. Nigeria is an extremely corrupted country, and, most likely, no matter the specified conditions, Nigeria under Babangida would consistently score at the greatest extreme of corruption measures. References: Abdulkarim, Y. (2012) . Socio-Economic Effects of Judicial Corruption in Nigeria. African Elections Database. (2015) . Elections in Nigeria. Agbiboa, D. (2012) . Corruption in the Underdevelopment of the Niger Delta in Nigeria. Ayeni, V. (2006) . Nigeria's Bureaucratised Ombudsman System: an Insight Into the Problem of Bureaucratisation in a Developing Country. Hossain, K. (2000) . Human Rights Commission and Ombudsman Offices: National Experiences Throughour the World. Human Rights Violations Investigation Commission. (2002) . Synoptic Overview: Conclusions and Recommendations. Oputa Panel. (2005) . Petition for the Justice of Dele Giwa . US Department of State. (1993) . Nigeria Human Rights Practices.

Other parties run for seats in parliament, however most of these are puppet parties used to give the appearance of democracy. They all follow the Ba'ath regime policies. Therefore despite elections being held they could never result in a regime change, and are tampered with if necessary. (US Department of State) Political Rights 2, there is universal suffrage in Syria, after women were granted the vote in 1949 Political Rights 3, opposition is allowed in Syria, however they follow Ba'ath policies and the parties are never allowed to get larger than a few hundred members. No one can run against Assad for the presidency and voting results are tampered with, so there is no hope of a change in government. Political Rights 4, in order to gain powe, one must be a member of the ruling Ba'ath party, which is made up of those from the Alawite minority in Syria. The presidency is hereditary, with Assad grooming his younger son to take power, unless you are member of this family or community, you have no avenues to power. (Freedom House) Political Right 5, the regime controls the entire media, and satellites are illegal. 88 foreign journalists have been killed in Syria since 1992 (CPJ) and it was named the world's most dangerous place for journalists. (Vanity Fair) Civil Rights 1, rule of law in Syria is difficult to find information on prior to the recent civil conflict. However based off evidence of Assad's ability to do whatever he likes, as well stories of many laws being upheld prior to the conflict such as crackdowns on punishing homosexuals (Pink News) I have made the judgement that law is upheld but that those in power are above it. Civil Rights 2, Human Right Watch details how people in Syria 'disappear'without a trace, human rights to women, homosexuals, ethnic groups and other minorities are denied, as well as artibitrary arrest, torture and violence. There is also no freedom of speech as media is controlled and freedom of movement is restricted. (Human Rights Watch) Civil Rights 3, both the legislative council and the judiciary are voted for by the people, but only Ba'ath members can be elected. There are elections, but essentially they make no impact on how the judiciary will work. (Human Rights Watch) Civil Rights 4, There is no checks or balances on Assad's power, or the power of the Ba'ath regime. All of the power lies in the Alawite sect, and no one can oppose the ruling party. (US Dep. Of State) Civil Right 5, There are no rights for ethnic minorities in Syria, and many actually have legislation legalising their discrimination, women have some legal rights, but these are often not upheld. (Human Rights Watch) Corruption, corruption is rampant in Syria, with the dissolution of democracy, the Syrian government uses corruption to ensure loyalty. Bribery is not against the law in the private sector, and due to general disregard for rule of law corruption throughout the police and other public sector areas is huge. Justification: Jordan Justification 18-20. In 1989 mass riots broke out over the current economic crisis and government corruption in Jordan. King Hussein decided to reduce dissent by initiating some liberalization and democratization processes. These limited reforms were undertaken with the aim of preserving the monarchical regime. I choose to research between 1989 and 1994 because these were the years with the most significant outwardly democratic reform. In years following 1995, repression became more prevalent and freedom decreased in Jordan. 21. I have given Jordan one point, because the Jordan in 1989 and 1993 did result in changes of composition of the legislature and cabinet. During the 1989 election political parties were illegal, but significant opposition became possible with legalisation in 1992 (Andrew Reynolds and Jorgen Elkit, Jordan: Electoral System Design in the Arab World, International IDEA, http://www.idea.int/esd/upload/jordan.pdf ) . The 1993 Election adopted a new 'one man, one vote' single transferable vote policy that made it more difficult for opposition in the Muslim Brotherhood to get substantial representation (Reynolds and Elkit) . It was impossible for elections to have a meaningful consequence on the ultimate exercise of executive power by the king. King Hussein held the governing prerogatives to appoint or dismiss the prime minister and cabinet from the house and had the ability to call elections when he saw fit (Freedom House Jordan 2012, https://freedomhouse.org/report/countries-crossroads/2012/jordan#.VV7VVPmqqko ) . 22. Jordan receives two points, because at this time Jordan had suffrage for all people over the age of 19 (Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, Arab Political Systems: Baseline Information and Reforms- Jordan, Washington: 2008 http://carnegieendowment.org/files/Jordan_APS.doc ) . 23. Jordan receives one point. In the Jordanian context this question crosses over with question 21; as discussed above, in 1989 there was no effective opposition, though some did emerge with the legalisation of political parties in 1992. There is no chance for opposition to gain the ultimate power which resides with the king. The control over elections and cabinet resided with the king. The opposition to monarchists in the legislature and executive is small and its numbers were decreased by the use of Single Non-Transferable Vote system (Reynolds and Ekit) . 24. Jordan has received zero points, despite the legalisation of political parties, people remained politically disempowered. Both elections saw less than half the population turning out due to their distrust of the state and the similarity between candidates policy platforms (Katherine Rath 'The Process of Democratisation in Jordan' Middle Eastern Studies, Vol.30 no.3: 1994, pp.530-557. http://www.jstor.org/stable/4283656 p.544) . Women were especially politically disempowered with only 70% female literacy in contrast to 89% male literacy (New Internationalist issue 252: 1994, http://newint.org/features/1994/02/05/profile/ ) . Although women were 50% of the voters, they made up only 2% of the candidates in the 1989 election (Katherine Rath, p.545) . Rath describes a social contract in Jordan where people were given some economic freedom in exchange for giving ultimate power to the State, this contract debilitated peoples political rights (p.538) . 25. I have given Jordan one point, as some independent but censored media seems to exist. Published information on Jordan's media in the early 1990's is scarce, but the Jordanian National Charter of 1991 guaranteed 'freedom of thought and expression' through the media at the same time as asserting that media 'must have a formative role in shaping citizen attitudes of commitment to their county' and 'preserving social harmony,' presumably this prevents media criticism of the institution of monarchy ( Jordanian National Charter of 1991 retrieved from RefWorld, http://www.refworld.org/docid/3ae6b53b4.html ) . Some estimated guesses were involved in answering this question, I have been influenced by Freedom House's first report on Freedom in Jordan, released in 1998, which indicates severe censorship of the press with regulations in 1997 ( https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/1998/jordan#.VV6vNvmqqko ) . 26. Jordan receives one point because the leaders of the state are not subject to the rule of law. Without a formal separation of powers between the institutions of political power or a fully independent judiciary, the rule of law is not maintained. In Jordan the Monarch and is not accountable, and the executive dominates over legislature and judiciary (Sufian Obeidat, Rule of Law Quick Scan Jordan, HiiL:2012 http://www.hiil.org/data/sitemanagement /media/QuickScan_Jordan_191212_GK.pdf p.7) . 27. Jordan receives one point, because despite the appearance of human rights on paper in the 1991 National Charter, they lacked reinforcement from the State and were often breached. However, after 1992 it became legal to assemble political parties. Physical violence against civilians was not widespread and the Cigranelli-Richard Human Rights Data Set gave Jordan a positive high score of 6 out of 8 for the physical integrity rights in 1994, where low scores indicate grave human rights abuses (CRI in Obeidat, Rule of Law, p.45) . 28. As described above, the judiciary was not fully independent and was dominated by the executive. To answer this question I drew on some information covering a slightly later period. In 1998, Freedom House indicated that the judiciary was not 'independent in sensitive cases' which I think demonstrated when nine cases of high-level corruption were dismissed by the courts in 1990 (Nigel Ashton, King Hussein of Jordan: a Political Life, USA: Yale University Press, 2008. p.255) . This led me to give Jordan one point. 29. Jordan receives 0 points, as seen above, there is no effective process to check the executive. 30. This question does not fit within a Jordanian context, as minority groups were advantaged in Jordan. King Hussein and the royals are of Hashemite ethnicity which is a smaller portion of the population than the Palestinian majority and held greater power due to their cultural heritage (Muldar Zahran 'Jordan is Palestine' Middle East Quarterly Winter 2012, pp.3-12 http://www.meforum.org/3121/jordan-is-palestinian ) . The smaller Bedouin also has been granted special privileges (Muldar Zahran Is Jordan's King Losing Control over the Bedouin 2011 http://www.gatestoneinstitute.org/2209/jordan-bedouin ) . I have nominated one point for this question, because the majority has been disadvantaged through the discriminatory advantages given to minority ethnic groups. 31. I am very confident with my answers in this section, nominating 5.4 because I did have to get support from some sources dealing with 1998 and later years to ascertain some aspects of Jordan's political landscape between 1989 and 1994. 32/33. It is hard to determine how exactly how much corruption there was in the 1989-1994 period, but corruption was certainly common. At this point in time, Transparency International was only begging to establish quality research and investigation, but the first paper they produced featuring Jordan in 1996 gave them a Corruption Perceptions Index score of 4.89 between the years 1993 and 1996 based on the perceptions of business people ( https://www.transparency.org/files/content/tool/1996_CPI_EN.pdf ) . This score indicated visible levels of corruption that had significantly increased in the last decade, and would continue to do so post 1994. During the 1989 riots there were allegations of corruption against the current Prime Minister Zaid al-Rifai that in part led to King Hussein accepting his resignation (New York Times, 'Jordan Plans to Lift Martial Law,' Amman:1989 http://www.nytimes.com/1989/12/20/world/jordan-plans-to-lift-martial-law.html. ) Nigel Ashton indicates that there was likely some significant high level corruption regarding 'siphoning-off of state funds' from powerful people ( King Hussein p.155) . Reports of bribery in Jordan today are very common, but there is no comprehensive study of low level bribery in the early 90's, however there undoubtedly was some minor low level corruption. The nine high level cases that were dismissed from court in 1990, included major allegations such as the selling of national gold (Ashton, p.155) . It is unfortunate these cases were not fully investigated, but the fact that the allegations exist suggests a degree of corruption among officials. Some estimation was required in answering these questions of corruption in Jordan, but the evidence suggests that significant corruption existed in the higher slopes of power in Jordan between 1989 and 1994. The above forms of corruption demonstrate some special privelages granted to politically-connected people, like the monarchy and royal Hashemite family, some misuse of public resources by top officials and suggest a degree of bribe-taking by officials.

Corruption_types: "Misuse of public resources by top officials"
Justification: As well as the information given through the Transparency index the evaluation of Romania in 2008 gives an outline of the governments views and the type of behaviour that was happening: http://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2008/eur/119100.htm This source was incredibly useful as an overview of the country and influenced my answers quite heavily. The report is worth looking at as it goes into more detail regarding the following questions. POLITICAL RIGHTS: 'Political Rights 1: Are there free and fair elections for this state's executive and legislature?' 'Political Rights 2: Does this country allow universal suffrage?' 'Political Rights 3: Is there an effective opposition and is there a possibility for it to be elected to govern?' I decided to group these answers as from my research established that Romania allowed all of these factors as they are relatively unrestrictive on the political rights of the individuals/political groups in society. However it is noted in the report that the way in which seats are presented in the elections is far to complicated for the general voter to understand and therefore makes it hard to know whether the person that has a seat really earned it. 'Political Rights 4: Do all people have effective access to political power?' From the reports everyone has access to political power and effectively anyone can be involved regardless of gender, ethnicity etc. 'Political Rights 5: Is there a free, independent and well-resourced media that is able to act as a check and balance on power?' The media is is widely free from government intervention however, there is still laws in place that meant that government slander was against the law and punishable. So although the media has free reign over what it puts out into the public it cannot slander the government. CIVIL LIBERTIES: 'Civil Liberties 1: Does this regime uphold the rule of law?' The regime aims to uphold the law in society however some laws are less followed up than others which means that there is some mistrust in the government's ability to uphold the law especially regarding the corruption in the police and officials. Corruption was one of the main issues that stemmed from the upholding of law. However, the government were trying to change this just not overly effectively. The government does aim to uphold law but can be said to be not that effective as seen through the corruption in officials, which causes public distrust. 'Civil Liberties 2: Do all citizens within this regime have access to fundamental human rights, including: Freedom of Assembly and Association; Freedom of Speech and Expression; Freedom of Mobility?' The government does not interfere with any of these civil liberties and as a result all citizens have access to these fundamental human rights. The only issue that came from my research was that there was subtle interference, nothing major but slight tweaking of these liberties that meant that there was some governmental influence. However, there was not enough interference to take away the civil liberties and they remained relatively untouched. 'Civil Liberties 3: Does this country have a free, independent and fair judiciary?' 'Civil Liberties 4: Does this country have effective processes in order to hold the governing regime accountable? These could be measures such as independent Ombudsman, inquiries, parliamentary question time, an upper house of parliament, select committees, etc. These processes must have some real effectiveness, not just exist on paper.' These questions were educated guesses as in order to be able to be in the European Union there are multiple checks and balances that would be required as a result of gaining entry as policies would of had to be shifted and changed to align with the EU's views. Government interference in terms of restrictions on the above questions would result in the government being far more corrupt and particularly see the government be more involved in the civil and political rights mentioned in these questions. 'Civil Liberties 5: Does this country uphold the right to equal treatment and due process for minority groups?' The civil liberties in Romania are generally really good and the report highlights all of this, there are very little restrictions and the country aims to encourage the equal rights of all citizens. CONCLUSION: Romania has Anti-corruption hot lines, as corruption in Romania remains a huge problem and it is established that in 2008 the public had a loss of respect for the police due to the levels of corruption and the lack of consequences from the government. The management of corruption is poor however; it is more among lower society individuals not the collective government. Romania is far less corrupt than that of Belarus and I found that this section was easier/harder to write about as there were some aspects of flaws in the government but they were trying to change this. The corruption issue in officials is more that the government has an ineffective way of dealing with it and that needs to change, but the civil liberties and political rights remain relatively untouched making it a much freer society.

Corruption_types: "Bribe-taking by public officials","Misuse of public resources by top officials","Fraud committed by private citizens against the government","Condoning illegal business dealings","Other"
Justification: Regime Period: I chose 2000-2006 to demarcate the regime period even though it doesn't represent one continuous presidential term because those years mark the event of elections. 2000 is one election year, but the then President, Aristide, was ousted into exile in 2004 and between 2004-2006 an interim government presided. 2006 is another election year where a government was actually elected, ending the interim period. Note: The 'Approach'and 'Definitions'section of the system apply to Haiti as they did for Chad. Thus I will not repeat the same sections. Sources All sources used in this research project are as credible as possible. The information attained from them is regime-period specific. Most sources dealt with evaluative and critical reports and information supplemented by technical/formal processes information. One subject in particular that was difficult to source information about was political power citizens had effective access to; very little information on citizens'avenues for power could be found. Freedom House 'places a greater emphasis on whether these rights are implemented in practice' . They were a baseline for further independent research (as far as possible) with the United Nations, Human Rights Watch, Institute for Democracy and Electoral Assistance (I.D.E.A.), Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, Inter-Parliamentary Union, United States Library of Congress, Reporters Without Borders, and World Bank. Challenges: There weren't too many challenges with Haiti, though some areas were harder to obtain information on than others. In particular, political recourse for citizens and specific information on government accountability was difficult to find. Classification Summary Haiti rated 7/30 points placing it well within the non-democratic category. The perpetual political and civil instability, natural distasters, lack of state resource in which to build infrastructures and rebuild severely weakened ones, and corruption all undermine any democratic process or efforts made. freedom House rated Haiti consistently for political rights, civil liberties and overall freedom as a 6 in 2002 (with 7 being the worst) . Haiti then dropped by half a point to 6.5 for overall freedom and down to 7 for political rights in 2006. Though Haiti is a republic, the lack of consistency in government and the inability for parties and presidents to stay in power leaves Haiti leaderless and directionless in the face of pervasive corruption, civil unrest and discontent, a badly damaging and deteriorated infrastructure, and severely underresourced civil servants and institutions. None of the institutions like judiciary, media, or elections are effective; combined with outdated laws, rampant violence, human rights abuses, and discriminatory practices. POLITICAL RIGHTS Question 1 Haiti has a bicameral National Assembly ( Assemblée Nationale ) consisting of the Senate ( Sénat ) and the Chamber of Deputies ( Chambre des Députés ) . The president is elected for a five-year term (consecutive terms are forbidden, although one can hold the office a second time after a five-year hiatus) . Deputies are elected for a four-year term and senators for a six-year term. One third of Senate seats are up for election every two years [1] . Jean-Bertrand Aristide was elected president with 91.5% of the vote in 2000. There were 4,000,000 voters registered, 2,871,124 who voted. In 2004, President Aristide was ousted and Boniface Alexandre became president in an interim government. René Préval one the 2006 presidential elections where there was a 55% turnout, with 3,533,430 registered to vote, 2,093,947 who actually voted [2] . There are some technical provisions that even the playing field. There is public funding available upon procurement of 40,000 citizens signatures. This money is earmarked for campaign spending and political education. There are also provisions for free/subsidized access to media for candidates [3] . All elections have been organized by a provisional electoral authority -Conseil Electoral Provisoire (CEP) -composed of nine board members: one appointed by the private sector; three by the Catholic, Episcopal and Lutheran churches; one by human rights organizations; one by the Supreme Court; and three by political parties [4] . Although nominally independent, the CEP is routinely subjected to political manipulation by the party in power [5] . The 2000 elections were marred by alleged irregularities, low voter turnout, and opposition boycotts. Both domestic and international observers noted irregularities in the tabulation of election results for some Senate seats. The Haitian government refused to address the earlier contested election results, so the United States and other international donors withheld election assistance and refused to send observers, and opposition parties boycotted them. Although Aristide won the election with a reported 91.5% of the vote, turnout was very low, with estimates ranging from 5% to 20% of eligible voters participating. Other controversial aspects of the elections included that, of 2.2 million votes cast, about 8% of the ballots were missing, many believed to have been stolen or destroyed; and 8% were nullified because they were illegible [6] . The 2006 elections were held in the presence of over 9 000 United Nations personnel including some 7 000 troops and 1 700 police officers. They were monitored by more than 200 international observers. The discovery of voting bags and marked ballots in a garbage dump triggered a series of street protests by Mr. Préval's supporters. The United Nations Mission in Haiti spoke of an 'apparent grave breach of the electoral process'. More here and here . Conclusion: Citizens of Haiti cannot change their government democratically, evident by the reoccurring electoral irregularities and fraud. Though there are some technical provisions to even the playing field and an electoral authority, they are basically ineffective. Haiti is rated 1 accordingly. [1] http://fas.org/sgp/crs/row/RL32294.pdf [2] http://www.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/arc/2137_06.htm [3] http://www.idea.int/db/countryview.cfm?id=99 [4] http://fas.org/sgp/crs/row/RL32294.pdf [5] http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Haiti.pdf [6] http://fas.org/sgp/crs/row/RL32294.pdf Question 2 Haiti allows those over 18 years, with Haitian citizenship, and full possession of civil and political rights, and residence in the country, to vote. Disqualifications included insanity/mental illness, criminal conviction, imprisonment, persons under guardianship/wards, holders of temporary entry permits, and undocumented immigrant. ( Source: http://www.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/2137_B.htm ) Conclusion: Given that Haiti has numerous reasons like incarceration for disqualification from suffrage, but not restrictive on more arbitrary, unalienable grounds like race, ethnicity, or gender, Haiti is rated 2 accordingly. Question 3 Haiti has numerous (mostly small) political parties who field candidates in elections. The smaller Haitian political parties often form alliances and coalitions. A broad alliance of democratically minded parties known as the Democratic Convergence (Convergence Démocratique ¯# CD) provides the most distinguishable opposition to Lavalas Family (Fanmi Lavalas ¯# FL) -the party with, generally, the most support. Other coalitions attempting to unite smaller parties include the Alliance for the Liberation and Advancement of Haiti (ALAH), Grand Center Right Front Coalition, and Haitian Greater Socialist Party (Grand Parti Socialiste Haïtien ¯# GPSH) [1] . Whilst the opposition can exert limited influence in the form of boycotting elections and political demonstrations, they have little in the way of democratically coming to power. Often there is a deadlock between the incumbency and the opposition, with the need for international assistance to broker an agreement. This is, in part, due to the perpetual instability of the system [2] . Conclusion: Even with the presence of an 'opposition', which is no singular formidable party rather a coalition, they exert little influence over the system. Therefore it can't really be said they are effective, nor can they, as evident, come to be democratically elected into power. Haiti is rated 1 accordingly. [1] http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Haiti.pdf [2] https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2006/haiti#.VV3xOet63zQ Question 4 One form of power is the ability to politically participate or be elected. Haitians can run as candidates but under quite demanding conditions; as long as they are 25 years+, are qualified electors, have Haitian citizenship by birth, full possession of civil and political rights, ownership of real property or employment/trade in the constituency, and residence in the constituency concerned for at least two consecutive years. Disqualifiers are imprisonment, insanity/mental illness, conviction of a criminal offence, persons under guardianship/wards, holders of temporary entry permits, undocumented immigrants, executives and members of the Electoral Commission, managers of public funds who may stand for election but are relieved of their duties if elected, agents of companies or corporations that are government contractors, government officials who did not resign at least six months before the elections, and members of the executive branch and directors general of public administration bodies who did not resign at least one year before the elections. ( Source: http://www.ipu.org/parline-e/reports/2137_B.htm ) But since there is little-to-no political stability or functioning government, and with competing basic needs such as food, income, and education (which Haiti desperately struggles with), the actuality for most Haitians is minimal. There is no recourse to referendum which, I suspect, wouldn't be viable anyway since civil society is quite removed from the political sphere (which itself is instable and almost non existent) . Conclusion: The small provisions for political power, like being a candidate or, presumably public office, is rendered ineffective since pressing domestic issues like poverty and illiteracy, as well as an unstable and shifting political landscape means little-to-none political power can effectively be accessed. Haiti is rated 0 accordingly. Question 5 Radio has the widest reach in Haiti with more than 300 radio stations believed to broadcast throughout the country. 'Talk show programs serve as one of the few ways in which ordinary Haitians can speak out about politics and the government. A law passed in 1997 declares the airwaves to be the property of the government, but at least 133 unlicensed radio stations operate freely. In addition, there are 50 community-based stations throughout the country.' [1] Freedom House rated Haiti not free regarding press in 2002, with a score of 72/100. Independent 'radio stations and newspapers exist in name only. Those critical of the government are targets of official intimidation and of inspired mob attacks. 'Television is state run and strongly biased toward the government. In December 2001, Brignol Lindor, news director of Radio Eco 2000, was stoned and hacked to death by an allegedly pro-Aristide mob' . Harassment, intimidation, and self-censorship from fear of violent retribution are commonplace [2] . Conclusion: Few outlets of independent media exist and those that do are heavily oppressed and censored (either by self or externally through violent silencing means) . Haiti was therefore rated 1 accordingly. [1] http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Haiti.pdf [2] https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2006/haiti#.VV3xOet63zQ CIVIL LIBERTIES Question 1 Rule of law has never been good in Haiti, but during 2001-2004, there was an intensification of political violence, economic recession, and a breakdown of government institutions and the rule of law [1] . The government also perpetuated its violation when, 'throughout 2002 and 2003 the government orchestrated attacks on opposition demonstrations by police and government-supported gangs known as chimères ' [2] . Though the constitution guarantees a full range of political rights and civil liberties, the protection of these rights in 2000 'remained precarious, as the rule of law was tenuous at best, and the situation was aggravated by a yawning security vacuum' [3] . There is plain disregard for rules and laws by justice actors [4] but also a great deal of uncertainty about what the law is [5] . Conclusion: Overall Haiti has little to show for its legal provisions, which are routinely (perpetuated by government agents no less) in the midst of political instability. Haiti rates a 0 accordingly. [1] http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Haiti.pdf [2] http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Haiti.pdf [3] https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2006/haiti#.VV3xOet63zQ [4] http://www.usip.org/sites/default/files/PB%2018%20Rule%20of%20Law%20in%20Haiti%20After%20the%20Earthquake.pdf [5] http://www.usip.org/sites/default/files/haiti_rol.pdf Question 2 In practice, many provisions are not observed, a poor human rights record. Issues include 'arbitrary and political killings, kidnapping, disappearances, torture, and unlawful arrest and incarceration& especially during periods of coups or attempted coups' [1] . Haiti's criminal laws predate the development of international human rights instruments and therefore do not contain these fundamental guarantees. Indeed, certain criminal offenses actively violate the rights of the ordinary Haitian human rights such as freedom of speech and freedom of association. For example, 'twenty persons or more who gather to discuss religion, politics and literary issues without official permission of the government are committing a criminal offense' [2] . More here . Conclusion: Despite legal provisions, Haiti clearly has numerous issues in all areas of its society. With such widespread abuse and criminality, as well as archaic criminal laws aiding violations, Haiti rates 1 accordingly. [1] http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Haiti.pdf [2] http://www.usip.org/sites/default/files/haiti_rol.pdf Question 3 Haiti's constitution calls for an independent judiciary to interpret the country's laws. The constitution guarantees defendants the right to a fair public trial, including the presumption of innocence and the right to be present at trial, to present witnesses and evidence in their own defense, and to confront witnesses against them. In practice, however these rights are often denied. Moreover, the government is not required to provide free counsel, and many Haitians cannot afford representation on their own. Haiti has 'a weak and corrupt police force and a weak judiciary' with 'persistent dysfunctions in the administration of justice' . This has encouraged prolonged pretrial detention and legal impunity, and use of excessive, sometimes deadly force in controlling demonstrations and making arrests. Further, the Haitian National Police perpetuate some of the criminality by committing arbitrary killings and disappearances [1] . Threats of violence often render judges and juries unable to make impartial decisions. Bribes not only sway judges but also taint potential witnesses. In addition to corruption, the judicial system is under-staffed and under-funded. The combination of corruption and inefficiency has resulted in a serious backlog of criminal cases and an overflow in the country's jails [2] . More here and here . Conclusion: Evident in the multiple problems of corruption, understaffing and underfunding combined with weak infrastructure, the judiciary is far from fair and independent despite constitutional and legal provisions. Haiti rates a 0 accordingly. [1] http://fas.org/sgp/crs/row/RL32294.pdf [2] http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Haiti.pdf Question 4 Haiti has a stark absence of checks and balances, let alone ones that are effective. Whilst technically judiciary is independent from the executive, it has little independence and is heavily corrupted. The Catholic Church and few other NGOs bring a slight balance by continuing to be voices of limited opposition. Occasionally, through international pressure and when the government resembles some structure and control, breaches are investigated. Conclusion: With little-to-no measure of accountability but with some activity of investigation, Haiti rates 1 accordingly. Question 5 Haiti's constitution doesn 't contain specific language prohibiting discrimination on the basis of race, sex, language, age, or disability, and, despite some working standards intended to protect women, few resources exist to ensure enforcement. Abuses against women and children are common. Rape, although illegal, rarely results in prosecution of the perpetrator. Haitian law excuses a husband for murdering his wife if the wife is found in an adulterous affair. Trafficking of children is a significant problem, with UNICEF estimating that 2,000 to 3,000 Haitian children per year are trafficked [1] . Further, there is racial discrimination: 'A small light-skinned wealthy business and professional elite located in the capital city controls most of Haiti's economy and decision-making. The mulatto population makes up half of this elite. Most Dominicans are prosperous and are active in business, as are many Syrian and Lebanese who are involved with trading. The large black majority is excluded from all formal political and economic participation.' [2] Conclusion: Haiti clearly has discriminatory activity against minority groups, well entrenched in society and a political and economic impediment. This is made worse by the absence of remedial laws or recourse to justice. Haiti is rated 0 accordingly. [1] http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Haiti.pdf [2] http://www.minorityrights.org/2571/haiti/haiti-overview.html Corruption Summary Haiti is a hotbed for corruption on all levels, made worse by the rampant political instability and weak infrastructures. There are entrenched systems of patronage, corruption, and inefficiency [1] . There is official corruption and high levels of crime, including drug trafficking [2] and judges and officials who accept bribes. [3] The police force suffers from mismanagement and corruption [4] and the justice system is rife with excessive pretrial detention and long delays in the penal process, corruption, involvement of government officials in money laundering and drug trafficking and pursuit of private interests. [5] Elections are heavily tainted with fraud, as the Organization of American States (OAS) observer mission, claimed about the 2000 presidential elections. [6] Observers also made increasing charges of corruption occuring between 2001-2004 with one investigation claim citing embezzlement of millions of dollars of public funds. 'The Central Unit for Financial Information reported that millions of dollars in public funds were illegally transferred to private institutions created by (2001-2004) President Aristide and that an estimated $20 million were transferred to personal foreign accounts belonging to him. [7] Transparency International went back as 2005 for Haiti, ranking it 155 out of 159 in 2005, with a CPI score of 1.8 from only 4 surveys due to lack of access (3 surveys are the minimum required for entry) [8] In 2006 it ranked the lowest at 163, with 1.8 from just 3 surveys. Corruption_types: "Bribe-taking by public officials","Misuse of public resources by top officials","Fraud committed by private citizens against the government","Condoning illegal business dealings"
Justification: The period picked between 1990 and 2012 was chosen because it the duration of Ali Abdullah Saleh's presidency in Yemen. Early 2012 marks the end of the Yemeni Revolution and the beginning of new but hotly contested regime, making research after 2012 difficult to consider. The evidence considered to answer the questions, once again came from a variety of sources but the information despite being helpful, it did not provide enough detail to directly answer some of the questions without making some judgment calls. The justification to this is at least from my research alone, is that there is little available information that can straightforwardly answer some of the difficult questions. The evidence that I sourced can be analysed as being quite vague at one end, only offering the extent of corruption throughout Yemen and broad conclusions, and specific at the other end, giving specific examples and statistics. This makes justifying my answers overall easier, but in some areas doubtful. As a result of this, some of the questions answered were left to educated guesses but much like the case of Sudan, the general consensus is that Yemen is rifled with corruption and faces some of the same challenges. This has made gauging what answers to choose less doubtful and more informed. Some of the questions were indeed difficult to answer not only because of lack of detailed information related to the question, but because some of the questions had limited scope. Some had options were too narrow and some too broad to make absolute definitive answers, in that they either included too little description or too much. Given the years chosen and data that was available, my research suggests answers that generally fit well with the options and did not suggest anything notable to the contrary. The research undertaken provided a lot of analytical data which was ideal in justifying some of the answers and where it did not, I feel confident that my judgement and findings will be accurate with the dynamics of corruption that had taken place between 1990 and 2012. Below is a list of the sources and SOME of the evidence quoted (Some sources contained a great deal of general information whereas other had not so much) . It would be impractical here to give all of the evidence consulted in answering the questions, so extracts of good evidence have been given. Sources: https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2012/yemen Yemen is not an electoral democracy. Past elections, while more competitive than in many Arab countries, have been marred by flaws including vote buying, the partisanship of public officials and the military, and exploitation of state control over key media platforms. Corruption is an endemic problem. Despite some recent efforts by the government to fight graft, Yemen lacks most legal safeguards against conflicts of interest http://yemen.usembassy.gov/root/pdfs/reports/yemen-corruption-assessment.pdf 'Since the early 1990s, Yemen has held a series of popular elections at the local, parliamentary and presidential levels. While the elections have constituted a step forward, they have also been plagued by problems and questions. Those problems include the overly partisan system of administering the elections, questions over the integrity of voter rolls, greater difficulties for opposition members to register as candidates, irregular polling places and rules in presidential elections, concerns over the printing and safekeeping of ballots and ballot boxes, the abuse of government facilities to privilege the GPC and its candidates and unsatisfactory election dispute mechanism' 'Yemen has all the usual attributes that create a permissive environment for rampant corruption, typically defined as the misuse of entrusted authority for private gain. As one of the poorest and least developed states in the world, Yemen suffers from weak state institutions with under skilled and under-paid state employees' 'The most common form of administrative corruption in Yemen is the taking of a bribe by a government employee.' 'Yemen's judiciary is reportedly rife with corruption. Judges are often bribed, and, in some cases, may be able to choose from the higher bribe offered by the competing parties to a case.' https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/news/middle-east/17179-yemens-saleh-netted-60bn-through-corruption The corrupt practices of Yemen's former leader Ali Abdullah Saleh have netted the strongman up to $60 billion, a UN sanctions panel will report to the Security Council on Tuesday. The panel's report says Saleh amassed up to $2 billion a year from 1978 until he was forced to step down in 2012. http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/middle-east/101006/yemen-government-corruption 'Mohamed Ali Al-Maqtary, Transparency International's executive director in Yemen, said corruption permeates all parts of society and has only gotten worse in recent years.' http://www.gallup.com/poll/147980/yemenis-widespread-corruption-government.aspx 'The proportion of Yemenis who believe government corruption is rampant has remained in the 70% or higher range for the past four years.' http://country-corruption.findthedata.com/l/156/Yemen 'Yemen has a Corruption Perception Index score of 2.3 out of 10, which is 38% worse than the average. In Yemen, 22.4% of citizens surveyed believe that the government is effective in the fight against corruption. Of surveyed citizens, 66% report having paid a bribe in the past 12 months.' http://blogs.worldbank.org/arabvoices/fighting-culture-corruption-yemen About two decades ago, corruption became rampant under the former regime. Ever since, in the absence of a system of control and accountability, it is now reflected in every area of public and private affairs. w. Corruption and patronage networks are running the country's public affairs, which has led to weak government performance, and the creation of corrupt power blocs that control public resources. 'The actual role played by the Yemeni parliament, however, is largely ineffective. The reasons for this include its current structure and the weakness and fragility of its internal capacity as an institution.' http://youthdo.org/en/images/yemen/10.pdf This document is a very helpful and detailed account of corruption in Yemen. It examines the state of corruption, its forms and at what levels.
